author: {'steamid': '76561197972330714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 1369, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1369, 'last_played': 1644875162}
review: Chasm may well be the blandest Metroidvania ever: You obtain stereotypical weapons and progress skills (e. g. whips, sub-weapon axe, double jump) to overcome trite enemies and environments (e. g. crawlers, zombies, a mine, a castle). Story and setting are unimaginative, the NPCs are cardboard cutouts and have no notable characterization. Art and animations aren't shabby, but not spectacular, either. The worst part, however, are the stiff controls. I defeated Dracula in the original Castlevania, I survived Dark Souls and I suffered through LaMulana. Neither of these games had great controls, but Chasm manages to be worse still. The floor in Chasm appears to be covered in debilitating superglue that drains the momentum out of your attacks, and the only chance of escape is perpetual jumping - which also seems oddly imprecise. Yes, you can still learn to dodge the well-telegraphed enemy attacks - doing so just doesn't feel fluid and rewarding.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043818901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 665, 'last_played': 1643021836}
review:
Llevaba mucho tiempo con este juego en la librería de steam y por fin me decidí a jugarlo, sobretodo porque me apetecía algo para cortito y para apagar el cerebro y Chasm parecía cumplir ese perfil.
Tenemos aquí un metroidvania bastante genérico y básico. Un juego que apenas profundiza en los puntos fuertes del género y con bastantes deficiencias en cuanto a calidad de vida que hoy día ya casi todos gozan. El progreso del personaje apenas da sensación de ese crecimiento, el equipo, que se divide en rarezas (no sé para qué), no posee apenas propiedades que te hagan querer conseguirlo. Jefes con cero mecánicas que los vencías en el primer enfrentamiento. Hay muy pocas habitaciones secretas, unas secundarias que por su recompensa no te incitan a querer hacerlas. El backtracking no me ha gustado en absoluto. Los puntos de salvados y portales mal repartidos e incómodos. Y hablando de incomodidades, el control de personaje se sentía muy tosco y lento. Y la historia… bueno, los metroidvanias no brillan precisamente por eso, pero este… salva una aldea… cero interés saltándome todos los diálogos.
En definitiva un juego que no recomiendo y que no volveré a rejugar. Ha sido lo justamente entretenido como para querer acabarlo, sobretodo porque era corto y cumplía mínimamente con lo que se busca en un juego de este género.

author: {'steamid': '76561198364618398', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 5139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5139, 'last_played': 1644177969}
review:
Análise feita na primeira hora de jogo: (A primeira sensação que senti ao jogar Chasm pela primeira vez, foi de que alguma maneira já conhecia o jogo, as paletas de cores junto a música com batidas de um desfile militar medieval  me lembrou Seiken Densetsu 3 (Trials of Mana), o herói ao saltar e correr para um lado e para o outro me lembrou Hook, Castlevania e Super Metroid, jogos Snes.
	Dito tudo isto, o jogo me arrebatou com sua arte e visual incrível, o jogo apresenta mecânicas procedurais na construção de sua masmorra, onde o jogador pode resgatar através de uma seed.
	Sua macro estrutura é em sua essência um Metroidvania, onde o herói tem uma variedade de armas a sua disposição, com diferentes animações de ataques, que variam em dano, velocidade e alcance. Os inimigos encontrados no primeiro andar da mina apresentam comportamentos comuns de inimigos encontrados neste estilo de jogo, causando dano ao herói com a colisão.
	Outro aspecto que é muito atrativo para mim, neste estilo de jogo, é a progressão de nível do herói, ganhando Experiência (XP) ao derrotar cada monstro.
	Chasm não esconde sua forte referência a jogos mais antigos, ao desferir um golpe, o valor é mostrado ao jogador e em caso de crítico o número é apresentado com um efeito furta cor, seguido pela própria palavra Crítico.
	A primeira impressão a respeito da história parece ser herói resgatando aldeões da vila Kharta, sendo cada um deles um NPC interagível que vai liberar novas mecânicas ou novos locais a serem acessados.
	O jogo também apresenta um possível mecânica de construção de build ao poder comprar itens que aumentam um dos quatro valores básicos do herói, sendo eles, Força, Inteligência, Constituição e Sorte.
	Como última análise, acredito ser necessário mencionar com mais afinco a arte do jogo, por ser um ambiente subterrâneo os elementos são muito bem apresentados, com candelabros, toras de sustentação de teto, os próprios monstros também são bastante condizentes ao ambiente, fazendo o jogo confortável aos olhos do jogador, tendo diante de si um mundo a ser explorado como uma aventura de RPG de mesa, com elementos apresentados em livros ou pergaminhos encontrado pelo jogador. O parallax está macio dando uma sensação de infinitude das minas.)
Análise por termino de jogo: (Hoje, dia 06/02/2022, concluí esse jogo incrível que me cativou de muitas formas, as músicas, a arte, a vontade de ganhar nível para ficar mais forte, coisas que senti na análise anterior, mas a minha impressão não foi tão boa para a escolha de level design para o ultimo ambiente de jogo onde em certo ponto você não pode voltar para poder salvar ou tentar se recuperar em um save point, então apenas para não indicar um defeito, acho que a solução mais fácil seria permitir a compra ilimitada do pergaminho que lhe traz de volta a vila ou um item no final do jogo com o mesmo efeito. Minha opinião final sobre este jogo é que foi muito divertido de jogá-lo e recomendo a todos a experiência.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198043268673', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 283, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1643491613}
review:
It has nothing notable: good or bad. A prime example of an average metroidvania game.

A few things I think lead to this being average experience.
[list]
[*] Loot is overall boring slot filler items with RNG stats. I imagine this problem turning worse later, as your drops inevitably start to outperform all the chest loot. 
That leads me to my next point.
[*] Exploration is not rewarded. I've played the game for something like an hour, explored everything I could. I found a bunch of npcs and 4 chests. Only one of those chests had a better item to offer and it soon became obsolete too.
[*] Contact damage. There are very few games that pull off contact damage being fair, and this is not one of them.
[*] Movement is a bit floaty. It's hard to land precise jumps and I bumped into enemies instead of jumping right next to them more than I would like to admit.
[*] Some enemies (including starter ones) don't have obvious tells and openings to react to. So for example, if you enter a room and see a drill goblin standing, there's a very good chance it will move (and hit you before you recover) after your first strike, but if you wait for it to move and stop you can land 2 hits safely.
[*] Attacks have recovery times, which cannot be cancelled by back-dash. Combined with previous problem It just makes combat against some enemies feel unfair unless you're using longer weapons. 
[*] It's probably just me, but I got tired of mine music in like 10 minutes.
[/list]

Don't get me wrong, it's not a BAD game. Enemies have readable behaviors, character controls are passable and there ARE metroidvania style ability-gated chests, but this is literally what every game in the genre does. I couldn't see a single thing this game does different or better than competitors.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963287051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1641186337}
review: If you like Symphony of the Night and its successors, you will probably enjoy Chasm. The movement and combat mechanics in particular show direct inspiration and will seem immediately familiar and comfortable to anyone who's played the later Castlevanias. The movement upgrades, unfortunately, aren't especially well-done: As the game progresses, it tends to become slightly less enjoyable to move around in, as you get different types of wall grab which behave unpredictably differently and clunky glide mechanics, with the ever-so-vital double-jump unlocked only quite late in the game. The randomization seems to be minimal, and overall I felt it slightly overstayed its welcome, but the solid mechanics and great soundtrack and art made Chasm an overall very enjoyable experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018275730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 911, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 911, 'last_played': 1642275101}
review:
Middling.

Procedural generation doesn't actually add much variety to your playthrough due to hard gated progression items. You cannot deviate from the developer's intended path.Map is composed of sprawling corridors which makes backtracking a chore.

Combat feels a little stuff due to lack of backdash cancels, hard animation locks on most weapons. 

Pacing is disappointing. A new weapon is immediately invalidated in a new area as the hp/damage of enemies takes a stark jump, making you never truly feel like you are getting stronger until the very end game. RPG elements have little impact on the game besides the hp/mp replenish upon level up. Your stats are truly dictated by gear and little else. Not really enough unique weapons and armour. Somewhat long for a game of this type (10hrs), due to how the game progression is locked behind specific items and powerups.

Despite this, its still a decent metroidvania. I'd only ever really consider it if it was on sale.

review:
Truly a great and (IMO) underrated (or under the radar?) game!!
Chasm is a metroidvanian game that plays just like the old games back in the day, especially Castlevania : Symphony of the Night. 

So if you are a 90's kid like me, and you played and liked Castlevania. This feels at home.

Apart from that, the art-style of this game reminiscences the classic JRPG looks (Xenogear, FF tactics, etc). Made me  feel like a teenage boy  even more. It truly brought a satisfying smile to me when the credits rolled.

I recommend playing this game on Hard difficulty. Just do it. Buy it! play the hell out of it!  :)

review:
7/10 "The pixel art is the best part of the game"

My biggest gripe with Chasm and probably the reason many people gave it a harsh review, it's that Chasm takes way too long to get as fun as it should be from the beginning, I feel like the many movement tools the game gives the player as you progress make combat a lot more interesting and fun just like the weapons you obtain in the later stages, which are more unique and should have been obtained way earlier into the game.

However, it takes quite a while to get there and the first half felt completely stale in my opinion while the second half feels quite awesome, there also little details such as a lack of atmosphere in sound design, decent, but underwhelming music, boring and annoying backtracking and grind, combat system doesn't feel as fluid as I had wished, etc.

review:
It's a good game worth picking up when it's on sale (I got it for under $9). It took me just under 15 hours to complete with 18/20 achievements.

I enjoyed the art style and variety of enemies a lot. The difficulty was just right for me (not trivial but not unforgiving either). The exploration is fun for the most part but could use some quality of life improvements to reduce the amount of time you're just running the full way back and forth between rooms and save points, especially if you want to unlock all the optional stuff such as the [spoiler]sword of light[/spoiler]. The items are interesting and unique and the optional quests and unlocks felt worthwhile.

One thing for me that would have been a huge improvement is the different gear actually appearing on your character model.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985802948', 'num_games_owned': 962, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 613, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 613, 'last_played': 1640304477}
review:
Razor's edge positive recommendation. 

It's just not finished. By the time it's over it feels like the 30% point of a much grander adventure. The randomly generated maps are boring to traverse and feel empty. It also seems to take clear inspiration from Casltevania: Circle of the Moon, where progression is gated by unlocking abilities specifically meant to force backtracking rather than actually make the gameplay more varied and fun.

Looks good, combat is okay but needs more enemy/weapon/magic variety, and has decent music, but is sorely lacking in the parts needed to make it feel complete. C+ if you're desperate for new 2D action-exploration games but there's so many others to choose from. It's not terrible but it's definitely disappointing that it never reaches its true potential.

review: Chasm is an extremely fun Rogue-lite dungeon crawler. You play as the top knight recruit your outpost has seen in many years. You are sent to investigate disappearances at the nearby mining town that your outpost relies on for ore. You will face monsters, puzzles, traps, and more! Dungeons are procedurally generated depending on the seed assigned your game when you start it. Explore, survive, and rescue! The controls are more fluid than any other game I've played so far in my life. The execution is simple, but varied and the replay value is through the roof. I cannot recommend this enough. If you have a chance to check Chasm out, please do so! You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561199008688025', 'num_games_owned': 38, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1048, 'last_played': 1706819623}
review:
This game does not deserve the bad rap it had gotten at release. IIRC, I think there was confusion over the proc-gen elements of the game? Regardless, Chasm is a fun Metroidvania romp that stands well on its own.

You take control of a lone Squire, spelunking through mysterious biomes deep beneath a mining town. With each new file, the stages shuffle about their layout and the locations of key items and townsfolk to rescue. Each member of town has a small sidequest line, and many of them offer supplies to the hero. Along the way you will uncover lore about the civilization that lived in this region before... and its dark secrets.

Gameplay-wise, the game is a comfy one for those well-versed in Igavanias. There's a bigger precedence of finding items in various spots, or as enemy drops, than buying stuff. It's closer in feel to Order of Ecclesia or Symphony of the Night in that regard than other Castlevania titles. The weapons you wield also reflect that series -- swords and maces swung laterally, fast daggers and knuckles for up-close carnage, overhead-swung great weapons, forward-thrust polearms, and even long-ranged whips can all be brandished! There are few subweapons to use your MP on, upgraded over time -- three staple Castlevania sidearms, with three unique ones.

Exploration is both exciting and challenging. Resources aren't so easy to come by, so every potion or food item you can secure will matter. Bosses are a test of your skills, but just getting to those battles won't be a walk in the park. Varied enemies, environmental obstacle courses and punishing hazards stand in your way. Because the maps change each time you start a new file, you can't always rely on the layouts you'd encountered in past runs. Add in the optional "classes" you can pick from for replay run -- a warrior, a magician, a thief, or the default jack-of-all-trades -- and your skills will be put to the test plenty of times. And if you seek additional glory and tests of skill? Chasm also provides daily and weekly challenges of predetermined maps!

In the end, Chasm is a fun adventure for a seasoned Igavania vet. Familiar mechanics come together with fresh ideas and procedurally-generated dungeons for plenty of adventures ahead.

review: Um jogo simplesmente fantástico. Ele oferece uma jogabilidade agradável, com direta inspiração em renomados jogos do gênero Metroidvania. Os gráficos são distintos, salta aos olhos a encantadora pixel art que fora desenvolvida com tanto esmero. A sua dificuldade é muito gratificante, é desafiadora do jeito que deveria ser, não é impossível de ser conquistada mas, também não é simples e dócil demais. author: {'steamid': '76561198047740091', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 1653, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1653, 'last_played': 1638570850}
review:
SUMMARY:

Chasm is your typical hack-n-slash metroidvania game. Start off with minimal abilities, progress through the dungeon, and unlock new skills to help you proceed further and uncover new hidden rooms and content. The only drawback to this game compared to others of this genre is the level of difficulty. During my time playing, it didn't provide much in terms of a challenge and was pretty easy to beat.

THE GOOD:

Chasm does a really great job making you feel like you're on an adventure. You have a small town (your hub) that slowly updates and adds new content/shops as you proceed further into the mines and rescue villagers. You find a nice variety of equipment along the way, as well. The best part being weapons. Each weapon has its own unique speed and style. This, along with a variety of spells, makes combat very fun.

The visuals and artwork is also well done. The first thing I noticed was the fact that each room has it's own unique backdrop. I found this to be a nice feature because it really helped immerse me into the world your main protagonist is exploring. The animations (character and enemy) is very fluid and feels balanced. Enemy deaths are done very well and gives you a sense of accomplishment when you defeat them.

Finally, there's plenty of places to explore and secrets to unlock. This is definitely not lacking in Chasm. You'll uncover tons of hidden chests, items and rooms, with some needing to be returned to once you acquire a specific item (just like most metroidvania games).

THE BAD:

The difficulty. While there were some mobs that gave me some challenge when I first encountered them, their move sets were easily learned and avoidable. I figured, at this point, maybe the bosses were going to be a challenge. That was not the case. I beat each boss (with the exception of the final boss) my first go. I did, however, beat the final boss on my second attempt.

Backtracking. This is very common in metroidvania games and the one part that I absolutely cannot stand, and Chasm doesn't hold back here. It's very common for you to unlock a new area, find climbing gear, and have to backtrack two floors just to unlock another chest... and then proceed further into the new area you unlocked. While many enjoy this, I find it to be repetitive and boring. Especially since you fight the same mobs, which at this point... only take 1 hit in a game that already presented little to no challenge. This would have been better if newer, stronger enemies showed up in the older zones, making them more enjoyable to re-explore.

And finally... armor. While it does increase your overall defense, magic resistance, luck, speed, and other stats... Chasm is missing the one thing I love about most adventure games... your character's look changing. It would have been a nice feature, especially since you find so many different types of helmets/hats and armor. Even a basic color change, or additional shoulder pad, belt, maybe some texture updates to your current look, would have helped. This isn't important to a lot of people, but I've always enjoyed it because it keeps your character interesting, and makes you feel like you're becoming more powerful as you venture further into the game.

CONCLUSION:

The good definitely outweigh the bad. Overall, I highly recommend this game. It's done very well, has some fun combat, and the story is interesting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059285796', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1302, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1302, 'last_played': 1638542904}
review:
The game's mechanics feel well-rounded. Finding out how to efficiently move around the enemies' attacks to strike back with the different types of weapons feels great and is arguably the main focus of the game.

A good deal for its price. If you like metroidvanias it will fit right with you.

The story is both simple and cryptic, so it feels good to piece it together. All of the NPCs are hidden so finding them is rewarding, but that feeling turns anticlimactic once you realize they are just menus with no writing put into their dialogues.

There could be some bosses in big rooms that you have to platform through instead of being square empty rooms. all the time.

review:
This is a short, but relaxing game that takes the oldschool metroidvania and rpg formula that makes it fun. Really great to have the option to change between CRT mode or normal. The music can be made oldschool on demand. 

Straightforward quests and nice puzzles here and there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198268936773', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 550, 'last_played': 1637872860}
review:
I'm not going to reccomend for or against Chasm, it does plenty of things well but also does some things vary badly.

So, where to start ... Chasm is a metroidvania in the Castlevania style. Lots of equipment options, inventory with recovery and utility items, backdash, et. cetra. This extends to mp being reminiscent of hearts in Castlevania installments with a Bellmont protagonist. Level design is above average, but the randomized tile placement holds it back somewhat. Enemy design is an extremely mixed bag, with plenty being "fair" enemies that can be defeated without taking damage with skill and observation of attacks - but many enemies being "unfair", either by having extremely brief delays between their tells and attacks, or charging the player - but having more hp to reasonably destroy before they make contact. A large portion of the problem with enemy design is the arsenal of weapons and abilities given to the player - all weapons are short range except the occassional whip (and a single, endgame weapon), and spells' are backloaded - requiring chunks of your precious mp (which does not regenerate on it's own), needing spell upgrades to become useful and being extremely reliant on equipment to deal adequate damage. This game is enjoyable if your a longtime fan of Castlevania series, but is generally worse than any 2d sidescrolling chapter of that franchise.

{'steamid': '76561198088209673', 'num_games_owned': 733, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 1405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1405, 'last_played': 1636216118}
review:
Chasm is a metroidvania style game that is surprisingly in a class of it's own in some ways it plays well, the upgrades are really nice both in terms of progression and in how it makes travelling around the world a lot easier in the earlier levels, the equipment is varied but they do something I'd like to see more often in metroidvania style games and that's having blue (rare) and gold (legendary) equipment which can have increased stats of a varied nature allowing for different styles of play whether it is purely offensive, or even defensive dood.

That said there are some issues with the game, for starters no NG+ (new game plus) now granted believe it or not if this wasn't a seeded game (Maps are randomly generated) I would say that's fine, NG+ is needed even if it's a nice bonus but the thing is most people don't want to lose all their progress to start from the beginning, this especially hurts the Blue and Gold equipment mechanic as they are extremely hard to attain in the first place which leads me to the drop rates being a bit too abysmal for a one run game, it's the kind of thing where if the game were multiple runs and you could restart on harder modes on  new seed for better levels and the like it would be fine but that just isn't the case and you could easily never come across a gold item if you just run through dood.

All in all it's a great game despite those flaws, if you play I suggest not grinding too much unless you are a trophy hunter as you will have more fun just playing the game with the drop rates, although even despite that my main suggestion is to not go for gold equipment unless you really have some free time and are desperate for that one item you super love, especially as the effects are random and no one want's to have a high INT build on a strength/ATK build character, keep that in mind and you're in for some real fun times with monsters with cool designs and attack patterns and some decently okay music dood ^-^

author: {'steamid': '76561198118816391', 'num_games_owned': 1467, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 2090, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2090, 'last_played': 1634060461}
review:
Главный герой — новобранец в крепости рыцарей Королевства Гильдея. Однажды в крепость приходит донесение, что произошло нападение дикого зверя в шахтах на рабочих в шахтерском городке Картас. Но из-за разгула бандитов в округе, в крепости почти не осталось рыцарей, которых можно было бы отправить в поселение. И в Картас отправляют новобранца. По прибытии оказывается, что в городке остался один мэр, а всех жителей похитили чудовища и утащили в шахты.

В ходе приключения нам предстоит открыть тайны древнего племени Ладори и основания королевства без короля — Гильдеи, спасти жителей и мир между делом.

Сюжет в игре подается через записки, наскальные тексты и диалоги с НПС — в основном с профессором археологии Бесденом, который приехал изучать племя Ладори.

Пробираясь через монстров, заполонивших шахты и спасая жителей деревни, мы будем получать от них простенькие задания, которые сводятся к просьбе принести ранее утерянную вещь. В награду же мы получим доступ к услугам, которые они оказывают, как например магазины или возможность создавать предметы у кузнеца. А также некоторым полезным предметам, таким как детектор секретных зон.

Кстати, секретные зоны тут спрятаны очень хорошо и практически не выделяются в окружающей местности.

Что касается ранее упомянутой системы крафта, то она очень простая. И для этого достаточно принести несколько слитков металла, добытых с монстров и в сундуках в шахты.

У персонажа есть четыре, достаточно стандартные характеристики, которые повышаются автоматически случайным образом по мере развития персонажа. Это сила, интеллект, телосложение и удача; которые в свою очередь влияют на физический и магический урон, количество маны, получаемый урон и т.д.

Боевая система также не вносит каких-либо новшеств в жанр, но и плохой от этого не становиться. Физические и магические атаки, отскок и использование зелий со свитками. 

Магия в Chasm имеет несколько нестандартную форму. Вместо огненных шаров, молний и заморозок — она представлена в виде набора метательного оружия. Нам доступны ножи, сюрикены, бумеранги, метательные топоры, коктейли Молотова и щит. А еще ее можно улучшать за драгоценные камни, что делает ее достаточно сильной, чтобы заменить ближний бой. Так что тем, кто не хочет усложнять себе прохождение брезговать ей не стоит.

Количество различной экипировки в игре маленьким не назовешь. Нам представлены различные мечи, ножи, дубинки, топоры, кастеты, кнуты. Все они отличаются уроном, скоростью, дальностью атаки и различным типами анимации ударов. В целом каждый найдет, то оружие, которое ему по душе. Но все же ощущается некоторое отсутствие разнообразия, поскольку на каждом участке прохождения у вас будет ограниченный выбор, того, что стоит использовать. А в будущем все это заменит магия.

Для дополнительного разнообразия предметы имеют несколько степеней редкости с дополнительными характеристиками. И возможность добыть такой зависит от случайности и удачи. А у некоторых имеются уникальные свойства от банальной регенерации жизней до призыва помощника, как у шляпы с перьями, призывающей попугая.

Что же касается игровых механик присущим всем метроидваниям — способности, которые дадут нам возможность попадать в ранее недоступные зоны. Их мы получаем, собирая артефакты, которых в игре целых восемь. Но, к сожалению, в большинстве они дают все те же двойные прыжки, скольжения и т.п. Выделить, пожалуй, можно только акваланг, который позволяет плавать под водой.

Используя процедурную генерацию, разработчики обычно сообщают игрокам о высокой реиграбельности их творения. Однако за этим следует и повышенное однообразие миров, созданных таким образом. И Chasm это не обошло.

Пространство между фиксированными сюжетными комнатами является сгенерированным и периодически ловишь себя на мысли, что ты уже проходил этот экран ранее, но в другом направлении. От этого временами устаешь, если есть желание облазить карту полностью, а не пробежать от босса к боссу. Сами же генерируемые экраны представлены тремя типами: платформинг, сражения и вертикальный для перехода между ярусами карты.

Для ускоренного перехода внутри зон и между ними сделан центральный хаб с телепортом. Однако только в первой зоне есть статуя Смотрителя, которая отвечает за сохранения в игре и служит в роли чекпоинта. Статуи Смотрителя встречаются и посреди локаций, но они часто расположены крайне неудобно и из-за системы быстрых переходов из хаба зоны проще всего пользоваться точкой сохранения в хабе шахт. В случае смерти, все это вместе приводит к длительным забегам из точки сохранения по безопасным экранам, что очень сильно утомляет.

С визуальной точки зрения разнообразие противников в игре действительно большое. Это и различные виды кобольдов с троллями, и простые слаймы с летучими мышами, множество типов нежити на любой вкус. А вот если посмотреть на них с точки зрения игровых механик и необходимых действий со стороны игрока, то окажется, что все они следуют заветам старых платформеров, где у противников менялся только цвет и увеличивался урон и жизни.

Конечно, местная фауна по мере продвижения по пещерам становится не только сильнее и живучей, меняя модельки. Они так же получают новые способности, например, учатся блокировать снаряды игрока; меняется траектория снарядов чудовищ. Да, действительно иногда попадаются монстры с более уникальным стилем, но в конечном итоге это не влияет кардинально на тактику игрока и подход к убийству противника. Впрочем, такое среди подобных игр встречается часто. Например, Blasphemous тоже страдает подобным механическим однообразием.

А вот боссы в Chasm выглядят уже посложнее и поинтереснее, чем в том же Blasphemous, если, конечно, закрыть глаза на магию, которая сильно упрощает их убийство.

Помимо рядовых противников и боссов, в пещерах Ладорианских гор встречаются и мини-боссы. На мой взгляд их слишком редко добавляют в игры, что является большим упущением.

Chasm звезд с неба не хватает. Игровые системы и механики были уже множество раз в других играх: двойные прыжки, скольжение, отскоки от стены. Параметры персонажа и вещей просты. И система крафта тоже. Процедурная генерация призванная повысить реиграбельность скорее навредила игре, чем сделала ее лучше.

Да и как метроидвания игра практически не работает. Большую часть времени структура карты достаточно линейна и лишь временами игроку предоставляется выбор с развилкой, который интуитивно угадывается через какое-то время, где будет тупик с сундуком или жителем, а где дорога к боссу. А возвратов в другую зоны, чтобы продолжить путь после получения новой способности и того меньше.

Но это не далает Chasm плохой игрой. Chasm — что называется крепкий середнячок. Он оказалась приятным хоть и простым платформером, хоть и тут процедурная генерация сыграла больше во вред из-за однообразности экранов.
В зависимости от стиля игры Chasm может оказаться для игрока как легкой прогулкой с незамысловатой, но занятной историей на простом уровне сложности. Так и сложным испытанием на высоком, если не злоупотреблять магией и зельями.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062872937', 'num_games_owned': 1186, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1069, 'last_played': 1635425181}
review:
This game is the most grindy and repetitive mess of an indie pixel game I've had the displeasure of having to try and beat for the sake of my completionist personality but in the end its just not worth it and I will stop roughly around the final boss area of the game because I dont see this as being enjoyable to play in the slightest. the weapons are unenjoyable the spells are underwhelming the armor and accessories might as well not even be part of the game since it has no impact on your characters looks at all and most of the enemies are put in some really frustrating positions given the clunky and sometimes unresponsive controls on PC, lack of Iframes also is a huge negative for me like why even have this back dash dodge maneuver if it doesn't provide any real benefit to the player.

Conclusion: this game had potential but with how it insists on this gimmick of procedural generation and how it has a very poor tutorial and direction in general for the player I'm going to have to say nah pass on this game its not worth your time or money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095752373', 'num_games_owned': 318, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1633695535}
review:
I really enjoyed playing this game (finished it once 100%, no replays)
I played the 1.079 version.

The good:
- The generated map that I got with my playthrough very enjoyable.
- Combat is easy, but enjoyable (all enemies have clear tells)
- Platforming with tight controls, I never missed a w
- The art direction : graphics + music.
- Ingame hints are very clear, no need for walkthrougs to 100% this.
- The game provides enough additional modes/content to spice up any replays.

The average:
- The story is basic, but provides just enough atmosphere.
- The swords are clearly the best weapons, you will probably only play with the other weapons if you want to challenge yourself.

The bad:
- Bossfights are very easy, because you can tank damage like a champ due to the abundance of food items (like in Bloodstained), but you can up the challenge yourself by refusing to use food items.
- The shovel mechanic, why do you need to equip this item.
- No quick respawn upon death, manual reload needed. This does not occur a lot because the game is not very hard.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087164363', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 323, 'last_played': 1632613922}
review:
Chasm sofreu muito em seu lançamento e com o que tinha prometido entregar em sua campanha de financiamento coletivo. Mas jogando pela primeira vez em 2021, eu vejo que ele foi injustiçado. 

É uma clássica experiência de metroidvanias remetendo a Castlevania Symphony of the Night, com gráficos em pixel art maravilhosos e entregando uma experiência desafiadora, mas justa. 

Talvez o ponto mais fraco do jogo seja realmente a questão dele ser gerado proceduralmente a cada run. Acredito que ele teria ganhado muito mais se cada bioma fosse pensado e estruturado como os jogos mais clássicos. 

Mas o que pra mim pode ser uma fraqueza, na realidade pode ser um ponto forte do jogo. Cada run vai ser diferente e única, evitando assim repetições e entregando sempre uma surpresa no final. 

Enfim, recomendo Chasm e acredito ser um jogo que merece uma segunda chance.

author: {'steamid': '76561198165915226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 1383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1383, 'last_played': 1634717812}
review: I want to like Chasm. I really do. The art style is fluid and expressive, the weapon variety is large, there's a lot of lore and story to sink your teeth into... But it fails at so much of the basics of a metroidvania, heck, even of a 2D platformer. There's a very noticeable stiffness to the controls, with such a lack of animation cancelling that you can often end up swinging your sword in the wrong direction because the game just didn't register the input. Low ceilings plague the platforming, often causing you to whiff easy jumps. And there are just so many poison pits. And that's not even to mention the underwhelming procedural generation. You end up with several bespoke maps that connect entirely incoherently, when not bookending one another, and you're left with a good looking game that has uninteresting and bland maps which plays like a slower, stiffer Symphony Of The Night. It is almost a passable game, it is so close to being something I can recommend but it just falls below the mark.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020092160', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1702948855}
review:
[h1] Chasm is a mixed bag, and getting an informed opinion on the game is a challenge in and of itself. [/h1]

Many critics of Chasm cite the game's procedural nature as its downfall. I partially disagree. The main criticism I would leverage towards Chasm is a lack of character, primarily within its environments. It is certainly possible that the lack of character found could be a result of the game's roguelike nature, but I do not think that has to necessarily be the case. A game like Darkest Dungeon uses randomized dungeon layouts, encounters, etc., all while having incredibly memorable dungeon environments. Chasm has the impossible task of competing with environments from its predecessors, namely Castlevania. Games such as Super Castlevania and Symphony of the Night have some of the best environments, and presentations in general, of any game I've played, old or new. Chasm has subpar environments, most of them feeling like stock fantasy cliches: the abandoned mine, the crypt, the castle, etc. These environments have been used time and time again, which is fine, as they are archetypal of the genre for a reason. However, Chasm does nothing special to integrate these environments into the world it has created.

The setup for clearing out these environments is forgettable. The game's story is told through various NPC's, none of which have any charisma. Additionally, there are lore pamphlets scattered throughout each dungeon, but they do not tell a compelling narrative. I feel what was missed in Chasm's story can be summed up in one word: emotion. At no point did I feel anything for anyone found within the game. If you are the kind of person who prefers lore to dialogue, maybe there is something here for you. There was nothing here for me, and what was there was often grating.

In summary, Chasm's environments are bland and its story lacking. What this game accels at is its combat design. Classicvania games are a bit one note, in that their enemies are all dealt with in more-or-less the same manner: whip them before they reach you. There is some variety in what angle enemies approach from, but rarely do enemies deviate from simply moving towards the player. Beyond its most basic adversaries, Chasm's enemies have differing methods of attacking the player. It is not uncommon for an enemy to retreat from the player for a few steps, and then wind up for a lunge before retreating again. Some enemies advance, some enemies retreat, some enemies lunge, some enemies move steadily but quickly, etc. What is important here is that the player must utilize the game's mechanics in order to overcome these enemies efficiently. There are many instances in which if one were to swing multiple times at an enemy, one would have to utilize Chasm's backdash in order to escape retaliation. Walking backwards or jumping would not be sufficient. With other enemies, ducking is required. Others still, jumping over them. The list goes on. What is important here is that there is legitimate interaction between the player and their opponents. No one strategy beats all enemies, and the core mechanics cannot be ignored. The sad reality is that this is not often the case in the genre, as most developers do not understand how the tools they have given the player function, and therefore do not design the player's enemies around those tools. Chasm is one of the few exceptions to this trend. Not all enemies are a dps race, not all enemies can simply be jumped over. Each interaction is unique.

It is worth mentioning that Chasm is deceptively challenging. The game gifts the player enough health to cover for many of their mistakes, but mastering the game is quite difficult. One of the reasons for this is that Chasm's protagonist is at a range deficit in comparison to virtually every other metroidvania hero I'm aware of. Chasm's protagonist has very stubby limbs, and the reach of something like a knife, or even a shortsword, is extremely small. These shorter weapons, particularly the knives, daggers, and gauntlets, tend to have insane damage potential. This means that in order to be optimal, one must be incredibly precise with their spacing, lest the player run into their opponents and take damage. Chasm is a game that rewards skill, and has a fairly high skill ceiling, which is somewhat uncommon for the genre, outside of self-imposed challenges, like speedrunning. However, I would have preferred the difficulty settings change more than just health and damage. While these changes are fine, I would have liked to see easier difficulty settings make things like reacting and dodging easier for newer players, whilst also speeding up enemies on harder difficulties. Oddly enough, the former is actually possible once one has beaten the game. After completing the game, the player unlocks the ability to select a class. Doing so will grant the player various buffs and debuffs that cater to a specific playstyle. Specifically, the Warrior Class will allow the player to swing faster, which in turn means kill enemies faster and have more time to dodge attacks, as you spend less time in the swing animation. A Warrior's lack in magic is hardly missed, and I would consider the Warrior Class to be something of an "Easy Mode." Unfortunately, this is locked away until you have beaten the game already, making it pointless as a new-player aide. Admittedly, that was not class mode's intention, and this was merely an example of how I would have made the game easier for newer players, rather than an implication that class mode was somehow an oversight.

Even as I write this review, I am debating whether or not to recommend the title. While the combat design is great, the game as a whole is lackluster. I have only chosen to revisit the game due to its Arcade Mode, which lets you play the game as a roguelike, and compete for highscores. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a Castlevania-esque game with excellent combat. If you are the type of person who does not have any qualms with the combat in other metroidvania games, particularly in the Castlevania series, and plays these games for exploration, story, setting, etc., than I would not recommend Chasm. Luckily, there is a demo, so if you are on the fence, I would recommend checking it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078034751', 'num_games_owned': 883, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 1705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1705, 'last_played': 1633786254}
review:
I'm not a big fan of metroidvania genre, I haven't played a lot of them. Only other metroidvania I've played was Hollow Knight and I couldn't make myself finish it when it turned out I was farming for an item I didn't need at the time to progress with the game. This one however I finished and I enjoyed it for the most part even though I had some issues with it.
First of all the retro graphics are really enjoyable and the game has 6 biomes You go through when You progress through the game. Soundtrack isn't the best but has some variations depending on the biome You're on and the music for Boss fights is there.
The story is simple but there's some lore in the Journal entries that You can find across the map. The NPCs offer You 1 side quest each which reward You with some consumable items, gold or an additional option unlocking for some of the NPCs. I felt rewarded for doing the side quests which helped in progressing through the game later on. Side quests aren't a big part of the game but give You some options.
There are plenty of weapons and equipment to choose from. While the drop rates might not encourage You to farm some of the items, You'll definitely feel rewarded with some of the Boss drops if You can kill them without taking damage. The Bosses mechanics are made in a way that You can learn them and evade most of the attacks if You wish so. The thing that was lacking for me in terms of equipment and items was that the NPCs have a limited supply of items which can be used for Crafting Gear or Upgrading Spells. You can farm a lot of weapons that just doesn't feel good to play with even though their stats are much greater than Your current weapon so You sell them and buy items that would allow You to craft more suitable weapon - but the item supply is really low.
The Spells aren't really overpowered or useless - some are more useful some are less but they're always helpful in getting rid of mobs in places You cannot reach because You would have to tank damage on contact. I saw someone complaining about having to grind money to buy gems needed to upgrade the Spells. That's not the case in the current build anymore - supply of gems you can buy from NPC is so limited that you could probably upgrade only one Spell to max level. I didn't have much trouble upgrading the Spells as I got plenty of them dropped from the mobs instead.
The replayability is there for some extent but it wasn't enough for me to play the game for more time after getting 100% achievements. Still I was enjoying my second run where I got some of the rooms with the traps a little easier to pass through. I also did every Boss that had no hit challenge without taking damage to get the drop and test it out and it felt really rewarding after beating the [spoiler]Titan[/spoiler] boss and getting op weapon.
The last of the issues I had with the game was poor map navigation for me. Some of the areas that are required to pass through to progress with the game aren't marked on the map. One area that isn't needed to progress with the game but is needed to 100% the game is also not marked. I had a lot of trouble running through almost whole levels again when I got abilities that let me get to the places I couldn't get before because I couldn't find the right area. If You're playing the game for the first time just remember there is a SET MARKER option. Remember to set markers in one room levels that are needed to progress with the game so You won't have to search for them for a long time. Here are the areas if You're wondering: [spoiler] area to place the Black Feather[/spoiler], [spoiler]area to place the Black Gem[/spoiler], [spoiler]area with the Gate and a sign next to it[/spoiler], [spoiler]tower area with 4 bells[/spoiler]. Also remember that treasures, Journal entries and other stuff is marked with 1 pixel in the middle of the square on the map and that the passages are marked with a hole on the border of the areas. You should also remember that if You have a blue square on Your map without an arrow and an icon indicating which area it leads to - it's probably a place You didn't go to. Just an advice from someone who got lost more than he should've.
With all of the above being said, I've enjoyed playing this game. The story was small but fun to play through, combat felt rewarding and the equipment pool was big enough for me. Drop rates didn't really matter that much to me as I mostly used long range weapons to avoid the contact damage. Crafting needs a lot of grinding and NPCs item supply is really limited and that could feel dissapointing. Navigating the map in Your first playthrough might be hard so I hope the tips I gave You help You even if just a bit. The game is a bit unpolished with all the stuff I talked about but it's really enjoyable so give it a try.

review:
It's an OK Metroidvania game, but it got nothing special about it and the reason is the inherent limitation that comes with the world being procedurally generated each time you start a new game.

This games was influenced by games like Castlevania Symphony of the Night and Order of Ecclesia -  exploring different environments, rescuing NPCs and find new equipment and unlocking new abilities to progress further.

You may find different environments in the game with the area specific mobs in them but you won't get special elements in the level design that would make them stand out from other environments other then the background and mobs.

For what it's worth I did have fun with the game for what it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095810248', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1219, 'last_played': 1633084407}
review:
Positives (good and quirky alike): Really good game if you like games like handheld castlevanias which felt like the main inspiration. Crisp movement and abilities. Something is ever so slightly off with spamming attacks which makes it not seemless to do so, both on controller and keyboard. Wished there were more secrets and hidden away stuff. Found it interesting/strange that a couple potions had only a one off use pretty much. Lots of enemy variation. Not too long of a game, seems well paced. 

Negatives (well one negative really) The one and only bad part of the game is the horrible item droprate, you can and will have to spend 2-3 levels to get both drops from some enemies. Luckscrolls seems to do nothing in regards to this issue and they are a finite resource too. Farmed for 2 levels with 80 luck much of the time thanks to all the luckscrolls. Still no itemdrop. Ended up reloading just to keep the scrolls. Used em all up again at another place with nothing to show for it. Seriously, this really bad if you want to make a complete savefile. I myself gave up on it since it got so bad and ive farmed all bestiaries and drops for completion in all handheld castlevanias which i find very fun. Here however I just cant justify doing the same, due to how extremely awfully elusive the drops are.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132503739', 'num_games_owned': 601, 'num_reviews': 548, 'playtime_forever': 1685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1685, 'last_played': 1632651489}
review:
[b]Playing status:[/b] 100% achievement, 2x playthroughs
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (13 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (1 achievement).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Chasm[/b] is a metroidvania game where you play as a knight delving into a chasm that leads to various regions. There are 5+1 explorable regions with a boss fight at the end of each region.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 4 difficulties
- Enemies and bosses with unique attack patterns
- Various weapons with different range and attack speed
- Bonus reward for exploring optional areas

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Sometimes it's hard to know where to go next
- You need to get used to the dodge mechanic to utilize it properly
- The game can be a bit grindy at harder difficulties
- No save point before the last boss fight

[b]Specs[/b]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like to play metroidvanias, buy this game. Achievement hunters need to be skilled at the genre or risk grinding for drops and enemies and/or retrying the same areas several times.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h3]Visuals[/h3]
A lot of care was taken into both backgrounds and characters, allowing you to see the beautifully crafted regions. Backgrounds are made in great detail with multiple layers to give some sort of depth to them while still having a unique theme for each region. It's nice to see the variations given for the enemies too. Some enemies might be of the same type, but they are made differently to distinguish them from the other.

[h3]Story[/h3]
The story is well written to give some context on what's happening. On the surface, [b]Chasm[/b] tells the story of a young knight that embarks on his first mission. Most dialogues are skippable for those who are not interested in such things, although people who want to know more can find more info in the form of journals scattered in the regions. I still didn't make out how the whole thing happened even after reading them, but at least you get the idea of what's happening before the main character comes into play.

[h3]The Game[/h3]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
The game is played like other metroidvanias, featuring interconnected areas with some that require certain items to progress. More items will be obtained as you play, allowing you to reexplore these areas to get optional rewards. However, some of these areas are mandatory to explore, and the game never gives any indication about it. There were times when I was stuck in the game simply because I wanted to obtain as many items as I could before reexploring previous regions.

The game might be randomized on each run, but I don't find the randomization to be that appealing. They only randomized some rooms while still leaving the important rooms intact. I know that it might be difficult to randomize everything, especially since some areas are tied to progression, but I'd rather play the game without any randomization instead.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663786

The areas can be difficult to traverse at higher difficulties, mainly because of enemies that can damage you for 1/4 of your HP pool with a single attack. You'll end up traversing checkpoints to checkpoints later on, retrying it several times until you can clear it without dying if you are not good enough. Sadly, you are forced to load your latest save whenever you die, so the amount of time that you took to retry these areas can turn into waste. You can always try to consume potions and items to prevent dying, but since the game isn't generous in giving them nor money that can be used to buy them, you might need to grind to afford it, especially if you use it since the first few regions.

Some platforming sections can be dreadful for those who are not good at platformers. Luckily, most of them are optional and serve as a test to give you some rewards. Moreover, they tend to give non-unique items that can be easily obtained elsewhere, so there's little reason to get them if you know what the chest contains.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663847

Different types of weapons allow you to choose your weapon of preference. [b]Chasm[/b] offers various weapons with different attacking ranges and speeds, with a shorter range weapon having a faster speed and a broader range weapon having a lower speed. I myself got used to a one-handed sword due to its faster attacking speed and tolerable range, although it might be problematic to use for flying enemies; they might slip from my attacking range and deals a lot of damage from that.

[b]Combat[/b]
Enemies are varied and unique. This applies to all enemies, including the normal enemies. Their attacks might seem to be impossible to dodge at first, but there is always a way to defeat them, whether it's by using your weapon or magic. It's fun to learn how their attack works and how to dodge them. The game has somewhat of a difficulty spike in the third region though since there is one enemy that can't be killed without taking damage due to their way of walking.

Bosses can be tough to beat. All bosses have different and varied attack patterns that need to be dodged. Some attacks can even fill the whole screen, forcing you to dodge them just like in bullet hell games. Luckily, they can always be cheesed with potions if you have a problem with them. In fact, I even used potions on the final boss fight because the save point before the fight is very far from it.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2612663841
[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished the game in the hard difficulty in 21.8h and replayed the game again in the easy difficulty for an achievement in 6h. The game offers 4 difficulties, with hard being the third hardest and easy being the easiest difficulty. To be honest, I found the hard difficulty to be hard. I had trouble clearing the area several times and got bored playing the game because of it. It wasn't fun to retry the area several times and rely on your luck to not getting hit. You can always use potions for these, but I chose not to use them before the very last region because money are quite scarce. You might need to farm money for it, and I'm already occupied with farming enemies to level up and raise my stat already.

Enemies drop rare, unique items. You might spend a significant amount of time grinding for the same enemies over and over to get that rare drop, or even grind enemies just to fulfill a weapon's requirements to make it stronger. Moreover, the game also has some sort of level system, so you might even need to level up a few times just to be strong enough to clear the areas in a harder difficulty. Luckily, I only had a problem with this in my hard run. The game becomes more enjoyable in the easy difficulty too since I didn't have to spend time reloading my save over and over because of stupid mistakes.

[b]Problems[/b]
Dodging can take time to get used to. You didn't get an iframe for dodging and pressing the left button while dodging will move your character to the right since it always moves backward from where you are facing.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[b]Chasm[/b] is a solid metroidvania for all kinds of people. The difficulty helps to adjust it for different kinds of people, while those who still want an extra challenge can try to beat the bosses without taking damage and get rewarded for it. Moreover, there's also a roguelike mode that can wipe your save if you die if you want to activate it.

The game can be hard at first, but it is fair. Enemies that seem to be impossible to hit with your sword can encourage you to try different weapons or magic, while others that have complicated attack patterns can be dodged if you know what you are doing. I could easily recommend this to those who like metroidvanias, especially the difficult ones.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039224848', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 237, 'last_played': 1632618507}
review:
Recomendo por motivos de: Metroidvania são os melhores estilos.

Alguns pontos que notei até agora:

*As habilidades de exploração demoram de MAIS para serem aprendidas, a primeira habilidade por exemplo leva mais de 1 hora até você obter.

*Nesse estilo de jogo onde inimigos podem vir de cima de baixo de um lado do outro é muito importante poder direcionar o ataque, pelo menos para cima isso faz muita falta nesse jogo sendo necessario pular pra fora das plataformas pra acertar bixos que estão acima de você (o que muitas vezes acaba fazendo você tomar dano tanto do bixo ao qual esta se atacando quanto do fogo que tem abaixo da plataforma).

*O mapa [spoiler]jardins[/spoiler] é extremamente exaustivo não possuindo teleportes suficientes nem mesmo saves sendo necessario fazer areas muito grande de 'platforming' sem save nenhum (sendo necessario até retornar por essas areas grandes) o que deixa é EXTREMAMENTE frustante pois você morre e precisa fazer TUDO de novo.

*O mapa [spoiler]templo[/spoiler] é mais exaustivo ainda que o [spoiler]jardins[/spoiler] ele possui somente 1 ponto de viagem rapida NENHUM save e possui varios corredores onde não é possivel desviar dos monstros por serem muito baixos ou pelo range de ataque dos monstros ser tanto para cima quanto para os lados, o dinheiro juntado durante toda exploração até o momento provavelmente não será suficiente para comprar itens de cura necessarios para o mapa todo.

*Os preços dos itens de cura é altissimo fazendo com que nunca tenhamos chance de andar com mais de 2 poções no inventario dependendo de mais da sorte de drops para cura. (Principalmente no mapa [spoiler]Jardins[/spoiler])

[spoiler]
*O posicionamento do ultimo boss totalmente sem noção sendo atras de VARIOS monstros com ataques em padrões super dificil de desviar sem save proximo para recuperar a vida, você chega no boss já sem vida nenhuma e o BOSS tem alguns ataques com padrões que precisam de desvios praticamente pixel-perfect, ou seja você VAI tomar esses ataques todas as vezes que eles forem usados. O mapa tem um save só que aparece logo após uma luta com um semi-boss ou seja você ja gastou todos seus itens de cura nesse semi boss deixando você com um save "quebrado" onde ou você se torna pro-player ou você NUNCA vai zerar o jogo por ter que passar pelos mesmos corredores SEMPRE sem chance de conseguir mais itens de cura.
[/spoiler]

Devido a esse ultimo ponto tô bem tentado a dizer que não recomendo o jogo esse tipo de coisa de "travar" o player sem dar condições de tentar outros meios de passar de uma parte do jogo é muito absurdo em qualquer jogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013961319', 'num_games_owned': 1497, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 820, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 820, 'last_played': 1630714181}
review:
A solid metroidvania, but it doesn't really add anything new to the formula. It plays pretty much exactly like an amalgamation of the latter Igavanias to a degree that makes me think the developers didn't really know what elements made those games good. The fact that the games it's aping are so good means it inherits a lot of that quality, but if you didn't really like metroidvanias I don't think I could recommend the game. 

Without playing through multiple times, and I don't intend to, I can't comment much on a lot the game design. In my playthrough there were often enemy placements that felt unfair or at least not how a human would design them. If the game is composed of room-tiles, this would be a knock against it, but if it's composed to sub-room-tiles, it's fine, I guess. It feels like a lot of effort that could have gone into the procedural design would have probably been better spent on proper level design and content. The game feels a bit sparse, with a relative lack of items compared to the games it's imitating, which makes the exploration feel less rewarding. Drop rates seem really low, which is fine in an Igavania where you're given a compelling reason to backtrack and a long list of items from a large list of enemies, but less so when there's just so little to obtain. The balance always felt a bit off, not too difficult, but I guess that might just be because of the procedural generation.

Overall, a fine game to play through once if you like metroidvanias, which I do, but probably not worth it otherwise.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972303784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 965, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180, 'last_played': 1630854263}
review:
Chasm isn't perfect:  Certainly things like the 60 fps lock (including the reason it's there) isn't ideal, but overall I'd say it's a fine game.

It has good balance too.  Nothing is slanted against the player in an unfair way.  There's a little bit of grinding necessary if you want to keep high defense at all times but just a minor change would fix that issue and it only wasted about 30 minutes of my time anyways.

One solid criticism I do have for the game is the lack of in-game markers for the map.  The map is great about labeling rooms with chests you haven't gotten yet but I'd still like to be able to mark the map myself to add notes like "need double-jump" or "need slide" for later.  This is especially bad in this case because the map is randomized for every player based on a text-string seed minecraft-style, so there isn't an online map/guide you can look over.

If you like metroidvanias then you should have a fun 10-15 hours with this game doing a run.

author: {'steamid': '76561198070842180', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 747, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 747, 'last_played': 1606971774}
review:
I went into Chasm pretty excited; For a while I had considered the idea of a rogue-like Metroidvania where each playthrough shuffles the map and collectibles to be great idea that I was surprised hadn't been done. So learning a game did exactly what I was thinking of was like a match made in heaven! Add some very lovely visuals and themes and you get what should have been a new all-time favorite... So what went wrong?

Well, technically speaking, nothing. Chasm didn't do anything particularly wrong, but it didn't do anything particularly right.

Chasm's primary concept doesn't quite work; Randomized level design is, on paper, a good idea but in practice Chasm's room design is repetitive, flat, and in no uncertain terms boring. Because of the nature of random generation, each room essentially needs to be built to fit against any other room, and this results in rooms looking, feeling, and in my playthrough literally *being* the same room. I found myself checking the map dozens of times just to make sure I didn't go down the wrong identical hallway.

Because of this level design, item progression and balance are also an issue. One of the biggest selling points in Metroidvanias is the feeling of growing stronger the more you go. To me, part of this is being able to get through rooms faster the more movement options you get, but Chasm fails in this department entirely. All the movement upgrades you get, save for the very last one, almost never resulted in room-traversing getting any faster. And because rooms can be against any other room, it's possible to get gauntlets of long corridors filled with tough enemies with little breathing room, which can result in you wondering if you're under-prepared or just unlucky. This particularly stings early on, where healing options are scarce, with only the occasional save point or random-drop-chance based healing items.

However, Chasm does have it's fair share of good to it as well. For starters, the game looks, sounds, and feels very nice! The sprite work is top-notch, the soundtrack is, admittedly a bit hit-or-miss; The themes of The Keep and The Mines being my personal favorite, and genuinely songs I go back and listen to. And the controls feel very smooth, with few times where I felt they worked against me. And while Chasm's level design is flawed, their method to fast travel was actually very well thought out; Each main area has a main hub with 4 sealed doors, and each door is located in the same area generally on the map itself, giving you an indirect method to knowing where to go; If a door is at the top of the hub, the corresponding door will likely be somewhere north on the map. These hubs also allow fast travel between the main areas of the game, and since the first area's hub houses a save area, these hubs double as healing and progress recording which is all too convenient.

Overall, my opinions on Chasm are very neutral-positive; The game doesn't do anything amazing, and it's only gimmick is it's biggest weakness, but if all you want is a decent Metroidvania that isn't one of the usual big name ones thrown around, go ahead and give Chasm a try, for as simple as it is I still enjoyed my time with it!

author: {'steamid': '76561197963366484', 'num_games_owned': 777, 'num_reviews': 210, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1701990192}
review:
Incredibly boring game that adds nothing to the genre.  Played the game for 3 hours and the character never actually developed any abilities that were remotely interesting or fun to play.  Nearly every item drop in a treasure chest was either a duplicate armor piece or a weapon that did slightly more damage and had a range of 1 pixel.  I had to resort to using the whip weapon which did terrible damage but could actually let me have somewhat of an advantage in combat.  Platforming works most of the time but you will find yourself missing jumps because half of the platforming revolves around grabbing ledges.  You have to actively push in the direction of the ledge in order to grab it, making it incredibly easy to miss a jump.

The game appears to have some kind of mana system although I have no idea how it works or what it is used for.  I imagine that it would give some ranged abilities as your character feels incredibly underpowered with only stubby weapons that take 5 swings to kill something.

I am not a particular fan of Metroidvania games but I can appreciate the genre when it is done right.  This game meets the bare minimum for the genre and seems to take very little risk.  Slogging through the same corridors over and over again is a chore but obviously a staple of the genre as a whole.  

The basic mechanics of this game could function on an NES cartridge and maybe that is the point, but nostalgia shouldn't be the prime motivator to play games like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003506597', 'num_games_owned': 1145, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 836, 'last_played': 1629655754}
review:
I've beaten this game and it's *okay* but, from a gameplay standpoint, it never rises above that. I really wish I liked this game more than I do, but there are a lot of weird choices that I don't quite agree with.

* Merchants never restock - once you buy out their supply of warp scrolls/baked goods/gems, you're resorting to farming for the rest of the game. Given the amount of times when I was REALLY happy to have a warp scroll and the amount of gems needed to fully level up your magic? Would have been nice to be able to pick some up, even if there was just a fairly long cooldown or something.

* No saves in a late-game zone - One of the late-game zones (the Temple) is a teleporter 'maze' that has you doing a lot of backtracking; it would have been great to have some save rooms here and I'm not certain why they chose to go that direction.

* Meteoric gear - Meteor gear seems to be... pretty useless? Maybe I got lucky by finding a gold crown in the Keep, but between that and a golden hammer (made at the blacksmith way earlier than you get access to meteor ingots) I found myself not even considering going for meteor gear, which is weird because it seems to take so much more effort to farm and is ostensibly a late-game item.

* Movement - The movement is *incredibly* stiff to me; I got used to it after a while, but compared to many other games, it just feels unpleasant. I'm not opposed to stiff movement (I played Dark Souls 1 before coming back to this one), but something just feels off about the movement and end-lag and general control feeling.

Again, I wish I liked this game more, but right now I could only recommend it as a deep, deep sale or part of a bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110957387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1042, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1629643311}
review:
After finally finishing the game I can share my opinion with you, fellow readers.

Chasm is one of that Metroidvania-Games which try to look good in the store page but don´t do anything special while playing.

  [h1] PROS [/h1]

- The pixel-artstyle isn´t that special, but it looks pretty, aswell as the animations.

- The music (standard and the retro version) is nice, nothing impressive, but atleast they got 
  something right.


  [h1] CONS [/h1]

- Story couldn´t be less relevant in this one.

- The combat  is bland and doesn´t feel completly balanced (stiff and slow).

- Spells feel like a neet extra instead of being essential to the core combat

- Backtracking doesn´t feel fun or accomplishing.

- Everytime you die, you get kicked out into the main menu and need to start the game from 
  the last safe 
  [b] EVERY [/b] [b] DAMN [/b] [b] TIME [/b] instead just respawning quickly, like in all other 
  games from this 
  genre.

- Farming Monsterloot doesn´t feel good at all, cuz of the lack of creativity for the drops.

- The way enemies get much stronger and your equipment completly useless in every new 
   area is ridiculous. 

- Fast travel, but the positioning of it feels off due to the procedurally generated map.

- The areas don´t feel unique, neither do the enemies in their distinct area.
   (Enemies look way too generic)


[h1] LAST WORDS [/h1]

Overall I was hyped when I saw chasm in the store, it looked appealing, but after some hours into the game, it just got boring and frustrating due to the poorly made gameplay. I bought it in sale and I really can´t recommend it for anyone that likes to play Metroidvanias. It does nothing to be in some kind unique to other Metroidvanias or to be a [i] good [/i] game at all, it just tries to be the [u ]most mediocre [/u] one it can be and that´s what bothers me the most.

3/10 wouldn´t play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004515240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2390, 'last_played': 1629580134}
review:
Pretty solid retro-style Metroidvania. Controls are mostly tight aside from some weapons having janky animations or swing speed and this is much more forgiving than a lot of games of this type especially early on, but sweet baby Yoda play this game with a controller and not keyboard and mouse. You can style around short to medium melee either unarmed or with a variety of standard sword & sorcery type weapons or do ranged with magic and you are not really locked out of respeccing or changing things up if you find you prefer one route over another. 

Graphics and music are great, the story is as interesting as it needs to be and there is a fair amount of replayability since most of the dungeons are procedurally generated and you can share seeds or keep track of your favourite ones. 

A few minor complaints are that the game is mostly too easy until quite late even on Hard, and the last significant dungeon is easily the most difficult area of the enitre  game with complex rooms and hard-hitting enemies, has NO save points at all and you really hit this point with no real expectation or warning.  Chasm also falls into the same Metroidvania progression trap of being fairly linear since you need certain abilities to progress further so your playthru will always sequentially be roughly the same even if the layout of your dungeons are different but that's more a flaw of the genre than the game itself. 

If you liked Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night, Hollow Knight, Vigil: The Longest Night or Blasphemous you'll probably enjoy this game.

review:
A good average Metroidvania game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059186278', 'num_games_owned': 260, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 719, 'last_played': 1629598314}
review:
Não comprem chasm. Não é um bom jogo. É frustrante em mais maneiras do que eu poderia descrever com palavras. É péssimo, é horrível.

Vamos lá, um metroidvania que saiu no ano de 2018, com absolutamente NADA de inovador, competindo com grandes 'tigres' do mesmo gênero como Hollow Knight e Ori and The Blind Forest, Chasm é simplesmente dispensável, mal feito e absolutamente sem graça.

O tempo de demora de Chasm o fez envelhecer mal. O gênero precisava de um revival lá pelos anos de 2013 quando começou a ser desenvolvido (acho até que foi antes disso), mas a demora para o lançamento dele o fez ser lançado quando o gênero voltava a explodir. O resultado é um jogo muito mal feito, extremamente frustante (por diversas vezes voce não sabe o que tem que fazer e o jogo não te dá nem meia pista). Simplesmente a ideia de criar um metroidvania procedural, com mapas aleatórios é ridícula, pois como não há mapa 'padrão', até mesmo para você tentar se localizar se estiver perdido é difícil para não dizer impossível. Não são raras os tópicos nos mais diversos sites (steam, reddit, gamefaqs) tentando de alguma forma PROGREDIR no jogo. 

A dificuldade, mesmo no modo normal é INSANA, ridícula, patética! É simplesmente um negócio que não tem cabimento. A progressão da dificuldade beira o ignominioso. 

Além dos cenários serem absolutamente sem graças, insonsos e repetitivos, o jogo leva o quesito exploração à beira do insustentável, pois, como dito, não são raras vezes em que você literalmente vai ter feito tudo que podia e mesmo assim não conseguiu achar o que fazer, porque precisava EQUIPAR um item que tem uma descrição que não serve para nada e entrar numa sala aleatória numa das dungeons e encontrar um personagem aleatório igualmente.

Chasm é um metroidvania RUIM, péssimo, horrível. Eu estou com quase 90 por cento do mapa completo e prestes a enfrentar o chefe final no momento dessa análise e digo que foi uma aquisição que não valeu UM CENTAVO sequer. Se tivesse como eu pediria reembolso.

Não espere nada de inovador de Chasm. É simplesmente um metroidvania que além de ser absolutamente difícil não te recompensa em quase nada. Normalmente o gênero possui um binômio muito forte: exploração = recompensa. Isto é, quanto mais eu exploro mais eu tenho recompensa. Porém Chasm te faz explorar a esmo.

Não recomendo. Não diga que não avisei. Tendo jogado e zerado mais de uma dúzia de jogos do gênero, posso atestar com clareza que esse jogo é péssimo!
