review: Metroid-like medium-rez 2d combat game in a medieval fantasy setting. You're a budding knight who's given his first field mission: go investigate what's going on at a mine. Fight monsters, get stronger, learn skills, rescue townspeople who open up shops for you.  Lightweight adventure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198875268438', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1681, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1681, 'last_played': 1595899031}
review:
Chasm é um metroidvania simples para os veteranos do gênero e nada complexo para quem quer conhecer.
Os controles são responsivos, os inimigos em sua maioria agressivos e a dificuldade aumenta gradualmente em uma medida boa o bastante para que o jogador consiga sempre se adaptar.
O mapa, apesar de ser semi aleatório falha em manter o valor de replay alto por não alterar as experiências o bastante. Não chega perto de ser um roguelike.
Falando em valor de replay, o jogo oferece ao jogador algumas opções que deixam suas jogatinas futuras um pouco mais frescas, principalmente caso queira jogar com outra "build".
O jogo conta também com um belo estilo em pixel art com criaturas e cenários belos o bastante para que você se sinta imerso no mundo no qual está inserido.
Infelizmente não posso deixar de apontar os pontos negativos. A trilha sonora, em sua grande maioria, deixa a desejar na maioria das áreas (marca geralmente forte em metroidvanias).
A história é absolutamente esquecível. Acredito que uma decisão melhor seria se tivessem deixado-a de lado para que o jogador pudesse estabelecer sozinho uma construção de mundo estruturada em sua experiência. A luta contra o último chefe aponta o ápice do desapontamento em um momento anti climático para o jogador que ousou se importar com a história.

[b]POSITIVO:[/b]
- Metroidvania com jogabilidade sólida
- Dificuldade gradual e justa
- Bela arte em pixel
- Grande variedade de equipamentos permite várias "builds"

[b]NEUTRO:[/b]
- Mapa semi aleatório não é satisfatório porém a construção de mundo é
- Valor de replay questionável

[b]NEGATIVO:[/b]
- Trilha sonora medíocre
- História e personagens nada envolventes
- Clímax do jogo é na verdade anticlimático

Chasm não se mantém forte quando comparado aos titãs de seu gênero porém continua um jogo no qual recomendo que deem uma chance, principalmente o fã de metroidvanias.

author: {'steamid': '76561198245792638', 'num_games_owned': 387, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 916, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 916, 'last_played': 1578940975}
review:
Chasm - ничем не примечательная, но все же неплохая метройдвания, имеющая при себе хорошую графику и отличное звуковое сопровождение. Выделяя плюсы игры, на этом, пожалуй, можно и закончить.

Геймплеем ничем не может выделится от остальных представителей данного жанра - она максимально отдает духом Симфонии Ночи. Не сказать, что в игре присутствует динамичность (а ее будет поменьше в сравнении с той же Каслванией), скорее медленный темп, отдающий этаким чувством... успокоения (этому еще способствует характерная музыка, проигрывающаяся в различных локациях). 

Все могло быть намного лучше, если бы не вырезали контент, ввели упрощения в геймплее в угоду для... чего? Неясно. 

И все же мне нравится эта игра. Она манит своей простотой, приятной для глаз картинкой и, разумеется, добротным саундтреком, реально заставляя игрока расслабиться. 
Порекомендовать игру могу всем, только не любителям жанра - нового или уникального для себя здесь вы не найдете. 

5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198044539233', 'num_games_owned': 1237, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 395, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 395, 'last_played': 1596159906}
review:
Promising engine held back by design missteps.

Chasm feels good to play at the start.  The controls are responsive and the artstyle is very nice to look at.  The early content is directed and purposeful.  It gradually begins to unravel after that.

After the first couple areas, Chasm falls hard into the worst trappings of the Metroidvania genre, which is collect powerup so you can backtrack to collect another powerup so you can backtrack.  Additionally, procedural generation combined with the extreme randomness in drops, loot modifiers, and the relative uselessness of the equipment vendors/crafting systems leads to an unbalanced sense of progression.  The randomness may allow for no two playthroughs to feel the same, but it also serves to muddle what could have been a more carefully crafted experience.

None of these systems are rotten by themselves, but each is off-kilter just enough to exacerbate issues in the others.  This, combined with other bizarrely tedious mechanics such as having to backtrack inside the hub to save, having to return to the surface from the hub on foot, and only being able to refill magic on the surface, suggests a game that needed to take more feedback from playtesters.

Fun for a few hours but not worth finishing.  Can be good as a timekiller on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094756216', 'num_games_owned': 1654, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 586, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1595403650}
review:
跳跃手感还可以。

author: {'steamid': '76561198135110687', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1595189447}
review:
In the beginning I am pretty enjoying this game actually, the pixel art is fine and the battle is simple but catch the old school spirit pretty well.

But the battles get more irritating when game goes on, there are so many kinds of enemies are so annoying even if you know how to deal with them. And why are the saving/teleport points so rare? Money is incredibly hard to earn and all the items are so unnecessarily expensive. I can feel this game is trying to be like Hollow Knight in many ways, but the difficulties about HK is based on the flexibility that player's character have. Chasm's character doesnt have that king of flexibility, but it's not a problem if the environment is designed right, too bad Chasm is not the case. The map design (including movement skill / process etc.) is bad, you will waste a lot time on going back and forth on map but it's not for exploring, just because the bad map design.  

This game is hard, but you cant call it "challenging" because it's rarely fun, more like annoying and frustrating.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052125808', 'num_games_owned': 1125, 'num_reviews': 234, 'playtime_forever': 649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1594914471}
review:
Chasm ist ein Metroidvania aus dem Hause Bit Kid, inc. und erfindet das Rad nicht im Ansatz neu. Es plätschert vor sich hin, gibt mir dann und wann Upgrades und lässt mich nach und nach die zufallsgenerierte Karte erkunden. Das ganze Spiel geht auf Nummer sicher und traut sich keine Innovationen zu - das finde ich schade, denn mir hat Chasm gut gefallen.

Der Plot: In <Generischer Dorfname hier einfügen> ist <Art des Grauens>, also muss <Insert Name here> los, um <Zu erreichendes Ziel>, damit er <Belohnung>. Punkt. Hier wird eine allgemein bekannte Geschichte erzählt, die genau wie der Rest nicht aus der sicheren Zone kommt.

"Hilfe, Hilfe!", rief <Wegweisender NPC>.
"Wie kann ich helfen?", fragte <Insert Name here>
"Wir haben ein Metroidvanialabyrinth unter der Stadt und alle Dorfbewohner wurden aus unerfindlichen Gründen in Käfige gesteckt und nicht einfach umgebracht, also wurden sie an schwer erreichbare Orte gebracht, die keinen Sinn ergeben. Hoffentlich kommt gleich einer, der in einer festgelegten Reihenfolge Upgrades freischaltet, damit er nach und nach unsere Bewohner befreien kann!"
"Sag nicht ein Wort mehr, austauschbarer NPC! Ich bin schon unterwegs!"
"Danke."
"Ich habe doch gerade gesagt, dass du nicht ein Wort mehr sagen sollst! Bedeuten dir klare Ansagen nichts?!"

Und so begab sich <Insert Name here> hinab in die Mine, prügelte sich in Castlevaniamanier durch Einstiegszonengegner, erreichte hier und da eine neue Stufe, um nach und nach stärker zu werden. Denn eins stellte <Inser Name here> schnell fest: Nicht die Endbosse waren der schwierigste Teil des Spiels, nö, Hindernisse und spätere Standartgegner waren's die ihm schnell mal die Hosen auszogen, um ihm zu zeigen, wofür man Stangenwaffen noch so verwenden kann. Das ist ein Punkt, den <Insert Name here> in seiner Ausbildung nicht gelernt hatte: Eigentlich soll es nicht sein, dass man vor großen Obermackern steht und munter drauf einhaut, bis der Typ umfällt - ein Obermotz sollte das bisher Gelernte auf die Probe stellen. Es kam nie vor, dass <Insert Name here> auf seine Items zugreifen muss, die er sich im Verlaufe seines Verliesausfluges erspielt hat. Es reichte, wenn er einen Stock mit entsprechender Wucht immer wieder auf die Rübe seines Gegenübers schlug. Irgendwann langte es dem auch mal. Dafür machten's die Bewohner des Untergrunds unserem austauschbaren Helden schwer. Sie wirbelten herum wie kleine Tornados und verfügten oft über mehrere Angriffsmuster, die sie anhand ihrer Körperhaltung verrieten. Mit Geschick und einer guten Beobachtungsgabe lernte <Insert Name here>, wie er mit welchem Gegner umzugehen hat und tobte von einem Raum zum nächsten. Neue Feinde erforderten mehr Aufmerksamkeit, aber wenn er <Zu erreichendes Ziel> wollte, musste er sich anstrengen!
Die seichten RPG-Elemente versüßten <Insert Name here> den Tag, denn nach genug verkloppten Feinden erhöhten sich die Charakterwerte automatisch. <Insert Name here> musste sich keine Gedanken über einen Build machen, er wurde durch die Bank weg stärker. Schade nur, dass diese Wertanstiege kaum ins Gewicht fielen, da sie zu niedrig waren. Ob er nun 61 oder 62 Schaden pro Kelle austeilte, fiel selten ins Gewicht. Nur gelegentlich brauchten Gegner dadurch einen Hieb weniger. Auffälliger wurden die Schadenswerte, wenn die Ausrüstung ins Spiel kam, die sich <Insert Name here> bei <Generischer Schmied> für einen kleinen Obolus zusammenbastelte oder im Dungeon fand. Seine Widersacher konnten Items in drei Seltenheitsstufen fallen lassen und wenn diese Gegenstände nicht ruck, zuck überholt gewesen wären, hätte sich manchmal ein gezielter Grind gelohnt. Nötig war das nie, denn der Ausflug unter <Generisches Dorf> dauerte nicht lang. Beim ersten Durchlauf benötigte <Insert Name here> lediglich 7 Stunden und das, obwohl er die einzelnen Stufen bis auf den letzten Stein erkundet hatte.
Schnell war die Dorfbevölkerung an der Oberfläche wieder vereint. <Generischer Schmied>, <Tränketante>, <Magieschickse> und der ganze Rest sangen Loblieder auf <Insert Name here> und zogen ihm keine zehn Minuten später das hart verdiente Geld aus den Taschen, anstatt ihren Retter kostenlos zu unterstützen, denn so lernte man es auf der NPC-Schule.

"Brauchst du magische Unterstützung bei deinen Abenteuern?", fragte <Magieschickse>, ein Sortiment aus hilfreichen Zaubern präsentierend.
"Ja. Ich nehme jede Hilfe an, die ich zur Rettung deiner Mitbewohner erhalten kann!"
"Das macht dann 250 Gold, aufrüsten kost extra und wenn du schon mal da unten bist, holst du mir gefälligst irgendwelchen Schnulli aus einer Kiste am Arsch der Heide."
<Insert Name here> schwieg nach dieser Aussage lange. Hinter ihm legte <Generischer Schmied> den Hammer beiseite und lauschte auf. 
"Habe ich gerade gehört, dass jemand ins Dungeon hinabsteigt, um irgendwelchen Rotz aus einer Kiste am Arsch der Heide zu holen?", fragte er und rieb sich die Hände. 
Auch im Gasthaus öffneten sich die Fenster. Der Bergarbeiter kam aus seinem Schmelzofen, um zu <Insert Name here> zu schlurfen wie ein Untoter. Ein Kopfgeldjäger, der sein Geld mit Auftragsmorden verdiente, dachte, dass es jetzt an der Zeit wäre, das mal nicht zu tun und den nächsten Auftrag einem dahergelaufenen Hobbyhelden zu überlassen. Sogar ein Kind, kaum älter als 8, gesellte sich zu den Bittstellern, um nach einen Spielzeug zu fragen, das tief in einer von Geisterrüstungen und Untoten bevölkerten Burg verborgen lag. <Insert Name here> traute sich gar nicht zu fragen, wie es da überhaupt hingekommen ist.
"Ihr elenden Parasiten!", fluchte <Insert Name here>, nachdem er mit Aufträgen be- und völlig überladen war. "Könnt ihr euren Scheiß nicht alleine machen?"
"Wofür hat man denn Helden?"
"Genau! Außerdem geben wir dir unbrauchbaren Dreck, wenn du unsere Aufgaben erledigt hast, also zeig gefälligst Dankbarkeit!"
"Hört, hört! Ich koche dir Essen, das kaum HP wiederherstellt, wenn du mir drei Säcke Mehl bringst - das kann doch nicht so schwer sein!"

<Insert Name here> seufzte. Das Leben als Held war kein schönes, aber es war eines. Wenn er am kommenden Abend am Speicherpunkt sitzen und über den Tag sinnieren würde, könnte er immerhin behaupten, er habe was geschafft und was aus seinem Leben gemacht. Geschlagen schlich er hinab ins Dungeon und ließ seinen Frust an den stärker werdenden Gegnern aus. Die griffen ihn wenigstens an und äußerten ihren Zorn ihm gegenüber nicht mit passiv-aggressiven Quests. Feinde waren ehrliche Gesellen! Die wollten einfach nur seinen Lebensbalken reduzieren und nicht, dass er ihre Besorgungen erledigt. Außerdem konnte niemand wissen, was er unter der Erde noch so lernen würde. Erst vor wenigen Stunden hatte er erfahren, dass man sich an Vorsprüngen [i]festhalten[/i] konnte. Das Konzept war so verrückt wie brillant. Warum hatte ihm das niemand vorneweg gesagt? Auch Wandsprünge waren möglich und wenn der Ausbilder in <Generische Heldenschule> mal mit der Sprache rausgerückt hätte, wäre es um ein Vielfaches leichter gewesen, jeden Morgen pünktlich im Exerzierhof zum Appell anzutreten. Grundsätzlich waren alle Rekruten zu spät, da irgendein Genie gedacht hatte, es wäre fantastisch, wenn die gesamte Umgebung aus schwebenden Plattformen bestehen würde. Dass es ein Grauen war, sich durch das Chaos hindurch zu manövrieren, fiel dem auch erst ein, als der Zug längst abgefahren war. 

Auch wenn die Dorfbevölkerung eine Ansammlung aus Arschlöchern war und <Insert Name here> nicht viel von ihnen hielt, so wollte er sie doch befreien - denn das war's nun mal, was einen Helden ausmachte ... ganz gleich, wer eigentlich der Obermacker war und warum der auf die losgehen wollte. Solche Dinge waren nicht wichtig, wenn es darum ging, etwas Gutes zu tun - oh, und außerdem hatte er echt verdammt viel Spaß unten im Verließ. Kobolde vertrimmen war echt fett.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065623985', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1593803467}
review:
A pretty apple with a rotten core, is what would be the best image to describe this game.

It has a really nice art and visual design, with a starting concept that would seem great on paper. And that's where the game falls apart. The map and loot is all randomly generated, and in consequence throws away all semblance of progression and level design.

You can get strong equipment really fast, and most of what you'll obtain will be obsolete before you even find it. Crafting is also very underdeveloped and will probably serve 1 or 2 times. Some mechanics/abilities are very throwaway and it's a shame. UI and inventory are not handy to use, and can be annoying at times.

The combat itself lacks fluidity and feels clunky at times, making fighting all the enemies in your path a chore. Lacks depth beyond kiting. And speaking of repetitive, exploration is also lacking due to previously mentioned RNG generation. The rooms will look the same and the layout lacks all the genius design a handcrafted environment can have.

Story is very forgettable due to how generic it is, though it isn't actually bad. It was fun finding all the townfolks as you progressed.

Honestly, it could've been a good metroidvania if it had gotten some design instead of using RNG, but since it's the foundation of the game it isn't enough to make it a positive outcome. I can't recommend it.

And if you really want to try for yourself, wait for a sale for sure.
Missed potential due to bad design decisions, shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993742278', 'num_games_owned': 435, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 284, 'last_played': 1663106171}
review: Enjoyable Metroidvania style gameplay with delicious SNES-era flair. There's a story mode that isn't necessarily a roguelike, but each game begins with a seeded world, as well as 3 difficulty levels. The seeded worlds are well crafted, and you'll have to explore earlier levels with new gear to access other routes and treasures. Alternatively, there is a faster (and shorter) Arcade mode with linear map design and many more additional random elements to help scratch that roguething itch.

review:

[b]Pros:[/b]

- Art
- Gameplay
- Difficulty/Level progression

[b]Neutral:[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198060632407', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 500, 'last_played': 1593367343}
review:
Well this is disappointing, only 8 hours in and I just wish it would end.

Get weird audio issues at times were the music seems to lag but not the game. Some times loading screens randomly take some time where most are almost instant. Once the game just crashed out of nowhere.

The game is mainly a slow never ending jumping puzzle with some enemies placed here and there. When you do fight it is slow and is mainly you jumping around them. 

Having the map split between areas is a real shame but that is because its based of a seed system. While that is something different it means that their is no uniqueness to the areas in a zone so when you get the ability to allow you to proceed your gonna spend 30+ minutes trying to find that one exact spot you need to go to.

Also the wheel of fortune where you can get a permanent de-buff is horrible. Having your max health lowered permanent because you decided to talk to a dude is not great; I ended up going back to last save making this game last even longer.

It looks nice and has some nice story elements but the game play is not great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105646510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 310, 'playtime_forever': 762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 762, 'last_played': 1592839039}
review: [b]Chasm[/b] is just okay at best, borrowing much of it's core gameplay from Symphony of the Night and other titles. Sadly it just plays safe and doesn't innovate or develop further on any of those ideas. The procedural generation addition doesn't really add to the replayability of the game, sure some rooms are shuffled (slightly), but you still go through the game in a specific order, so I have to ask what's the point? The RNG-factors in general just drags the game down if I'm honest. I can't really say it's worth the time to go out of your way to play unless you've already exhausted every other option in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991576316', 'num_games_owned': 2515, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 924, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 924, 'last_played': 1592823525}
review:
Chasm is an interesting take for fans of Metroidvania and classic adventure platformers. Visually it is an excellent game, there is so much detail in every room. Another strong point is the musical score, most of the tunes add more flavor to each location.

 However, there are some aspects of the game that have a negative impact in the outcome. First of all, there is a procedurally-generated map each time you start a new adventure. You may find yourself deep into one of the dungeons and a save room is still many rooms away, if you die you return to your last save room so there will be many infuriating moments. Secondly, the combat is a bit fiddly, the animations are fine but to make every weapon different there are too many recovery frames in most weapons. The result is that you get hit too often because the main character is still recovering from your last action. Finally, the price of some of the most useful items is too high, use them too many times and you will need to grind enemies for gold.

All in all, I recommend the game to fans of the genre but this is a game with some issues. The developers are often stuck  in classic games rules and that hurts the final result.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016999910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1592620299}
review:
I want to start by saying the artwork is great. Excellent use of sub pixel animation really brings the environments to life.

This game tries really hard to be a SoTN Style Castlevania game. The main weapons all behave the same as their Castlevania counterparts. All of the spells are reticent of the sub weapons front the classic Castlevania games. And you can even cancel your attack delay by landing.

This game has a serious problem with the drop rates. I wouldn’t be surprised if the chance for anything to drop was literally just your luck stat as a percentage. You will never have money for anything in this game.

The map is procedurally made with pre-built rooms. I don’t think that the enemies are baked into the rooms though, so a repeat room might have different monsters in it at least. As far as the actual layouts go though, it wasn’t so bad. Segments of rooms are mixed together to make a lot of similar rooms with slight differences.
This can lead to some sadistic placement of enemies and save points. Healing items are not easy to come by. Enemies will rarely drop light heals. In town you can buy from a very limited supply of cheap food or some expensive potions. Otherwise you are at the mercy of the save points.

I played on hard and got a alright challenge. I really had to memorise enemy placement and attack patterns to get by. 
I was pretty frustrated that the town portal scroll was crazy expensive. I already don’t have enough cash for healing items or equipment. But it cost double the price of the big health potion just to keep my exp?!

The game is pretty light on puzzles but can have some rough platforming at times. I blame most of this on the wall jump. It feels bad. Just having the wall slide makes it hard to grab ledges. It pushes you far out from a wall so you can't vertically climb a single wall. Which isn’t a bad decision, but in the Temple zone, it pushes you out towards laser walls and it sucks. Also when you instinctively move the way you want to jump, you will just let go of the wall like that and fall. It makes sense in the sequence of events, but it feels bad. There should be some coyote time to do the wall jump.

Speaking of the upgrades. Some were super situational and others invalidated previous upgrades. There overall wasn’t a ton of variety with them, but that's fine because this is a combat focused game.

I wasn’t a fan of the loot modifiers. When I open a hard to reach chess, I expect some fat loots. But because of the modifiers I’m encouraged to save scum until I get a good version of whatever is in the chess. Again the drop rates of money and gear suck, so what's in that chess is the only new gear I’m going to see for a while.
I did like how similar weapons aren’t all just re-skins though. For example, the long sword is long! This lends itself well to a more balanced gear selection like Dark souls has. However the gear is tiered. So you will eventually have to trade out your weapon's unique quirk for something that just does a lot more damage.

Also the magic system is pretty busted. Its super spammable and mana potions are super cheap compared to everything else. Upgrades spells only cost gems, which aren't used for anything else. So its the one thing you can reliably spend.

If you can’t tell I am super salty about the drop rates. Because when I got to the final area I didn’t have a lot of heals or money. The space between the save point and the boss room has a lot of lava and tanky monsters, so it’s crazy hard to reach the end with any resources. I was already at my limit with the difficulty so I just gave up.

Overall the game isn’t bad, I definitely could have enjoyed myself more on a lower difficulty. But I think the procedural map is a massive crutch. I would have been a lot happier if I had a better seed, or better yet, the devs made a map with actual pacing… I just don’t think it works for long form games. Moreover I don’t think it helps replayability, because the bosses, zones, and upgrades are all still the same.

A similar game “A Robot Named Fight!” has a ton of alternatives to upgrades and bosses, and even zones. And the runs only last an hour, so any repetitiveness is easily overlooked. This makes every seed feel like a unique game and I think it all just works better there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147278389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2097, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1043, 'last_played': 1605841431}
review: I was mislead on what this game was like (I thought it had more rogue-lite qualities) and that is on me for not doing enough research but still I think the game makes some key mistakes for a metroidvania. The levels don't really flow into each like they do in great metriodvanias, the random generation of in-between rooms doesn't help replayablity that much, the stats can keep increasing without actually increasing the related damage, and looking and the wiki it seems that a lot of the more interesting items are backer-only (wiki is very incomplete and looks like stuff actually got removed).  All in all, still a good game one can enjoy, just not high on the list. Hollow Knight or Ori would be a recommend.

review:
Tudo é muito bom (gameplay, arte e som).

Os únicos pontos negativos são: a falta de tutoriais, a ausência de dicas para quais mapas o jogador deve ir e quais itens ele precisa pegar para alcançar as áreas novas. Precisei de bastante ajuda de walkthroughs na internet, pois fiquei empacado diversas vezes. Também achei meio chato esse lance de ter que ficar indo pra altares pra poder salvar o jogo (poderia ter uns check points ou salvamento automático); e também o lance de ir para o menu inicial quando o jogador morre é meio desnecessário...

Enfim, falei sobre muitas coisas negativas aqui, porém esses pontos negativos são insignificante à experiência como um todo. O jogo é muito bem feito.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971201484', 'num_games_owned': 3766, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1705204258}
review:
又是一款類似惡魔城的橫向卷軸遊戲
主角跑到一個小村莊，結果發現該村莊有個地下礦坑
礦坑中竟然還有各種不一樣的地貌
所以主角帶著他的武器在地下救村民
只是村民為什麼會在礦坑中這點我一直感到納悶...
可能是我對英文不好吧，劇情應該是有介紹到，只是我看不懂而已...

戰鬥部分中規中矩，可惜很多地方的的戰鬥性沒有這麼的流暢
攻擊後沒有辦法瞬間後退(類似惡魔城這樣)，可能是還沒有拿到二段跳
目前能行走的地方仍然有限，但是很多移動地形部分，個人認為還是有點可惜
真要說，這款的遊戲性比上不足，但比下有餘，只能算是一個中規中矩的ACT遊戲

遊戲內的裝備道具除了黑心商人製作打造之外
就是從怪物或敵人身上農出來了
這點算是這款遊戲少數刷刷刷的地方
道具掉落率還滿高的，配合等級，其實不太需要在同一個地方農太久
若是喜歡這種類惡魔城的遊戲
看著這款的價錢，其實這款遊戲是十分推薦收下的

review: Some of the most repetitive and uninspired level design for a platformer that I've ever seen, sometimes on par with what you would expect from a level made by someone messing around in Lunar Magic: big rooms with platforms interspersed without rhyme or reason, only there for the sake of keeping you busy. Add that to the fact that your character is extremely slow, heavy and unresponsive, put in a handful of annoying bullet-sponge enemies just for good measure, and you have yourself an amazing gameplay loop of just barely missing platforms and constantly trying to keep your distance from enemies that inflict damage upon touching as you swipe your one-inch-range melee weapons at them. Fun, right?

review:
This feels like one of the later 2D Castlevania titles (with leveling, multiple weapons, etc).  It's magical weapons even feel like the castlevania heart weapon staples: axes, crosses, holy water, etc.  The procedural generation of the map is a mildly interesting mechanic that thankfully does not shift each time you start up the game, only on a new game file.  Boss fights are tough, fun, and engaging. Exploration is encouraged and rewarding, although you do notice a few room forms that repeat themselves. 
TLDR: A really fun randomized Castlevania-type game. Id recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093059898', 'num_games_owned': 683, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 3263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3262, 'last_played': 1591985628}
review:
Dużo recenzji na Steam wspomina o dziwnych problemach z możliwością sprzedaży kluczowych przedmiotów, małą ilością savepointow itp. itd. Z tego co się orientuję większość z wymienianych problemów zostało w kolejnych patchach naprawione i ja z żadnym bugiem się nie spotkałem (grałem na patchu czerwiec 2020, 1.076). Gra nie jest porzucona i developerzy ciągle ją patchują po kilku latach od premiery więc tu bardzo na plus. Jeśli recenzje wymieniające bugi Cię zniechęcały to nie powinieneś się tym obecnie przejmować.

Nie jestem miłośnikiem metroidvani i może dlatego nie mam prawie żadnych uwag do tego aspektu. Owszem ten zakres gry jest uproszczony, skille, itemki, zarządzanie rozwojem postaci to wszystko jest zgrzebne ale będąc graczem którego głównie interesował element zręcznościowy nie miało to dla mnie większego znaczenia. 

Powiedziałbym, że klasyczna metroidvania jest obecna w 30% zawartości a 70% gry to część zręcznościowa. Tak, zręczność palców i cierpliwość w powtarzaniu poziomów bardzo się przyda i zostanie poddana sporemu testowi ;) Proceduralnie (pseudo, wiele fragmentów się powtarza między seedami) generowane korytarze i poziomy niestety nie sprzyjają balansowi trudności rozgrywki. Brak balansu w tej grze (na początku każdy nas bije, od połowy gry my bijemy bez problemu każdego) jest jedną z większych jej bolączek, która dla mnie osobiście zabija chęć powtórzenia całej gry na innym seedzie i poziomie trudności.

Czasem dysproporcja trudności między 2 przyległymi poziomami i brak checkpointów na długich odcinkach poziomu daje we znaki. Pojawia się spora dawka frustracji spowodowana śmiercią i koniecznością przechodzenia poziomu ponownie ze świadomością, że za następnym nieznanym rogiem znów możemy zginąć i wracać tam kolejne 15 min. Wiele razy miałem ochotę odstawić grę na kilka dni właśnie z powodu długich trudnych odcinków wypełnionych wrogami i pułapkami (chociaż wydaje mi się, że twórcy gry w kolejnych patchach zwiększyli szanse na wygenerowanie "savepointa" w postaci komnaty gdzie odzyskujesz całe zdrowie i zapisujesz grę). Dopiero w poźniejszym czasie gromadząc sprzęt przez losowe dropy albo zamierzony powtarzalny grind (osobiście polecam kalkulowany grind by podbić level i wydropić lepsze itemki niż liczenie tylko na przypadkowe szczęście) stajemy się na tyle bogaci by zakupić potki HP czy MP i wtedy życie staje się łatwiejesze :)

Ostatecznie grę ukończyłem i była to przyjemna podróż. Okraszona frustracją ale ta gra miała dla mnie rzadką moc w swoim gameplay'u czyli gdy wkurzony śmiercią wychodziłem to godzinę później już ponownie byłem w grze. Ta gra miała dla mnie [b]siłę magnesu[/b] pomimo wywoływanej irytacji a to jest dla mnie rzadkość i bardzo to cenię. Taka mieszanka wybuchowa, jak smaczna ostra pizza :D piecze na wejściu, piecze na wyjściu ale i tak ją w końcu zamawiamy następnym razem :D

Muzyka w grze nie powala, jest czymś co nie przeszkadza. Fabuła jest... właściwie to jej prawie nie ma ale czasem zdarza się humorystyczny gag i jest spoko :) [b]Grafika za to jest genialna i piękna[/b], to była zresztą pierwsza rzecz którą gra przyciągnęła moją uwagę. Sterowanie (klawa) było przyjemne, nie mam uwag, nasz bohater reagował tak jak powinien.

Polecam gierkę wszystkim osobom lubiącym wyzwania zręcznościowe, zatwardziałym platformowcom którym setki lub tysiące śmierci przy nieudanym skoku nie są obce ;) Ten typ gracza moim zdaniem będzie miał tu [b]ogrom zabawy[/b]. Osoby które chciałyby zagrać dla metroidvanii muszą podejść do gry dużo dużo sceptyczniej i lepiej będzie obejrzeć 30 min z rozgrywki na YT przed zakupem.

Przejście gry na normalu zajęło mi 18 godz. w tym zrobienie 16/20 osiągnięć.
Ocena 7/10 (jako platformówka 2D).

review: I watched the development of this game for years. I was disappointed when it came out and had mixed reviews. I can honestly say I had to buy it after several updates. It feels like a snes metroidvania. It is true to the snes style gameplay. It is a well done game. author: {'steamid': '76561198078930018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 187, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1591713937}
review:
Well I have other issues than most people here.

Lack of a map. For reference I have played Hollow Knight without the compass addon and im fine with
not knowing where on the map i specifically am and figuring it out myself.
But not having a map at all is fucking annoying. Especially in this game where there are just empty rooms.
Backtracking is a pain and without a map you will get lost in dead ends all the time.

The weapons are basic. Extremely basic. 
The choices really are only attack in front of you at different ranges and an overhead swing.
Its boring af. The only (laughable) skill factor is how you use them which is you jump,
cause if you use the weapon on the ground, enjoy being rooted for the duration of the swing.
So if you want to keep up any momentum while attack, enjoy bunny hopping.

The magic just straight up pissed me off.
Its Castlevania items. And only the most basic ones. 
Throwing knife, throwing axe, throwing boomerang.
I was extremely disappointed that my magic molotov turned out to be Castlevanias holy water,
and it was weak as fuck on top of that.
Then I got the shield ... I thought I could maybe block attacks with it,
I mean what was i thinking, of course the shield isnt an actual fucking shield.
Its 3 orbitals that rotate around you and deal barely any damage. 
(this is also a Castlevania skill. in Dawn of Sorrow it was called Buer)

The enemies are boring. Their ai is stupid, they barely do anything.
Their patterns are crap. Theyre target practise at best.
The most damage I have taken from them was me taking contact damage from literally 
standing inside of them to burst them down.

The bosses arnt fairing much better. They have patterns at least.
But thats literally the good things I can say about them.
Their "Arenas" are empty rooms, havnt seen a platform in a bossroom yet.
Their attacks are either easily dodged like dashes or swipes, 
or you dont know what the fuck to do since your maneuverability is limited.
Like some worm thing shot homing plasma balls at me and I couldnt really do anything,
so I just stood inside of it and kept hitting it. As you can imagine its riveting gameplay.

And now the worst thing about this game. Level design.
Compared to all of the above, this is the true plague of this game.
There are so many goddamn empty rooms. 
I climbed up an empty passage, with the most basic repeating platform patterns only to find 2 empty dead ends at the top.
Thats how bad it gets. And even if it isnt completely empty, that one enemy that barely does more than
walking in a straight line is hardly a threat.

Conclusion I guess:
You know, I like Castlevania a lot and while it is cheap, unoriginal and unimaginative,
I would not mind a game copying its features if the result was good.
But they only took the worst parts and made everything else shit too.
I am majorly dissapointed

author: {'steamid': '76561197988418446', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1690860446}
review:
Great Metroidvania, I had to guess a bit at times but the atmosphere and music are great, both the normal and chiptune versions. The small scale nature of the game is noticeable in that some rooms repeat a lot, just with slightly different enemies but that is easy to forget with how different some rooms are to each other.

Overal 8/10
Gameplay 9/10
Story 6/10
Art 7/10
Music 10/10

review: This game's pixel art is as beautiful as its mechanics are rage inducing. Specifically swinging your weapons, which root you in place for way longer than it should and whose motions are not cancellable. Be prepared to be constantly jumping to take advantage of the fact that you can move in the air just fine while swinging but become a sitting duck while standing on the ground. There's a lot of good things about it but ultimately I can't bring myself to give it a good review for how painful the combat is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976418610', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1080, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 632, 'last_played': 1591708936}
review:
This is a very simple metroidvania, and there's very little in the game to make it stand out from others in the genre, but I still found it enjoyable. I've seen some complain that the game is too easy, but I definitely think playing on hard is a decent difficulty. The controls and combat are pretty fluid, and there's decent enemy variety, however most of the enemies' attack patterns are very predictable and easy to dodge after a couple of fights. Unfortunately with the weapons, I've found no reason to use anything other than regular swords, as heavier weapons generally have a minor damage increase but at the cost of much slower attack speed, and weapons like fists and knives just don't have the attack range to be effective.

The procedural world generation seems like it was just tossed in the game without much reason; I only have one save file, but I don't think another playthrough with a new layout would change the game very much. So overall I'd give a "light" recommendation, as I had fun with it, but it was nothing remarkable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140067356', 'num_games_owned': 1536, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 132, 'last_played': 1635828324}
review: It seems like i've only just started Chasm, and maybe I have, but so far, this game has proven to be an extremely fun experience for me. It's very basic and easy to understand from a gameplay perspective, but as you traverse deeper and deeper into the dark, youll find it's no longer so easy. This is no Souls game, but it does present a challenge of its own. The farther you dive into the cursed mine and uncover its secrets, the more dangerous your surroundings become, and the more fearsome your enemies prove to be. Every enemy has a unique attack style, you'll have to learn them if you want to survive. Every fight is like a chess match (until you start one shotting lower level enemies.) I'm very excited to keep playing this game and continue the story that comes with it. I heavily recommend this game to anyone who may be interested.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016381041', 'num_games_owned': 3567, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1591217727}
review:
I would have chosen mixed instead of negative if Steam allowed it since Chasm isn't a bad game. However, the slow, clunky combat, uninspired powerups and enemies, extreme grindiness, and the infrequency of save stations hold this game back in a crowded genre. 

The art is great and saving villagers is somewhat rewarding, but with so many excellent metroidvania titles out currently Chasm just isn't up to par. If you've somehow exhausted all the better metroidvanias, this might be worth the playthrough if you pick it up on sale. I'll probably dip back into it on occasion, just not with a ton of enthusiasm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013484803', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1706, 'last_played': 1590823210}
review: Um metroidvania razoável. A evolução do personagem é bem linear; o design level é bem interessante com as diferentes fases interligadas por túneis que são descobertos com um pouco de exploração o que ajuda na movimentação entre as fases. Os controles são razoavelmente responsivos, não é fácil emendar sequencias, há um tipo de lag entre os golpes que varia de acordo com a arma utilizada, o que pode prejudicar o jogador nos combates; Os gráficos pixelados são bonitos, a história é simples e direta ao ponto, mas apesar da linearidade não é raro nos perdermos entre uma missão e outra, tive que pedir ajuda no fórum do jogo depois de ficar perdido após derrotar um chefão, aliás o fórum do jogo está cheio desses pedidos de ajuda, o que é um pouco frustrante. No conjunto, Chasm é um jogo no mínimo interessante, não esculacha com o gênero, mas também não chega a ser uma gema do metroidvania. Compre numa boa promoção.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974618029', 'num_games_owned': 2769, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 228, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1589844348}
review:
Chasm is a good game I can't honestly recommend.  

As a Castlevania-like platformer it is nice and fun, with one big BUT... The controls are a bit clumsy, but that's not a huge problem, it just costs you when you miss some platforms or so. This however grows as a problem, when you get deeper in the dungeon. There comes a real issue - save system. 

You can save only in special rooms, which is fine, but they are too faaaaaaaar away. It's not uncommon that you search dungeon for an hour. After you make few mistakes (either by your fault or because of controls), you are almost certainly low on health. There is not enough items to heal yourself, so only possibility is to backtrack all the way to last save. All the enemies respawn when you leave and re-enter the room (even though it was 1sec ago), so backtracking is the same danger like going forward. Well, let's say you survive that and get to the save point. After the save you gain all your health again, go forward to the final point you reached in the dungeon before, hopefully with less errors than before.

Big problem is in some places you can't see what you can expect during first run so it's common you loose your health until you realize what is happening.  When you make few of those mistakes you couldn't really avioid in a new room, you are low on health again... that means you need to backtrack all the way again. 

From some places there is not even possible to backtrack to save point (because of story). The result is you are sometimes in a position you know you will die soon, for example when the only way is to go in a boss battle, but you can't do anything about it and you know in advance all you have done in last hour will be meaningless. 

I'm sure there are many players that are more skilled or patient than me and are ok with this. But to be honest, I don't get this concept. For a proper hard-to-win game it's far too easy, almost a casual game as common enemies are really simple to match. If you seek just fun, it's unnecesarily annoying and punishing for small mistakes, because of save system, game design and you pay for errors with too much time consuming repetition.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970530938', 'num_games_owned': 2733, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1039, 'last_played': 1589379905}
review:
It started so well. Looks good, feels ok, lots of items and stuff dropping, it's all very exciting. Even the randomized levels are fine. Having played A Robot Named Fight I know they can work in this genre. ARNF it should be noted is designed to be 30-90 minutes a run. This I would learn is an important detail.

And then it just keeps going. Backtracking over the same randomized nonsense levels. Fighting slight variations of the same enemies, watching the same items drop most of which are useless. Oh cool, another new ability that's just a glorified key. Oh this one's just an actual key, and now I'm stuck again.

I don't like handholding, but when you don't have handholding you need some logic to connect the dots in your brain. This works out a few times quite well in the form of some semi-obscure puzzles. Other times you're expected to remember the shape of a hole in a door you saw 5 hours ago. Maybe if the levels weren't random blobs you could have a logic to the level design that would aid in that, but no.

There's a number of things that aren't properly thought out in this game and the longer you play the more you encounter them. For instance it became impossible for me to complete the bestiary because no one thought things out. The shops outside of the potion vendor become useless very quickly because again, no one thought things out. The game stops being fun because of course, no one thought things out.

Or worse, they thought the wrong things - like perfecting a randomized map system that sabotages the game - out instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009752238', 'num_games_owned': 953, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1589145758}
review:
.....I really want to like this game, I truly do. But I can't get past the frustrations it causes me when I play it. If you played Castlevania Symphony of the Night, then you'll feel right at home with the controls of the game. Slow walk speed, nice sprite animation quality, and back dashing is faster than walking.

The story is that you are a soldier sent to investigate the mine of a mostly abandoned town to save the townspeople who were abducted by monsters. The further you explore into the mines, you start finding other areas and lore based on the monsters and where they come from.

Most reviews I have skimmed have said that the problem with this game is the grinding and annoying combat. I agree that the combat is slow and very punishing. You have to learn enemy patterns or lose a CHUNK of health. They get harder and harder with little room for error the further you get into the dungeon. And if you want decent gear, even when you save townspeople, the shops are EXPENSIVE. Gold is few and far between and you'll really have to work your butt off leveling up and just trying to survive. 

My other main issue is the save points. You can't save at anytime, you can only save in certain rooms (just like Castlevania). The problem is that these rooms are few and far between. So imagine searching for an hour through the dungeon, your health is low because there is barely any health items in the game and suddenly WHAM you die. Guess what, that hour of progress is gone and you gotta do it all over again. Add the many leaps of faith and perfect timing jumps you have to make with how stiff your character is, and you're in for a rough start. I know you get some new abilities as you continue like wall climbing and the slide, but I grew so tired and frustrated from losing hours of progress because of the annoying combat, inability to save, and the grinding.

Final verdict? Give this game a try if you like metroidvanias with a challenge. Be prepared for lots of grinding, precise jumping, and tough gameplay. This is not a bad game, it's just really tough and precise and I do not have the patience to finish it. Thank you for reading!

TL:DR: A nice metroidvania but plagued with unforgiving combat, lots of grinding, and barely any save points. Looks very nice, but you gotta bring your A game or you will suffer.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985373995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 423, 'last_played': 1589086378}
review:
I feel like there is a good platformer in here somewhere, just below the surface. But everywhere you look, there is jank and jank and poor design and more jank. I just couldn't take it anymore and had to write this review after the parachute failed to function after a "double" jump yet again. 

The bad
-Developers were far too conservative with movement skills. Where's the high jump? The grapple? The Roc's Feather? The Black Panther Soul? The <Insert other iconic interesting movement skills>? Nah, we two types of wall jumps and a neutered 1.5x jump masquerading as a double jump. And no, you cannot increase the character's slow movement speed - have fun backdashing and sliding everywhere just to get around slightly faster. Maybe the devs watched Symphony of the Night speedruns and thought "wow, all that backdashing looks fun, let's make our entire game that!"
-Half of the enemies in the game. Many of the game's enemies are either pathetically easy or stupidly difficult. In the same area: "Takes 3 hits to kill, deals 20 damage: I jump over his attack and stab him in the back until he dies." vs "Takes 12 hits, does 30 damage, huge so takes up the entire hallway, has highly inconsistent attack so you're going to take huge damage practically every time. Better have potions to chug."
-Most of the bosses. The bosses use attacks reminiscent of bosses from other popular platforming games. This isn't a good thing. As mentioned before, the character moves around like a lead brick and has a giant hurtbox, so avoiding fast attacks or weaving through bullets Touhou-style does not work very well. In most cases, you will take less damage by taking a hit and using the iframes to damage the boss, thereby reducing your number of hits taken by killing the boss faster.
-Backtracking. To clear Area X, you have to backtrack to a number of areas equal to X/2, rounded up, to find that one item that lets you progress. The problem isn't the backtracking, but the lack of any real content in the areas you need to go to and, again, a lack of fun movement skills. "Go back to Chapter 2 and slide through a passage to a room where you will receive an item that lets you wall jump, so you can go back to Chapter 1 to wall jump to a room where you will receive an item that will let you breathe underwater to let you complete Area 4 and move to Area 5, before which you will need to backtrack to Area 3 to get an item to let you double jump leading you back to Area 4 to get a lamp so you can progress to the second half of Area 5 before backtracking to Area 1 for..."
-Itemization. Why are red chests dropping me items inferior to a white item that dropped off of an enemy two areas ago? I had to go through the Arena to get to the area that dropped Iron Armor, so why is the Iron Armor worse in every way than the chest that I got from beating the Arena? I have been using the same blue sword for most of the game and it would be great to get an upgrade, or at least a sidegrade that I can switch between when the sword is less effective. Early in the game I had options, but as I progressed the interesting weapon variety disappeared.

The good
-The other half of the enemies. There are a lot of enemies where you have to recognize their tell and act in different ways, where if you act properly, you can successfully and consistently avoid and then punish the attack. This is good gameplay.
-Sound design. Music, etc.

I thought my list of good points was going to be larger.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963858057', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1112, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1589514000}
review:
From the very beginning I found that the game was going to be something I will enjoy.  

I like the story, the controls and character movement are smooth as I am using a Gamepad to play. I also love the Castlevania 'esk style of the game. 

I would recommend this game for any one who enjoyed the older Nintendo games such as Zelda 2 or Battle of Olympus.

I gave up towards the end as I was able to find all of the townsfolk but it was unclear as to where I needed to go or what to do to finish the game. Probably because I sold an important item.

I feel that there is too much Backtracking over the same 4 areas which slows the game down and makes it more of a chore than fun.  Super Metroid had more areas which were just inaccessible and you didn't have to remember where things were, you could just look at the map and see what area you haven't been to yet. Thats what made Chasm difficult and time consuming as you would pass by areas and it would highlight the map forcing you to have to stop and remember what you passed by. If you forget where something is prepare for at least an hour of backtracking or searching the entire map to find it. 

When I started a 2nd play through of the game I found that it didn't change much. This is due to certain parts such as boss fight areas and main entrances staying same. Its as if each room on the map is simply shuffled like a deck of cards and put in a different order each new game. This doesn't compare to a game called Terraria where the entire world is random and is never really the same.

Nonetheless, I had a good time playing and feel that its worth the effort to at least invest a few hours of time into Chasm just for the experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198303303614', 'num_games_owned': 588, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 1688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1688, 'last_played': 1588974714}
review: quando comecei a jogar Chasm, eu confesso que fiquei um pouco frustrado, porque o combate era muito simples, eu morria direto e perdia todo meu progresso (ainda mais porque eu estava jogando no hard), mas depois de um tempo eu comecei a me interessar pelo jogo e a admirá-lo também, pois sua arte é muito linda e detalhada (eu não via uma animação tão suave de um sprite em pixel art desde que eu jogava Castlevania Symphony of the Night num nintendo DS) e com o tempo fui progredindo no jogo de uma forma bem natural. Chasm realmente se mostra muito similar a Castlevania, até porque foi desenvolvido tendo-o como uma forte inspiração, mas eu não vejo Chasm como uma simples cópia de Castlevania, eu o vejo como um sucessor de seu gênero para a modernidade, porque ele tem elementos semelhantes, tanto que depois que terminei o jogo meu deu muita vontade de jogar Castlevania de novo. E apesar de Chasm ser um metroidvania genérico, e existir muitos outros jogos melhores do gênero, ainda é possível se divertir e aproveitar muito. E pra quem nunca jogou algum Castlevania, Chasm vai trazer uma boa experiência.

author: {'steamid': '76561198252373268', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 503, 'last_played': 1588745313}
review:
Prosta pod każdym względem gra. Po zdobyciu następnego poziomu nowy punkt jest przydzielany losowo do jednego z czterech atrybutów. Przeciwnicy są prości i większość zabija się szybko i bez większego problemu, jeżeli tylko ma się możliwość cofnięcia lub zrobienia skoku. Co innego z bossami, którzy zostali tak zaprojektowani, że uniknięcie ich ataku może być niemożliwe w zależności od losowości i tego jak blisko podejdą, co potrafi zdenerwować. Światy są robione przez ziarno i widać pewne niedoskonałości. Miałem sytuacje, gdzie miejsca szybkiej podróży były blisko siebie, ale znacząco oddalone od mini bossa, choć przy faktycznych zawsze można było się wyleczyć.

Dodatkowe zdolności tu nazywane artefaktami nie przydały mi się w niczym poza dojściem do wcześniej zablokowanych przeszkodami obszarów, choć tu muszę zaznaczyć, że odkryłem tylko pierwsze 4 w ciągu 7 godzin rozgrywki. Nie ukończyłem gry, ponieważ przez przypadek sprzedałem kluczowy przedmiot potrzebny do dostania się do nowej lokacji. Po prostu zobaczyłem jego marne statystyki i się go pozbyłem. Twórcy twierdzą, że nie da się sprzedać przedmiotów kluczowych, ale nie byłem pierwszym, któremu się to zdarzyło. Radzę często kopiować stany gry. Ja tego nie zrobiłem i musiałbym wczytać stan sprzed 2,5 godzin, żeby kontynuować. Już po paru czułem znudzenie, a nie mam ochoty jeszcze dodatkowo powtarzać dużego fragmentu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126367972', 'num_games_owned': 1235, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1588877664}
review:
[h1] Czas, aby giermek stał się rycerzem.[/h1]
Chasm to bardzo przyjemna gierka z gatunku metroidvani.
Na poziom trudności nie ma co narzekać, nawet normalny jest bardzo dobrym wyzwaniem.
Fabuła przedstawiona jest bardzo wąska i gdyby ją opisać, zmieściła by się w kilku zdaniach, ale sporą część świata gry przedstawiają notatki możliwe do odnalezienia po świecie, co jest dużym plusem bo sporo uzupełniają. 
Trzeba tutaj dodać, że świat generowany jest losowo lub można wprowadzić własne ziarno więc nasze podziemia nigdy nie będą takie same (chyba, że tego będziemy chcieli).
Całość ozdobiona jest dość typową jak na owy gatunek grafiką - co nie znaczy, że jest zła, jest na prawdę przyjemna, każde kolejne lochy wyglądają inaczej czy każdy potwór ma własny styl.
Dodatkowo muzyczka wpasowuje się w to, gdzie jesteśmy.
System walki jest dość prosty, stwory z którymi się mierzymy mają własne strategie ale na każdego jest indywidualny sposób - nie wspominając o bossach, którzy zasługują na swoje miano.
No i wisienką na torcie jest tutaj możliwość zmieniania ekwipunku i decydowania, co będzie dla nas najlepsze (a także drobny wybór klas postaci, któremu zawdzięczać będziemy rozłożenie punktów statystyk); jedyne co można byłoby zmienić, to aby nasz bohater zmieniał swój wygląd wraz ze zmianą przedmiotów - zbroi, bronie akurat wyglądają inaczej a także mają różne ataki.
[b] Gra na prawdę warta zagrania, nie tylko na przyjemną rozgrywkę samą w sobie, ale również na różne tryby jak wyzwania czy poziomy trudności - w tym permadeath - który w tego typu grze wielu wyjadaczy na pewno skusi. Jak dla mnie normalny poziom trudności wystarczy, sam tytuł udało mi się przejść w 12h - choć na liczniku 9 (wiadomo, jak się umrze, to lecimy do poprzedniego zapisu) i 100% w odkryciu mapy oraz odratowaniu zaginionych ludzi, ale do zdobycia wszystkich osiągnięć jeszcze daleko. [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198120140561', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1588852438}
review:
☆요약: 역시 데드셀이 짱이시다☆
난이도: 어려움(노말 기준)
친절도: 불친절함(튜토리얼 없음)
조작감: 별로(난 보통이지만 호불호 갈리는 듯)
비쥬얼: 보통(픽셀)
사운드: 나쁨
피로도: 높음
스토리: 뻔한 스토리, 
한글어: 지원X, 패치X
총 평: 4점 (10점 만점)

1. 조작감
1)장점(주관적)
- 점프 할 때 중력 가속도 안받고 점프(점푸 중 방향 전환이 가능하다는 말),
2)단점
- 공격 캔슬이 안됨
- 회피기는 몇몇 몬스터한테만 유용하고, 점프 공격이 훨씬 효율이 좋음
-> 데드셀 같은 회피기를 생각하면 안됨(걍 뒤로 가는건데 무적이 아님)

2. 피로도
1) 거지같은 맵 디자인
- 마을에 포탈이 없어서, 마을을 갈려면 광산에 포탈을 타서 마을을 가야 한다
->즉  쓸데 없는 이동 시간이 생긴다.(마을에 포탈을 만들었으면 되는데 이걸 굳이...)
- 또 피 회복과 저장을 위해서 특정 장소를 찾아야 하는데 그게 광산 포탈에 있다. 
-> 새로운 포탈을 발견하면, 광산 포탈을 이동하여 피를 채우고 저장을 해야 한다. 
- 포션이 비싸기 때문에 이런 시스템에 의존할 수 밖에 없으므로, 엄청난 시간 낭비를 해야 한다.

이런 것이 계속 쌓이다 보니 쓸데 없이 시간낭비하는 구간이 생기며, 게임이 지루해 진다.
고전게임 특유의 지루함을 좋아하는 사람이면 추천한다.

3. 전체적인 게임 디자인에 대한 평
1) 직관적이지 못한 퍼즐
- 퍼즐도 직관적이지 못해서 짜증이 나며, 그렇지 않은 퍼즐은 너무 뻔하고 재미 없다.
2) 쓸모 없는 보조 무기(마법 무기)
- 날파리 잡기(칼), 보스전(매직쉴드) 빼고는 마법 무기는 거의 사용하지 않는다.
- 솔직히 없이 플레이 해도, 지장이 없을 정도이다.
3) 매력이 하나도 없는 시스템
- 먼가 아이템이 새롭거나, 시스템이 독특하거나, 혹은 손맛이 있거나 등등 이 게임만의 고유성이 없다. 다른 게임에 있는 시스템 엉성하게 따라 만든 "망한" 게임이다.
4) 가독성 떨어지는 문서들
- 나름 색깔로 구분 해놓았지만, 폰트 자체가 너무 구려서 읽는데 짜증난다
- 고전 게임을 따라 만들었지만, 내가 고전게임을 하는 것도 아닌데 굳이 거지같은 폰트로 된 글자를 읽고 싶진 않다.

4. 한글 X
- 유명하지 않은 게임이라서 한글패치도 없다. 이런 플랫포머 게임 치고 문서들이 굉장히 많이 나온다. 영어를 잘 못하면 읽을 수 없다. (대부분 쓸데 없는 내용이지만)

5. 게임 플레이 하면서 엿같은 점이 굉장히 많았는데, 지금 보스를 잡고 나서는 까먹었다.
아무튼 결론은 이딴겜 하지말고, 잘만든 횡스크롤 게임(deadcells, ori) 등등이 있으니 그걸 하는게 낫다.
너굴맨의 시간 15시간을 날렸으니, 안심하고 다른 게임 플레이 하라구!!

*번들로 구매해서 어쩔 수 없이 플레이어할 사람들을 위한 꿀팁
1. 플레이어 마다 맵이 조금씩 다르다
2. 자주 저장하는 습관을 들이자
3. 점프만 잘 써도 웬만한 몹은 한대도 안맞고 잡을 수 있음
(후반에 그게 귀찮아서 걍 노가다로 포션 사서 깸)
4. 숫자 퍼즐은 요번년도에 새로 업데이트 되었음. 유튜브에 있는 건 예전 버전이며, 큰방1개만 찾으면 된다(다른 길찾기도 잘모르겠으면 공략보고 하는걸 추천)
5. 보조무기는 매직쉴드랑 칼만 있으면 됨
6. 회피기는 쉬프트로 바꾸면 편리함

author: {'steamid': '76561198157170208', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1588847300}
review:
"Chasm" è un metroidvania nato su Kickstarter, grazie a tanti contributi. Questa cosa mi fa molto piacere, perché c'è tanta gente con buone idee che merita un finanziamento.
Nel caso di "Chasm" posso dire che il gioco è venuto bene, seppur con delle mancanze.
Questa recluta dovrà scoprire cos'è successo in un piccolo villaggio, dove tutti i suoi cittadini, tranne il sindaco, sono spariti.
Se dovessi descrivere questo gioco, la parola giusta sarebbe "anonimo". Ed è anonimo perché è buono in tutto e non eccelle in niente. Una volta finito non c'è niente di "Chasm" che ti rimanga. Questo perché la storia che narra, approfondita da pochi documenti, è abbastanza semplice. Inoltre i personaggi del gioco, compreso lo stesso protagonista, non sono per niente descritti ed approfonditi. Non ti senti legato a nessuno. Nonostante questo, il gioco si lascia giocare con piacevolezza, sia per il buon numero di nemici che popola le varie mappe, sia per la buona quantità di segreti che potremo trovare. Anche per quanto riguarda le armi posso dire che sono diverse nelle skin, ma troppo simili nei pattern d'attacco. Buone le location, carine le musiche. Nota storta sono le boss fight: fatta eccezione per gli ultimi 3 Boss principali, questi saranno poco pericolosi e poco ispirati sia come design, sia come pattern d'attacco. Le boss fight segrete sono da dimenticare. C'è poi una simpatica modalità Arcade, dove potremo completare dei livelli random con un tempo di scadenza.
Non c'è stato il minimo impegno neanche nel creare un finale un pò più articolato ed approfondito.
"Chasm" lo consiglio a chi ama i metroidvania, ma sappiate che esistono tante produzioni fatte meglio. Un buon gioco e basta.
VOTO: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198024634645', 'num_games_owned': 738, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 452, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 452, 'last_played': 1534105712}
review: Critical disappointment.  I just now realized that I never actually posted my review for this absolute travesty of a game.  Everything that was present in the demo, with the exception of the graphics is gone.  You can't choose your stats or abilities on level up, everything is automated, leaving the player with no agency in how their character actually performs or advances.  The magic is boring; it just feels like generic projectile attacks like the items from Castlevania, very tacked on.  None of the magic feels like it is worth it when you can just get better items anyway.  Magic doesn’t make you feel powerful, or even magical.  The graphics are okay, I like the art style, but the motion blur is annoying, and some people have problems with it making them nauseous.  The enemies are incredibly stupid, and only walk towards you menacingly, not to mention their iffy hit boxes.  The level design is also annoying.  Since it’s semi-randomly generated at world creation, you get important rooms, such as save points and bosses, at roughly the same location no matter what, but the rooms between them are random.  On paper this is actually an excellent idea, but unfortunately, there’s no actual guarantee that those rooms will be any good.  For example, in most Metroidvanias, the rooms outside of critical need locations, such as healing, or saving rooms, are made to be easier or safer to traverse, so you don’t die at the last minute, and have to start all over again.  In game design, challenges are meant to be punctuated with safe easier areas to give players breathing room, if not check points.  Because the games ‘in between’ rooms are randomized though, you may get two challenges in a row that must be overcome in order to progress, or a particularly difficult challenge right outside of a boss fight or a save location.  Overall, this is a hard avoid for me.  I wanted to like it, as the PS3 demo was absolutely excellent, but the final product is devoid of everything that made it more than just a platformer.  If you like Metroidvanias, there is better elsewhere.  If you absolutely have to play this game, then get it at a discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063628919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1587609759}
review:
[h1] Overall Disappointing [/h1]

Overall,  on  a range from "Woohoo!" to "Cat coughing up hairball noises", I have to give Chasm a solid "Meh".

I had anticipated this game once it was announced on Crowdfunding, but due to my serious reservations with the whole crowdfunding idea, I waited until the game was 50% off and paid $9.99 for it.

I'm glad that I only paid $9.99 for it. I like to judge how much fun I will have, or have had, with a game based on price and how much time it would take me to work for the price of that game.

I don't feel like I overpaid for it, and but also don't think that the experience is worth a full $20. Playing the content within the game for "18 hours" (7.5 hours of actual game time), the value of the game for me was about $1.33 an hour. I felt like the game was worth $1.33 an hour.

Overall, I felt like Chasm was tired though. After the games originally created content of the Mines location, the content felt repetitive and dry. The monsters had very similar characteristics, and the actions and "puzzles" seemed expected. I like when a game surprises me, but Chasm didn't do this other than rare occasions.

Parts of the game felt disjointed like: [spoiler] Ringing the bell tower bells [/spoiler]. Like why?

I felt myself just kind of playing the game not because "I just had to see what happened next!", but because I kept telling myself, "maybe it will get better?" 

Well, it didn't really.

It is a "Metroidvania" style game, with backtracking for almost always useless things that don't make you feel more powerful.

these reasons are why I give Chasm a "Meh."

author: {'steamid': '76561198054712891', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 831, 'last_played': 1588534397}
review: In terms of how well Chasm stacks up against other Metroidvania games I'd say not very much but that does not mean that the game doesn't have its own strengths that separates it and makes it special. The seed generator for starters is its most notable feature allowing the player to go through rooms in different orders with different enemy placements in every new game thus guaranteeing that each play through will be different. The music is another strength since each level has a catchy tune which is a must when the player is required to go through them for extended periods of time although I did listen almost exclusively to the chiptune version which to me just fit the game better given its pretty 16-bit graphics so my thoughts on the original track are inconclusive. In terms of overall gameplay I had a pretty good time. There's always a sense of progression due to the level up system, you're always finding new loot, and it feels good to kill stuff. One thing that made me almost hate the game by the end of it are the last two levels. They were an absolute CHORE to get through. One stage consisted entirely of teleporters so I was never sure which ones I had to take to progress and by the end of it I didn't even bother collecting any of the optional items because I just wanted to get the hell outta there as soon as possible. Unfortunately the final level was somehow even worse with projectile spam that made it almost impossible to avoid taking damage. Worst of all the final boss was 8 rooms away so when I died it'd be a while before I'd get another shot. God forbid I got hurt though because I needed every last bit of HP for the boss. I finished the game at level 31. Overall I'd still recommend Chasm because what it has going for it is honestly really good but don't expect something truly great.

review: I'd give Chasm a "so-so" rating if I could, but on the whole, it's an acceptable metroidvanai game. Chasm tries to set itself apart from the pack with procedurally-generated levels, which is unfortunately lost on most players since they'll only play the game once and be unimpressed by areas whose design is somewhat loose.  However, my main gripe is the lack of attack-cancelling, which make combat less fluid than I like and you end up taking a lot of avoidable hits or contact damage just because you're stuck in an attack animation.  It would have been nice if there were more weapon variety too, but still, I never though "ugh, Chasm" until the very end. The game is only about 9 hours long, so it can be nice way to spend a weekend if you're a fan on the genre (and get it on sale).

author: {'steamid': '76561198051819615', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 760, 'last_played': 1588534454}
review: This game checks all the metroidvania boxes but doesn't go beyond that.  The core game play is ok.  Nothing really stands out, the bosses and enemies are so-so and game progression feels like a slog.  Armor and weapons are almost completely reliant on the random drops since the in game shops offer very little even once you unlock them.  You can craft items from drops, but  the drop rates are really low, so you'd have better luck hoping for a rare weapon drop or farming like it's an MMO.  The random map generation doesn't actually make the game stand out, because there's no real point.  New game + isn't a thing, so it's doubtful completionists will start more than 1 new game (once they realize that perfect clearing bosses gives special drops) and no one else will bother because the characters and story are as mediocre as it gets.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042948809', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 259, 'last_played': 1625751866}
review:
Its pretty neat at first - but it doesn't go anywhere any time soon. 

Greatly dislike how fast and random the bosses are initially, makes fighting them a real pain when your movement options are slide jump or walk without a divekick or anything (at least from what i experienced - you might get one later I only got slide the wall hang on certain ledges and the lantern), not that fun when a boss does a tenth of your hp every hit and you have to restart the fights repeatedly to learn proper timings to dodge things for phase 1 before triggering a phase 2 if there is one. 

Wouldn't particularly recommend unfortunately, would personally go obtain one of the older castlevanias or buy bloodstained just due to the sheer slog Chasm has to get back to wherever it is you died.

Unless there's something I'm missing regarding the weapons, there is no "go-to" that solves most of my issues, as the greatswords/clubs are very slow (as they should be admittedly, but there's no way to speed them up to my knowledge), the swords are quite clunky when you need to hit something smaller than you, the dagger is a death sentence and the same for fist weapons unless there's some hidden parry skill I missed. 

Magic can be quite broken from what I heard but because I found the vendor for it late I probably didn't get the full mage experience and it wasn't broken for my runs so I was forced to rely on melee.

Perhaps its just not my thing, I don't know - I just feel that something like bloodstained would be a better choice :shrug:

author: {'steamid': '76561198041956308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 601, 'last_played': 1587964529}
review:
Chasm falls short in a lot of ways, I think.  

Its claim to fame is its "procedurally-assembled areas from hand-crafted rooms".  I was ready and willing to like this aspect of the game. However, what this really means is that each level is a patched together slog of long rectangles with 3-5 enemies in it, a fork in the road, several dead end rooms with a buff or chest, some environmental hazards, then the boss.  It feels incredibly shallow and not worth ditching an ACTUALLY hand crafted game for.

The combat and movement is clunky and unsatisfying.  You do not have enough options to make regular enemy encounters  interesting, so despite there being 80ish enemies in the game, most of the have similar movesets from level to level.  Even with what is on offer, sometimes I was still asking myself "how was I supposed to dodge that while still being able to deal damage?" I know there are those who find this style nostalgic or whatever but honestly it just doest feel fun to play half of the time.  

The upgrades you get fulfulling the "metroidvania" part of the game are some of the most boring, worst integrated upgrades ive seen in a game like this.  Almost half of the upgrades are never utilized in more than a few fringe cases, and a quarter of them are completely invalidated by future upgrades.  There isnt a single unique thing to experience in this game in this regard.  I suppose thats the cost of not being able to, again, actually hand craft the levels.

Chasm suffers tremendously from what feels like dozens of oversights which make it a chore to play.  Some enemies's attack animations take way too long to end, resulting in them holding out their weapon waiting for you to walk into it.  Instead of there being a save point in each level's hub, the first level is the only one that has one.  Added to this, the only way to replenish your mana is to make the trek back to the hub town, or by destroying lanterns for 1-3 mana...sometimes.  The loot is baffling, as probably within my first few hours of gameplay I got a legendary leather armor that I never replaced because everything else was worse.  Some pieces have semi interesting effects, but more often than not youll just pick whatever has the highest numbers.  You never get crazy strong so backtracking remains annoying, coupled with enemies that respawn when you exit and reenter a room.  So getting a chest at the end of a gauntlet isnt just a challenge once, but twice.  There are more, but thats enough from me.  

*Edit:  I have 100% completed this game, only missing the 4 rarest achievements.  At the time of writing this original review, I had seen the final boss and decided the game hadnt bought enough good will from me to do what it was asking.  A few days later, I decided to just grit my teeth and finish what I had started.  An hour later after cleaning up some chores, I beat the game.  Afterward I uninstalled, content that after editing this review, I never needed to think about this game again.

If none of what I said bothers you, then youll probably enjoy Chasm.  Its art is pretty good, and despite what Ive said, if youre looking for something to scratch that exploration itch, then this game can certainly try.  Its just to rough around the edges for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045389052', 'num_games_owned': 1342, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 707, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 707, 'last_played': 1587579713}
review:
Начало у игры довольно бодрое: Вы новобранец в армии небольшого королевства и вас посылают в ближайшую деревеньку для того чтобы разобраться с монстрами внезапно появившимися там.  Геймплей стандартный, обследование карты, борьба с монстрами, поиск предметов позволяющих пройти дальше.  И вот тут вылезает ряд проблем.
1) Примитивный бой. Обычный удар, удар в прыжке, отскок назад.
2) Оружия вроде бы много но его можно разделить на три вида:Кинжалы(быстрые, но бьют недалеко),мечи(средняя скорость, средняя дальность), тяжёлое оружие(большая область поражения, очень медленная скорость).
3) Прокачка и уровни здесь тоже есть. Но вся суть в том что после набора нужного кол-ва опыта чуть-чуть повышаются статы и восстанавливаются мана и здоровье. 
4) Есть магия но разница в основном во внешнем виде и траектории полёта снаряда. Мана заканчивается очень быстро, а восполнить её можно получив уровень, выбивая по чуть-чуть из разрушаемых предметов или выпив элексир(который нужно купить). 
5) Гринд. Золото, Мана и некоторые предметы нужно выбивать с постоянно возрождающихся монстров. Шанс выпадения зависит от параметра "удача" и без увеличения при помощи предметов очень мал. Причём цены довольно высокие и для покупки некоторых вещей придётся попотеть. 
6) Однообразность и затянутость. Перемещаться можно через "сеть туннелей" расположенных в определённых местах.  Много времени тратится на беготню по пройденным локациям и битву с монстрами, "секреты" не приносят много радости(часто выпадают те же вещи что и с монстров).
Игра была получена в Humble Bundle Monthly. Не была пройдена потому что надоела.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079065891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 324, 'last_played': 1587676110}
review:
O Gameplay do jogo é legal e possui uma ótima resposta aos controles, todavia nem tudo é perfeito.

A história achei bem fraca e você dificilmente vai conseguir criar empatia pelos personagens ou até mesmo ao personagem principal. Se está esperando uma boa história recomendo Ore, Hollow Night ou Dust An Elysian Tail, mas não esse jogo.

O Chefes também possuem algumas mecânicas bem fáceis de derrotar. 

Se o jogo tiver com uma promoção legal, vale a pena, mas preço cheio, não.

review:
I'm not sure how bad the previous versions of this game were, but judging by the current version (1.076), I'd say I disagree with most of the negative reviews. 

Out of all metroidvanias on Steam, this one is probably the most similar to igavanias. That means that you have a medieval/fantasy setting with tons of weapons and armors, subweapons, consumable items, a bestiary, relics, etc. The game's difficulty is also more on the easy side, just like the igavanias. 

I enjoyed my first playthrough a lot and I simply could not find anything bad about this game. Perhaps the art and the music are too generic,  and the story isn't great, but the gameplay was very solid nonetheless. The randomly generated world didn't feel bad at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198887611684', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1587690005}
review:
这是我玩过的独立游戏里最原汁原味的银河城游戏（这里的原汁原味为中性词）。无论是操作手感还是系统、地图和怪物，都和gba、nds平台上的几作恶魔城非常相似。(boss战的房间式样以及掉落的hp max up, 还有与刻印雷同的救村民的任务......甚至有些借鉴过度的感觉)
但是，这也意味着这款游戏未能进行创新：它不像《空洞骑士》那样，取消了数值设定并使用截然不同的徽章系统；也不像《神之亵渎》、《death‘s gambit》那样，结合了黑魂的防反动作并引入新的成长系统。
至于这款游戏的随机地图生成系统，我暂时不做评价......如果它能让你在二周目时拥有全新的体验, 倒也是挺不错的......希望能和我想的一样吧.
总而言之，这款游戏是个中规中矩的银河城，没有什么让你惊喜的地方，也不会让你过于失望。如果是此类游戏的爱好者，那么我还是挺推荐的。
