author: {'steamid': '76561198136043314', 'num_games_owned': 811, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2390, 'last_played': 1583270553}
review:
Es kann ein sehr anstrengendes Metroidvania werden. Es hat paar schönen Momenten die aber, auch ihren reiz verlieren fals man noch einen Run startet. Gegner sind teilweise nicht nur schwer sondern unfair weil es manchmal unmöglich ist sie zu hiten
und das stresst und frustriert ziemlich. Das 100% Map Archivment bugt teilweise wovon auch andere Spieler in Archivment Foren berichten. Als großen Pro Aspekt muss ich aber das Design der Gegner ansprechen die sehr schön und kreativ gemacht sind die Welt hingegen löste bei mir oft ein Déjà vu aus weil es oft wie Copy and Paste wirkt. 

Steam lässt leider nur die Wahl zwischen Daumen runter und Daumen hoch wobei hier ein Daumen zur Seite angemessen wäre.

author: {'steamid': '76561199013685904', 'num_games_owned': 116, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 4455, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1628303927}
review:
Chasm é um jogo metroidvania gerado por seed.

A história começa: você é um cavaleiro, que tem como missão explorar uma mina, Karthas. O que você encontrará na mina, desde pessoas desaparecidas, inimigos, bosses, é tudo com você.

O jogo conta com um sistema de magia e ataque, além de armadura, e outros status, como inteligência.

Com gráficos pixelados e em 2D, o jogo é muito bonito. Apresenta vários bosses, mas esse não é o principal do jogo.

Com o tempo, você obtém powerups, habilidades especiais que te ajudam em várias partes, além de melhores equipamentos, melhorias e itens específicos, para missões específicas.

O jogo ainda conta com alguns puzzles, mas eles não são o foco principal do jogo.

Jogo muito recomendado, 90/100.

https://store.steampowered.com/app/312200/Chasm/

author: {'steamid': '76561198043473689', 'num_games_owned': 690, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1583040620}
review:
I have mixed feelings about Chasm. The artwork is very charming, but beyond the nice visuals it is a bog standard Metroidvania.

I remember when I first heard about Chasm a lot of the hype surrounding the game was tied to the potential of playing through more than once with different map layouts, but honestly by the end of your first playthrough there is no reason to go back. 

Frustratingly, the game has a good amount of backtracking (as one would expect in a metroidvania game) that requires revisiting rooms that have no unique marking on the map, meaning you can waste a lot of time looking for them. The weapons you gain throughout your playthrough are also very bland, there is very little variation to make different builds.

All in all despite the bitching, I'd recommend Chasm if its on sale, if you plan to play on normal, and if you've run out of other Metroidvania games to play.

(Seriously it is not worth playing on hard. I play all my games at the highest difficulty but this one was not the enjoyable kind of difficulty, more the tedious kind)

author: {'steamid': '76561197994851714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1585343641}
review:
I've enjoyed this game more than I thought I would. The art style is pleasing in general. I especially liked the enemy design and animation. Otherwise, the protagonist's sprite is a little bland but is also well-animated. The environments are fine but they lack variety.

The gameplay itself is enjoyable and will be very familiar to anyone who's played metroidvania games before. The game is clearly influenced by Symphony of the Night, which is not a bad thing in itself. Weapons are sufficiently varied and most items have their use. Controls could be a little less stiff but they are responsive, at least. Traversal can be a but of a chore, though. Artefacts that grant new movement powers are a little awkward to use at first and backtracking can tedious.

In general, though, this is a very nice effort and it's clearly a game crafted with love.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025475618', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1585194126}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049380486', 'num_games_owned': 1131, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 450, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1585257975}
review:
It's derivative from SotN, make no mistake. If you get this game, prepare for a SotN-type game, all down to the after-images when moving around.
That said, this is a very comfy game. Some bits of gear can be better than average, giving you some extra physical or magical attack, or extra luck. The magic options you have are pretty much 1:1 to Castlevania subweapons and can be upgraded to the point it can possibly out-damage your physical attacks. The enemy variety is pretty neat and the music comes in two flavors on top of being pretty high quality.
As of now I haven't finished it, so I can't say anything about the different difficulty modes, or seeds, or how those are even worth it, but depending on how much more I have to go, I can see this being a fun thing to go back to every now and again to try out another run.
I have no clue if there will be any DLC for this or not, but with how every run can be randomized, there's room to grow.

Overall, pretty nice game to play. If you want something unique or out there, this isn't it. It's the type of game you play when you've gotten tired of beating SotN in 5> hours and want new yet familiar ground.

author: {'steamid': '76561198263316031', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 462, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1605993057}
review:
Wow, realmente es un juego que merece mas amor a pesar de tener unos puntos que molestan un poco, no podia pensar en otra cosa que jugar a esto.
Es un metroidvania tirando mas hacia el lado de los castlevania, con un pixel art que me gusto mucho a pesar de que me parecia un poco borroso, me gusto el efecto que daba en movimiento.
El camino del juego esta enmarallado como lo haria otros metrodvanias, para que tengas que regresar cuando tengas la reliquia adecuada, pero no asi los caminos secundarios que apenas y son un par por reliquia, me falto un poco eso, pero esta bien.
Ya digo que tiene muchos elementos castlevania, recuperas salud con comida que sueltan los enemigos y la usas desde el resguardo del menu (que en un mundo post dark souls, ya no se ve tanto), tambien los enemigos tienen loot, pueden soltar equipamiento de distintas raresas, para mi tenia una tasas muy bajas porque apenas y me salio una rara, en todo el juego. Tambien tienes un dash hacia atras para esquivar y un puñado de magias que recuerdan mucho a otros juegos, una bomba de fuego, un hacha en arco, una daga, etc.
De lo poco que me fallo es que los enemigos apenas y reaccion a tus ataque casi que ni los empujas entonces avanzan y te hacen buen daño. Y que cuando mueres no solo pierdes todo desde la ultima vez que guardaste sino que te manda al menu principal, ¿para que?, me hubiera gustado que me mandara directo al punto de guardado.
Me gusto mucho, recomiendo que se le de una oportunidad, un juego muy confortante, que da gusto explorar, no muy dificil ni muy facil.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025092012', 'num_games_owned': 512, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1584473460}
review:
As a lover of Metroid and Castlevania games alike, I have been quite excited about this game for years now. So many critics were saying they couldn't wait to try it out and then after the game's release... silence. I had forgotten about it. Fast forward to now, I got it for "free" in Humble Choice and was pumped to give it a go! Unfortunately, it didn't live up to it's hopeful hype...

Yeah some enemies are a pain and yeah the drops to restore HP are to few, but the game's main problem is It's just... so boring. Like there's some anomaly I can't quite put my finger on that makes it feel like an unexciting slog.
3 hours in, I gave it a solid go, but I'm gonna move on at this point. 

Thankfully my money has indirectly gone to the dev already (and thankfully I didn't pay $20), so I hope they can learn some lessons and improve on their next game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994935749', 'num_games_owned': 2058, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1584397260}
review:
Seriously, don't. It's great fun and all. Nice, if a little rudimentary mechanics. Cool graphics. Tricky, but not too hard gameplay.

But the mandatory puzzles suck, and if you're stuck, you're stuck. Missing an item? Have fun searching every single room you've cleared (well, not really cleared as the monsters reappear) in the past 2 hours again, just to turn up empty-handed because.. no idea, you missed something? It's a bug and the item in question just hasn't spawned? Who knows.

I'd love to play and finish the game, but I can't. So, again, save yourself a few hours of time and skip this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025185275', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 273, 'last_played': 1610744429}
review:
Metroidvania (action rpg platformer) - 8/10

One of my overall favorite genres of games. If you're into them, this is absolutely a solid entry. Can't wait to see what comes next from this dev!

Interesting variety of areas and enemies. Movement abilities get interesting, like clinging to ledges or wall jumping. The game could be a little more heavily populated with enemies in my opinion, I generally like more combat than I'm getting here. The jumping puzzles are really enjoyable though, makes exploration pretty fun.

In addition to melee weapons, you can also build your equipment to focus on sub-weapons, although I haven't seen a decent way to recover mana reliably yet, so it could be an interesting challenge to try a magic build. So far, you get drips of mana from breaking candles. Can I just whine about having to break every candle in this entire genre?

Story isn't bad, but it's nothing exciting either. Essentially, you're on an expedition into the mines, and some townsfolk are trapped inside, and there's something about an ancient civilization, which might lead to a cool ending, here's hoping! Story usually takes a back seat in this genre, so it's not really a point against this game, but just a gripe in general.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066784959', 'num_games_owned': 1090, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 971, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 971, 'last_played': 1583961275}
review:
When the game came out I read a lot of on mixed and negative reviews.
I must say after completing the game I was blown away by the quality.

-Fluid controls - I cannot stress this enough, controling your character is pixel perfect and smooth
-Rich enviroment - each biome is fresh and new
-Excelent pacing - not one minute was I bored or annoyed
-Perfectly placed save spots

A lot has been said about random generated map and how it ruined the game. Honestly, if I never knew this game has random generated map I would never know. I played games with much worse manually generated enviroment!
I played a lot of metroidvania but I have to place this one at the very top!
Great job devs!

I'm glad you stuck with the game and polished it. Final product is a true gem!

author: {'steamid': '76561198075573784', 'num_games_owned': 537, 'num_reviews': 137, 'playtime_forever': 1834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1834, 'last_played': 1583949090}
review:
Got this in a bundle and I enjoyed my time with it! 

[h1]The good:[/h1]
+ The artstyle is great!
+ Enjoyed the enemy variety (there are different types for each zone.
+ Combat was okay. (Almost exclusively poke and run gameplay)

[h1]The bad:[/h1]
- the story and world building could definitely be better. Although there were in-game book collectables, I felt that it didn't really sell me the story of the game.
- you need a wiki/guide to know how to progress in some areas. 
- YOUR CHARACTER LOOKS THE SAME REGARDLESS OF THE GEAR YOU EQUIP. It rubs me the way - "Oh look at this cool dark armor I found! Too bad I cant see my character wearing it :("
- Could use more weapon and spell variety

Definitely give it a try at a discount. Would recommend this if you enjoy metroidvanias.

author: {'steamid': '76561198844708181', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1583524054}
review:
Chasm is a simple and pretty fun metroidvania game.
If you have played any of the castlevania titles you will recongnize a lot of things right from the start like the kind of upgrades that you'll get or the weapons and sub-weapons that you'll use.

Chasm main selling point was supposed to be it proceduraly generated world that would give you and unique and inovating experience, but i would said that's the main flaw that this game has. I beated the game twice ( 1st time on HARD mode and the 2nd time on Normal - mortal aka  die once and your save file is gone) and i didn´t notice big changes in the rooms or locations except from some random rearranged rooms. Theres no room or location in the game that will get written for ever in your mind like Hollow Knight's City of Tears or the entrance to Riddley's lair of Super metroid, everything feels a bit simple and uninspiring, in other words, Chasm lacks a sense of identity to make it set apart from other metroidvanias titles.

The story is pretty simple, the OST has some good beats on it but it kinda gets repetitive a bit quickly and the animations and pixel art are (by far one) of the BEST POINTS of this game, it's a pretty good example of a beautifully crafted pixel art.

BUT don´t get me wrong, Chasm is still a pretty fun game to play and if you like this kind of titles give it a try but don´t expect to be mind blown by it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029254070', 'num_games_owned': 1209, 'num_reviews': 333, 'playtime_forever': 2107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2106, 'last_played': 1634608907}
review:
Jeśli podczas grania nie przeskoczę na notatnik, by przygotować reckę to często potem już jej nie tworzę. Tak było w tym przypadku, jednak...
ta gra potrzebuje dobrego słowa. Nie, nie z litości, a dlatego że jest fajna.
Chasm to staroszkolna rpg - metroidvania, która wciąga jak czarna dziura i to jest jej największy plus, podkreślam to bo jest to najważniejsze w tego typu grach i cokolwiek bym nie napisał dalej, to będzie to już tylko dodatek.
Dobry pixel art, tzn postacie i wrogowie są świetni, ale jeśli chodzi o mapy to już poziom bardzo zróżnicowany, od super do smętny. Dobry system walki, oparty częściej o wyczucie odległości ruchów przeciwnika niż strategię, na mój gust zabrakło czegoś dodatkowego typowo na refleks (choć ten element jest w innych aktywnościach gry). Ciekawszych kombinacji z blokami i kontrami itp. tu brak, jednak zróżnicowanie broni to rekompensuje, a opłaca się nie raz przy bossie ją zmieniać, bo ta o najmniejszym zasięgu daje najwięcej obrażeń na sekundę. Nie udało się ciekawie rozwiązać back trackingu, za to spryciarze chcący poexpić znajdą ciekawe miejscówki i za to spory plus.
Pomimo iż gra wciąga to brakuje jej klimatu muzycznego, mimo to daje miłe poczucie powrotu do wioski by przygotować się do kolejnej podróży wgłąb kopalni.
Plusem są różne rodzaje broni, które działają zupełnie inaczej, więc trzeba się ich nauczyć i to na prawdę daje frajdę. Minusem jest jednak brak szczegółów czysto liczbowych (np. damage per second), bo choć zapewniam to nie one by stanowiły o ulubionej taktyce to właśnie dlatego że tak by nie było, to byłyby dobrym dodatkiem.
Zdecydowanie za wolno się rozkręcają niektóre możliwości jak podwójny skok, czy spadochron przedłużający "wartość" skoku.
Problem z balansem, z jednej strony Chasm jest dość trudne, z drugiej jeśli pofarmi się kasę i kupi miksturki to zaczyna się "hulaj dusza, piekła nie ma". Wolałbym by ów balans argumentów postaci był po stronie skilli (nawet pasywnych) aniżeli chlania zawartości przeźroczystych piersiówek z czerwoną cieczą. Lubię wiśniówkę, jednak smok od nich nie zginie... czy jakoś tak.

Frajda z gry = Chasm, zróżnicowanie gameplaya jest tu choć sztampowe to wystarczające by uznać za atrakcyjne. Szczerze, temat takich gier jest mi obecnie obcy ( a kiedyś miałem NES-a i SNES-a, grało się z Ninja Gajden, Captain America and The Avengers ect.). Od teraz  szukam czegoś podobnego.

Oceniam jak zwykle surowo: 7/10 i łopatologicznie polecam, bo jak na grę niskobudżetową to niemal jak maksimum jaki może zdobyć gra.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035469548', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 177, 'last_played': 1583268061}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025287051', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1583, 'last_played': 1582344362}
review:
Apesar da ideia por trás de Chasm ser interessante, o diferencial dele acaba trazendo mais problemas do que novidades memoráveis para o estilo de jogo. 

Um metroidvania com salas e mapas gerados de forma procedural soam até que interessante, mas no final, acabou destruindo o ponto mais forte dos metroidvanias: a exploração. 

O enredo do jogo é simples e bem raso, apenas apresentando a razão da aventura acontecer. 
O combate do jogo não tem nada de incrível, mas funciona muito bem. Armas com diferentes tipos de golpes, alcances e claro, não podiam faltar as magias: arremessar adagas, machados, poções e até mesmo shurikens. Na prática parece incrível, mas no final, é tudo muito simples e sem graça. 

Ficava ansioso achando que a próxima magia que eu ia comprar seria incrível ou super interessante, mas quando eu descobria como era... acabava sendo frustrante por todo o dinheiro investido nela.

Os inimigos são até que legais, mas o brilho fica mais pros chefões, que tem suas dificuldades, principalmente se você quiser matar eles sem tomar nenhum golpe (fornecendo um equipamento de recompensa, que facilita a jogatina). 

Geralmente após os chefões, você vai encontrar habilidades especiais, que te vão permitir acessar áreas que antes não eram possíveis, o clássico metroidvania... e ai começa o grande problema.

O maior problema desse jogo é o backtracking, ou seja, retornar a lugares que você já passou no jogo, pra descobrir novas áreas e usar suas novas habilidades. Em um jogo onde os mapas são repetitivos pelo fator procedural e com lugares nem um pouco memoráveis, a experiência de backtracking acabou sendo muito frustrante e cansativa. Precisei passar pelas fases, sala por sala, várias e várias vezes, tornando o progresso do jogo tão irritante, tão frustrante, que me fez questionar minha sanidade mental. 

Infelizmente o jogo teria um potencial muito mais bem aproveitado se o mapa fosse feito a mão pelos desenvolvedores, pois essa ideia de criar um jogo único pra cada jogador, acabou criando um jogo chato, repetitivo e irritante. Seus pontos positivos são completamente anulados pelos pontos negativos, e por conta disso, não recomendaria a nenhuma pessoa o jogo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969374860', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1533516776}
review:
I kickstarted this game way back in the day, what was it 6 or 7 years ago? And it's unfortunately one of the biggest gaming disappointments I've ever encountered. I'm a big fan of Metroidvanias, but this game is by far one of the weakest that's come out in years. Nothing about the game stands out, combat, progression, the random level design, enemies, abilities, the music, etc... all are just incredibly mediocre.

Even  over a year later and multiple patches in, the core design of the game is still fundamentally flawed. There are so many more interesting and better indie Metroidvanias out there, as the competition has grown fierce over the past decade... even on sale or for free, I just can't recommend this game. It's just uninteresting and excessively generic.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984240274', 'num_games_owned': 2708, 'num_reviews': 460, 'playtime_forever': 1361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1582991269}
review:
Jeśli brakuje ci przyjemnych tytułów z kategorii metroidvania do ogrania, to Chasm jest jak najbardziej produkcją, na którą warto rzucić okiem. Fabuła 'jest', bo przyznam, że wydawała sie na tyle sztampowa, że po prostu ją olałem. Ale sam gameplay jest przyjemny i zróżnicowany. Wyraźnie widać, w które miejsca będziemy mogli wrócić dopiero po odblokowaniu jakiejś umiejętności, bossowie nie są na jedno kopyto, a gra oferuje miejscami całkiem niezłe wyzwanie. Na minus, że kilka razy był drobny problem z kolizją, ale to sporadyczne przypadki.
Ogółem przyjemny tytuł, godny polecenia fanom gatunku.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127427880', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 618, 'last_played': 1582902216}
review:
All-in-all, as a game, it does a good job. It focuses on a deliberate (borderline frustrating) play style where you have to pay attention to the enemy's attacks rather than hacking n slashing your way through. I'll argue that this play style becomes annoying when there's so much backtracking and looking-around involved. But maybe that's the vibe the developers were going for; the perilous adventure of combing through a dungeon filled with monsters. (Needs better narrative writing, though. Like this review; too wordy.)

Pros:
- Good music
- Great pixel animation
- Simple and easy enough to play.
- Final boss fight was okay
- Controls feel responsive (when you're not clunkily falling into poison/electric pits) 
- Reminiscent of SotN (Except all the dying)

Cons:
- The narrative, while simple, is tedious to follow. Very text-heavy, and I feel it could've been more concise. Plus, reading through the dialogue won't really give mush (if any) clue as to what you're supposed to be doing, tbh.
- A LOT of backtracking. Which is fine if you've don't have a day job.
- Those little dot's in the map are treasure chests!!!?? I've been running around trying to look for the ones I missed and they're been staring at my face all along!?
- Poor conveyance. You WILL be looking up walkthroughs. 
- Can we please be done with "enemies damage you even if u brush against they're shoulder" thing? They have "Attack" animations for a reason; to cause damage. What's the point of an attack animation if all they have to do is invade my personal space to kill me? At least lower the damage caused by non-attack contact?
- You'll die A LOT. So much you'll think this is a Salt & Sanctuary sequel.
- Potions are expensive (after you actually unlock the person who sells them to you) + you earn money veeeeery slowly. So you best git gud, or get used to seeing the game over screen.
- Jump+Attack is your go-to mode of attack, since anything else will lock you in place for 5 years and leave you open to attacks (99% of the time)

author: {'steamid': '76561198162239521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 209, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 209, 'last_played': 1582753243}
review:
En mi caso no ha superado la prueba de las tres horas. Si tras tres horas, un juego de estas características no me dice nada, no puedo recomendarlo. Comenzaba muy prometedor pero conforme vas jugando, se va viniendo abajo.

Chasm es un pequeño metroidvania de libro. De hecho, se juega de forma extremadamente similar a symphony of the night, aria of sorrow o cualquiera de los castlevanias de ds... pero peor. Es extremadamente parecido en su propuesta jugable. ¿El problema? Que los desarrolladores, sean novatos o no, se comportan como si lo fueran. Me explico.

No tienen coraje ninguno. Son unos cobardes con respecto al diseño del juego, lo que se manifiesta tanto en la jugabilidad como en el diseño artístico. No hablo aquí de presupuestos o potencia gráfica. Estos tíos tienen un arte de píxel bastante avanzado pero completamente desaprovechado. Si queréis que emplee una terminología menos hiriente, a estos chicos les falta ambición.

Se nota en todos los detalles, que hay muchos porque además duele lo detallistas que son los desarrolladores. Se lo curran, pero entienden todo mal. Por ejemplo, quieren hacer una mazmorra que parezca infinita, laberíntica, sin fondo. Muy bien. ¿Por qué todo parece una mina rústica? ¿No tendrías que haber creado un par de paletas diferentes, distintos tipos de roca, algo que rompa la monotonía del paisaje? Siento que todas las salas son iguales, aunque propongan puzles (sencillos) diferentes. Ellos creen que están siendo consistentes pero no, están siendo repetitivos. Haz la mazmorra más corta o fragméntala en áreas más pequeñas que ofrezcan un cambio en las vistas al jugador, Blasphemous lo hace, Hollow Knight lo hace, todos los que tienen dos dedos de frente lo hacen. He jugado metroidvanias de presupuesto cercano a cero que conseguían aportar algo más de variedad en las primeras horas de juego.

Y echan sal en la herida: Ves a tu personaje viajar por tierras hermosas, valles, montañas, y estás deseando explorar... para que en cuanto llegas a tu destino, te metan en una mina no sé cuántas horas. Eh... ¿qué? ¿Por qué? ¿Por qué no estoy explorando un sitio hermoso y fascinante si me has enseñado que sabes hacerlos? 

Otro ejemplo de diseño equivocado: Las zonas de guardado. En los metroidvanias vais a pasar mucho tiempo en zonas de guardado, porque intentaréis visitarlos con frecuencia. Normalmente se intenta que sean lugares llamativos, fascinantes, estéticamente diferentes. Aquí también lo intentan: Es una estatua de un viejo con un candil. En serio. Le intentan insuflar un aire místico con el lore pero es un viejo con un candil. Y de diseño bastante simplón y cuadrado. Parecen tonterías pero ahora voy con una que afecta al gameplay.

En casi todos estos juegos empiezas con armas débiles. Pero enseguida encuentras armas que molan, que da gusto utilizar, o habilidades que compensan un arma rústica. Generalmente sucede en los primeros 10 o 20 minutos. Aquí el segundo arma que consigues es un cuchillo... tras un par de horas de juego... que es mejor que tu espada corta en estadísticas, significativamente para ese momento del juego, pero que da asco usar porque no tiene alcance. Te están proponiendo un dilema clásico de los castlevanias pero en los castlevanias no se hace tan pronto, primero te dejan degustar la satisfacción de armas divertidas, con alcance, que permitan combar o semejante. Luego te darás cuenta de que son débiles y las cambiarás por otras. Lo cuál suele ser fácil porque suele haber armas a porrillo. Aquí, no. Aquí puedes pasar una hora entre que consigues un arma y la siguiente.

Y los puntos de guardado. Veréis, cuando tenéis que jugar con un arma cutre en un juego de estas características, con poco alcance, débil, etc., durante mucho tiempo, vais a sufrir daño. Es inevitable. Cualquier enemigo que haga algo más que quedarse quieto esperando morir te puede acabar hiriendo. De forma que aumentan la dificultad del juego dándote enemigos débiles pero un arma más débil todavía. Lo guay de los castlevanias es sentirte fuerte. Aquí te ves calculando las distancias a la perfección contra un puñetero murciélago o una rata porque cuidado como sufras daño, estás apañado. Ya que otra cosa que al cabo de un tiempo empiezan a hacer es distanciar bastante los puntos de guardado. No siempre están en lugares lógicos. Atraviesas un área grande, esperas un punto de guardado... pues no.

El aspecto rolero más básico también se cae. Subes tres, cuatro niveles, y no notas ninguna diferencia. No ves cambiar las tornas. Las subidas de nivel son casi irrelevantes.

En conclusión: Pasas sala tras sala idéntica una tras otra, con enemigos patéticos pero que te suponen una amenaza porque tienes que jugar con un arma patética. Una hora... dos horas... tres horas... tres horas y media... y en ese punto te preguntas, ¿por qué estoy jugando esto pudiendo jugar un juego mejor? 

Pregúntatelo tú también. Hollow Knight, Blasphemous, Bloodstained, incluso Mirror of fate, siendo un cutre port de 3ds es mejor que esto.

Por poner algo positivo, voy a estar muy atento a más juegos de estos chicos porque tienen potencial. Chasm tiene potencial, no es un absoluto desastre. Si le echan un par de... narices (pegi 10), el siguiente juego puede ser muy bueno. Pero tienen que dejar de asumir que por ser un juego de bajo presupuesto se pueden permitir apuntar al barro. Tienen que aspirar a algo más. Hay talento aquí, falta la ambición.

I findsome reviews unfair to this game so let me just say it is a great game in what it does. I see some comparisons to Blasphemous saying that game is the better one, well after playing both I can say that is not true. The UI in this game is far superior, the soundtrack as well. author: {'steamid': '76561198007145340', 'num_games_owned': 1506, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 1433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1433, 'last_played': 1581194463}
review:
[h1]Decent Low-Budget Metroidvania[/h1]

Chasm is one of those Metroidvania games that does not push the genre towards any new revolutionary direction. Combat involves repeatedly hitting enemies until they fall, once you've learnt their attack patterns of course. I usually put down any game that forces a hard difficulty for the sake of it and I was close in this game a few times but eventually it clicked and the game was somewhat enjoyable. A general lack of checkpoints in-between lengthy areas was rather painful.

Having played enough Hollow Knight, this doesn't compare to that quality but it has its own place in the genre. I got the game in the last Humble Monthly so value-wise, I got my money’s worth here with a combined playtime of about 24 hours.

There are six biomes to explore in the game, starting with the Mines and there's a linear path to take from therein. The game imposes this by locking away basic functions such as sliding under small crevices, double jump, wall jump etc. If you've played Dead Cells this might be a bit off-putting but it's just how it is and you get used to it.

The maps are generated procedurally with a seed system which you can note down to use for multi-runs but areas themselves tend to repeat themselves in later playthroughs as the general structure seems to be the same, just rooms swapped around. Puzzles are still randomly generated though and for a first playthrough, they seem to have been done well. Expect a lot of backtracking.

Gauntlets can be frustrating in other games but the most challenging rooms in Chasm are child's play compared to Hollow Knight and I'm relieved somewhat because I just wanted an easier time with a game for once. Rescuing the townsfolk slowly and rebuilding the town was a good way to take a break in-between the "chasm runs" - just wish there was to do in the town itself as it never really felt alive as much as it should have been.

Chasm excels in other areas such as ambience and general BGM but it suffers in how effective a lot of the weapons are. 

Whips and short-swords are great but daggers require you to almost touch the enemy and the heavy weapons are too slow to use - maybe intentional by design but it is impractical in this game as there is no way to block.

Magic skills are varied enough to switch out but pausing and unpausing just makes it not worth the effort. I stuck to Throwing Daggers most of the time, sometimes the Throwing Axe for the boss fights but rarely used it other than to clear off enemies standing on the edge of ledges blocking the path ahead - you get knocked back if you touch them. 

Equipment has its own RNG element and you can get marginally better drops in chests and off monster loot. Each area has its own boss to face and a mini-boss too and it takes about 12 hours going at a leisurely pace to finish it (on Easy). 

I played through the game three times to get 100% and thoroughly enjoyed it but I would only recommend this on a heavy discount or as part of a games bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972091126', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1582538034}
review: Decent Metroidvania, if rather short. Interesting difficulty curve in that you more or less cap out very early in melee strength (Chasm has RPG stats and different weapons to find), which makes the game significantly harder as you progress. Enemies get more hp, become harder to avoid, and do huge amounts of damage. Magic abilities basically consist of fancy ranged/semi-ranged weapon tosses, and until you upgrade them to Level 3, they just aren't that great. Movement compared to, say, Hollow Knight is much slower and more tactical. The best comparison might be with Mega Man, minus any speed upgrades. The story is ok, but nothing we haven't all seen before (mystery civilization, evil cult, etc.). Overall, certainly not Hollow Knight, but worth the price if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040037265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 469, 'playtime_forever': 1632, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1632, 'last_played': 1581617745}
review:
[code]El “Español de Hispanoamérica” de este juego es “Español de España” a todos los efectos (más info al final de la reseña) [/code]
[code]Puedes ver más reseñas como esta en la mentoría [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34129733/][u]PIXEL 404[/u][/url][/code]

[h1]Esta reseña no contiene spoilers[/h1]

Chasm es un juego que me ha gustado bastante, básicamente porque me ha ofrecido aquello que andaba buscando. No es el mejor metroidvania que vas a encontrar, y no llega al nivel o complejidad de otros como Hollow Knight, Axion Verge o similares.

Sin embargo, ofrece bastante entretenimiento y diversión con un acabado gráfico bastante bueno, sobre todo si se usa el filtro CRT, que le da ese aspecto de juego de épocas pasadas que tanto nos hicieron disfrutar.

En el juego controlaremos a un soldado cadete del imperio de Guildea que marcha a un pequeño pueblecito minero para descubrir qué sucede en el lugar y hacer frente a un mal que parece estar abriéndose paso a través de las minas.

El argumento no es demasiado original, pero tampoco importa demasiado, porque lo que hace lo hace muy bien. El juego posee abundante lore sobre los hechos que han sucedido en la zona, a través de manuscritos o libros que iremos encontrando en las entrañas de la mina.

A su vez, podremos realizar determinadas misiones secundarias en aras de ayudar al denostado pueblo. No son muy numerosas, pero cumplen perfectamente dentro de la globalidad de la experiencia jugable.

Como todo buen metroidvania que se precie, el juego está lleno de estancias y lugares por descubrir, con diferentes zonas muy bien diferenciadas unas de otras y con algunos puzles que aun no siendo difíciles, sí que amenizan y enriquecen bastante la experiencia.

Además, contaremos con un elenco de armas bastante numeroso, así como una ingente cantidad de enemigos diferentes a los que enfrentarnos, casi 100, que no es poco y habilidades por desbloquear al encontrar los objetos pertinentes.

Los enemigos serán bastante variados, aunque en pocas ocasiones nos sorprenderemos por sus diseños artísticos. Sin embargo, y una vez más, no es necesario. Trols, arañas, brujas, kobols y un largo etcétera poblarán las diferentes zonas del juego, así como jefes finales y sub-jefes.

Esto ha sido especialmente criticado en el juego, su falta de “originalidad” pero es algo que no llego a comprender del todo. Los enemigos están muy bien representados y cumplen perfectamente con su función. No son tan originales como los que encontramos en Hollow Knight, cierto, ¿y qué? Están bien realizados y representan perfectamente un mundo lleno de bestias y enemigos.

Hay que destacar en este aspecto que las animaciones, tanto del personaje principal como del resto de personajes y enemigos del juego, están muy bien realizadas. Las animaciones son muy suaves y se ve que se han esforzado bastante en ofrecer una experiencia bastante profesional en todo momento.

Esto es así especialmente con nuestro héroe. Ya sea corriendo, saltando, atacando, agarrándonos a cornisas o dando volteretas en el aire. Todo está perfectamente implementado dentro del juego.

El mando responde perfectamente a todas y cada una de las órdenes que demos, pero no es un machaca-botones. El personaje al atacar efectuará un golpe y si fallamos tendrá que recuperarse un breve momento antes de poder atacar nuevamente. A mí me parece un sistema bastante lógico, y además provoca que no vayamos atacando así a lo loco.

El juego como tal no es que sea especialmente difícil. Yo me lo pasé en “difícil” y morí una barbaridad de veces, pero nunca tuve la sensación de que el juego estuviera siendo injusto conmigo, ni mucho menos. Aunque supongo que en la dificultad “normal” el juego puede llegar a ser un paseo.

En lo tocante a su aspecto sonoro, el juego muestra unas melodías bastante entretenidas y que amenizan bastante la experiencia. No son muy numerosas, pero las que hay cumplen perfectamente con su función.

En lo referente a su traducción al español, la tienda indica que el juego está en “Español de Hispanoamérica” pero realmente esto no es así. Después de haberlo pasado de cabo a rabo, y haber leído decenas y decenas de conversaciones en el juego, puedo afirmar sin ninguna duda que el texto está en “Español de España” al 100%.

No hay ni un solo modismo, ni una sola expresión o atisbo de utilización de español de Hispanoamérica en ningún momento. Además, no hay faltas de ortografía de ninguna clase. Algo que desgraciadamente suele ser muy habitual en estos casos. 

Puede parecer raro, ya que la traducción es de México según parece. Así que mi duda realmente después de jugar este juego es si las buenas traducciones de “Español de Hispanoamérica” son cuando quedan como una de “Español de España” habitual que todos conocemos. Sí es así, bienvenidas sean. Aunque desgraciadamente esto no suele ser la norma.

En definitiva, Chasm es un metroidvania realmente entretenido, con bastantes retos que superar y misterios por descubrir. Puede no llegar a los mejores de su género, pero aun así tiene muchas virtudes que lo convierten en un título muy recomendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971404422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1023, 'last_played': 1582008351}
review:
This is a cautious recommendation. While I did finish the game, I enjoyed far less of it than I thought I would.

I (as I imagine most people) was drawn to this game by its art style and the fact it was another metroidvania. However, once you get past the scripted and story driven intro section (which is great mind you), what remains afterwards is a set of poorly generated levels filled with bad pacing. It could have been caused by a bad seed, but therein lies the issue so your mileage may vary.

The game borrows a lot from Castlevania (weapons, spells, combat, exploration), however it doesn't do enough to set itself apart. The "thing" in Chasm is the procedurally generated levels. 
I experienced bland and uninspired rooms and corridors repeating all too often. Because so much effort went into this concept, it feels very little went in the way of actual pacing. Weapon variety is low, it's possible to get the best weapons within a few hours of play, there are only 6 spells, the grind to level up spikes up around the mid-30's so it doesn't even make sense to do that either. 

If you came here looking for another Hollow Knight or even Axiom Verge, then this isn't it. What this is however, is a castlevania-light with procedurally generated levels that you can experience in a bite sized 10 hours.

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*]Art style - stellar work on that end.
[*]Plays like castlevania right down to how combat is executed.
[*]Another metroidvania!
[*]Chiptune soundtrack (overall a very low variety of music however).
[/list]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
[list]
[*]Pacing and progression seems at odds with itself. What I thought was just a side activity ([spoiler]Arena[/spoiler]) and ignored it for most of the game, ended up being a major arc to acquire a new artifact ([spoiler]diving gear[/spoiler]). However the areas I now had access to and the rewards I received were not worth the effort. It doesn't make sense. The whole [spoiler]sight[/spoiler] potion and two [spoiler]invisible[/spoiler] chests is another one, there's just no direction or purpose for it all to even be there, no story behind it, glimmer of its capabilities or other purposes, it's just there and once you get it done you'll never use that potion ever again.
[*]There was far more platforming than actual metroidvania-ing. Huge sections felt like playing Super Mario Bros.
[*]The menu/inventory is poorly implemented - no filter to sort weapons.
[*]Badly located save points.
[/list]

[b]To the Dev - great job on the game. I can see you're still actively updating the game so to that end:[/b]
[list]
[*]I know it's a big ask/recommendation, but the sequence and progression of artifacts to the areas you gain access to, the risk/time vs reward is poorly designed. I feel that re-evaluating either the order you get the items in or simply design the levels in such a way that there are more areas to use them in (water sections, slow potion etc) would not only create more uses for some of these items but also flesh out the game world a bit.
[*]Why give the player a special item to dig up dirt, but then force them to navigate the poorly designed inventory just to equip it for a few seconds and then back to their main weapon? Allow using it without having to equip it.
[*]Grant the ability to sort our equipment by strength, intelligence... anything. Searching for the best weapon/armour while they're hidden amongst trash loot is no ones idea of a good time. Trash loot can be sold, sure, but then we'd have to navigate each item one by one in order to see their stats, price alone shouldn't be what determines the 'value' of an item.
[*]More on the above point, why do we have to click into an item to see its stats? Why force a player to select an item to see how much it heals them? It just feels like there's always one too many clicks to get something done.
[*]Please don't waste a players time. You could introduce a checkpoint save system or better save/gateway locations. For instance, why place a save point only in the mines portal zone and not any of the others? It's as if you want to penalise the player for wanting to save by forcing them to go through those extra couple of zones just to save.
[*]Allow us to use the parachute several times during one fall. Increase it's utility for some quality of life fun - it won't ever get used once the feathered shoes are unlocked.
[*]If you're going to be inspired by castlevania right down to the movement style - a small suggestion is to stop mana drops from lanterns once mana is full, it's a redundant pickup. Instead provide more low-tier money drops if MP is full.
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197983536968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 794, 'last_played': 1587882797}
review:
Chasm is a fun little metroidvania game worth at least 12 hours of gameplay. If you enjoy it, there is some amount of replayability but a 100% 'normal' playthrough took about 12 hours.

I don’t really have many complaints about the game; controls are solid, atmosphere is good, traveling around the world was quick and accessible, the RPG elements were effective without being grindy, variety of equipment was good, etc.

My only two niggles with the game were that some of the items needed to unlock other items were too long an arc for too little of a reward; things like getting the light sword was a bit of a disappointment for how much work you had to do to get it and how the water relic was used in two places to get two items and that was literally it. Maybe this was just what my seed did and other seeds would have better pathing or more interesting uses for some of the relics but my experience was less than ideal in these circumstances.

My other issue was that most of the relics give you a small boost and allow you to do new and interesting things to reach new areas and traverse the world in different ways right up until you get the feather boots (vague non-spoilery terms used on purpose). The boots are a huge game changer in the way you move around the world- too huge really. The options you have once you acquire them are required for you to have access to with the way the game is built of course, but the power increase that this one relic gives you feels very unbalanced next to everything else the game provides. It also almost completely invalidates one of your previous relics (almost). I would have rather had some of the 'power' if this relic infused into others to balance out the gains and make those, shall we say, less useful relics more interesting.

With that said, I still 100% recommend the game to anyone who likes the genre. At the time of posting, there are 'mixed' reviews on Steam and I don’t really understand why. I see a lot of people saying it's as 'a worse version of SOTN' and while even my rose tinted glasses feel like SOTN was "better" than Chasm, there is still nothing wrong with this game. If you liked SOTN, this is a great love letter to enjoy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198200854499', 'num_games_owned': 616, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1592, 'last_played': 1577690474}
review:
游戏一开始，作为一个像素风冒险游戏爱好者来说，是合格的。
但是，游戏的一些瑕疵，也慢慢随着游戏的进度深入而变得明显起来。

首先我可以理解在街机模式里面安排种子来加强随机性，但是给故事模式也安排种子是个什么鬼？首先，这游戏的故事模式一周目起码要20h，我相信没有人闲着无聊一次又一次的玩儿故事模式吧。而且就算重新开始故事模式，我相信游戏的流程并不会改变，还是要挨个解救村民，解锁道具，只不过这些东西在地图上的位置变了而已。官方解释是说：加入种子是让你和你的好朋友在相同的世界里面玩耍。又不是上个世纪的游戏社交，不能线上合作搞个相同地图，难道还想让玩家在线下交流心得不成？

武器的优劣性十分明显。双手武器的跳砍和小皮鞭是这个游戏里最强的两大武器，别看那把只有一个像素厚的单手剑了兄弟，就算你挥地再快，它始终是根针。

人物和武器的属性很单一，完全可以不用任何魔法道具无脑堆物理攻击来通关游戏。武器造型那么多样，结果还不是拿到更好的就把旧的卖了，只能体验到武器性能的单一升级，没有任何武器的多元化。

更不用说后期解锁了连连看和老虎机无限刷钱之后，打boss只是个时间问题了。玩家心里想的只是快点让游戏结束，而体验不到击败boss的成就感了。

总体而言，若是有时间空余，还是值得一试的。
6.7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198315483653', 'num_games_owned': 185, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1678513726}
review:
Let me start off by saying, I see why this game has mixed reviews. Most of the people who don't recommend this are saying two things.

1. The game is a lot like Castlevania or other Metroidvania games. 

2. The game doesn't have enough save points.

And I agree with both of those opinions. I've never played Castlevaina, but I have played Hollow Knight, which is one of my all time favorite games. Right off the bat, as soon as I was in the mines I could see a lot of similarities between the two games, from the enemies to the landscape, it looked very similar. What I think happened is that Chasm drew a lot of inspiration from other Metroidvania games, but so much so that it looks like the Devs just copied a bunch of different games and rolled them all into one to create Chasm. There is a lot of room for originality and it doesn't look like there will be too much of it. 

As for the save points, yeah, I wish there were more. This is a mildly difficult game, and it's a real pain to have to go back so far when you die. But, in a lot of cases, there are save points nearby. It's often times a matter of choosing right over left. So, instead of making more save points, I wish there was some kind of marker or sign that lead you to save points nearby. 

The only other problem that I have with this game is that if you want to equip or use an item, or if you want to check the map, you have to pause the game and navigate to what you want from the pause menu. That is kind of a pain, and I think it would be much easier if you could bring up the options in game. Like, lets just say you could press 'M' for the map, 'E' for Equip and 'I' for inventory, or use tab or something, that would just make it a bit more convenient. 

All of that being said, I still do recommend this. It's not the best game in the world, but it's fun, and it's good if you are bored.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038582320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 658, 'last_played': 1581283626}
review:
I try to be understanding and more forgiving with indie devs. This game had been in development for quite a long time, and I had it on my wishlist for years. So long that I actually forgot it existed until I was surprised to see it up for sale one day. I went ahead and bought it, as it had a lot of what I enjoy. I love sprite-based games, and am a huge fan of metroidvania-style games. As others pointed out, this game doesn't do anything innovative, but for me that wasn't a concern. If it played closely to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, I'd be happy; and for the most part it does! However, there is one major thing that gives this a "no" from me. Following are my pros and cons, mostly cons, sadly:

1. The biggest thing is that this game is poorly optimized. It's programmed in XNA, and I don't know much about that framework, but I've never had a 2D sprite-based game drop frames like this game. And keep in mind, it isn't my system. I JUST finished playing and reviewing Doom 2016, and I played that game on Ultra settings without losing frames (with two minor instances). Not only does this game stutter, but actually, as of now, it's been rendered unplayable. I cannot open the game without it stuttering to the main screen, and even then it takes several minutes to get there. I had to fully reboot to get it to load properly, and it played well for another 10 minutes before the slowdown happened again and I'm not going to keep rebooting my computer to play this game that I had already grown bored of. 
2. The story isn't interesting enough to keep me invested in playing on to see what happens. Normally I wouldn't care about the story if the gameplay was fun, and while there isn't anything necessarily wrong with it, your character just isn't as acrobatic as Alucard or other metroidvania characters are. It makes the backtracking absolutely annoying. Your character is slow, and the artifacts you get to add to your moveset are also slow. Samus Aran you are not. At all. I was super excited when I initially got the slide, thinking I could finally zip through the levels and get the ball rolling, but there is such a long delay between your movesets, it just isn't fun to me. If this was supposed to be more realistic, like Salt & Sanctuary, that'd be fine, but it isn't. 
3. The music is virtually non-existent and unmemorable. 
4. Combat gets old fairly fast. I will say that, one problem I had with Castlevania SOTN was that, it too, got old regarding combat, but at least in that game  you had a lot of options to ignore or tear through enemies as you advanced in power. I could transform into a wolf and just zip right through them. However, in Chasm, I can Megaman-slide and then wait a solid 3-4 seconds before I can slide again. 

I legit feel bad writing this review because I'd hate to put in so much work in a game to have some idiot whose probably never created anything shit on it after just a few hours. There is a lot of potential here! The artwork is absolutely beautiful, and I love the pixel art. There are unique weapon animations for each weapon type, and I may not have given it a "No" if this were just a generic SOTN clone, but the performance issues I had make this a solid "No" for me. If there are future updates, or a DLC, or even a sequel, I will certainly be checking it out, because I think this is a great, responsive developer, but I can't say yes to a game I can't get to perform correctly when I can play Triple A games on their highest settings without issues. 

I WILL check back from time-to-time and change my rating should this issue be addressed. I want this developer to do well, and wish him the best.

review:
[quote]
加入[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ADZZW#]爱の榨汁屋[/url]&关注[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34815366/]爱の鉴赏家[/url]，用爱品鉴世间作品，用心流淌真情实感。
[/quote]
[h1] 《深渊矿坑》（《chasm》）的不靠谱初见评测[/h1]
游戏没有玩过多少，仅仅打完第一个boss，不知为什么，没什么耐心玩一下。
游戏缺少让我眼前一亮的“灵魂”。
一款游戏的灵魂到底是什么？玩法？剧情？画风？Bgm?打击感?角色？
是，也不全是，有，也不全有。
这款游戏让我感觉玩家只是来做任务的，而不是游戏中的一份子。
就像那一个个怪物，军中的npc，我只感觉到他们的数据，却没有感到他们的灵魂。
当我杀死怪物的时候，我没有感到角色的变强，只是木然看着怪物死去消失。
进入游戏，我是一个新兵，要去一个矿石镇，解决那里出现的怪物。
我深入矿洞，发现游戏不是那么简单。
1.打击感一般，只能说一般，打怪，掉血，哦，没了。
2.剧情看得出来精心设计过，有很多文字记载的细节来充实整个世界观，但没有吸引我看下去，反而看着汉化的文本头疼。
3.说到汉化，网上下了个汉化文本，勉强能看，但体验不太好。
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1992971908 
4.比较糟心的地方就是，平台跳跃的某些地方，会被怪堵着，我跳上去受到伤害会硬直往后倒，导致有部分地方跳得很累。
5.武器系统，对比1，换什么武器都没有酷炫的打击感，让我体会不到爽快，私以为这类杀怪游戏在杀怪方面应该让人更爽一点？目前玩了两种武器，大棒和剑，他们的后摇貌似都有点长，让我不是很喜欢，感觉不是很cool。
6.怪物设计方面，史莱姆，哥布林，大老鼠，都是很传统的怪，毕竟一个矿洞，考虑实际情况也不会有那些骇人的怪了。
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1992971971 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1992972032 
7.平台跳跃方面，一般，不难，大概也是因为我没打到后面，没有刺激感。
8.画风方面，像素风虽复古，但同时也失去了特色，如果没有一定内容的支持，很难在一众游戏中脱颖而出。
综合评价 7/10分
[h1]总结 [/h1]
《chasm》总体而言是一款中规中矩的游戏，作为一款类银河恶魔城像素游戏，在动作打击感、怪物设计、叙事等方面都显得中规中矩，没能超出同类型游戏，导致玩起来游戏新鲜感和冒险的刺激感都稍有缺失，喜欢类银河恶魔城的玩家可以尝试之后再做出自己的评价。

author: {'steamid': '76561198049790598', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1581094213}
review:
The art, music and, from what I've seen, narrative are all great. The platforming is ok. But the game is completely ruined by its bad combat and terrible progression/saving system. 
The weapons, at least the ones available in the early game, all feel terrible to use. Each weapon has something different it's good at, but that's because it is garbage at everything else. For example, the knife has good damage and mobility, but extremely low range, requiring you to stand right beside the enemy - which means that it will move into you while you can't move. Because you can't move while using a weapon. The club, on the other hand, has good range and even attacks things above you (good against flying enemies), but has an extremely long swinging animation, during which you can't move, so anything that isn't one-shot by it will damage you. Compounding these issues is the bad enemy placement. Sometimes an enemy will hang out on a ledge that you need to jump on. You can't damage the enemy without jumping on that platform, but every time you try it just knocks you back off.
This by itself would still be tolerable, after the first one or two times you die to each enemy you figure out the timing and tricks to defeat it, but it is completely unacceptable coupled with its other major defect: every time you die you lose all progress since the last time you saved. Checkpoints are very sparse and in non-obvious locations, so sometimes you can even pass them by completely. There is no way to regenerate health except at checkpoints so every hit an enemy gets in on you counts down to your doom and if you don't find the next checkpoint in time you have to do it all over again. You can't even go back to the last checkpoint because all enemies respawn as soon as you leave the screen, so going back is just as dangerous as going forward. There are destroyable lanterns all over the place, but they drop mana, not health, for which I still haven't found any use. Presumably I'll be able to use spells later. After a while you unlock the potion shop which can sell health potions, but that doesn't solve the problem because they're very expensive and you only get a little bit of gold sometimes when you kill an enemy. The rate at which I was dealt damage by enemies is greater than the rate at which I got money equivalent to the same amount of health.
As if having to replay large parts of the map when you die wasn't enough, I kept coming across chests blocked by obstacles I didn't have the ability to remove yet (large jumps, not-yet-breakable walls/floors), clearly indicating that I'd have to redo that entire area later when I got those abilities.
I ragequit multiple times after the game forced me to redo large sections of the game, but I resolved to come back multiple times because the great art and music and interesting lore really made me want to give it a chance. I was always hoping that maybe I'd find that spell which let me regenerate health, but I never did. I won't try anymore though. The straw that broke this camel's back is when I died for the last time: I was two rooms past the last checkpoint when I noticed that I didn't actually save there: I entered the warp hub, but didn't remember that I'd also have to warp back to the warp hub of the previous world and from there get to the checkpoint to save before going back through both warp hubs into the part of the game that isn't just mind-numbing (and slow) walking back and forth. I had just fought against a new kind of enemy, whose patterns I didn't know, so my health was at a bit less than 1/2 of the maximum. Unfortunately, those two rooms were chock full of enemies. I tried to avoid fighting them by jumping over them and running away, but one still managed to land a hit on me. I was half a screen away from the end of the second room when I was boxed in between two ranged enemies (boomerang-throwing skeletons) and two short-range/melee hybrids (spitting and dashing snakes). I died in two hits. I lost ~20 minutes of work. The game didn't even have the decency of respawning me at the checkpoint, it put me into the main menu for some stupid reason.
In summary: 
art/music/presentation: great.
narrative: good.
main gameplay mechanic (platforming): fine.
secondary gameplay mechanic (combat): bad.
UX: absolutely terrible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053075672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 486, 'last_played': 1580924422}
review:
This isn't an amazing game, but it does what it sets out to do well. If you like the Metroidvania genre, than this is a nice short excursion.

Pros:
-Good graphics, a lot of detail in the sprites and the backgrounds look nice.
-Diablo inspired (probably) loot system means that enemy drops can have additional stat boosts or effects. This is nice and probably the most original aspect of this game. I don't think any other metroidvania has done this.
-Bosses are fun to fight, and sub bosses keep you on your toes.
-Shortcuts are frequent, which makes backtracking and getting back to town easy. It's nice.

Cons:
-Music, while not bad, is very forgettable. It aims for ambiance, which suits the style of the game well, but besides the Mines theme it's barely noticeable and might as well not be there. There's a lot of potential for the composer, try different styles!
-Getting lost in this genre is common, but for how short the game is I felt lost for way too much of it.
-Not much originality. It's hard to be innovative in this genre for sure, but with a few exceptions like the loot modifier system, it's all stuff you've seen before. Almost every powerup is predictable the second you see an obstacle you can't get around yet.

There are better games in this genre for sure, but this one is fun and worth playing. It's randomization brings some replayability to the table as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963491995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1580617264}
review:
Just barely good enough for a positive score though really deserved a neutral rating instead. There are so many detractors throughout the game be prepared to be mired down in mediocre. 

[strike]1) The game completely fails to explain what each character stat attribute does. This is passable to veteran gamers but less experienced players will be dumbfounded. It’s obvious this game takes inspiration from the NES 8-bit titles but those games came with a manual to explain any nuance. A trip to the discussions will get you a vague understanding.[/strike] Looks like there is a steam manual these days and the stats are explained inside.

2) Procedural generated dungeon hype. The whole concept is wasted as there just is so little reason to replay again; especially if you picked hard difficulty the first time. And even so the procedural generation just doesn't affect the game play enough at its foundation. 

3) Combat does not have a fluid feeling due to the design decision to lock the character into an action for a bit after taking it. In addition the complete lack of reach on some of the weapons is absolutely laughable; can just toss those dagger-type weapons straight in the bin. 

4) Monster drops are far too infrequent; even with a luck boosting scroll it could easily take 50 kills or more to get both item drops.  

Art, music and novelty of initial the vision save it from being a complete train wreck. Unless you are obsessed with metroidvanias I wouldn’t be in any rush to play this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102038554', 'num_games_owned': 762, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 938, 'last_played': 1580219273}
review:
Сюжет очень простой и не замысловатый. Управление приятное, на геймпаде не возникло никаких трудностей. Под конец игры, уже начала уставать от нее, ничего нового, монстры стали однотипными, секреток уже нет, сохранений все меньше и меньше. Перед последним боссом вообще вначале карты, умер - беги снова через огненные ловушки, теряй жизни и пытайся снова. 
Поиграв 7 часов, хотела написать как можно более положительный обзор, но игра средняя, концовка оставила не приятное послевкусие, гриндить в платформерах - раздражает.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992511533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1580103686}
review:
The art is gorgeous, especially the backgrounds, but I didn't care for the general gameplay. I think this is a fine metroidvania, and if you really enjoy that genre then you would probably really enjoy this.

Combat is often very confining, with low ceilings, narrow platforms, and very short attack ranges. There's also a bit too much filler between the interesting bits. Lots of backtracking through the recycled content. Add to this the amount of attacks it takes to kill enemies and that they respawn each time you enter those rooms and it's just a painful slog.

Again, I don't think it's a bad game just not the sort that I like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000662689', 'num_games_owned': 1479, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 879, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 879, 'last_played': 1579585975}
review:
Recommended, with caveats.

As Metroidvanias go, the /mechanics/ are tight - combat and movement usually feel pretty decent, with a couple of quibbles for a few rooms. Equipment feels SotN-like, with items often hiding special effects that you have to discover by use.

The random generation is a nice thought, but the game's gating is strongly linear, and items generally seem to end up in the same regions, so it's at most an aesthetic difference which rooms connect which major points each time. Don't go in expecting a roguelike either - the map generates once when you start a given savefile, and doesn't randomize on death.

The art is quite pretty pixelwork, but the designs of most zones aren't distinct enough to make the enemies truly shine.

All-in-all, it's a solid platformer, with a modicum of replayability if you really feel like being a maximal item completionist, or hitting up the highest difficulty, or trying a different class. As it stands, I'm satisfied with the 10-hour playthrough on regular, and have no inclination to return for more - I feel as if I've mastered the game sufficiently that just adding more health / damage to push through wouldn't be all that much more fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018812372', 'num_games_owned': 426, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 120, 'last_played': 1579572072}
review:
The good:
[list][*]The static graphics are great. It's interesting that there is an optional CRT mode.
[*]The audio is great. It's interesting that there is a chiptune-stylized alt for each track.
[*]There are daily and weekly high-score-focused time attack modes for those who don't care about the story mode, which is cool, and they're currently active with lots of players.
[/list]
The bad:
[list][*]I don't know why my character looks so angry all of the time. I'm not sure of the design choice that went into this, but it actually annoys me a bit.
[*]I don't understand how I can logically put on two Leather Belts simultaneously as accessories ACC 1 and ACC 2.
[*]There is no explanation of anything for the two-story house at the beginning. At least putting up a sign or something to let early-game players know that it should be populated or something would help them not waste time... 🙄
[*]Note that I said above that the [i]static[/i] graphics are great. However, the motion blur that your character constantly exhibits is terrible, and there is no way to disable it in the game options.
[*]Map color is not distinct enough with regards to holes. There is also no way to mark "tiles to remember" if you see a region of the map that clearly requires a specific skill or tool that you don't yet have, so if it's been a while since you last played, you may end up wasting time revisiting that part if you forgot.
[*]Inertia is not properly rendered on moving platforms. If you jump onto a moving platform right as it's about to pull away from the direction in which you approach it, and then you move back in said direction, you whoosh right off of it, even though you should have begun to accumulate momentum towards the opposite direction already.
[*]Why don't the spike traps trigger when an enemy steps on them?! (Egyptian zombies, I'm looking at you...)
[*]Basic UI problems involving custom keyboard shortcuts: https://imgur.com/a/O6auMG8 (I'm not sure of why the entire screen is darkened; my screenshot program must be incompatible with the way Chasm handles full-screen resolution)
[*]I'm just not convinced of how fair it is to put healing stations increasingly so far away from each other, with the only other options when you're low on health being either to spend a truckload of money on Warp Scrolls to return to the town-of-a-main-hub, or risk regaining health by consuming extremely rare food items that seem to come more from pots than ever from any enemies. Granted, I only reached the second dungeon thus far, but even so, in Axiom Verge, Hollow Knight, etc., you don't have this kind of highly specific, "ugh"-fueled tension from risk of death due to injuries from easy mistakes, because enemies in [i]those[/i] games can heal you fairly easily. From what I could gather in Chasm, there wasn't even a magic spell that could perform self-healing (even when mana is gathered at a snail's pace, itself). Granted, I didn't get the witch doctor her Book of Incantations or whatever, but it sure seemed more-than-a-bit discouraging.
[*]Speaking of those spells, it was sort of a blind man's game to try to decide on what magical skills to buy next. The descriptions were so vague that you weren't even informed that magic axes are gravity-influenced while other magical weapons are not. Even the "shield" is offensive, not defensive. Some type of brief, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/893180/Catherine_Classic/]Catherine[/url]-like animated GIFs previewing what each one does would be way fairer to early-game players wary of paying so relatively much for things that do what they're not even sure of.
[/list]
And the ugly:
[list][*]You lose 100% of all control of the character when you take a swing of any weapon at an enemy while you're on foot, even if you were running forward at the time of the swing. Your character unrealistically just grinds to an instant halt, and stands still while swinging. You can't even interrupt the attack to defend if you change your mind or see that your foe will beat you to it, timing-wise. I understand that this won't be fixed at all because the dev wants people to memorize and master specific enemies' attack patterns to time their usage of the game's [i]really[/i] awkward backwards-dash feature. I get it; it's a design decision, which probably makes it easier to animate the protagonist. This is also why games like Hollow Knight and any Metroid title will stay ahead of the pack in this genre.
[*]Even if character control was not an issue, here is actually my biggest pet peeve: the level design feels like it "tried" to be a roguelike, but excellent roguelikes don't feel like they tried. One with superb level generation should feel totally organic. I got very annoyed when passing through the second dungeon (Egyptian-like catacombs, complete with zombies and venom-spitting snakes), because I came across multiple rooms that were very close together that followed an almost identical structure of a reverse Z shape (you have to travel to one side, hop backwards the other way across a series of hanging platforms above the ground, and then traverse yet a third tier of suspended terrain above both of those). So I was, like... "All right, I can feel the dev put every square meticulously together," because spaces were well placed for jumps. But... it's unimpressive if a relative [i]lot[/i] of tiles on the map follow an exact upside-down "U" shape, and so on. Like, the reverse-Z-shaped rooms were never even in reverse order. It was [i]always[/i], so far, an opening in the bottom-left, and then one opening on each upper side.

For another example: in the previous dungeon, the caverns, there were multiple tiles on the map that followed exactly the same structure: pools of acid with oscillating floating blocks of always two pools with two blocks each, or a larger pool with three blocks. There was never, like, a pond with one block and then two, or a short wall to surmount, or something. Essentially, there should have been five times as much level variation, or else Axiom Verge, Hollow Knight, etc. win with their handcrafted asymmetrical, interesting, never-repeating layouts.[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198301252255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1679306027}
review:
My thoughts after finishing it once. I avoided buying this because of the earlier reviews but after seeing the last round of updates I thought I'd try it out. I am glad I did.  Overall it was a fun albeit short game and there were no real hiccups along the way.  

Game play: It's very much cut from the same cloth as SOTN/Bloodstained. You'll be constantly on the lookout for better items. Due to it being shorter than the previously mentioned other games I found it to be a lot less grind focused than they were. There is SOME grinding but I never felt that it took up enough of my overall experience to give it much notice. (These were mostly situations where I would find a monster that gives a lot of XP near the edge of a screen and would take advantage of that to level up once or twice and then move on. That happened maybe three times at most not including an NPC sidequest.)

You will do a lot of back tracking as its a Metroidvania type game.  You will battle your way through long stretches to get items that aren't what you need or are less powerful than what you currently have but you can sell them to aid you in finding something more to your liking.  This brings up a kind of short cumming of the game - I never felt there was enough divergence between options for your character (spells, weapons, ect.) to make for anything much more than the swordsman you start out as in the game. Even with projectile spells you're going to stay the dedicated swordsman.

Map:  The biggest worry for me was that the procedurally generated map wouldn't 'unfold' properly and thus would leave me unable to complete the game (or leave me with some unplayable map layout that would ruin the experience.) Well it never happened for me. The map was fine as far as I was concerned and I got the hang of it in about the same amount of time I would have with any other Metroidvania.  

The areas were different enough to provide incrementally difficult platform jumping and the monsters became more complex the deeper into the mines I went. Each area has a shortcut room which makes switching between areas a much more tolerable experience. 

Story: SPOILERS. - It's a simple one about an inexperience soldier on his first real mission. He is charged with going to a small town and getting to the bottom of their troubles. This leads him into the mines of that town and a lengthy dungeon crawl where he learns about the forces of evil that held sway over an ancient civilization that once called the area home. There are also some NPC sidequests but they all amount to "find me X".

Controls: I stayed with the default layout and found them to be more than adequate.  There is a lot of wall jumping, ledge grabbing, and even some tricky platforming along the way and I can say I never found myself at odds with the controls. The movement of your character is responsive and I never felt there were situations where I died and it wasn't my fault.  Any kind of movement I wanted to initiate in order to make my way through a room was possible. 

Graphics: It has fairly well animated sprite graphics that give it a charming look. There was some thought put into the animations of the main character and it shows. (I liked the little details like him continuing to breath as an idle animation while he's holding onto the ledge.) Stylistically the game borrows much from games like Bloodstained/SOTN.  For example the animation to swing your weapon looks just like the mentioned other games animations. 

The monsters are also animated well and there are some interesting foes to come across in your travels as well as some standard ones. Cave? Bats and Goblins. Castle? Haunted suits of armor and skeletons. But there is a large bestiary of monsters to keep things fresh and some decent bosses/minibosses along the way. 

There are some interesting areas to explore but they do feel a little similar in the beginning and its not until you get to the Garden where the color pallet finally breaks out of its solemn scheme.  

Overall: It's a standard Metroidvania game with the twist of having a new map layout each time you start over. It doesn't really bring anything new to the table.  You've had this meal before (and prepared better) but you know what you're getting and you'll probably enjoy this one too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073414804', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 348, 'playtime_forever': 159, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1579442494}
review:
Got this from humble bundle.

Chasm is a good game with some bullshit decisions made by devs. Like many others i got stuck with the catacomb lock puzzle where you need to enter 3 digits between 1 and 9 in order however without googling it the hint for this puzzle was not obvious at all, apparently you need to find 3 rooms with randomly generated count of items, stars, cups and swords. wow..................... this is a simplistic game and they made a puzzle that you would need an observation skills of an eagle to figure out what you need to do without google? pff stupid. It's also randomly generated so noone can tell you what the code is. If you get the code wrong you need to climb all the way back up, which just adds to frustration and annoyance with otherwise great game. 

Premise is that you are young knight sent to some random town to save the miners that are trapped in mines. Controls are smooth, it supports chinese controllers and it's a great game, minus the annoying platforming sections and bullshit puzzles like the one described above. Who knows what more terrible puzzles these devs could have added in later stages? I recommend but be ready to be annoyed and have a google search ready..

review: The only things that are ok in this game are graphics and enemy variety. Everything else is average at best and sometimes bad. Level design is mediocre, music is mediocre, exploration is bad and tedious, but the game could redeem itself if it had nice gameplay. Unfortunately it hasn't, animations are horrible and lock you into position until they finish and most of the powerups make your life harder than easier because they're horribly designed. I wonder if someone from the devs has ever played a single game which features wall jumping and tell us what they think about their game. The game is very monotonous and boring. If you finish every half decent Metroidvania out there and the game is on deep, deep sale I suppose you could buy it. But I could watch a painting dry off for 8 hours straight and find it more exciting than Chasm.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972836357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 179, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1579215492}
review:
I only played for an hour so take this as you will, but the combat is slow and unresponsive, the controls are floaty (which is a problem, because there's quite a bit of platforming for a Metroidvania title) and there are entire stretches of corridors with enemies that make the game feel like a slog (because of the procedurally generated levels, I assume). Nice pixelart and pretty good music, but that's not nearly enough to compensate for core issues. It's playable, but it's extremely average in its genre and progression doesn't feel rewarding. 

Also, procedural generation isn't a magic pill that instantly makes a game more interesting and it has little business existing in a Metroidvania.
