author: {'steamid': '76561198089683297', 'num_games_owned': 1528, 'num_reviews': 108, 'playtime_forever': 1229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1229, 'last_played': 1578946129}
review:
[code]If you enjoyed this review, please consider following my Curator Page [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/33864135/]Nep's Gaming Paradise (Nepiki Gaming)[/url] for more reviews![/code]

[h1]Nepiki's Stats[/h1]
[table]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall length[/td]
        [td]5-7 hours for beating, 10-20 hours for completion (can be done in one to three playthroughs).[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall difficulty[/td]
        [td]Low to medium difficulty.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Overall score[/td]
        [td]★★★★☆[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Review[/h1]
I've played through Chasm a total of three times since I am an achievement hunter. At this point, I also felt like I could give you the most accurate review I could provide you myself since Chasm is an.. interesting game. Let's start off with this game's defining feature and the one you're probably most curious about: the procedurally-generated dungeon design. Yes, this does indeed mean that with every new save file you start, a random world is created for you. And yes, this also sounds better than it does because really, since it's a Metroidvania that relies on you getting upgrades in a specific order they can't go all-out. In my three playthroughs, I can easily say that perhaps only 30% of the entire map changes with each new savefile. And since they are handcrafted rooms, it is very well possible that you might have seen those rooms in a previous playthrough, perhaps just in a different position. It's unfortunate that it's not as random as I hoped it would be, as my three playthroughs all very much felt the same with minor differences like every chest item being random. What hurts even more is that because of this feature, the world feels limited as well. It is still a Metroidvania, but don't expect a rich map where every exit leads to more exits. Instead, it is very linear and only demands you to go back to previous places on a few occasions. There's of course a lot to find in previous areas but most are optional and occasionally also worse than what you already have. I feel like a world in a Metroidvania can make or break a game and while Chasm's isn't bad or anything, for a Metroidvania it's slightly underwhelming. I will appreciate the map showing you where something of interest is however. On that front Chasm is also very noob-friendly.

The other part of a Metroidvania however, is the gameplay. Chasm does control pretty smoothly and very much reminds me off a Castlevania game. Not surprising as the magical weapons are literally Castlevania sub-weapons, and normal weapons are reminiscent of the weapons Alucard could use in Symphony of the Night. The upgrades our main protagonist gets aren't too surprising either. Stuff like a double jump, wall jump and a lantern to illuminate dark places should not come as a surprise. I was a big fan of the bird and sword hats however; they are summons that attack enemies and can level up independently. You can also choose right from the start what class you want to specialize in. Magic in this game is very broken though, especially the knives. This does not necessarily come as a surprise but if you want an easy time even on the hardest difficulties, just upgrade the knives to the maximum and you won't have to worry about anything. Lastly, I want to mention the challenge mode which is actually pretty interesting as it actually puts you into a randomly generated dungeon and you're on a time limit to get a highscore. I personally was done with Chasm after the three playthroughs, but this is a fun addition to the people who want more out of this game.

This is however the extent to which Chasm goes. It plays well overall, but at its core it's just a basic Metroidvania with a basic map. There is nothing wrong with that, but if you are a veteran Metroidvania player you might not get much enjoyment out of it as there are a serious amount of good ones out there. I can't stress enough that Chasm is not bad, it really isn't. But because it set out to do something so ambitious, it had a lot to sacrifice and as a result is nothing more than an average-to-good Metroidvania.

review: Fairly straightforward side-scroller with interesting puzzles. The random level layout takes away the ease of cheating through solutions. When you get stuck, it will take a while to find the way forward due to backtracking for puzzle items with new equipment or necessary artifacts. Enemies aren't overly challenging, and controls feel pretty accurate. A few jumping puzzles will get old fast, but they are a right of passage for anything with a platform. The stories are nicely rounded with innovative details and unexpected minor twists. Overall a very fun game that I'd recommend.

review:
Surprised to see so many negative reviews. Chasm is a solid, little game that unfortunately brings nothing new or groundbreaking to the metroidvania table. Lovely tilesets, good music, bosses (especially after Hollow Knight) are rather on a weak side. Procedural approach to levels increases replayability in some way but harms level design quality in general. Almost no powerups made me excited to backtrack and reexplore unlocked areas. Late game pickups closed behind potions and other items are near useless. None the less we all got spoiled by games like Hollow Knight, Momodora and Chasm still is a good game just not a good 
[strike] Fallou [/strike] .. ah fuck off, just play it.

PS Kudos to BitKid as an omnipresence on literally every forum or community board dedicated to this game, helping users, resolving issues and taking criticism like a champ. Respect and we need more devs like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272374716', 'num_games_owned': 13029, 'num_reviews': 3562, 'playtime_forever': 345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1578695445}
review:
[h1]«Chasm»[/h1]
[b][i]Приключенческая, пиксельная метроидвания в духе старых частей «Castlevania».[/i][/b]

[code]Разработчики игры вдохновлялись старыми, классическими играми серии «Castlevania», особенно «Castlevania: Symphony of the Night».[/code]

Нам предстоит обследовать огромный подземный мир из шести областей, состоящих из множества связанных между собой комнат, залов и катакомб. 
В игре присутствует элемент процедурной генерации. Заключается он в том, что с новой игрой комнаты каждой области перемешиваются случайным образом, составляя уникальную карту. Поэтому каждая новая игра будет отличатся не только лутом, но и картой местности (порядком расположения комнат). 
Как в любой метроидвании проходы в некоторые области будут недоступны, пока герой не получит соответствующие умения, предметы или не выполнит определенные действия.

Персонаж может бегать, прыгать, делать отскок назад, рубить мечом (дают в самом начале игры) и использовать второе магического оружие, расходующее ману (его придется раздобыть или купить). С прохождением откроются новые умения: отскок от стен, цепляние за выступы и перекат.

Характеристики главного героя повышаются автоматически с получением нового уровня и с помощью обмундирования/предметов, которые можно найти в сундуках или купить у торговцев, но торговцев придется найти в подземельях и освободить. Только после этого они появятся на поверхности в деревушке и смогут с вами торговать и давать задания.

У героя есть полноценный инвентарь с предметами, возможность взять в каждую руку по оружию и надеть шлем, броню и пару украшений.

Лут в виде золота, кристаллов маны, вещей можно получить из сундуков, при убийстве врагов и разбивании некоторых предметов (лампы, ящики и т.д.). В игре процветает гринд монет для скупки необходимого снаряжения и фарм опыта для повышения характеристик. Этому способствует то, что враги появляются снова, стоит только зайти за экран и вернутся в любой комнате, где есть живность. Если испытываете сложность с прохождением какого-либо этапа, босса или вам хочется купить что-либо у торговцев, можно гриндить врагов бегая между двумя экранами. Если напялить на перса предметы, повышающие удачу, то лута и золота будет выпадать значительно больше!

Радует, что это не рогалик, и нам дают сохранить прогресс в определенных местах. Тут не приходится проходить все с самого начала! В зависимости от умений игрока и генерации карты полное прохождение игры займет 6-10 часов. Это не считая того, что в игре есть аркадный режим с ежедневными и еженедельными испытаниями.

[code]Отличная игра. Настоящее классическое приключение в стиле «Castlevania» с испытанными временем и полюбившимися механиками, увлекательным геймплеем, адекватной сложностью, красивой детализированной графикой, великолепной анимацией и с приличной продолжительностью (около 10-ти часов). Из минусов: сомнительная генерация и невнятный сюжет.[/code]

[u]Если вам понравился обзор, информация была полезной / интересной, то поддержите лайком или комментарием.[/u]

[i] Обзор был написан для группы [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Obzzor4ik]Обзоры Онлайн[/url]. Почитать другие отзывы можете[url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28776273/] тут[/url].[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198082606558', 'num_games_owned': 364, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1578520150}
review:
Je viens ENFIN de terminer ce jeu. Et quel jeu fort plaisant !
J'ai téléchargé ce jeu dans l'espoir d'y dénicher quelque chose ayant un rapport, de près ou de loin, à Hollow Knight, un jeu 2D que j'ai jugé beaucoup trop hâtivement. Evidemment, Chasm est loin d'être un Hollow Knight, mais il fait tout de même le café, à mon avis.

Le principe est assez similaire; on a un jeu 2D (pixelisé d'ailleurs, ce qui n'est pas sans rappeler les jeux rétros), et on parcourt divers donjons en parcourant la map. Comme Hollow Knight, on fait divers allers-retours afin de récolter certains items ou objets importants pour avancer dans l'histoire, et ainsi progresser. Cependant, la grosse particularité du jeu est que la map est ... générée de façon aléatoire ! Cela donne une très grande autonomie au jeu, puisque le recommencer vous permettra de vous imposer de nouvelles difficultés par les chemins. De plus, vous pouvez très bien jouer sur la map d'un ami, en modifiant la graine. C'est bien pensé bien que peu utilisé en pratique à mon humble avis. 
En bref, ce jeu a su attirer ma curiosité et m'a plutôt plu.

Cependant, il a néanmoins divers points négatifs ... et ils sont nombreux malheureusement. Tout d'abord, je trouve la musique correcte. Juste, correcte. Elle est pas mauvaise, mais elle est pas assez cool non plus. Je trouve que ça manque de rythme très globalement, notamment dans les combats contre les boss. 
Parlons en ensuite des boss ... Je trouve la difficulté de certains boss (notamment le boss final) un poil abusé. On est très très loin de la difficulté légendaire de Hollow Knight, mais c'est un peu complexe quand même. Le flemmard que je suis a dû faire le plein de potions pour se kamikazer sur le boss de fin. En clair, si comme moi vous aimez moyen la stratégie, ce jeu risque de vous mettre de sérieux bâtons dans les roues. 
Parlons ensuite de la map. Ce jeu dispose, bien sûr, d'un système de carte, pour vous aider à ne pas vous perdre. Cependant, mon dieu, la carte est si pauvre ! Elle indique les sorties, quelques trésors par un malheureux point ... Et c'est tout. Vous n'avez aucun moyen de placer des marqueurs (enfin, si ... Mais seulement un seul, à l'endroit où vous êtes). Autant dire que si vous n'avez pas autant de chance que moi dans ma partie (où globalement tout s'enchaînait assez bien, je n'ai pas eu besoin de passer trois jours à chercher un endroit en particulier), vous êtes très mal barrés avec une carte pareille. Je pense notamment au système ingénieux des "grottes". Dans le jeu, vous allez parcourir différents niveaux, qui sont assez grands. Chasm a eu le génie de créer une espèce de salle avec un téléporteur pour relier les niveaux, et des grottes pour accéder rapidement à différents endroits du niveau. Le hic, c'est que, à moins de le connaître par coeur, vous ne savez pas quel chemin vous mènera là où vous voulez qu'il aille. Pourquoi ne pas l'avoir indiqué sur la carte ? Ce serait plus agréable ! 
Et tant qu'on y est, la carte a parfois des ratés ... Il m'indique la présence de trésor dans des salles déjà dépouillées de leur trésor. Bof bof, mais c'est qu'un petit bug.
Enfin, et c'est je pense le plus gros point noir du jeu; OU EST LE BACKGROUND ? Certes, il y a une histoire, mais ça part un peu dans tous les sens, notamment au début. On vous parle un peu de qui vous êtes, dans quel pays vous êtes etc ... Et ces infos là, typiquement, on s'en tape en fait. Le plus important, c'est la suite. L'histoire avec le Roi Trell, la tribu, Ulak, etc ... Ces éléments de l'histoire sont racontés par des journaux trouvés dans le jeu et par les PNJ. En soi, l'histoire est très intéressante, cependant je suis très déçu par le bestiaire. Le bestiaire regroupe les différents ennemis que vous avez tués. Cependant, pour les amateurs de background comme moi, vous serez très déçu de voir qu'il n'y a aucune description ... Si vous avez tué par exemple l'ennemi "Démon", vous n'avez aucune idée de son histoire; à quoi il sert, quand il a été créé, etc ... C'est très dommage quand on voit que l'histoire a l'air géniale.

Néanmoins malgré ces points négatifs, Chasm est un jeu, je trouve, assez addictif. Il faut néanmoins garder en tête qu'il faut bien aimer ce type de jeu similaire à Hollow Knight. Il se finit plutôt rapidement, mais on est quand même très satisfait quand il est terminé. Je vous le conseille, mais regardez bien des vidéos sur le jeu avant de sauter dessus. C'est un type de jeu assez spécial qui ne plaît pas à tout le monde !

author: {'steamid': '76561198032424682', 'num_games_owned': 2012, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 893, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 893, 'last_played': 1578427567}
review:
The game in general is quite well executed, but doesn't do much renewing the genre or anything. It builds on the foundations that have been laid out for Metroidvanias, so be prepared to mark areas that you can't yet proceed through to make it easier to know where to backtrack too. Personally I'd have liked the ability to have different coloured markers (as to indicate new skills needed or just treasures). For me this was quite annoying once, since I forgot to mark a certain gate, and it was the only point of progression, which meant I had to go throughout all the maps and check everything out (I feel like this is more on me than on the game though). Besides this the soundtracks are quite basic but nice to listen to anyway and won't annoy you into turning off the sound. The environments look really nice and fit well with the rest of the style of the game. The magic feels a bit basic (and honestly strong as in most of these games) but to be fair I haven't used much of it since I prefer combat over magic. The different types of weapons are quite nice, however since it's (somewhat) randomly generated you quite often find weapons weaker than the ones you already have.

The only real performance problem I encountered was quite odd and I'm genuinely not sure if anyone else would ever encounter it. I'm using a Xbox Bluetooth Controller, which means it might sometimes (temporarily) lose connection, most of the time this is just for a second, however Chasm really doesn't seem to like this. Whenever my controller would lose connection the game would slow down to being pretty much unplayable, yet recover to normal speed when the connection was restored. In general this wasn't a problem (as you don't lose your connection that much) but since my controller was apparently low on batteries it had a real problem keeping up the connection (which took me a while to figure out what the problem was).

In conclusion I'd recommend buying it, especially when on sale as I feel it's worth around 10$ easily.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049134301', 'num_games_owned': 4192, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 922, 'last_played': 1578359225}
review:
It's... fine. Uninspired Castlevania.

What you need to know:

It's a metroidvania with random layout. The random generation isn't apparent. Based on some guides lots of stuff appears in fixed locations.
New monster. What's your attack routine? I am now invincible.
Give me XP. Level up. Monster is now worth less XP. 
Very easy to tank boss attacks with healing items.

You know what's lazy? The Bestiary. There are 80 odd entries that unlock after killing a fixed amount of each enemy. There is no description of the monster, just some basic stats and what it drops. You scroll through each page 1 at a time so it's hard to find any given entry.

You know what else is lazy? There is no way to sort your equipment. So you go to the blacksmith and look to sell some stuff, and you've got 7 knives all in different places based on when you get them. Some are enchanted but you can't easily compare stats. Want to wear your 2 Jade Rings? They sure aren't next to each other.

It's not bad, but it doesn't feel like a passion project. It feels like the devs had an idea for a procedurally generated metroidvania but got bored with it and put out a decent but ultimately pretty boring game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997328781', 'num_games_owned': 749, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2554, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 727, 'last_played': 1644286750}
review:
[h2]A Brief Summary[/h2]

You are The Main Character, knight apprentice who is sent to check on a small mining town when they lose touch with the rest of the kingdom. What you find there might go a bit beyond the skills of an apprentice, but it's not like you could just go get reinforcements, right?

Right?

[h2]A Brief Review[/h2]

Well, here we are - another procedurally generated Metroidvania. I dunno, man, there are just a hell of a lot of Metroidvanias running around out there, and this randomly generated stuff is all kinda samey. So how about Chasm? How does it stand up?

It's... not bad.

Chasm has a pleasing 16 bit quality to it, with attractive environments and a choice between great chiptunes or great orchestrated music - either way is a win, and having the choice is neat. There's a feel of exploration that I enjoy, and there are plenty of things to find and uncover as you rescue the villagers. The controls are pretty darn good, too - not Dead Cells perfect, but pretty close.

The procedural generation is per save in this one, instead of per run. That means that every time you descend into the Chasm on one save, it'll be the same, but if you start a new game, you'll get a new layout. This is an excellent way to give a game replay value, but it's somewhat let down by the lack of variety in the dungeons. They're great, but I don't think (I haven't beaten it yet, so I don't know for sure) just shuffling them around is going to make a significant difference; it's just going to make one person's play-though a bit different than another's. That's fine as far as it goes, but I don't think it was the goal.

Another thing that could have been addressed with the procedural generation is to have put more found equipment in the dungeon. This is especially true of the sub weapons, which are mostly purchased from a vendor in the village (at least, so far). I would have preferred to unlock them as random drops or to find them in different places depending on the RNG, but this is fine. 

One thing I really don't care for though is the crafting system. It's not that it's bad, it's that it's not especially interesting or well implemented, so it doesn't really ad anything to the game. I'd rather just buy the stuff from a vendor or find it in the dungeon. 

Another small complaint is the shovel. This is really petty, but you get a shovel to dig through certain areas, and you have to equip it and de-equip it as a standard weapon. Not all of the buttons on a standard controller are mapped in the game, so mapping the shovel to a dedicated key would have been much, much less annoying. It wouldn't be so bad if the shovel was a decent weapon, but it's not, so when you need it it's pause, equipment menu, equip shovel, unpause, dig, pause, equipment menu, equip better weapon, unpause, continue the game. It's tedious and it really didn't have to be that way.

Fortunately, the core gameplay loop is entertaining enough to carry multiple playthroughs (or it it for me so far, anyway). The game is charming, the music is quite good, and it presents a decent challenge. All in all, I say go for this one. 7 out of 10, there are much worse ways to spend your money. 

Side Note: I got this on sale, but I think it's worth full price. I guess I just got lucky on that one ;-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198029186921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1354, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1344, 'last_played': 1578753062}
review:
[u]Positives[/u]

+ Wide range of weapons, allowing for different attack strategies.
+ Varied environments for each area, with their own unique styles
+ A good selection of skill upgrades, allowing for more skilful movement as the game progresses
+ After finishing the game at the normal difficulty setting, the challenge seemed spot on.
+ The random loot drops and procedurally generated levels make for a nice twist on the genre

[u]Negatives[/u]

- The procedural generation of levels means that the game has missed out on creating some truly intricate and memorable levels or areas within those levels
- The skill upgrades have not been utilised to their full potential, with some feeling like they are only used to get past a specific section or puzzle as opposed to adding to later game strategy

[u]Overall[/u]

I had a great time playing this game and would recommend it to all fans of platform games. I picked it up for around £6 in the sale, and it was fantastic value for money. I cannot say whether the procedural generation is going to add in terms of replayability, but I am looking forward to re-attempting at the next difficulty level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961951106', 'num_games_owned': 1565, 'num_reviews': 289, 'playtime_forever': 1385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1385, 'last_played': 1578175753}
review: Disclosure: I play almost no platformers and among those few this might be the first metroidvania - can't remember. I did two playthroughs - first on Hard, second on Easy. I'm gonna spare you a tirade that I already had typed out and just say that I find the game ridiculously difficult - in terms of level scaling, enemy HP, player HP etc. I was seriously considering giving a thumbs down just because of this. The game expects you to grind in place, stockpile consumables, overlevel to have a chance and this is acceptable to me in a JRPG but not in a platformer. Onto the positives. The biggest one that comes to mind is the atmosphere. The snowy village, [i]it's music[/i] and the aesthetic of the first world all combined made me feel like I was playing Icewind Dale 1 or Diablo 1 way back when, captured in a side-scrolling format. This is high praise coming from me. The game world is not at all fleshed out in terms of what goes on beyond but it has this delightfully generic quality akin to a quickly hacked together AD&D campaign in middle school. I got no complaints about the pixel art or underlying engine (only saw two minor bugs) and the music is very good. Occasionally the vibration on my gamepad would get stuck on full blast, requiring me to replug it. Winning the game once unlocks a bunch of new options for playing again, such as permadeath mode and "classes" (heavily influences level-up stat gains to force a particular build, ex. magical). On my second playthrough I encountered lots and lots of rooms which were not present in the first. This might be due to the different difficulty level or there may be enough of them prepared that only a random handful get chosen for a newly generated world. Either way - pretty cool. So if you're experienced in the genre I can safely recommend this. If not, this is more of a question mark, and if you want to get all achievements as well then I recommend [i]against[/i] it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071985830', 'num_games_owned': 727, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 886, 'last_played': 1578156589}
review:
I remember back in the day when there was quite a bit of excitement about this game and after the release how much disappointed those who played it were. Having played it I can see why. 

The Chasm borrows heavily from Castlevania. The leveling, monster drops, equipment, even subweapons are almost identical and that's not really a bad thing but there's nothing to the game besides that formula. It gives off a feel like there was something else there, some ideas of its own that were scrapped later on.

On a mechanical level the game is pretty solid. On my playthrough I didn't encounter any bugs or jankyness. One big problem I did encounter is weird difficulty; every boss except the last one were a cakewalk since you can chug potions or sometimes even stand still spam the attack button. In fact I haven't died until about 7 hours into the game. Things got a bit harder in two of the last areas. With the last area having mobs that would kill me in about 3 hits. Having less and less saverooms was a real pain when you died and wasted about 15 minutes. I stopped before I beat the final boss because I just couldn't be bothered anymore.

To finish on a positive note the music was quite enjoyable, although I mostly listened to the chiptune version. While there wasn't much detail in the tilesets they looked nice and fit well into the theme of the area.

I can only recommend  this game if you're a fan of the metroidvania genre, but don't expect anything new from it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025557930', 'num_games_owned': 1359, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 683, 'last_played': 1578136940}
review:
I do recommend this game, BUT only if you're very into metroidvania stuff and don't know what to play.

The whole point of random generated map is seriously flawed. It's pretty much just reorder the room and that's it? you still fight same bosses, get same key items in the same order. And because every room is randomly placed based on seed, the whole map is boring as hell. Gameplay-wise I like the feel of this game. It's responsive and really feel like playing GBA/DS Castlavania (like, even the animation is there). So if this isn't what you're looking for, it's not worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980371475', 'num_games_owned': 2410, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1578035845}
review:
While I have overall enjoyed my time with Chasm, this thumbs down comes exclusively due to the crash bugs that I have experienced while playing this game. While two crashes in four hours of playtime might not seem like enough to warrant a negative review, these crashes were severe. The first corrupted the entire game installation and required me to uninstall and reinstall it. Then after rebooting my computer the game would finally launch again. Of note, I know the exact cause of this bug although due to its severity I have not attempted to reproduce it. My wireless keyboard ran out of batteries in the middle of playing (I was using an Xbox One controller and so didn't notice). Upon plugging the keyboard in the game crashed and corrupted. 

The second crash was so bad that programs on my computer would no longer execute and I had to perform a hard reset of my whole system to fix it. Note that my computer is custom built with a very limited number of programs running on it at any time. It also has the latest drivers and Windows firmware updates, and exceeds the system requirements of this game by several orders of magnitude. 

I have nearly 1500 games in my Steam library. Probably over 500 of them played on this computer. Of those not a single one has ever caused me to hard reset my machine. That includes AAA titles, indies, classics, and random forgotten relics that I'm running in emulators like DOSBox. And if an already awful game from the mid-nineties can manage to not crash my whole system, I expect an otherwise good game that is only a year old and still receiving regular updates to achieve that bare minimum requirement.

As such, despite very much enjoying this game, I have to recommend people stay away unless these bugs are fixed or people want to risk damaging their systems.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980054291', 'num_games_owned': 2277, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 658, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1578002991}
review:
A genuinely good Metroidvania that is mechanically excellent. But lacks that truly beautiful world design, probably due to the procedurally generated map. It's not a roguelike, just every new game world is procedurally generated.

It might never live up to the likes of Blasphemous or Hollow Knight when it comes to presentation, but the gameplay is very solid, exploration is satisfying and the upgrades, while none particularly original, make progression very satisfying.

review:
Chasm has everything metroidvania game needs, following the canonical features of the genre. You start with nothing, you get permanent upgrades/abilities that allow you to progress and you return to early locations to find new routes with your new powers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020385919', 'num_games_owned': 1478, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 945, 'last_played': 1577071487}
review:
Todo mundo já deve ter jogado algum jogo estilo Metroidvania pelo menos uma vez na vida, como os jogos da antiga série de Castlevania ou alguns indies mais famosos como Hollow Knight, agora imagine o fato de jogar um metroidvania que sempre é alterado ao iniciar um novo jogo, com todos os power ups colocados em lugares diferentes e  tendo que fazer sequência de telas totalmente diferentes a cada novo jogo, então deixe me apresentar melhor o mundo de Chasm.

Ao começar o jogo somos apresentados um pouco a sua lore, nela nosso personagem principal é um recruta do reino de Guildean no qual é encaminhado para sua primeira missão, essa missão consiste em investigar o sumiço de alguns moradores de uma vila e enfrentar um monstro no qual vem causando confusões no mesmo.Claramente esse é apenas um resumo da história do jogo no qual vai se desenrolando conforme avançamos no jogo, mas não pense que a história é tão impactante ou divertida, já que acaba sendo uma narrativa um pouco cansativa de se ler, sendo uma história bem básica para a jornada do herói. para tentar concertar isso Chasm introduz alguns livros como coletáveis que tentam explicar alguns acontecimentos no jogo mais aprofundados na história do grande chefe e no desaparecimento dos cidadãos do vilarejo, mas novamente de uma leitura bem chata e não tão empolgante.

Já o gameplay do jogo é bem fluido e divertido, inicialmente nosso personagem poderá apenas pular e dar golpes comuns com sua espada, assim sendo mais incrementado conforme os powerups que pegamos ao longo dos mundos que visitamos, podendo dar pulos duplos, se agarrar em paredes, nadar e outros que serão essenciais para visitar todos os locais do mapa.Cada arma que nosso herói adquire ao vencer inimigos terá uma forma de manuseio diferente e alcances distintos para acertar os inimigos, espadas terão alcances médios e uma velocidade média, adagas serão super rápidas mas com um curto alcance e martelos ou espadas de duas mão serão compridas e fortes porém bem lentas de se utilizar.Logo Chasm lhe dá a liberdade de você escolher o seu estilo de combate com essas diversas armas,vale lembrar que o herói também poderá usar magias de combate que podem ser adquiridos ao salvar um dos cidadãos do vilarejo.

E falando mais dos cidadãos do vilarejo, essa é praticamente uma das quest principais do jogo, não só para fazer 100%, nele mas para conseguir ter uma facilidade em avançar nos mundos. Cada cidadão poderá te ajudar com alguma especialidade que eles tem, o ferreiro pode lhe vender armaduras e armas no qual podem lhe dar bons atributos para avançar nas telas, a padeira pode lhe fornecer comida no qual é essencial para recuperar sua vida, a maga pode lhe dar magias novas para ter ataques melhores contra alguns inimigos e entre outros que não citei aqui. Cada um estará perdido de forma aleatória no mapa então vale a pena explorar bem cada mundo.

Chasm também tem suas Side-quests que podem ser adquiridas com os cidadãos do vilarejo, grande parte deles vão pedir para entregar algum item específico, em troca lhe darão pequenas recompensar ou vão melhorar seus arsenais para que o herói possa comprar itens melhores, no final acaba sendo até que útil pois as recompensas ajudam muito no decorrer do jogo lhe dando mais atributos para enfrentar inimigos.

Sim. Chasm contém um sistema de atributo,sendo Força,Sorte,Inteligência,Vitalidade. Nosso herói tem um sistema de level up no qual derrotando monstros ele evolui e ganha atributos aleatórios, vale lembrar que aqui não é igual Ragnarok que podemos escolher e montar uma build específica. O mais importante nesse sistema é as armaduras e armas que o herói possui, todos eles têm atributos importantes e um sistema de raridade no qual pode deixar nosso herói muito mais forte ao longo da jornada, também é possível usar alguns pergaminhos que acabam fornecendo um atributo aleatório para o herói.

Sobre os mundos,existem um total de 5 mundos que poderão ser visitados, cada um com sua trilha sonora específica e monstros totalmente criativos na forma de pixel art, vale ressaltar que esse é um aspecto muito bom do jogo os gráficos em pixel art estão incríveis e muito bem desenhados, para dar uma vida extra no jogo existe também o bestiário no qual o herói deve matar alguns inimigos inúmeras vezes para registrá-los e assim saber um pouco de seu lore e itens que podem ser dropados.

Chasm pode ser muito divertido no início mas acaba se tornando bem enjoativo conforme sua trajetória, sua história é bem fraca de fato e os personagens secundários e cidadãos da vila são totalmente fracos, por não ter muitos acontecimentos o jogo se torna um “visita aqui mata ali” não tendo um algo a mais ou momentos épicos, até mesmo os chefes se tornam bem sem graças ao enfrentá los. Logo Chasm se torna um simples metroidvania que tem seu valor sim, mas está muito longe de ser um indie de peso comparado com outros Metroidvanias por aí.

Nota: 7/10

review:
Wondered why so many reviews praise the early game and then give it a thumbs down.  Well no more. This game has brilliant first hours and then pace slows down until you either get bored - or in my case just plain stuck. I spent the last 1½ hours systematically going through maps and looking for something - anything i might have missed as i could not advance any further in any of the areas i had access to. 

Broken world generation? hard to tell but i gave a very good effort trying to figure what it could be but then it's just time to give up and uninstall which i did. Better luck next time. author: {'steamid': '76561197972087465', 'num_games_owned': 2036, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1576982900}
review:
(Note: I played most of this in Offline mode, hence the playtime.)

Chasm was one of my most anticipated Metroidvanias this decade; sharp art design, SOTN influence, procgen world leading to infinite replayability? How could I not be excited?

Well, a few things happened. One, a billion games came out, and wanting replayability no longer became a value add to me. And procgen games had already started to wear thin, with aggravating dupe rooms, dead ends, and an overwhelming feeling of malaise. Two, A Robot Named Fight came out, and was everything Chasm had promised but for Metroid. So how would that impact my enjoyment of Chasm now that it’s finally here?

It’s going to be impossible not to compare the two games, so I will talk about why both inhabit the space without pushing the other out. Like a double helix, these two games!

What ARNF gets right is all in the seed generation and content. Because it takes inspiration from games like the Binding of Isaac, you are constantly unlocking new ways to play in your runs, which the seed generation incorporates. Both games do an adequate job of building a world map that does not result in an unwinnable state, but because ARNF gets content updates and has all the unlocks to manage, that makes it all the more impressive that it continues to hold together.

But if it doesn’t feel right, then it’s all for naught, and this was my constant issue with Fight, and where Chasm shines. ARNF’s movement and aiming is clunky and feels like a low budget Axiom Verge, while Chasm is responsive and fun to traverse. Combat in Chasm is along the lines of Castlevania, with meaty axe swings, quick sword thrusts and swift daggers (a high risk/reward option as their range is very short). You also have magic you can wield in a pinch, although I did not use it much.

But the map is a deficiency for both in certain ways. In ARNF I experienced dead ends, a roguelite crime. In Chasm, was encountered at least five duplicate rooms in my play through. Chasm also relies on the vertical tunnel too often, and in the early going... hey, it’s exciting to see where each path leads. But when you haven’t saved in twenty minutes and none of the paths lead to a save room, it’s a bit aggravating. Especially when warp scrolls cost as much as two health hi-potions.

Speaking of saves, ARNF is about do-it-or-die single runs, so its fast travel and saves are limited (is there even fast travel? I forget), while Chasm has no permadeath or even a penalty for dying, so the challenge is not quite as high. Naturally enemies get stronger, but that’s about it. So you can be aggressive in scouting further and further, as long as you have the healing items to keep you alive.

Rescuing villagers will send them back to town to open up shops, but I was a bit disappointed here, because I had hoped for a bigger visual revamp as the town gets back up to speed, and the shops don’t carry a ton of products even after you fulfill each townie’s side quest.

Visually, Chasm kicks ARNF in the tush (pardon my language!!) with gorgeous character animations and map detail. But let’s be honest here, this was not a hard competition, as Fight traces over elements of Super Metroid with reckless abandon.

Your purchasing decision will ultimately come down to what kind of game you want. I feel that both are a 7.5 out of 10, so which do you prefer: a conventional SOTN style game whose procgen feels pointless and detracts from the experience (Chasm) or a Metroid-like that will kill you over and over, which you’ll play for 100 hours (Fight)? Personally I prefer Chasm because I like to finish what I start and move on, but your tastes may be different.

Chasm doesn’t live up to the expectations of the Kickstarter, but it’s a perfectly serviceable game in the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198197048946', 'num_games_owned': 71, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1582459908}
review:
Chasm é um jogo lindo, sem dúvidas, mas quando compramos um jogo, buscamos mais do que isso, e é nesse "mais" que ele deixa a desejar.

Após anos de desenvolvimento, chasm chegou "datado". Com um sistema procedural que não cria um mapa/salas a cada vez que você morre, e sim um mundo a cada vez que você inicia um novo gameplay, levando isso em conta, ser ou não ser procedural, não muda nada, as salas principais, são sempre as mesmas, o que muda é o trajeto, e ainda assim, muda muito pouco.

Sobre a história, ela é bem simples, uma jornada do herói clássica.

Sobre o gameplay, ele é divertido, pelo menos depois que você aprende a lidar com algumas mecânicas "zoadas". O dash, que só vai para trás, e eventualmente, se você aparta o direcional enquanto usa o dash, o personagem vira e vai de costas em direção ao inimigo, juntando isso com o fato dele não cancelar o dano, acaba sendo meio inútil.
O sistema de wall jump, além de inutilizar uma melhoria adquirida anteriormente, é bem esquisito.
As side quests se resumem a buscar algo para algum npc que você salvou anteriormente.

O mapa é relativamente grande, e vazio, talvez por ser procedural, e isso pode fazer com que você se perca, além de ser cansativo, pois os checkpoints tendem a ser distantes, te obrigando a ficar perambulando pelos corredores das dungeons correndo o risco de morrer.

Chasm é um jogo genérico, não que isso seja ruim, mas quando se soma essa falta de originalidade a mecânicas ruins, você tem um jogo não tão legal. Por mais divertido que possa ser, para mim chasm é aquele tipo de jogo que não vale ser rejogado. Se adquirido com um desconto bacana, vale a pena.

review: Chasm é um jogo curioso, ele demorou bastante para ser lançado e na época que foi anunciado ela seria uma inovação gigante e possivelmente um dos melhores jogos do gênero, após 5 anos de adiamento enfim chegou Chasm, ele não inova em nada porém não deixa de ser relevante, joga-lo foi divertido seu combate é maravilhoso e responsivo, falta variedade de armas secundárias porém as primarias são boas, suas músicas são muito boas, e sua pixel arte é bem refinada, porém o mapa desse jogo é relativamente ruim pois ele não marca pontos importantes a não ser baús, ele podia ter o sistema de marcadores igual Hollow Knight, apesar de seus erros Chasm ainda é um jogo divertido e uma experiencia interessante sendo uma fácil recomendação.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049433567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1577689902}
review: Overall a pretty positive first hour of gameplay, which is more than I can say for a lot of metroidvanias/indie games/humble bundle stuff. I actually broke an hour and am considering going back for more. On the whole, I agree with the critical points made by most of the positive and critical reviews that the procedural element doesn't seem to add much, it seems very much like something you're likely to only play through once, although honestly the procedural elements are fluid enough that I kinda forgot every now and then it was randomly generated. First boss fight was pretty fluid and a good mix of options for dealing with enemies and enemy progression seems okay. All in all pretty solid.

author: {'steamid': '76561198162388568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1577594807}
review:
The game at its core is great, if you are interested in lore, it is there, soundtrack feels atmospheric, but I believe it could be just a bit better.
Combat wise it feels very limited, I have been meaning to use different weapons, but the fact that swords just overpower every other weapon is a bit underwhelming. Armor upgrades feel very satisfactory.
Magic is where i find the game to be very lacking, the spells are useful, but the very small selection of spells really let me down, not even mentioning that there is no elemental spell whatsoever, since they were removed.
Overall, I recommend the game if you want a quick, but definitely not bad experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198807269583', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1577594058}
review: Chasm is a perfectly average platformer. It is not necessarily that bad, but almost every aspect of the game is just ho-hum okay to bland. The soundtrack; passable, but not stellar. The gameplay; solid for what it is. The graphics; again, a solid pixel game. The story; it does indeed have a story. I can't complain much about Chasm, largely due to the method by which I acquired it (a random online giveaway). I also haven't played much, compared to the amount other players seem to have sunk into the game. But I digress. Chasm may be a worthwhile experience for you. The asking price is quite high, so waiting for a sale if you want to take the game out for a spin should be a given. All in all, Chasm is an average game. Simply put, a so-so game at worst, a solid one at best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106152551', 'num_games_owned': 1233, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 930, 'last_played': 1577386868}
review:
Ho visto tante recensioni negative su questo titolo. Mi sento dunque in dovere di dire la mia, cercando di fare un po' di ordine e sottolineare quelli che sono sia i pregi sia i difetti di Chasm.

[h1]Introduzione[/h1]
Chasm è un metroidvania procedurale nato su kickstarter. La storia non offre chissà quali novità, siamo un cadetto inviato in un villaggio di minatori per far luce sulle disgrazie che da poco tempo si sono abbattute sugli abitanti. E' proprio a partire da questo punto che muniti di spada ci avventureremo nelle gallerie sotterranee, uccidendo mostri e affrontando boss.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Chasm presenta la [b]classica struttura dei più classici metroidvania[/b], ci saranno una serie di aree collegate tra di loro da scorciatoie. Ogni area avrà zone irraggiungibili o segrete, almeno fino a quando non otterremo degli upgrade che ci consentiranno di farlo tornando indietro e riesplorando la zona.
I nemici sono molteplici e abbastanza variegati. Ognuno di loro, anche i più comuni, possiedono un paio di move set che li rendono discretamente interessanti. 
La difficoltà generale è [b]medio/bassa[/b], ulteriormente abbassata dalla possibilità di fermare il gioco a inventario aperto ed usare pozioni a manetta.
In compenso la [b]struttura delle zone è molto buona[/b], sia come ambientazione che come disposizione stanze. [b]Esplorare non mi ha per niente annoiato, anzi.[/b]

[h1]In generale[/h1]
+Un titolo abbastanza solido...
+Buona l'atmosfera sia a livello di musica che comparto grafico (pur parlando di una pixel art abbastanza minimale)
+Si lascia giocare fino alla fine
+Bilanciato sia a livello di minions che boss...

-... ma rimane un classico metroidvania. Nessuna novità o qualcosa che mi abbia particolarmente colpito.
- Storia quasi assente e lineare
- ... come già scritto nella sezione gameplay la possibilità di far scorte di pozioni permettono di fare fuori i boss al primo tentativo senza difficoltà. Mi rendo conto che resta a discrezione del giocatore, tuttavia anche mentalmente il pericolo "Morte", diventa quasi assente.
- Un platform procedurale ? Ebbene sì, la struttura del mondo dovrebbe essere leggermente diversa da giocatore a giocatore. Nonostante questa unica novità il risultato è deludente. Insomma anche se le stanze hanno ordine leggermente diverso nulla cambia se giocato da me a qualcun altro. Anzi, l'unica cosa che si aggiunge è una leggera difficoltà nel caso in cui si cerchino delle guide online con mappe che ovviamente mai corrispondono alla propria.

[h1]Conclusioni[/h1]
Pur avendo elencato non pochi difetti penso che Chasm faccia il suo lavoro. E' un gioco che intrattiene e diverte fino alla fine. Non il più memorabile dei platform vania, ma una run ve la farete volentieri.

-Al

review: Se você busca um metroidvania raiz, esse é o jogo para você. Confesso que minha estréia no gênero foi com esse jogo, o que me fez gostar bastante da experiência. A história por mais simples que seja, é cativante e prende a atenção para conclui-la.  A dificuldade se encontra na movimentação engessada do personagem, e de certa forma isso é um ponto positivo no jogo, que procura fazer uma homenagem (quase uma cópia, eu diria) ao clássico Castlevania Simphony of the Night. Entretanto, os cenários serem gerados proceduralmente gera um certo desconforto na campanha principal.

review:
Um bom jogo, mas que poderia ser um ótimo jogo.
Pros:
Bons gráficos
Trilha sonora marcante, possui versão 8 bits também
Jogabilidade simples 
Não é difícil

Contras:
Muitos inimigos não possuem ligação lógica com o cenário/lore
O comando de dash para trás não tem nenhuma utilidade prática
Necessidade de dar backtrack (revisitar) no mapa por muitas vezes
Lore mal apresentada
Inimigos possuem padrão de golpes muito parecidos
Alguns glitches visuais, mas que são raros e não atrapalham nada a jogabilidade.


Esse jogo tem potencial de ser melhor ainda com pequenos ajustes.
Por exemplo: 
Coletar os orbes azuis mesmo ao sair do mapa enquanto eles estão se aproximando do herói.
Ter diversos símbolos e cores para marcar o mapa. Existem variados eventos que só liberam com itens chave, fora a necessidade de dar backtrack, então isso facilitaria a revisitar os locais sem acesso.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992142036', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3105, 'last_played': 1577046844}
review:
Despite the improvements made over the years, way back when it was in beta, Chasm is not only a lengthy game, but is also very drawn out. It isn't unlikely that your first run through will require some to keep backtracking, say, from the keep back to the mines just to get an artifact and head back to where you once were. Many times I head back to where I think I need to progress but end up finding only a junk chest and have to head back and find a teleporter room.

It is a fun game. The weapons are fun to play around with, the [always respawning] enemies have a fairly unique pattern, and there is no need to grind for any levels once you get used to the easy, smooth, and responsive controls. 

However, like I mentioned earlier, for the amount of backtracking you have to do, the respawning enemies after just going from one room to the next, and uselessness of going back to the surface is annoying is enough to make me not recommend this game to everyone. The concept of a randomly generated Castlevania-esque adventure was quite ambitious, and a great idea on paper, but the game feels so terribly drawn out at a consequence. I wouldn't see myself searching for everything that there is to find in this game, just finish it and move on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017033103', 'num_games_owned': 1426, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1576781282}
review: It's a fine game, but has nothing that would make it special among its peers. The fact that the game world is randomly generated from parts instead of being fully designed by hand creates an messy maze, with the possibility that rooms will have the same design and enemy/corridor placement. I've had at least one dupe room in every area. The progression also gets really bad later on, with worse drops than those in midgame, and game ending before you can even manage to get stuff for endgame crafting. At least enemy diversity is quite nice, art direction is good and combat is fun, but easy to break with game's magic system.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009744465', 'num_games_owned': 6422, 'num_reviews': 177, 'playtime_forever': 2075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1645855211}
review:
Неплохая "метроидвания"на твердую четверку с плюсом.

Игра выполнена в ретро-стиле, начало несколько затянуто и геймплей поначалу однообразен - карты подземелий генерируются самим компьютером и комнаты сегментов подземелий выглядят не слишком различающимися, практически без своих "изюминок". Хотя как и в любой "метроидвании" такие изюминки есть, и нам придется возвращаться на старые места не раз. Тут, кстати, всплывает и еще один из главных недостатков игры - подобные "места интересов" на общей карте подземелий никак не отмечены (кроме сейвпоинтов и системы перехода между районами подземелий) и учитывая размеры самого подземелья приходится с трудом вспоминать где и что ты видел, когда приходит для этого время. В результате игру довольно сложно продолжить через какое-то время, немного отдохнув от однотипного прохождения. Приходится заново пробегать подземелье вспоминая где там и что, а это опять быстро надоедает.

Блокировать персонаж пока что не умеет, вместо этого может отпрыгнуть, но с учетом заторможенной отработки нажатия нужной кнопки джойстика сделать это часто не удается вовремя. Управление вообще слегка заторможено и не всегда регистрируются нажатия кнопок джойстика, что не есть хорошо, так как прыгать приходится много, а позже во время прыжков еще и использовать парашют. Впрочем, игра достаточно медленная и в большинстве случаев это не критично.

В остальном всё довольно обычно и чуть выше среднего по больнице.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1940165340

Игра не ограничивается стори-моде, есть дневные и недельные челенджы, которые позволяют посоревноваться в прохождении одинаковых для всех претендентов рандомногенерируемых лабиринтов.

Ачивки в игре сложны в получении и тем кого напрягают пройденные меньше чем на 20% всего сета ачив игры лучше за игру даже не браться.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034315837', 'num_games_owned': 7747, 'num_reviews': 764, 'playtime_forever': 2247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1576654733}
review:
A solid metroidvania but one whose approach doesn't really fit with its 'selling point' of being procedurally generated.

The game would have been better with a fully handcrafted experience so you can enjoy a better game in your first and usually only playthrough rather than try to entice you with multiple runs just to experience the same rooms in different order. The haphazard approach the the random generation of room structures invariably means the level design as a whole suffers relative to a well thought planned approach to proper level structure that the metroidvania genre in its best iterations is known for.

If you want to try a similar game that does this procedural concept better try Rogue's Legacy. This game is worth a shot too if you're a genre fan though. It's still solid even with those level layout issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979982910', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1575689545}
review:
Ehh...I'm going to go back and give it one more fair shake, but this game feels pretty much "fine". It would earn a mythical "sideways thumb" if it existed, but in absence my hand has been forced. 

The combat feels pretty bland - which surprised me, as I noted one update was focused entirely on improving combat. If it was worse before this, I can't really imagine how; this feels like the most basic that combat can get. 

Chasm doesn't feel like it does anything interesting or new - which doesn't disqualify it from being good in-and-of-itself - but it's mechanics also aren't good enough to make up for it. It also lacks things like a deep pool of game changing power ups - powers that do exist are spaced out strangely, can come too slowly, and make too little difference; you don't really feel more powerful or like you can play differently. The overall game speed feels slow, the jumping is kind of floaty/finnicky (even though it works fine in practice)...

Bottom line is it just doesn't *feel* good to play. It's fine. It doesn't do anything poorly, but there are much better examples of this kind of game out there.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980771676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 553, 'playtime_forever': 641, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1576479333}
review:
[h1]Hörst du den Abgrund nach dir rufen, lieber Metroidvania-Fan?[/h1]

Ich war anfangs ein wenig über die schlechten Bewertungen erschrocken und kann sie (Stand heute) absolut nicht nachvollziehen. Mag sein, dass es dank dutzender Patches, die ich alle nicht mitbekam, für mich als Spätzünder-Gamer nicht mehr nachvollziehbar sein kann, aber der Artstyle kann's nicht gewesen sein - so schön wie das 16 Bit Abenteuer aussieht, sieht selten ein Retro-Game aus. Ich hab mich echt schon lange über den Release des Spiels gefreut und wurde nicht enttäuscht.

In Chasm geht's durch eine zufällig (aber einmalig für den jeweiligen Spielstand für immer gleichbleibende) generierte Dungeon-Landschaft, die sich an diversen 0815-Settings orientiert: Mine, Folterkeller, Gärten, Festung und Lavahöhle. Diese erkunden wir nach und nach und obwohl sie zufällig generiert ist, wirkt sie nicht störend baukasten-förmig, sondern in sich stimmig, auch wenn einzigartige Locations viel zu selten sind. Aber wirklich gestört hat es mich nicht. Das Hochleveln, Ausrüsten, Quests erfüllen, neue Fähigkeiten erwerben und in die entlegensten Winkel vorrücken hat einfach dauerhaft enorm viel Spaß gemacht - eben auch, wenn das Geschehen mit toller Musik untermalt wird, die man auch noch als Chiptune-Version aktivieren und hören kann. Was habe ich mich aber in die Standard-Musik vom Game verliebt. Soooooooooooooooooo toll!

Das Gegnerdesign ist sehr schön, teilweise sehr fordernd (auch auf Leicht).
Nur die Story und die expliziten Hinweise wie es jetzt weiter geht, haben gefehlt.

Nichtsdestotrotz für jeden Metroidvania-Fan empfehlenswert!

author: {'steamid': '76561198034118715', 'num_games_owned': 4134, 'num_reviews': 508, 'playtime_forever': 849, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 849, 'last_played': 1576416627}
review:
グラフィックだけは褒めておきたい、つまりそれ以外はあんまり褒められないドット絵メトロヴァニア。特に、ステージをランダム生成することの利点がさっぱりわからない。

入り口から道なりに右に行くとキーアイテムがあって取ると左へ行けるみたいな、進行上必要なユニーク部屋の位置関係そのものは固定。それらを繋ぐ通路部分だけがランダム生成っぽいのだが、つまりステージの大半は特になんの演出意図もこもっていない、ただただ部屋と部屋を繋ぐだけの無味乾燥な通路。

何回生成し直そうが最初右に行ってアイテムを取って引き返して左っていう大筋に変化はないし、そもそも死んでもロードしてやり直すだけで再生成なんかしない。本当になんの意味があるんだこれ。

また戦闘のメカニズムもダメな方向にシナジーを生んでいる気がする。

このゲーム、通常攻撃をバクステでキャンセルできない。一度振り始めたら最後までやり切ってしまう。普通に敵に近付いて殴ると絶対にモーション中に殴り返されるので、近付いて攻撃を誘う→離れて空振りさせる→また近付いて殴る、が基本戦法になる。

離れて空振りさせられるだけの空間が後ろにないと話にならない。なので通路が広い。ちょっと歩いて敵がいて、またしばらく歩いて敵がいて、と散発的にしか接敵しない。そんな通路がランダムでこれでもかと生成される。面白さの密度が薄い。

いっこいっこの要素はさほど悪いとも思えないので、きちんとまとめ上げて方向性を与えてやれば次回作で化けそうな可能性はある。もちろん化けない可能性もいっぱいある。そんなゲーム。

author: {'steamid': '76561198193576345', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 1174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1576443882}
review:
I've played through this once on hard (be warned, starts out easy and gets much harder and you can't change the difficulty later on).  The visual aesthetic has a charming, grim Black Cauldron meets SNES appeal to it. The story is beyond forgettable and the music is pretty low-key.  

Its a metroidvania heavy on the castlevania side of the equation. While it has equipment and leveling up like SoTN the combat requires patience the way linear castlevania games do.   Traversing several corridors between save points can be rather daunting, I died countless times due to a combination of tricky monsters and getting sloppy when I'm in a hurry (such as when backtracking).  Strangely, the bosses frequently proved less difficult than the path to reach them because if you save 2 or three health potions you can spam attack them to death before really learning their patterns.  Most of the weapons and equipment are pretty boring, and the 'spells' (sub-weapons) are lifted directly out of the Konami series.  I found a couple hats that summoned familiars and I would have preferred that was a separate equipment slot so I could use other hats and keep the familiar active.  

The level design is pretty decent for a game that uses an RNG seed.  The rooms are well-populated with platforms, monsters, traps and treasures. Very reminiscent of Rogue Legacy, except the map is set. There is a lot of slow back-tracking in this and the fast travel spots can be kind of clumsily organized.  There are hidden corridors in walls, almost all of which I missed initially until I got an item that pings when they're nearby.  There are some minor puzzles “where do I take this item” kind of stuff scattered throughout, and it can be kind of annoying if you want to look up solutions because everyone's play-through is different. 

I've played 19 metroidvanias because it is one of my favorite genres. This one is about 12th in over-all quality for me, but it depends on how much you enjoy the aesthetics or heavy castlevania emphasis.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990189966', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 1018, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1576617514}
review:
Having just finished Blasphemous, this game's combat feels incredibly stiff and clunky. For my tastes, it is enough to not recommend.
That said, if you can look past how Chasm does combat, there is a lot to love about the game. 
- Randomly generated maps for replayability is a wonderful concept.
- Very solid Metroidvania game
- Boss battles are fun, fair, and challenging
- Great art

review:
The game was okay until I reached the presumably last area. Suddenly there are no more savepoints or quicktravel rooms. Instead you are faced with a lot of jumping puzzles and enemies that do abnormally high damage compared to anything you have met before.

That last part leaves the metroidvania area and becomes a roguelike. It's a pity. I somewhat liked the game. It was not stellar but still entertaining. There lies the problem: The mediocrity does not really motivate me to overcome the frustration of that last area.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188944435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2813, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 974, 'last_played': 1600121325}
review:
Very fun and quite difficult, metrovania, where every single enemy has a different behavior. The combat is simple, yet quite challenging, especially when multiple enemies of different personalities gang up on you. I found my playthrough to be extremely well-balanced. I was quite impressed. I am looking forward to second, I hope faster, playthrough.

 I just finished my second play through, and my opinion of the game has not decreased. This time it only took me 10 hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970477037', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1576390641}
review:
I enjoy the Metroidvania genre, but am in no way an expert player. While I finished the game on the default difficulty and enjoyed my time with it, I feel most of the value here will be for players that are interested in replaying the game multiple times, taking advantage of the random map generation and arcade mode.

The random map generation seemed very competent during my playthrough; the spacing of the save points was reasonable and for the most part rooms didn't appear repetitively. However, on more than one occasion did I open a chest to find an inferior weapon or piece of equipment, which was frustrating. In general I feel I missed out on seeing several pieces of equipment due to my map seed, so I would have preferred a default map with more curated treasures, and then the option to use a random seed for further play. 

If you're the type of person to only play through a game a single time, I wouldn't recommend this game unless it's on sale for under $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992082286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 918, 'last_played': 1576365633}
review:
Metroidvania simple y entretenido. Tiene sprites bonitos, variedad de enemigos y distintos biomas para recorrer. No tiene ninguna mecánica extremadamente complicada, y los bosses son sencillotes.

A veces parece que no puedes acceder a ciertos sitios por fallos del diseño del mapa, pero en realidad necesitas desbloquear habilidades para poder llegar. También tienes que buscarte la vida para encontrar cuál es el siguiente paso o la siguiente zona. A pesar de eso, no es difícil.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188201725', 'num_games_owned': 608, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1246, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1174, 'last_played': 1670350579}
review:
3/5 Stars.

The game feels great to play, the core mechanics are there that you want. It is fun to play and i had a blast... while it lasted. There is an art to level/game design that allows you to guide the player along their journey without actually instructing them, but still leaving a clearly defined "this should be where you need to go" direction. Sadly... they dropped the ball here and lost my interest after wandering around aimlessly for over 2 hours tracing back and forth over the same 3 maps, checking walls, levers, paths ... everything... only to find that my progression had been hindered by a "hidden" secret tunnel.

I had just had enough, That was a total waste of my time due to bad design.

Would i recommend it? Yes, it is fun and generally a great game. Would that recommendation come with a caution? Yes... it would.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993268783', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 549, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1576357383}
review:
This game is good to start, then slowly becomes exhausting, draining the enjoyment of the game, and that is the unfortunate side.

There are a lot of great aspects about the game itself, but I quickly began to realize the downside of the procedurally-assembled areas. For one, it causes mechanics for things like using the shovel to be in a spread of places, and the outcome of using the shovel is often an underwhelming reward. This means "inaccessible areas" may not always be progressive, they may in fact be worthless and underwhelming. That slowly grew on me, causing me to not want to finish the game. I was not overcoming challenges at that point, just roaming in between those challenges in a way that felt wasteful.

While I was having fun in the beginning, I quickly started to feel tired of the game. The challenges presented by combat and some of the rooms felt awesome, and I quite enjoyed learning boss mechanics and getting past parts...but the
journey started to make those end points feel not worth the time.

There is a lot of potential here, and I wish I could be more enthusiastic about, but it unfortunately fails to be 'exciting' and heads towards tedium.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061895759', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1576350914}
review:
Only one hour in and I'm already pissed, frustrated and bored. And I dig Metroidvanias to boot.

Game is slow, and you can't skip "cinematics" or dialogues.
Everything's a bit clunky. The character seems frail, and he attacks really slowly.
Even scrolling the map feels clunky.
Many enemies types are introduced in a way that you will be punished for not knowing how they work.
Nothing new under the sun. It just seems like a bad Castlevania.
There is a case of double inputs in the menu, and I use a Microsoft controller.
You can't change difficulty halfway through.
You don't even have any indication about what are the specifics of each difficulty level.
Fights resemble a one-button rythm game.
The art depatment's just meh.

And that's not the pointless achievements ("slain 100 foes") that will keep me trying not to die exploring samey aeas.
And I read it gets worse afterwards !
I even wonder if these guys played videogames before making this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990027567', 'num_games_owned': 1144, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 709, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1576342373}
review:
I went into this as the first metroidvania style game I've buckled down to play since Super Metroid. As a kid. Which I was -super- bad at. I was a bit...iffy at the procedurally generated dungeons up front, just because of the negative connotations that term has managed to get. However, I was very pleased with the game! A nice, simple control scheme, plenty of exploration, and bosses that challenge you. 

The only direct shortcoming, to me, is the magic system. Requiring jewels to upgrade meant that I was just ignoring magic for the most part, as farming for jewels to upgrade wasn't super worth the time to me. Be nice for a bit more experience given per gem, or higher drop rates when you get to the depths of the mines for the better ones.

All in all, on an arbitrary number scale, 9/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055530457', 'num_games_owned': 520, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 23, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23, 'last_played': 1576226541}
review:
This game is legitimately inferior to other popular metroidvania games like Hollow Knight and Blasphemous. I put barely any time into this game and already feel the need to uninstall. 

Some of my primary complaints are to do with the user experience and the quality of life. Simple things like tweaking audio and video are severely limited. Audio slider tweaks in increments of 5, while video has a simple resolution picker and a fullscreen Y/N feature. There is no windowed full screen and you can't drag the window to resize. 

Control scheme is clunky at best. Press a to jump, hold A to jump higher. Apparently there is a ledge grab but I never got far enough to find it. Y to dash backwards bu that very often hinders you more than it helps. I made it to level 3 before dying but never figured out what leveling up actually does for you, as there didn't seem to be any level up or ability or skill menu to speak of. Maybe one exists further in, but again, with no tutorial or explanation, I just felt like I was floundering. 

The story feels pretty half-assed. You're a generic knight in a generic country doing generic quests for generic reward. Fight skeletons and slimes and save the kingdom. Whoop-d-doo. 

I got to the first boss or mini boss, don't know which, in the first dungeon I came across. He had a simple attack scheme, but with no discernible way for me to heal myself mid fight and before long I died. Instead of throwing me back to one of the save statues or a city I've been in, it kicked me back to the title screen. This alone made me quit playing. In metroidvania games you die. A lot. If I'm gonna be going all the way back to the title screen every time I die, then I'm just going to take that as a sign from the developers that they don't really want me playing their game, and you know what? I don't want to be playing it anyways. 

Overall, I'm glad this game was in a Humble Bundle because I don't think I'd want to spend money on it otherwise, but I definitely cannot recommend this game to anyone. There are just far better metroidvania games out there, and some of them even feature pixel art.

review: A neat mixture of procedural generation and purposefully set pieces, with gorgeous music and art. This is one of the most polished metroidvanias I've ever played. Rather heavier on the 'vania than the Metroid, the homage to Symphony of the Night is obvious across the board in the controls and gameplay, although I've still yet to get used to the obligatory Castlevania backdash not cancelling out of attacks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054213808', 'num_games_owned': 886, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 462, 'last_played': 1593058328}
review:
it's been fun. I wish I hadn't learned that bosses give you extra drops if you kill them without getting hit, because I'm an obsessive completionist. that said, the bosses patterns are easy enough to figure out in a couple of kills, and then it's just a matter of finding the right actions to counter their few difficult attacks to counter.

I find that a good knife or glove blade are best for most bosses if you can get in range with them to stab them several times, with a larger weapon for platforming and the remaining bosses.

the variety of spells is interesting, but with a lack of mana regeneration it makes using anything other than the dagger (or shuriken/axe for some bosses) a waste of mana. the biggest waste of mana is the boomerang, that only goes in extremely close range, but does less damage than just hitting the enemy with your sword.

I was also disappointed to learn that the console version has classes that give you perks. I'd have preferred to play as a mage, with double the mana efficiency, or a rogue with guaranteed crits on backstabs. alas, no class selection on the PC/Steam version.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071206305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 1007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 766, 'last_played': 1665245277}
review: As a huge fan of Symphony of the Night, I found a lot to like in Chasm. The pixel art is superb, with detailed animation and great character design. There's a lot to explore and discover and a good variety of weapons to experiment with. The music is a little weak overall, favoring atmosphere over any truly inspiring tunes. While I know the game features procedural generation, it was seamless to the point where I wouldn't have noticed had I not already known. Worth playing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055509418', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1235, 'last_played': 1578164411}
review:
TL;DR - The update made things so much better, if you didn't like this game before, consider trying it again, they've fixed backtracking and a few other things with version 1.070.

A while back, I played a demo of this game at my local big-box store. From what I played of the demo, it was lots of fun. With a throwback to classic Gameboy Advance Metroidvanias such as Circle of the Moon and Harmony of Dissonance, it's a new take on one of my favorite genres of games. Initially, I was slightly discouraged from buying it, because I didn't have a good gaming laptop and it wasn't on any of the consoles I owned- but with a new laptop and a release on Nintendo Switch, I've finally had the chance to play the full game.

With the new 1.070 patch, it significantly cuts down on the amount of backtracking required and eases travel through the game's areas. The game only has two major puzzles, both of which are required to progress, but the patch eases things up (for one, you have to count the number of objects in three murals in one area, and in the other you find a song you play on bells in a tower to open a gate)

Personally, I find the mixture of set pieces and corridors to be a wise choice. There is some variety in the game's generated maps- it has enough differences and variations to feel new, but enough consistency that if you know what to look for, you'll have little trouble navigating around. You can mark areas of interest on the map, and an area where there's a chest or a breakable crate will always have a dot, though it may take just a little bit of looking to find what you're looking for.

Overall, it's a good game, a wonderful example of a Metroidvania, and an excellent throwback to the days of Castlevania on the GBA. I'd recommend this game to anyone who liked those games, as well as Symphony of the Night. The class system you unlock after the first playthrough is similar to Circle of the Moon's, in that it changes your starting stats, items, and growths, as well as a few other features, such as the Mage class recharging MP at save shrines.

8/10 - I think it was a little short, personally, but otherwise it's an excellent game, and a wonderful metroidvania.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980449859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 279, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1575908768}
review:
Approx 1 hour impressions- the pixel art is beautiful in the outdoor areas. Once you move into the mines it quickly becomes very generic 2D Indie Platformer stuff. 

The game follows a lot of the SotN Metroidvania conventions but in the most generic way possible. Rooms are designed by the devs but the way they are put together is randomized making even the early part of the game feel like a slog with no rhyme or reason to anything. Story is very bare as well, at least up the point I played. You're a knight in training with no personality and you get sent out to rescue some people. 

The story seems to be mostly told through dense writing that you find laying about rather than dialogue. 

Controls seem okay at first but there's a certain sluggishness to your actions that make it very hard to be precise. The backdash is awful, and jumping just seems off. It's tolerable but we've all played better. 

And I guess that sums up the game, but I have too much on my backlog to put up with tolerable for very long.

review:
Enjoyed the first half of the game. The second half requires you to think where to go as you'll have to revisit areas. Can get pretty frustrating. The major problem with this game is the item drop rate. You can have high luck, and still not get one of the two items after 100 kills.

This game rewards players for not rushing monsters. Once you study their attack patterns, you'll be able to kill them (and farm them 100+ times for the item) without taking damage. There's not much incentive studying bosses though, can just tank through them with full hp or potions if needed (and they don't respawn in story mode).
