review:
Decepción.

El pixel art es hermoso, sin embargo, por el diseño de niveles se vuelve  monótono y aburrido.
En 2 horas de juego solo he conseguido 2 armas, 1 armadura y un anillo, peleando con los mismo enemigos recoloreados, el juego tiene habitaciones repetidas, los puntos de guardado están tan separados que mejor no los hubiesen puesto.

Sinceramente pensé que después del area de la mina, el juego mejoraría, pero no, la segunda area es aún más repetitiva, si tal vez los desarrolladores hubieran construido los niveles en lugar de usar generación procedural el juego valdría la pena.

PD: si alguien conoce metroidvanias completamente opuestos a éste por favor háganme saber

author: {'steamid': '76561198336608168', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 3597, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1286, 'last_played': 1560528862}
review:
En el episodio de hoy de Manqueando... "hago Chasm y aparezco a tu lado"

El juego que nos ocupa hoy, de nuevo, es un metroid (mi guta muncho muncho). ¿Y como es? Pues a todos los efectos es el juego de super nintendo que nunca tuve y siempre quise.

Buen control, buena música, buen mapa (me refiero al mapa, no a los escenarios)... en resumen, todo bastante bien. Pero... ¿es perfecto? No, claro que no. Pero desde luego no es tan malo como parece ser por las calificaciones.

Desde luego que no es uno de los mejores y más originales juegos que he visto, pero la originalidad sin objetivo es un elefante blanco. A mi la originalidad me la pela. Y mucho. Lo único que me importa es que el juego sea divertido, y personalmente, ha cumplido con creces.

De modo que si eres una de esas personas que en cada juego busca algún tipo de reinvención del genero o gaitas por el estilo (cosa que me parece perfecta, cada cual tiene sus gustos), entonces mejor pasa de largo. Pero si lo único que te interesa es jugar a un juego que simplemente te aporte entretenimiento, creo que es una buena opción.

Por cierto... y esto no es que sea una pega, sino más bien una curiosidad. Este es un juego de cifras bajas. Con nv32, no he llegado a dar una jostia de 100. 
Otro dato, es que el juego viene recibiendo parches regularmente, ya sea para corregir bugs (no recuerdo haberme encontrado ninguno), como para añadir idiomas (en principio no estaba en español, ahora si), de modo que los desarroladores se preocupan del producto, cosa de agradecer.

Y poco más que añadir... le voy a cascar un 8 y lo recomiendo.

Y en el próximo Manqueando... "Odallus The Dark cagada"

author: {'steamid': '76561198254654242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 772, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 765, 'last_played': 1615548619}
review:
Overall, the game was pleasant enough to play, but it didn't "wow" me.

I was disappointed by the game's lack of imagination; it didn't show me anything that I haven't seen multiple times before. The enemies, settings and story were all role-playing-game cliches. The progression, combat and platforming were all metroidvania cliches. These prefab ideas were all put together in a competent way, but I don't feel the developers added nearly enough new things into the mix.

As other reviewers have noted, the procedural level layout doesn't add anything to the game, and it can leave the levels feeling sprawling and monotonous. All metroidvania games include some aimless backtracking (especially if you're aiming for 100% completion), but Chasm was a particularly bad offender.

The pixel art is some of the best that I've ever seen; it's the game's strongest feature by far.

The combat was hit-and-miss, but generally enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993670834', 'num_games_owned': 703, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1581624658}
review:
A lovingly crafted game with some very poor design decisions that make it needlessly hard.  I don't mind the procedural level design, I even kind of like it, but the lack of weapon choices for the first hour or so of the game, the limited save points, and the fact that you ONLY heal at the save points (enemies don't drop healing orbs or anything) quickly wore out my patience.

Aside from that, most things in the game are pretty average.  Combat is functional, but not exciting. If anything it's just annoying, and leveling up is a pointless linear exercise that feels like it was just added to let them use the "RPG" tag,

I was one of the original backers, but I really can't recommend it, especially not at full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067231972', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1611023489}
review:
This may be my first review ever on Steam. I've been tracking this game since its initial announcement (which I believe was 2012).
Lots of ups and downs in its development, done by a small team, and I have to say even if it isn't perfect, it's a darn-good entry in the Metroidvania genre.
Graphics are beautiful, and you can switch between a few different modes to make it look more NES/SNES-era or more modern.
Sound is pretty good, though I think I'd enjoy one or two additional tracks to increase variety.
Gameplay - a ton of fun IMHO. Yes it involves learning enemy patterns, and yes there's backtracking, and yes you have to learn how far/short your weapons will reach to make sure you don't die, but honestly I think it comes with the territory.
I think I would've enjoyed a little faster weapon-acquisition/gold acquisition, and a way to track the small number of sidequests (also one or two more sidequests would've been cool).
Overall I'd give it an 8, and I look forward to revisiting at least once more in the near future.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972126231', 'num_games_owned': 1176, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 875, 'last_played': 1656781335}
review:
No me parece una mala base para hacer algo mejor, pero en su estado actual es un juego de suspenso. No me ha parecido tan malo como para que no tenga redención pero francamente no puedo listar nada bueno y si bastantes cosas mal hechas:

-Hay momento en los que te quedas atascado sin ninguna pista. Eso está bien para un rato, pero cuando te pasas más de la mitad de la partida investigando sitios para tratar de saber por donde tirar (de las 14 horas que llevo probablemente lleve 9 sin avanzar y tengo experiencia en estos juegos) sabes que hay algo mal hecho. Para darte notas con pistas desde luego faltan bastantes.

-El mapa es bastante simple. No tan simple como Dead Cells de todas maneras, pero el sistema procedural no me parece bueno para este tipo de juegos. La gracia está en el laberinto bien pensado, la evolución del personaje y el backtracking todo bien mezclado, no en poner salas en cierto orden lógico para que tenga algo de interés porque para eso juego a un Mario o a un Sonic.

-No hay enemigos remarcables, ni en diseño ni en mecánicas. Todo muy típico.

-Todas las mecánicas y controles son como las del Castlevania y ya. Está bien como base pero añadir algo original estaría bien. No se porque hay tanto zote en las opiniones diciendo que "es como un Dark Souls en metroidvania" cuando el combate es un calco de un Castlevania hasta el punto que son exactamente los mismos hechizos.

-Gráficos que no destacan a pesar de lo que se comenta por aquí, hay miles de indies que tienen el mismo aspecto que este juego. Bastante poco variados.

-Farmeo de monstruos para alguna misión secundaria. Afortunadamente son pocas y no es el grindeo de mierda que había que hacer en Portrait of Ruin o Order of Ecclesia pero por favor, alejad esa mierda de este maravilloso género, gracias.

Ahora mismo no pagaría más de 5 euros por esto. Si te apetece algo de este género y te has pasado todo, vuelve a jugarte algo que ya te has pasado porque aquí no hay nada que rascar. Aun así creo que hay potencial para algo bueno y espero que ya sea en parches o en una segunda parte.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206999976', 'num_games_owned': 1110, 'num_reviews': 510, 'playtime_forever': 407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1670837981}
review:
[h1]Review zu Chasm[/h1]

Chasm selbst hat sich zum namensgebenden [i]Abgrund[/i] verfrachtet.
Ich würde nicht so weit gehen, dass Chasm durch und durch ein schlechtes Spiel und eher ein Daumen zur Seite als einer nach unten ist. Da mir Steam diese Option nur leider nicht bietet bin ich eher auf den Daumen nach unten angewiesen.
Chasm habe ich mir schon vor Monaten irgendwann mal gekauft. Schon da sah das Spiel nicht wirklich rosig aus. Abgesehen von der ästhetischen Seite des Spiels, aber dazu komme ich später noch.
Das große Problem von Chasm ist das Gameplay, wobei man hier zwischen dem Movement während des Kämpfens und dem des Erkundens unterscheiden sollte. Zwar fühlt sich das Movement während des Erkundens stets einen Ticken zu langsam an, jedoch gewöhnt man sich irgendwann an diese, wenn auch zu langsame, Geschwindigkeit. Beim Kämpfen hingegen fallen die Schwächen des Movements und den ebenso einhergehenden Problemen des Kampfsystems deutlich auf. Sollte man irgendwann mal einen Blick, vor und nach einem Kampf, auf die HP-Leiste riskieren, so wird auffallen, dass man große Mengen der Lebenspunkte schon nur nach einem Gegner verlieren kann. Und jetzt kommt das knifflige an der Sache. Das liegt nicht daran, weil das Spiel zu schwer ist, nein, sondern eher, weil sich die Bewegung während eines Kampfes furchtbar anfühlt! Ich habe im Forum mich schon vor Monaten über dieses Problem beschwert und auf Patches seitens der Entwickler gehofft. Es kamen zwar welche und seit dem Neuesten der auch eine deutsche Übersetzung mitgeliefert hat, dachte ich mir, dass ich es mal wieder erneut probieren möchte, aber ich habe einfach keinen Willen mehr meine Zeit mit diesem höchstens mittelmäßigen Spiel zu verschwenden.
Das Kampfsystem ist allerdings nicht durch und durch schlecht. Kämpfe sind, wenn man erstmal dahintergekommen ist, recht strategisch und irgendwann hat man eine Knopfreihenfolge verinnerlicht, wie man jeden Gegner einzeln besiegt. Etwas, dass ich schon mit größter Freude in Hollow Knight erfahren habe.
Apropos Hollow Knight. Dies ist auch ein weiteres Problem von Chasm. Es gibt bessere Alternativen zu eben jenem Spiel. Axiom Verge, Dust: An Elysian Tail, Hollow Knight, The Messenger, Ori and the Blind Forest, Owlboy und vor allem Timespinner kann ich mehr empfehlen, als Chasm. (Timespinner kommt an Chasm auch noch am ehesten heran, ähnlicher Artstil, aber ein viel besseres Kampfsystem) Und bei all diesen Alternativen hatte ich stets die Frage im Hintergrund warum ich mich überhaupt noch mit Chasm beschäftigen sollte, abgesehen davon, dass ich dafür Geld ausgegeben habe. Ich sage nein! Lieber ein paar Euro in den Sand gesetzt, als meine Zeit weiter verschwendet!
Vielleicht mag es den ein oder anderen geben dem das Kampfsystem nicht so schrecklich ist, aber dazu gehöre ich bedauerlicherweise leider nicht...

Kommen wir für die Schnellen unter uns einfach mal zur Pro-Contra-Liste:

[u][b]Pro:[/b][/u]

+ Der Pixelart war schön anzusehen und wer möchte kann sogar einen CRT-Filter anmachen!
+ Musik macht Laune, bleibt allerdings nie wirklich im Ohr. Ist okay
+ Level UPs können strategisch genutzt werden, um seine Leben aufzufüllen
+ Es gibt eine reiche Anzahl von Gegnern. Zwar nicht auf Hollow Knights Niveau, aber immerhin
+ Mir hat die Erleichterung einen Speicherraum endlich zu finden immer wieder aufs Neue gefallen!

[u][b]Contra:[/b][/u]

- Die Karte ist zu einfach gehalten. Zwar machen dies so einige der Alternativen zu Chasm weiter oben auch, aber wenigstens konnte man dort noch weiterführende Wege und Kisten per Marker markieren
- Man kehrt beim Tod ins Hauptmenü zurück. Dergleichen ist unnötige Zeitverschwendung und sollte im heutigen Spieledesign eigentlich nichts mehr zu suchen haben
- Gegner sind mehr Hindernisse als richtige Feinde, weshalb man ihnen ausweicht nachdem man den dazugehörigen Bestariumseintrag zu ihnen bereits erhalten hat. Natürlich erst nachdem man eine gewisse grindlastige Anzahl von ihnen erledigte
- Es ist sehr unbefriedigend, wenn man Schaden durch einen Gegner erhält, weil das Movement einfach dermaßen clunky ist. Ich rede dabei nicht von Eingabeverzögerung, wobei das die Situation noch verschlimmert hätte, nein, ich meine die Tatsache, dass man eine Schwertschwunganimation nicht abbrechen kann und sich so das ganze Kampfsystem unangenehm anfühlt...
- Aufgrund der Zufallsgeneration erscheinen lange Gänge, die mit langer Lauferei verbunden sind und nicht wirklich aufregend gestaltet worden sind. Selbst die Schnellreise kann nicht ohne Beinarbeit geleistet werden

[u][b]Prontra:[/b][/u]

+- Die Bewegung des Charakters ist etwas zu langsam. Die Möglichkeit zu sprinten wäre toll gewesen
+- Waffennutzung zu träge, da die Gegner jedoch kurz zurückschrecken, nachdem man sie attackiert hat (zumindest meistens), ist das in Ordnung, jedoch noch sehr grenzwertig
+- Ausgerüstete Kleidungsstücke verändern nicht mein Äußeres. Zwar macht das Timespinner auch, aber wenigstens gibt es noch zwei weitere Outfits als Alternativen
+- Gegner lösen leider keine Fallen aus. Ich persönlich bin stets ein großer Fan von unterschiedlichen Spielmechaniken, die sich gegenseitig ausboten können (Beispielsweise, wenn Gegner sich gegenseitig verletzen können) Leider bietet mir das Spiel dies nicht
+- Die Menüsteuerung ist mit dem Stick auf einem Gamepad zu groß, sodass man für feinere Eingaben das Steuerkreuz verwenden muss

Rückblickend fühle ich mich richtig lächerlich, dass ich mich vor dem Kauf auf das Spiel mal gefreut habe. Welch ein Narr ich doch gewesen bin...

author: {'steamid': '76561198103746022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1711, 'last_played': 1546793553}
review: Era pra ser um sucessor espiritual do Castlevania - Symphony of The Night, mas ficou mais pra um meio termo. Ele consegue extrair o melhor do CSotN, o jogo não tem muita ação como um Dead Cells e pra jogadores mais atuais, pode parecer "um pouco duro". O financiamento coletivo começou em 2013 e estava previsto para lançarem o jogo em 2014, mas ele só saiu em 2018... E bem, esse lance todo de jogos metroidvania já estão cansando e a chegada da ideia tardia fez o jogo cair num ostracismo irrecuperável. A geração procedural do jogo, que deveria ser o diferencial de tudo é bem pobre. As quests são irrelevantes, sem nenhum impacto na história (a própria história do jogo não tem nada de interessante) e só servem para conseguir itens que podem ser dispensados. O jogo é bem linear e pode ser terminado em cerca de 5 horas, eu acredito. Eu durei cerca de quase 30hrs pra extrair o máximo de experiência e procurar o máximo de coisas num jogo que não é nada instintivo. Não é o pior jogo do mundo, mas também não é o melhor.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960574225', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 520, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1629000111}
review:
I waited so long for this game. The idea of a procedurally generated metroidvania got me excited.

I can safely say it was not worth the wait. 

On the plus side, the pixel art is pretty.

On the negative side, the story is uninteresting, the combat is clunky, and the music is boring, repetative, and forgettable.

My biggest gripe about the entire game is something you'd expect to be in a sidescrolling game like this...Controller support! There isn't any unless you launch the game through steam big picture with your controller mapped through that first. How incredibly ridiculous! This game was in development for years and they didn't add proper controller support.
developer_response: Thanks for the feedback! I was unaware how out of date our controller database was until I saw your review. I was able to update it and we now support a couple hundred more controllers out of the box without the need for mapping.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019572936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 1074, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1066, 'last_played': 1680362026}
review:
I'm not a Metroidvania fan, but this game got my interest when it's first kickstarted so I gave it 35$. It took so many years to come out that I stopped counting. 

I didn't know what to expect while playing this game, but I noticed that I suffer a lot while playing this game. Everything feels like torture, especially fights. It's way too boring and meaninglessly hard, enemies are always either walking towards you(which feels really cheap and annoying af), or just jumping on you, I felt so annoyed everytime a I met a new enemy. Basically all you gotta do is hit and spam dodge(and sometimes jump).

 Treasure chest in map made me feel like I'm playing a hentai game, they are just there to add some playtime, I nearly never used any weapon I got from chest, different weapon types feels mostly unnecessary anyway, all it matter is damage. 

 Walking around map just to see if I missed something is boring. Like when I got a new upgrade, like wall jump or slide, I need to check every missing area in my map so that I can be sure that I didn't miss anything there. I don't enjoy combat and visiting same areas again and again is feels meaningless. Like after sometime, all I do is open a new upgrade, then visit all the map again just to get pass an area I couldn't before, for each map. How is this a game? I'd prefer Demon Semen.

 I'm not a lore fan but it didn't seem like there is one. Story didn't progress in 17.8 hours too(thought I guess it counted my playtime before full release). 

 Musics doesn't make any sense and except the graphics, there is no atmosphere. And about the main character, why does he look like a kid? Aren't we supposed to be a knight or something?

 I don't know, how can you make a game in 6 years, like this one which could be done in 2-3 years? This game feels so empty, waste of time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971288614', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1546045443}
review:
Let me start by saying that I love Metroidvania games, and I am also a fan of Roguelikes.
This game is both so I thought what the heck, I'll give it a try.
I made it about an hour into the game but just couldn't stay engaged. This game feels extremely bland and generic with very little variety. You can't make a good roguelike without a lot of material to pull from, or it simply feels repetitive and dull. That's what this game suffers from. A whole lot of running through too-similar rooms, killing too-similar enemies with ONE standard attack. The blandness of this game could be forgivable if it were 1988 and we were talking about the NES. In this day and age, there's no excuse for it. Do yourself a favor and spend your money on something else instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981094693', 'num_games_owned': 1596, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1545679749}
review:
Pros:
- Really nice looking pixel art.
- The game makes sure to scale the graphics correctly at higher resolution so you maintain non-blurry image quality (something all pixel art games should do).
- Alternate "arcade" mode which lets you play through the game at a faster pace (though it feature zero exploration).

Cons:
- Almost all of the level design is procedurally generated. It's technically impressive, but the end result is a lot of featureless corridors. There's a couple of instances of more interesting level design, but those areas are user made. It makes me think the game would have been better off with a fully handcrafted map.
- Combat feels very dull. Attacking is slow and every enemy feels like they take 2-3 too many hits to kill. You learn the patterns for enemies quickly so combat quickly starts to feel like an uninteresting chore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047576261', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1537, 'last_played': 1693249182}
review:
[b]The best Metroidvania beside Axiom Verge. [/b]

Where Axiom Verge is more like an 8-bit Metroid(SciFi-Setting), Chasm is more an 16-bit Castlevania(Fantasy-Setting) with its own world.

The graphics are very nice (especially in the gardens) and evoke memories to SNES-titles sometimes during the game. The soundtrack is somehow special but always fitting. The gameplay is fantastic with very direct controls like in old 8 and 16 bit games. You have a clear ingame map and inventory, you have RPG-elements like levelling up and choosing your gear, a big variety of different weapons, armour and items to find, many different enemies, hidden secrets to discover, searching for ways to get into another area, etc.

I don't understand the criticism for the partly-generated map. In my opinion it works very well. 

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198049535680', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1576105187}
review:
Très grand fan d'Aria of Sorrow, j'ai sagement attendu Chasm ces longues années depuis la campagne Kickstarter qui date maintenant de plus de 5 ans, et si beaucoup de backers ont été déçus, je retrouve pour ma part la grande majorité des aspects qui m'avaient plu à l'époque :

- Gameplay technique. Il faut savoir lire les patterns des ennemis, et on retrouve des mécaniques de combat similaires à AoS dans lequel, pour optimiser ses dps et sa mobilité, il convenait de timer ses attaques et mouvements selon des "combos" de type mini-saut > attaque juste avant d'atterir afin d'annuler la fin de l'animation > backdash > attaque dès les premières frames du dash pour l'annuler et porter un deuxième coup quasi successif au premier.
Ici dans Chasm, un coup porté pied à terre vous maintiendra plusieurs longues frames en position fixe pendant la complétion de l'animation d'attaque, ce qui semble très lent quand on s'est habitué aux jeux plus contemporrains comme Deadcells. C'est pourquoi il est vite essentiel de maîtriser ces techniques d'optimisation, le jeu s'avèrant assez difficile dans ses deux derniers chapitres si on joue trop "conventionnellement".

- Possibilité de chnager d'armes, dont le type modifie la portée, la vitesse, et la zone d'effet de vos attaques (par exemple une lance aura une longue portée avec vitesse d'attaque moyenne, une dague aura une portée très courte mais sera plus rapide, tandis qu'une hache sera très lente mais offrira une zone d'attaque verticale permettant de toucher des ennemis au-dessus de vous).

- Graphismes pixel-art très soignés, DA plutôt classique mais bien maîtrisée. Personnellement je trouve le jeu magnifique.

Il est clair que si vous attendez de Chasm un jeu rapide aux standards d'aujourd'hui, avec du nouveau contenu débloqué à outrance au fil de la progression au sein du jeu, vous serez très probablement déçu. Le nombre d'objets et équipements est très limité, l'aquisition de nouvelles compétences est lente (on reste coincé sans double saut pendant une eternité), et la génération procédurale n'apporte vraiment pas grand chose au jeu (j'aurais préféré une map fixe sur laquelle il aurait été possible de se lâcher bien plus au niveau visuel notamment). Chasm s'adresse davantage aux nostalgiques du genre, et même si je ne suis généralement pas très réceptif au rétro-gaming, j'ai fort apprécié la poignée d'heures passée sur ce petit jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962872327', 'num_games_owned': 2329, 'num_reviews': 191, 'playtime_forever': 585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 585, 'last_played': 1575663693}
review:
Pros: 
- It has a good enough story to continue playing to see what happens next.
- The pixel art graphics are cool (Your milage may vary).
- Weapons that have different attack animations so to min/max one could swap to a short sword for a quick attack or a club for a slower attack, but it covers more range.

What's Wrong With This Game:
The game is missing some of the updates from the recent years such as quirky, or charming characters to have some form of a comic relief during the gameplay. Other reviews expand on the issues in this game in greater detail than what I will provide here. But while playing, I could not help but compare Chasm to Owlboy. Owlboy does majority of the things better. It has abilities that you character gets that change up the gameplay while Chasm remains a sidescroller. There's a lot to write about what could have been different. But the game is already finished so, there's no going back.

Lastly, I want to state that I think this is a good game, but it is only for those that have played old school sidescrollers. This is more of a pure sidescroller than a game like Owlboy. So you'll enjoy it if you keep your expectations in check. But I don't know if I really enjoyed playing it... I still recommend buying it, and trying it out yourself to see if it's what you're into. I'd give this game a 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009011377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1099, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1099, 'last_played': 1541293355}
review:
Overall a solid Metrodvania. Enjoyed the playthrough but don't think I'm motivated to play through again, which renders the procedural generation system a bit pointless for me.

The Good:
- Solid combat and platforming with a nice choice of weapons and spells.
- Looks great. Pixel art is on point in all 5 worlds. Great ambiance.
- Decent music and sound effects. Though the music can start to grate a little when lost and looking around for extended periods (more of a metroidvania issue than just this game though)

The Bad:
- The procedural generation. This seems to be done once at the start of the game, locking in the seed for the rest of the playthrough. I didnt get the impression I missed anything or left any threads left to be discovered so didnt feel like replaying, meaning I never saw any value in the procedural gen. I guess if you loved your first playthrough and felt there was more to discover this would be pretty cool though.
- The story. Somewhat bland on this front, no real twists or shocks along the way. Nor was there any real stand out characters.
- Challenge. Playing on standard difficulty I only really died to standard enemies whilst mucking around trying to find the next objective. Managed to just tank through almost every boss without learning movesets on the first try.

I'd give it about 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037745359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1624129565}
review:
Big fan of this genre, and actually supported this in the Kickstarter ages ago.

To be honest, if you're looking for more of the same Chasm is exactly what you're expecting it to be. There's not much new here, and what it does well is done better elsewhere. Combat isn't as bland as most reviews make it out to be, but the killer of this title is the map design: the random generation removes any real cohesion between rooms and makes the game bland very quickly.

I have to avoid recommending this, and I'm sad to see what I thought was a brilliant idea fall into being a medicore title filling my library. The ultimate irony is that if Chasm had continued to just pull in influences to make it a randomly generated roguelike with unlockables you earn each run, it'd have been far more enjoyable than the bland slog it ended up becoming.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994487037', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 711, 'last_played': 1539136385}
review:
I'm about halfway through, and struggling to justify beating the game at this point.

The procedural generation of Chasm doesn't reward exploration so much as it makes you go through samey-looking hallways over and over again checking looking for which of the four narrow passageways/tall walls/dig spots/etcetera leads to a new area and not just a chest with a minor treasure in it.

The gameplay feels very much derived from Symphony of the Night, but without many of the toys that are fun to mess with and/or use to completely break SotN. You can backdash, and swing your weapon while backdashing, but you can't swing your weapon and *then* start backdashing. It makes me want to macro it because of how many enemies are trivialised if you do it right, but punish you if you do it wrong.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068750992', 'num_games_owned': 4028, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 1534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1497, 'last_played': 1634532071}
review:
Jogo maravilhoso. Valeu a pena esperar 6 anos para jogá-lo.
Muito divertido, puzzles bem pensados, armas diferentes, arte linda. Recomendo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993399977', 'num_games_owned': 1466, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1790, 'last_played': 1594665200}
review:
Restraint. That's Chasm's thing. The combat is deliberate, so much so that it occasionally resembles a Souls-like. There's an RPG system, but your character attributes will stay firmly in the double digits, even at end-game. The excellent pixel art is almost shockingly understated, as is the music. Narrative elements are so light-touch that they're barely there.

I like the restraint. A lot of games (triple-A games especially), utterly terrified that you'll get bored, just throw [b]stuff[/b] at you. Loot. Enemies. Features. Abilities. Spectacle. The result is often a sloppy game that has no idea what it's actually good at. Chasm, meanwhile, feels confident. They understand the experience they're trying to create, and have provided a thoughtfully considered path through their game.

If BitKid were just making an action game (something like Volgarr the Viking), this would all be great. As you know, however, Chasm presents as an exploration game — a Metroidvania. The restraint comes off more as stinginess here. Exploration games need [i]treats[/i] to entice the player through all of those corridors. They need [b]STUFF[/b]. Unfortunately in Chasm, a long trek down a dead-end is likely to reward you only with a potion, or a weapon no better than what you're currently using. More even than loot, an exploration game needs moments of transcendence to offset all that aimless wandering. Chasm isn't interested in providing cool setpieces or great character moments though, and the boss encounters aren't ambitious enough to truly stick in the mind.

Still, I enjoyed my time with Chasm. Playing on Hard, combat was a good challenge. I felt I had to learn each enemy's pattern in order to thrive, and so every first encounter with a new enemy was meaningful. At least, until I discovered how exploitable magic becomes late-game. I don't know if I [i]recommend[/i] Chasm, but it's a rock-solid foundation, and with some post-launch content support, it might yet stake a claim in the pantheon of great Metroidvanias.

Disclosure: I backed Chasm on Kickstarter.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980327565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 419, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 419, 'last_played': 1534876475}
review:
Another metroidvania carried entirely by its artwork, but not carried nearly hard enough.

The game is a bit of a let down, crippled mostly by the modular procedural map generation.  Which turns the game into a hedgemaze of similar looking rooms with nothing interesting in them.  I could ask myself a thousand times why they thought procedural generation was the way to go, and I will never find an answer.

Another devastating problem is that the player is tasked with completing several quests for people in the town.  Some are fine, but others will have you farming the same monster over a hundred times to collect 5 copies of the item it drops at a 1% droprate.

The combat, while interesting at some points, is mostly clunky.  Attacking has an extremely limited range and will bring your character to a full stop for an excessive amount of time.  Lots of games have this issue, but none to the extent that Chasm does.  Basically every point of damage you take will be because you attacked an enemy and they immediately attacked you back while your character finished his animation.  The classic Castlevania "jump cancelling" exists, but has been watered down to not be anywhere near effective enough.  You'll find yourself taking the longest range weapon you can find in order to just outrange your opponents, which usually comes at the cost of attack power, forcing you to spend ridiculous amounts of time killing a single enemy.

There is some issue that this game has with giving out money that is utterly bewildering.  You'll find yourself starved for cash throughout the game, which isn't a huge problem because for most of the game there is nothing worth buying.  Later on when money does become a necessity, the only decent way of obtaining it is a slot machine game that is beyond tedious.  Also to get coins for the slot machine you have to play a card matching game that is, you guessed it, also unbelievably tedious.

The music ranges from adequate to abyssmal, and you'll be hearing a lot of it as you backtrack through areas just to enter a single room that was inaccessible before and obtain an irrelevant weapon.

The plotline is completely forgettable.  I think I killed the demon king of the world or something at one point and it meant literally nothing to me.  I should also note I am a massive lore nerd and really did try to give a shit, I read every document I came by fully, talked to every NPC, and at no point did I ever care what was happening.

I was not able to finish the game because I ended up at a point where I needed to either backtrack through everything to find the next wing of the dungeon or complete a 1% droprate quest, I don't know which.

I hate to be so negative, because I'm well aware of how much time and effort was put into the game.  The artwork especially is nothing but stellar, some of the best pixel art in any current game.  The failure lays entirely on whoever decided to construct the game as a criminally slow slog through grindy monotonous content.
developer_response: We're very sorry to hear you didn't enjoy the game but appreciate the time you spent playing Chasm and writing a review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097424549', 'num_games_owned': 181, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 10338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 910, 'last_played': 1687100050}
review:
*UPDATE* 8/10 Good updates to the game but its still not exactly as advertised.

7/10 Very good first playthrough; Needs updates to encourage multiple playthroughs.

Solid game on a first playthrough and has very good replay POTENTIAL. Now, I put emphasis on potential because the game still needs a lot of work on the randomizing aspect that the developers sell as part of the main course meal. The randomizer seems not to impact the location of anything important in the game. All important items, bosses, and NPC's are in the same spots every time, and there are no alternate bosses or enemies for each area. In fact, it seems like all the randomizer does is choose from about 3 options for every connector room, maybe split into a few smaller rooms or one larger room with slightly different layouts and enemies, and any room with any importance whatsoever seems to have the same layout, in the same position on the map, on every seed. The randomizing aspect, simply put, is very underwhelming from what you would expect a randomizer to do. 
For updates, more map randomization and item randomization is a must. More bosses, more enemies, more artifacts, more items, and varying enemy drops would be nice. 
Another small thing I personally noticed is that the luck stat didnt seem to have any noticable effect on my playthroughs. It seems as though I got just as many enemy drops with 5 luck as I did with 50 luck. 
Regardless, I recommend the game to anyone who enjoys SOTN style castlevania games, as this is essentially a clone of those games and is fun on your first playthrough. I hope there are more updates to this game that make it more interesting to play multiple runs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009932254', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2454, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2272, 'last_played': 1533411380}
review:
Surprisingly depth-less for a game called Chasm. Might be worth getting for $5.

The art of this game is amazing. Great visuals and great music. Howeve, everything else falls short. The rooms are all to similar and boring. You have mostly long hallways broken up by vertical hallways with "challenge" rooms thrown here and there. Don't bother exploring or backtracking because the rewards are hardly worth the time let alone the effort.

The procedural generation only serves to make each playthrough TECHNICALLY different. In practice, your next game will play exactly as it did as the last. Instead of flat hallway 1, you will get flat hallway 2.

The combat it decent, but you can cheese through the whole game using the overpowered magic. There is a backdash, but it's mostly never usable. You're almost always better off jumping or walking backwards.

It's a real shame the game is so bland. It seems like the foundation is there but nothing built on top of that adds up to anything more than mediocrity.

review:
(Disclaimer: I kickstarted this game, back before I knew any better than to do so.)

Yeesh, where to start with this one?
* Fighting enemies is a bore
* Bosses are uninspiring and also a bore to fight
* Magic spells are just Castlevania subweapons, and they're not fun to use
* Controls just feel a bit stiff & off at all times (the backdash is USELESS, e.g.)
* Some rooms have precision platforming that requires a lot of trial & error

Some pros:
* Music's OK
* Pixel art graphics are pretty good

I LOVED the idea of a Metroidvania with procedurally-generated levels in THEORY, for the replayability. It's just a shame this one brought nothing to the table to make the FIRST playthrough worth my while. I doubt I'll even finish this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002209131', 'num_games_owned': 618, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4147, 'last_played': 1558944901}
review:
This game is mediocre for most of it, and goodish for some of its better moments. At this point I have played it 69 hours, I've defeated all the bosses without taking a hit at least once each, I have a good flow & understanding of it all. The music is forgettable.

This game was announced on Kickstarter back in 2013. They 'estimated' the game would be released in mid-2014. A mistake on that front. I don't just mean because the game came out four years after its estimation, but the amount of metroidvania games that have come out in that time frame... so many are far more interesting, clever, and beautiful frankly. The novel element of Chasm is that it's procedurally generated. You can re-explore the game with changed up rooms, puzzles, enemies, et cetera. I know that will be great for some people, but it's just 'there' for me.

When this was still a kickstarter, A lot of people & I commented that we'd love if there was at least a secondary lady protagonist.
The dev that replied to me basically told me that the story was incredibly important to the game, and the protagonist being who they already were was 'important,' and that a [reskin to have at least a secondary female protagonist] was just far too much work to change the story.

There are no pronouns or gendered language used for the protagonist at any point in the entire game. The interesting elements of the story & lore are about the past, the eldritch deity, and past explorers. The importance of the protagonist is little to nothing, and the gender couldn't be important as it never even came up.

They set the goal for a female protagonist extraordinarily high for the low effort it would have required. While it is pretty easy to see the protagonist as a relatable butch lesbian, and I absolutely did. Making it to the end without "the important story purpose" coming up a single time felt like a joke to me.

Worth getting if you love castlevanias and the game is on sale, there are many other excellent Metroidvanias that exist now. I'd play some of those first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119074915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 335, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 335, 'last_played': 1533366568}
review:
This game was announced in a time where metroidvanias were in very short supply, paricularly of the indie variety. What set this game apart from the small crowd at the time was its procedural generation promising replayability and attractive pixel art. Ultimately, time has moved on and the metroidvania boom has happened and likely will occur again next year with many quality titles on the horizon.
Chasm feels like it would have been more appealing had it not been delayed so many times and released in 2014 (or was it 2015??). Unfortunately everything that chasm does is eclipsed by other games in the genre that have released in the past few years. Even its procedural generation does not do much to set it out from its competitors, resulting in maps that feel overly stretched out and singular in their pathways for the most part, unlike the densely layered and flexible pathways that open up through progression in other games. The map's straggling woes become more apparent in the awkwardly placed fast traveling system. The game's lack of memorable characters and enemy design works against it nowadays, and whilst the art is pretty, its over-reliance on fantasy tropes sticks out when placed against its competitors

Ultimately, this game is mediocrity distilled. The long wait meant that what was once interesting now appears jaded. Hopefully all the long overdue metroidvanias on the horizon do not suffer the same fate.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994894769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1282, 'last_played': 1533437372}
review:
It didn't really meet my expectations, but it's visually gorgeous and still a solid game at its core. Unfortunate that the game's release was so close to Dead Cells coming out of Early Access; though the games do very different things, it's easy to make certain comparisons.

One of the features that the game touts is its randomized level design. Rooms themselves are prefabricated, but the rooms are joined together in a different arrangement for each new save file (the finalized maps are assigned to a seed, so it's possible to replay the same one or share yours with a friend). There is some novelty to this, but ultimately it only serves to increase replay value somewhat and to make it difficult to seek help if you find yourself getting stuck (which is fairly likely for first-time players).

The game is divided into several biomes, each with its own sub-map, its own enemies, and its own mobility roadblock to overcome. Functions like ledge-grab, slow-fall, wall-kick, and double-jump are gradually unlocked as you progress through the game, and the unfortunate side-effect to this is that portions of the early stages feel clumsy to navigate without them. Platforming in certain portions of the beginning zones can feel a little too punishing when you don't wait until the last pixel to initiate that standard-jump. Add monsters that throw bombs or fly at you, and you've got a recipe for some very frustrating jumps. There is a small amount of satisfaction to be had from revisiting a zone with new upgrades in order to reach That Chest From Earlier, but it's criminally underused. When you get a mobility upgrade, you may feel compelled to do another lap of every previous zone, because who knows if that chest you couldn't reach contains a Key Item, a permanent HP/MP increase, or just a piece of equipment that you don't want to use. Because some of the linear pathing is not very clear, you may stumble on a bunch of optional stuff while searching for the correct way forward. 

One of first objectives you are given is to find the missing townspeople. There are about a dozen NPCs in the town of Karthas, most of whom have vanished under mysterious circumstances. Despite being your clearest objective, very few of the rescues are actually required in order to complete the game. In most cases, a rescued character living safely back in town will give you a side quest (typically "fetch this Key Item for me") or begin to function as some sort of shop. You'll want to buy a subweapon from the witch as soon as possible.

Each zone culminates in a boss fight, as one would expect, and boss fights will be the primary road block (and potion-sink) to advancement. The story gradually unfolds, and you force your way through increasingly resilient enemies, constantly backtracking to see which unfinished path has become accessible after your newest upgrade. The game feels more fun as you gain more control of your own movement, but I personally don't feel hooked enough to replay it any time soon.

It's worth playing, but don't expect to be blown away.

Princess / 10

author: {'steamid': '76561197998340377', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1335, 'last_played': 1554656422}
review:
Chasm is a game that I backed almost 5 years ago and I have happily waited with much patience to play the finished product. I am happy to report that all of those years of waiting have paid off with what is one of the most polished, mechanically sound and gorgeous Metroidvania games on the market today. 

Some might say that this game is generic or that it doesn't do anything particularly well but I couldn't disagree more. Chasm is a game that comes from a place of love and reverance for the classics, especially Castlevania Symphony of the Night. The way that Chasm plays is so close to SotN in terms of mechanics that you would think Bit Kid somehow got their hands on the original game engine and adapted it to their game. When you stop and remember that this game was built from the ground up you begin to realize how expertly crafted the whole thing is.

Bit Kid poured their heart into Chasm and it shows. The variety of weapon types allow for myriad play styles. The magic spells you acquire act like subweapons from Castlevania games and expand your arsenal nicely. The map is exact and informative and lets you place down markers in areas you'd like to revisit. I will say that having options for different marker types or colors would have been a nice touch but it's not a necessity. Every area is beautifully rendered in what I can only describe as some of the finest pixel art I've come across. Your character feels weighty in a way that lends some realism to movement and combat. The music isn't anything overly melodic but it is very effective at establishing the mood of each area, and the town music is especially nice with it's accoustic guitars reminiscent of Tristram themes of old. Speaking of the town, as you are exploring you rescue town members that are sent back to become shops, mini-games and quest-givers which is a strong incetive to explore everywhere.

One aspect of the game that really needs to be stated apart from the rest is that every time you start a new game you are getting a randomly generated seed which is going to change dungeon layouts, item locations and the like. For such a polished game to also grant you immense replay value in the form of proceduraly generated worlds is a huge accomplishment. The seed can be typed in manually too if you want to play the same one as a friend.

I am truly saddened to see that at the time of writing this review Chasm sits here with an undeservedly middling aggregate rating of Mixed. I understand that Chasm might not introduce new mechanics never before seen in the genre. I understand that some people have come to expect games to revolutionize and reinvent the ground other games have tread already. What I don't understand is why a game like Chasm that does a fantastic job of implementing core design elements, features and mechanics integral to the Metroidvania genre doesn't get praise for achieving that. This is a game that serves as a reminder of what people fell in love with when they first picked up a quality Metroidvania game. Chasm should serve as a standard of quality when it comes to modern iterations of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007683726', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 2146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2055, 'last_played': 1537214175}
review:
(review by a huge Metroidvania fan) 
CHASM is not a bad game... but not a good one either. 
"randomized" level design isn't good, many times I got completely lost, some puzzle solving aren't obvious at all (for ex that part with the 3 numbers). 
Gameplay is just decent, quite a bad jump system (thankfully it get better once u get the "double jump" item, unfortunately almost at the end of the game).  
I would recommend this game only if you get it for less than 8€. 
Not the worst Metroidvania I have played, but there's definitely much better Metroidvania out there to buy instead, for ex Shantae And The Pirate's Curse, Ori And The Blind Tree or Dust An Elysian Tail.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095099076', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1042, 'last_played': 1663147473}
review:
I have been hyped for this game for quite sometime actually. After it finally came out i was itching to buy this as i had been wanting a new Metroidvania to play. At first i had mixed feelings about this game, letting my own over hype hurt the experiance but i won't let that get in the way of an honest review. Anyways lets get down to what's good,bad and ugly.

-Pros-
*Challenging and simple but fun gameplay
*Expansive maps with little secrets around every corner
*Good map with enough information to convey what is needed.
*Difficulties to satisfy everyone.

-Cons-
*As much as it pains me to say this not all the music clicked with me but this is subjective and may not apply to everyone but i felt the need to mention it because it felt like an issue to me. The music however does serve it's purpose and fits the area's they were composed for.

-Bugs- [This has been fixed but im leaving it here for archival purposes]
*When activating cheats via the console, which i assume is for fun, leaving without saving and loading another save(or starting a new game) carries over cheats like GODMODE and Reveal. This needs to be fixed as it will allow players to easily obtain hard mode and Mortal mode achievements with little to no challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970982293', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1536778754}
review:
If there was a mixed review option I would select that, but as it is there are already so many great Metroidvanias you could play aside from [i]Chasm[/i] that I find it hard to recommend. I say this as someone who backed [i]Chasm[/i] on Kickstarter many years ago and loves [i]Metroid[/i] & [i]Castlevania[/i] games.

The only definite positives I can muster are the art looks astounding and the music suits the game (although none of the tracks are very memorable). Unfortunately everything else with this game is lackluster at best or very disappointing at worst. If you want more detailed info as to why I think this, then you can read my essay below lol

- Combat is clunky, and not in a way that feels weighty or purposeful. When you swing your weapon you are grounded in place, so the only skill in weapon usage revolves around canceling your jumping attack animation by landing, so you can act again almost immediately and attack/jump/dodge as needed. You do have magic but there is almost no point in using anything other than the magic knives, as they are quick, cost efficient and reliable at long range. The enemy design and variety is good, but combat never evolves beyond attaining magic and then upgrading your numbers.

- The artifacts you find to improve your character are uninspired and boring. I'll spare you spoilers for everything else, but I will say that the best upgrade you will find in this game is a double jump and that is very late into the game. The lack of mobility is what killed my enjoyment the most; not only does combat feel clunky, but so does moving around the world, and that is never remedied with a new artifact (as much as I hoped it would). And the last two "artifacts" are extremely disappointing (one of which could only be used in literally two spots in my world generation).

- World design is incredibly lackluster. Not just in the art direction of the zones, but how the world is generated does not add to the game in any meaningful way, and in my opinion, detracts from the experience. The only area that felt like it had some purposeful thought put into it was the start of the Catacombs, as the rest of the game is just hallways, challenge rooms and boss fights. Compounded by the fact that mobility never feels good, having to backtrack through tons of long hallways was extremely boring, especially when there was platforming involved.

[i]Chasm[/i] was clearly inspired by the [i]Castlevania[/i] games but they didn't seem to iterate on what made those games fun and instead chose to focus on procedural generation (and I have a feeling that that is what hurt the development of [i]Chasm[/i] the most). I wanted to love this game as much as I love [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] or [i]Aria of Sorrow[/i], but I could never justify the time/sanity commitment to filling out the [i]Chasm[/i] bestiary, unlike in [i]AoS[/i], where I have no problem grinding out 100% soul completion. I wish Bit Kid the best in their next endeavours, but please focus your scope for your future titles, as [i]Chasm[/i] feels like a missed opportunity.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991783799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 871, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 871, 'last_played': 1536643403}
review:
I kickstarted this game about 4 or 5 years ago, and it finally came out!  
So, I'm a LITTLE vested in my expectations for it.

Basic metroidvania platformer, but with a basic RPG (gear and weapons, stats,  but no stat tree or skill tree).  
However, my seed was a bit more linear than I expected.  Yeah, there was some backtracking but I should have saved most of that for the end as only one or two rooms outside of the main path would really open up with each new skill.

The battling was fair, as enemies broadcast their attacks and you can dodge back quickly.  
I heavily relied on the magic daggers, those are unbalanced in your favor so level them early.

No real point in grinding, better to explore a little more and find stat boosters in the game.

I did hit a skill wall where 3-4 new skills were compiled on me once.  (sawblade walls, in the dark, with wall jump, followed by new poison enemies in the dark).  Also, it was missing a downward mid air attack that could have improved fights.

Other than that, it was fair.  Enjoyable, I didn't get all the achievements, but am happy with what I did.  I could probably get 2 more pretty quick, but the last 3 would require another playthrough (one without deaths?? nothankyou)

author: {'steamid': '76561198026580933', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 521, 'last_played': 1536641748}
review:
I love Metroidvanias. I want to love this game since I waited so long for it. I paid for it at Steam release, but I've been watching it since it was first announced on Kickstarter.

Chasm is beautfiful, but for an exploration game set underground, it really lacks depth. I beat the entire game in two sittings with 99.9% explored. My 8 hours of playtime include about 2-3 hours of being away from my computer with the game running.

I was following it because Metroidvanias with RPG aspects are my shit.

Game's too short. I was convinced that since it was taking so long to develop, it would be quite the game. The procedurally generated maps means very few secrets and upgrades you find throughout the game. You can backtrack once you get upgrades to find some treasures, but hardly anything feels meaningful. The controls are mostly good, the walljumps feel a little weird though.

I dunno. I'd be a lot more positive if it was a $10 game, but it's $20. I'm trying to avoid comparing it to other games, but Hollow Knight is in every way its superior. Salt and Sanctuary is much better as an RPG with Metroidvania elements. Both of those games are less expensive and on more platforms.

I'm disappointed with Chasm.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976926313', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 651, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 556, 'last_played': 1646102656}
review:
The ambiance is insane! I recommend slapping some epic headpones on while playing. Also there are a lot of reviews saying that the game brings nothing new to the table. Could it be that this game is meant to be a good game, without being completely revolutionary? If you take those arguments then half of the original castlevania games were complete garbage..... yet they were epic.

The game had no "early release" stage where demands of players could be developed on the fly. So of course we have a full game (good as it is) which will without a doubt only get better with updates.

As I write this review I have almost 10 hours in the game. How much would it cost you to get 10 hours of enjoyment at a movie theater, or a club? The 20 bucks is a no brainer and the future updates are just icing on the cake.

Disclaimer I know one of the developers. Second disclaimer I know they are working on future updates based on community feedback.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047815272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 417, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1536380406}
review:
I really wanted to like this. I thought all the downvotes were wrong. Turns out, I was. This game is sadly very medoicre. The levels are not that great. There's a lot of unnecessary precision platforming. I don't want pixel perfect jumps all over the place in a metroidvania - especially when you are forced to constantly revisit the same rooms over and over and over again. 

There's tons of backtracking. That's fine, this is a metroidvania, I expect that. But because the game is procedurally generated, warp points are inconvenient. None of the warp points I've hit so far have actually been useful in returning to a place I need to go. They're all just sortof 'in the middle' so you still have to walk through a dozen rooms to get to the thing you want to check out. And walk through the exact same enemies again, except this time they give you 1/1000 of the xp you need to level, so you just jump over them because they're now worthless. 

And as for getting around the game, unfortunately, NONE of the upgrades I've gotten so far (5/8) have increased my _speed_ to get from point A to point B. You're doing the exact same rooms, over and over again, with zero improvement. Great, you got the ability to grab on a ledge. Doesn't let you get through rooms faster, or grab onto *platforms* because those are different. Great, you got the ability to wall jump. Doesn't let you get through rooms faster, because it's super limited in how it works. 

And lets talk about the wall jump. Doesn't work the way every other game does wall jumping - which actually makes it really frustrating to do that. You have to push into the wall to jump away from it - if you push away from the wall before jumping, you fail. /sigh. 

Like I said, I really wanted to like this game. 

The characters you meet in the game seem interesting, but they all have one fetch quest and then they sell you stuff. Not super exciting. Different weapons are ok at best - I haven't come across a 'wow' weapon. Just three basic types - dagger, sword, club - which you occasionally want to switch between to hit inconvenient enemies, but switching weapsons is inconvenient in itself.

Game just feels really average. There are other metroidvanias out there to spend your time on. Pass on this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198407857308', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 491, 'last_played': 1533267663}

author: {'steamid': '76561197996047566', 'num_games_owned': 432, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1177, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1533902686}
review:
I had to think about whether to recommend this game or not, but in the end I had fun with it. The combat is... odd. I felt like I had to fight against all my years of experience with similar games to have any success or fun at all with this game. One really useful bit of information I wish the game had pointed out so I could have started doing it earlier is that you can attack while backdashing, which makes the backdash way more useful, since you can't use it to cancel attacks.

Anyway, the art, exploration and music are all pretty good. I had fun in the end. The procedural elements are really pretty pointless since they seem to just change the chests and the hallways between important rooms. Once I got used to the combat it wasn't bad. It probably wasn't quite worth the $20, but I'm sure it'll go on sale, and I would recommend it then. I guess that's good enough for a thumbs up from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986331966', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1535340957}
review:
Chasm is a game that ought to have been very good and is instead incredibly tedious and boring. The movement feels clunky, hit detection feels weird, there's very little "play" in your movements (and you aren't allowed to cancel much of anything into anything else, which makes the slightly clunky movement feel even more clunky), the game has a ton of rooms with overly precise jumps all over the place (which is frankly unnecessary)...

It's amazing how good the game felt and how much promise it held when it was a demo for a Kickstarter, and the product we  got now... I don't know. I don't think it was worth my multiple-year wait. I really wanted to love Chasm. I desperately, completely wanted to love Chasm. it looks beautiful. It sounds great. It nails the atmosphere. It has a neat story.

It's just a drag to play. A complete, boring drag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961100324', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1082, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1671591647}
review:
Hey, Valve! Where the neutral review option? It's 2018 and there still isn't one. Wtf, Valve....

Everything that you've read in most of the major gaming outlets (PC gamer, Destructiod, RPS, etc.) is all true. This game is exactly what these outlets have said about Chasm. The procedural generation produces bland, monotonous  rooms. The biomes are bland and repetitive. There aren't enough monsters, and even more damning, there isn't enough [i]variation[/i] of monsters. This games deserves every one of the 7/10 "meh" reviews.

So, why am I giving this game the thumbs up? Mainly because I cannot place it in the grey, neutral/MEH zone. Did I have fun with this title (initially)? Yes. Here are my thoughts:

First and foremost, this game became very boring, monotonous, and vapid by the third biome for me. I'm surprised I held out for that long....

[olist]
[*]Chasm is, for all intents and purposes, a Castlevania: Symphony of the Night (SotN) knockoff. This game wants to pride itself as belonging to the "Metroidvania" subgenre, but I fail to experience or see the Metroid part of that portmanteau. The developers, Bit Kid, will say that Chasm is "influenced by" or "pays homage to" the SotN spin-off franchise, but it's hard to see past such modesty when they actively have Konami's testicles deep in their mouths. Even to say that Chasm is a SotN ripoff doesn't do it justice because it also takes several elements from the other SotN derivatives (Aria of Sorrow, Harmony of Dissonance, Circle of the moon, Portait of Run, etc., etc.). So, we're talking an egregious derivative of derivatives!
[*]I still do not understand why indie developers spooge in their pants over the awful nostalgia-driven, hispter bait, pixel art. The background images present in the game look great. Many of the character sprites and animations do not, however, because they exhibit too much awful pixel trash art.
[*]Why do developers still cling to that awful trope of having their character sprites being contantly in motion. Does everyone in this world have palsy?
[*]The music in Chasm leaves a lot to be desired. It's borderline grating. I can appreciate not having a bombastic, orchestral score, but I would appreciate something that's immersive. As it stands right now, all of the tracks I heard sound like the generic muzak produced by royalty-free musician, Kevin Macleod. Seriously, Bit Kid, HIRE A REPUTABLE SOUND DESIGNER!
[*]The biomes in this game could definitely use some TLC. Not enough variation. Not enough life. Also, the catacombs were seemingly ripped straight from SotN down to the ossified background.
[*]There needs to be more monsters, AND greater variation.
[*]You're most likely not playingChasm for the story, but if you were/are, you're out of lucky, Matey McMate mate. The non-story present is enough to be completely not immersed nor interested in the lore and backstory.
[*]While the backslide is stolen directly from SotN and its derivtives, I will appluade this game for actually making it necessary in combat and not just an over-glorified way to move about the game.
[*]I will also applaud this game for having a fairly intricate comabt system in comparison to SotN. It's not simply just ran, hack, jump, hack, etc. You actually have to time your attacks, otherwise you're going to get blasted and take unnecessary damage. Some of the attack patterns/rhythms and hitboxes can be quite obtuse in some instances, though.
[*]Chasm has a straight-forward, clean UI. The inventory management system, character stats, menus are all clear and easy to navigate.
[*]Full controller support (tested with both official Steam controller and PS3 controller). This always gets props from me.
[*]The difficulty (played on Normal) is right in that sweet spot of not being not being too hard, but still has times of being difficult.
[*]Some sound effects were straight up pilfered from SotN. The greatest example is the sound the Knife and most swords make. Compare that to the sounds of the Baselard or the Crissaegrim in SotN. I seriously do not understand how Konami hasn't DMCA'd this game and sued Bit Kids yet. This isn't to say that the sound effects are bad. In my opinion, they are quite good. Some just sound a little too "familiar."
[*]Chasm adopted the awful hand-holding some of the handheld (hyuk...) SotN-derivatives had, in that the map displays a dot on areas of the map that contain unopened chests or tiles you cannot interact with yet.
[*]Further exanding on the previous point, the map mysteriously doesn't display room additions where you've walked through the wall (i.e. a secret room).
[*]Chasm's controls are tight and responsive. Highly important, and Bit Kids nailed this.
[*]The CRT Mode option is a great edition. Despite the aforementioned pixel art, the rest looks like it came straight from the SNES
[*]There are woefully not enough secret areas (i.e. breakable walls, ceilings, floors; hidden areas; puzzles; etcetera) present in the game. Bit Kid, please ADD MORE!
[/olist]


[b]As of right now, I would personally give this game a [u]6/10[/u][/b].

author: {'steamid': '76561198022312447', 'num_games_owned': 639, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1258, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1258, 'last_played': 1535368254}
review: Normally I don't write reviews on steam, but on Chasm I felt like it was necessary. Chasm, I think, is a shining example of a category that is both misunderstood and underappreciated in this day an age: The mid-card game. It's not re-inventing the metroidvania wheel. It's not the longest game ever. It's not got the most original story ever. But all the things it does it does competently. The most brilliant aspect of the game is undoubtedly the art, looking like it came straight from a 16bit console. The controls are tight, the pacing of upgrades is good - even if the use of the shovel was slightly unclear to me. There is a decent challenge to the game and you can grind if you want to or not. The game never felt unfair, even at the last zone/boss where the difficulty ramps considerably. I would definately reccomend this game to any lover of metroidvanias and/or platformers. Just don't expect the next coming of Metroidvania Jesus. This is a mid-card game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097014501', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 590, 'last_played': 1537129509}
review: I'm only six hours into the game, however I'm in love with Chasm. I'm not an avid gamer by any stretch, I'm a busy professional who sometimes has an hour here or an hour there to tune out and play something as an escape. I have only played a handful of new games over the past decade, usually when someone recommends one. Since SotN is one of my all time favorites I was told to check Chasm out. Maybe that's why I like it so much, I don't have a bunch of other recent games I'm comparing it against. I'm only appreciating it for what it is on its own; a retro inspired platform adventure with great art, thoughtful story, and spot on controls. This is exactly the game I would make if I could. Thanks for keeping it simple and getting the important things right.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961883382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 2585, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2585, 'last_played': 1535753947}
review:
After a full completionist run,  I can without a doubt say, this game has one amazing thing going for it. The art. 

Now for the not so good, in no particular order: the music, the combat, the loot, the rng, the enemy layout, the traveling system, the economy.

This game has forced combat method if you engage - and by that I mean you MUST fight with the enemy attack pattern in mind, or you will have a bad time, so prepare to play counter-attack for 10 hours.

Playing this I decided very early on due to the tediousness of combat I would not go for 100% drops. About halfway through I figured, I would go for it. I waited until levl 35 or so, with full luck gear to back track for those drops that I was missing.

20 hours later I finished, with many of the rares taking 2 hours or more. I began letting myself die to save the trip back to a save point to save time. I then began investing in high tonics, to spam dagger throw to kill from a distance and quickly, or injuring and using the emerald dagger for the finishing blow to increase drop rates.

It was the most absolute unenjoyable completionist run of any metroidvania I've ever had. I still have to go through the "Mortal Mode" for the last achievement, but the inability to skip the intro scene / setup makes restarting runs a pain when trying out nightmare mode. You cannot copy a save in Mortal mode, all copied instances of the save are disabled when you die as well, so this cannot be used as a work around.

If you have an immense retrovania itch to scratch, then buy this on sale, if it all. Otherwise invest elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561197963765812', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1463, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1327, 'last_played': 1588909486}
review:
Chasm is... Astoundingly mediocre. It's not offensively bad, but it's not particularly good either. It's stuck in the old-timey Metroidvania ways of the past, denying the player the ability to attack while moving unless they exploit their superior air control. It even directly apes Castlevania: Symphony of the Night's control scheme, which is dated and kind of unwieldy. If the developers had a time machine and somehow released this game in this state five years ago, it would have been a huge hit. But as of now, it's unfortunately overshadowed by other similar games that have taken a more modern approach to the genre.

I've played through all but the final area on hard and have felt like the difficulty was fair. I don't hate the game, and I've enjoyed my time with it. The spritework is great, the animation is gorgeous, and the music is good... It just feels pretty repetitive, and the limited procedural generation of the dungeon doesn't make it feel unique enough to overcome the lack of enemy variety. Or the stale enemy placement. Or the lack of variation to enemy attack patterns. Or the lack of abilities the player has to attack or evade with at any given time. Or how there's almost nothing to ever interact with in the environment. Or how frustratingly lengthy the fast-travel system is.

There's an entire laundry list of problems, really, and a large number of them exist specifically because of the bad habits Chasm picked up in pursuit of Symphony of the Night. But even if it's not ferociously pushing the genre forward, Chasm is doing some interesting things, like incorporating some mild survival elements by limiting the inventory of NPC shops. And the game is slowly getting better. If Bit Kid continues to work on it post-release like they have been, I believe they'll overcome most of the bigger issues it currently has.

The Bit Kid crew has serious promise. Chasm may never quite be the masterpiece they (or we) wanted it to be, but I hope they aren't disheartened. I look forward to seeing what they accomplish in another five years with what they've learned from it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970319688', 'num_games_owned': 1034, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1260, 'last_played': 1533665563}
review:
"Well, it's pretty to look at." I feel like that one sentence can summarize a lot of the indie games that have out in the last few months. I backed Chasm on Kickstarter, and after a long wait...the result is kinda meh. Not bad, but certainly not great.

To get to the high points of the game first, graphically Chasm is a nicely drawn and animated 2D pixel art game, in the style of the 16bit era of consoles. The monster designs are well done, well drawn, and well animated. The player character is as well. The dungeon areas have distinct looks and biomes and again are well drawn. Sound design is functional though nothing spectacular, and the music is decent but unmemorable.

The core idea of Chasm is the semi-random map generator: the devs created rooms, but how areas of the map are pieced together from those room do change somewhat, as well as item placement in chests and NPCs you can discover to repopulate the town above the dungeon. In practice, it works OK. Again- impressively functional but not great. It does what it's supposed to, but you can't really have memorable areas if you don't hand place everything and you have to limit the shapes of the rooms so it works with your generator.

More problems come in the movement abilities- which are very clunky. Backdashes have a noticeably delay which makes them useless for dodging. There are also delays when "attaching" to walls and ledges with the wall jump or ledge hang abilities, which makes it feel way way worse than every other Metroidvania ever.

Then finally come the enemies and weapons. They're decently animated and designed, however the enemy attack patterns are fairly repetitive for 75% of the game. In addition, due to how weapon hitboxes come out and a strange design choice where landing from a jump resets your attack swing, the optimal gameplay for 90% of enemies is to continuously jump over their head and do two attacks. Nothing terrible 'wrong' with it, but a bit boring and not a great design.

And that's pretty much it. The theme of it all: Chasm is 'fine', but it's not particularly 'great'.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062220379', 'num_games_owned': 963, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2034, 'last_played': 1534341932}
review:
Chasm could be described as an homage to the older titles of the Castlevania -series. You explore areas in a 2d environment, gather items and abilities, unlock new areas as you progress and fight the occasional boss. There are spells to cast, weapons have different speeds, ranges and damage numbers, and you can level up your character as well. Bigger and heavier weapons are usually more cumbersome to use than light weapons, affecting for example the length of the attack animation.

The levels you explore are also somewhat procedurally randomized each time you start a new game, altough I feel the changes aren't drastic enough that you should even notice a difference while playing. There are six different areas/tilesets which doesn't feel quite enough, but isn't horrible either. Exploring is generally fun, but can get tedious if you happen to backtrack through an area for the fifth time.

The game is somewhat short (about 10 hours),  but maybe that's just because I enjoyed the game and wanted to explore more areas. All-in all, I'd definitely recommend Chasm if you are looking for a good quality Metroidvania type of game.
