author: {'steamid': '76561198053401690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1327, 'last_played': 1535405820}
review:
После долгих ожиданий игра наконец-то вышла. Сквозь орды нечисти мы спускаемся в бездну, разгадывая тайну древнего короля. Поначалу игра весьма радует - шикарный пиксель-арт, хорошее управление, интересные и разнообразные враги. Из минусов можно подметить только сюжет уровня "для галочки", музыку (в каждой зоне свой унылый отрезок в несколько секунд, повторяющийся бесконечно) и отсутствие визульного разнобразия на уровне - за небольшими исключениями каждый огромный уровень сложен из примерно одних и тех же невыразительных тоннелей.

Но чем дольше играешь, тем яснее становится главный для меня недостаток - нефункциональная карта, на которой обозначена только общаая структура уровня и некоторые точки интереса (далеко не все). Мы постоянно встречаем непроходимые пока препятствия, алтари на которые нужно положить то, чего у нас пока нет и т.д. Большинство из этого на карте не отображатеся. А если отобраатеся, то просто точкой или синим квадратиком. То есть когда мы находим например фонарик, то приходится обходить все уровни, в поисках мест куда раньше было не пройти из-за темноты.

Все бы ничего, но уровни большие, и монстры респавнятся когда мы покидаем экран, и местами присутствуют довольно сложные участки с платформами, шипами и прочим. И чем дальше проходишь, тем больше эта проблема усугубляется. То есть, например, чтобы посетить еще раз арену, мне придется обыскивать вообще весь уровень (хорошо еще если помнишь на каком она уровне). В общем, потратив 3 унылейших вечера на поиски алтаря, на которой надо положить очередную цацку, коротый я точно где-то видела но не помню даже на каком уровне, я поняла что пора бросать игру и заняться чем-то поинтереснее. Например, смотреть как сохнет краска. 

То есть основной челлендж в игре - это не интересные монстры, не сложный платформигнг, а хоеновая карта. Игра не уважает время игрока, поэтому не могу ее порекомендовать.

ps Ах да, огромный плюс за поддержку Logitech Rumblepad 2. В большинстве остальных игр в последнее время приходится прыгать с бубном чтобы оно заработало

author: {'steamid': '76561198017381248', 'num_games_owned': 1611, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 4253, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3510, 'last_played': 1642396283}
review:
[h1] A great game with a promising future! [/h1]

After five years of waiting, Chasm finally arrived! I got the honor of interviewing James after the convention (E3 I think?) where I saw it, and have been checking out some of the early builds over the years. The final product is a game that I fine very satisfying, both directly and subtly full of nostalgic references (gelatinous cube from D&D, something like the mushboom from Secret of Mana, and the vine crawling bug from Super Mario Bros 2 and likely other games) all wrapped in a non-vampiric Castlevania SotN-like wrapper. 

The art and animation are rather beautiful in a modern retro style, audio design of both music and sound effects (and their timing) are solid, proportions of character size relative to movement speed and jump height are extremely comfortable and easy to work with, and bugs are both minimal and comical (and get fixed when you report them in Discord). The flow of gameplay is fun and satisfying, and I'm already on my fifth run now that the Class system has been added. 

Bug fixes and the class system represent just the tip of the iceberg for this game's future. There's and obvious late-game event that appears to set the stage for future content to be added. The developers seem to be eager to add more features, and I'm excited to see where Chasm will go from here!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068505820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 948, 'last_played': 1670444904}
review:
Chasm is a fantastic game that does a great job at paying tribute to old school platformers.  It has amazing art and animation.  The one thing I somewhat dislike is that after using an auto attack you character has a momentary follow through animation you cannot cancel or break so you really have to learn how to be proficiency with attacking.

The game IS challenging and is NOT going to hold your hand.  It is like Super Metriod from the Super Nintendo and often does NOT give you guidance on where to go or what to do.  It relies on you knowing how to use your map and have the ambition to explore areas left uncharted.  Along with having the same relative upgrade system that means some areas are inaccessable until you get the appropriate artifact to go back and explore it.

The game, does it right.  It takes an old SNES platformer and makes it feel so very modern.  For the youth of this generation, this is what good games were like in the 90s/early 2000s.  This game was a brilliant nostaligia throw back to that time period and it added so much more.  The RPG inventory system is so much fun.  You get excited with every new item or piece of gear you get.  The one real disappointment in that regard is that late game gear you find or craft is virtually worthless if you found some of the better items.  I felt like for sure the crafting items because of how long it would take to acquire the ingots should have been the better tier gear.. but it was not.

Absolutely LOVED this game IMO.  It was so much fun.  And despite a few frustrations it was an overwhleming positive experience.  I am greatly looking forward to replaying the game on their Hardcore mode perma death setting.  

If you are looking to play a game that guides you.. holds your hand.. gives you quest markets.. probably best you pick another game.  This game is not meant for people that need that level of hand holding.  It is meant to challenge your intellect and make you figure things out.  For those that truly invest into the game you would not be disappointed.  Walk in understanding that this is not a modern style game thats made easy for your convenience.

For anyone interested, please check out this game on my youtube channel.  I cannot say enough good things about the game in this review:  https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVPj4mBnXSzl8vUIqIzyzDQ

author: {'steamid': '76561198006526576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1702710088}
review:
I first saw Chasm at PAX several years ago. I was instantly drawn to it based on its artstyle. Its pixel art is very reminiscent of classic Gameboy Advance games, while not actually being directly derivative, and I'm a big fan of it.

Seemingly forever since then (It turns out indie development can be slow) it's finally here. So what did they deliver?

Chasm is a metroidvania (heavy on the vania) game with a slight procedural twist: Your gameworld is procedurally generated when you start the game. But this isn't a rogue-like or rogue-lite or whatever you want to call it. This gameworld stays consistent the entire game. The procedural generation, then, is purely a feature to add replay value. I admittedly have not played it through more than once, so I can't say how much the game world changes between games. The map seems to tend a little too much toward long corridors and vertical shafts in between large rooms, which I assume is due to the its procedural nature. 

In terms of gameplay, Chasm leans heavily on Castlevania. Combat is not fast-paced or nimble compared to others in the genre, but is very sensitive to where you are and when you decide to backstep or jump. Enemies deal small hits that add up quickly enough to threaten death while travelling, and for much of the game I had only a few healing items. The enemies' patterns are easily learnable, though, and after a few exposures to a new enemy I was rarely taking damage any more. The spells in the game are straight from Castlevania. There was something a little strange with the spells - I felt like unless I optimized my build for them they were almost not worth using, but once I did optimize my build for them they were overpowering. I would have liked to see a little more middle ground there.

The plot of Chasm is nothing to phone home about. It's a pretty simple story of people stumbling into an ancient evil and our stalwart (and silent) protagonist having to deal with it. There's some things in the lore text about the hero possibly being a person of pure good or the villain being from another dimension, but I didn't really feel like these details influenced the scenario much at all. The protagonist is just a cipher doing his job and the villain is just a monster attacking because it's what it does. Which is fine, I didn't come into this expecting Shakespeare.

In summary Chasm is a solid game which was entertaining and kept me playing, but it wasn't groundbreaking. I'll be interested to see what the developers plan to do next.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040246919', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1549176004}
review:
先说结论: 缺点不少, 但还是可以一玩
-----------------
 + 美术
精美的像素风格, 远景和近景的结合非常完美

 + 谜题
谜题不多, 但是解谜方式挺新颖

 + 音乐
大多不错

 - 场景设计
使用随机生成迷宫的代价就是场景简陋和重复, 让人没有什么探索的欲望;
如果这是个roguelike游戏那没什么, 但是在metrovania类型下就是一个很严重的缺点

 - 操作
手感相当一般, 攻击硬直啥的可以接受(毕竟恶魔城也是有这类武器的), 但是出现硬直后不能接蹲/后跳等操作(这也间接导致后跳变成鸡肋), 恶魔城式的[落地取消硬直]在这里也不是那么好用, 因为不少武器挥舞速度很慢, 挥舞结束前落地还是会进入硬直, 而且即使相同类型的武器挥舞速度也会略有不同, 使得用起来更难受. 我已经尽力去适应这个硬直但是还是会经常卡点;
另外攀爬和抓悬崖两个技能结合非常容易导致操作失误.

 - 平衡性
游戏的平衡性设计得并不好.
1.首当其冲的就是副武器系统. 游戏前期副武器相当鸡肋(前期普通平砍>>副武器, 副武器不受STR加成, 但角色普通攻击是依赖STR的, 而且前期角色MP低也无法大量使用); 然而到了中后期, 副武器却强得让平砍变得毫无意义, 足够MP让副武器的使用频率大大提高, 高等级副武器强大的杀伤力和范围, 再加上商店出售的强化饰品更让副武器强到IMBA;
2.滑铲杀伤力不和武器伤害挂钩, 这里可以理解作者是想追求真实性, 但是作为攻击方式的一种, 伤害不同处理就显得很奇怪;
3.打造系统, 打造的装备强度太低, 跟收集材料的难度不成正比.
(其他还有不少问题就不一一列举了)

 - 怪物图鉴
图鉴需要杀同一只怪物多次后才能解锁, 除了拖长开图鉴的时间外, 不理解这么设计的意义何在

author: {'steamid': '76561198022382239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 755, 'last_played': 1665789284}
review:
I backed this on kickstarter.

It's much better than a lot of the reviews out there make it seem like.

The combat is a little one note, but the gameplay has a lot of flow and it gets even better with every upgrade and levelup. Its not an extremely long game. I guess you can see everything one map has to offer in about 9 - 10 hours. Then you could start again on a different seed. I don't know how the random generation fares, but my dungeon had pretty cool design and almost no duplicate rooms.

Didn't want to play through a second time though.

Some of the bosses toward the end and maybe even the last part of the dungeon feel a little slapdash, but most of the content here is fine. I especially love the art style and animations of those enemies - and there are lots of baddies to fight. Sure, some of them are just very basic, but there are more devious ones later on.

Overall, this game is pretty cool and I'm glad it came out after all this time. Maybe not one of the Kickstarter greats, but an awesome thing nonetheless.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992760436', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1856, 'last_played': 1535180728}
review:
[h1]Nostalgia at a Price[/h1]
[i]For TL;DR you can read only bold sections[/i]

I have been looking forward to Chasm for a long time. I didn't back it on Kickstarter, and didn't know anything about it other than it was a Metroidvania type of game, with pixel art, and a look to it highly reminiscent of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. [b]I began playing with no expectations, only a hope that it would recapture the classic feel of SOTN.[/b]

Here's the thing about Chasm: it's a bit [i]too[/i] inspired by SOTN for its own good. Now, it's not a bad thing to want to emulate one of the greats in a particular genre. Chasm has plenty of weapons, armor, and accessories to find, secrets to discover, and enemies to fight. [b]Slain enemies erupt into flames and splatter pixelised gore across the ground in perfect immitation of SOTN, which is just as satisfying now as it was in 1997[/b]. You gain access to spells early on which match the traditional special attacks of our favorite vampire hunter family: daggers you toss in a line, axes that arc up, and flasks to fling against the floor which spout flames, among others. There are also all the basic RPG stats you would expect.

These things all come together and scratch the itch you might be feeling if you've been wanting to go back and replay one of the old Castlevania games. Except...the itch doesn't go away. It gets worse, and it's because [b]while Chasm does its best to bring the feel of those games that inspired it, it brings along more baggage than it can comfortably carry.[/b]

Small things first. Combat, while enjoyable enough at the outset, can become tedious and feels somewhat clunky overall. A delay exists after player attack animations where you are unable to take further actions. It doesn't take long to adjust your playstyle to account for this, and can be avoided entirely by attacking while jumping, but [b]combat never feels quite as tight as it should[/b]. Sometimes this sort of delay with attacks is an intentional design choice, and is actually an important part of the original Castlevania's game design. In Chasm though it feels out of place, like combat just didn't get that last bit of fine tuning.

Secrets are a mainstay of the Metroidvania genre and Chasm certainly has them, but unfortunately they are by and large poorly implemented. Most are painfully obvious (e.g. a hidden section of wall you can walk through positioned in a place you are naturally jumping to anyway), and aren't fun or satisfying to discover. Some rooms are "optional," containing a handful of hazards to navigate through in order to reach a treasure chest. Unfortunately, these [b]bonus room chests are often anti-climactic side-grades not worth your while.[/b] Depending on when you reach them, they may end up being downgrades. While this should be expected to some extent in a game like this, it happens far more frequently than it should, as most of your equipment upgrades come about naturally as you progress through "main" rooms you are required to go through.

One of Chasm's selling points is in its procedural generation. This sounds exciting, but on a scale to 10 the actual varience between maps is maybe a 2 or 3 tops. On subsequent playthroughs you may find a few small rooms and hallways in different locations, but these differences are inconsequential unless perhaps you are doing several playthroughs back to back. The thing is [b]by the time you finish one play through, you will have wandered through the same rooms dozens of times, trudging your way back and forth from one location to another in the biggest downfall of this game: backtracking.[/b]

Of course, a defining feature of the genre is going back to previously explored locations after unlocking some new ability; using a new slide to get through a low passage or double jumping up to a formerly too-high ledge. Chasm takes this to extremes, [b]and if I didn't spend more time backtracking than making actual progress in new areas then it certainly felt like it.[/b] The longer I played, the worse this issue became. Earning a new environment-traversing ability, making your way back through countless rooms to reach a chest which before was just out of reach and finding it contains only a bit of armor weaker than what you already have, or a single piece of health-recovering food is always a let-down. A lack of detail in the map and inability to mark rooms in any way other than adding a dot exacerbate the problem. Luckily if you get too lost or frustrated trying to remember which dead-end you'll now be able to overcome after gaining a skill, you can find a guide thanks to how little the map changes between playthroughs.

It's not all bad. The game is decent if you can get past the backtracking and archaic design choices (teleporter rooms you must  activate, watch the animation, and then repeat until you cycle through to the correct room was annoying in SOTN and it's just as annoying now). The music and atmosphere is fine, but not stand-out. A passable story which does little for keeping you interested and characters you won't end up emotionally attached to, while not deal-breakers on their own, certainly don't help elevate Chasm.

[b]Despite all this, I recommend playing Chasm and here's why: I feel it's important to play through games that are just OK in order to more completely appreciate other games in the same genre which excel.[/b] Chasm is an OK game, but more than that it is an important reminder of how far the Metroidvania genre has come over the last 20 or so years. The developer clearly loves this type of game, and [b]while Chasm may not sit on the same level as similar games I want to see more of what Bit Kid has to offer.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561197971273881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1535132213}
review:
I really enjoyed the graphics and the controls, the moves are fluent and easy to be familiar with.
The combat system is ok, but it lacks diversity. You basically have only two types of attacks, physical or magic, but there is not a big choice between them.
Moreover, some key items seem a bit redoundant (grip vs wall jump).

The big issue for me are the very annoying plateform phases which are not what I expect from a metroidvania game. It doesn't make sense to me to have added this gameplay. 

Overall the game is not a bad game. The basics are here, and I hope the devs will improve the game.
 But it lacks some creativity and content and the fail & retry type of gameplay is really not what I like.
I would not recommend it to a friend so far.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983511231', 'num_games_owned': 1086, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 621, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 621, 'last_played': 1534480487}
review:
"Mixed" is right.

The pixel art is gorgeous. The game itself is meh, but was decent enough to hold my attention until the end. So thumbs up, but marginal.

There's a lot wrong though: the procedural map generation made a map with way too many long coridoors in my playthrough, the timing on the backdash means that it's better to just try to tank hits than avoid them, there's no reason to use anything other than the knives as your magic spell, and while I have a screenshot claiming I have 100% map completion, the achievement for it never popped.

Still. If you don't have anything to play, and it's on sale for $5, the game is at least functional and completable and contains some very beautiful art. Don't pay full price for it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059114721', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 160, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1535079925}
review:
I cut right to the chase. This game is an absolute love letter to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Maybe not specifically in tone, but I have yet to play a game that has nailed what made its mechanics so great. I've seen a lot of Metroidvania style games that emulate an open world, striving for deep exploration.. but one thing they all did was spin their own formula that was really just an analog to something similar to Super Metroid.

None of them have taken cues from what made Castlevania so great. Chasm nails it.

You'll note in the opening screen a "seed" number. When you play each playthrough, the game randomly generates a pattern for each specific area and the enemy layout. But this isn't a roguelike. Instead, it simply switches up the formula each time, so room patterns won't feel stale. Is there a draw back to this? Yes. For one, there isn't too much uniqueness to "most" given room layouts. The game still benefits in that each area isn't so large, that you cannot remember the seeded layout you generated, however. I found myself remembering enough of each seeded layout to be able to backtrack to closed off areas enough. The size of each section is perfect.

The music is okay. The mines can be a little repetitive, sometimes.. but it didn't really bother me. The keep music really rocked.

The battle system is really where this game shines the best. Its fast, fluid, and full of playstyle customization, just like SoTN was. The feel is almost 1 to 1 to it. You can get cool benefits from the gear you get. There are even rare drops off monsters,  for the ultimate load out and playstyle chaser. It feels well balanced, the whip weapon feels exactly like how a Castlevania would feel and I can tell the developer put a TON of heart to get that perfect. The boss fights feel exciting, the game is pretty challenging, and I feel this is a labor of love.

Definitely pick this up, I love the feel that harkens back to a style long forgotten.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964982259', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 690, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1533259050}
review: It's ok, not as long as I had hoped. The game was kind of easy most of the time with little to no difficulty in steamrolling your way to the boss, most of the time the only difficult parts were finding out where to go next due to poor directional advice provided in the game. It took me 11.5 hrs to beat the game, but i'd imagine 4 or more hours were me backtracking and going the wrong way because I got lost. The in-game map offers almost no benefit and is extremely barebones and frustrating. The procedural generated areas were meh and you could tell because they would repeate often. I voted to recommend this game because there aren't a lot of metroidvania's out there, and though it is not a great metroidvania it is still a "good" game and definetly worth a buy on sale if you are interested in these types of games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124918358', 'num_games_owned': 2086, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 882, 'last_played': 1534878959}
review: Chasm is a solid entry in the Metroidvania genre. I impulively  bought the game on day one after getting notified about its release in a Steam e-mail, since it was on my wish list for four years or so, but I have not been anticipating it like the kickstarter backers. I usually don't buy games on day one (my last day one game purchase goes back to 2000, when Baldur's Gate 2 was released), but I don't regret having done so. The awesome pixel art and the controlls make playing it fell like it is on Super Nintendo, and that's what I expected it to be. Some people complain about the controlls, or going through similar looking (randomly generated) rooms, or about the backtracking, but those guys probably never played a platformer before, or a rouge like, or even a Metroidvania. My only gripes with this game are the difficulty and the crafting aspects; on normal difficulty it was clearly too easy, and I went through the game with minimal crafting / upgrading spells which is either good or bad, depending whether you like crafting or not. Guess people who look for a challenge should play it on hard right away, maybe crafting is more important on the highest difficulty. Other than that I clearly enjoyed the game and can recommend it to anyone looking for a nice Metroidvania experience with lovely pixel graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000426874', 'num_games_owned': 1723, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1534827706}
review:
I had a lot of fun with this game. Classic Metroidvania leaning heavily towards SOTN. There were a few draw backs but mostly it was a really good time.

Pros
--Feels and plays like SOTN
--Game is super polished and mostly bug free
--The music is really good
--Graphics and animations are great
--Rewarding RPG progression
--Lots of items to find
--Big world to explore
--Side quests are a neat addition to the formula
--Tons of enemies drawing inspiration from Castlevania and Metroid

Cons
--Too easy once you get near the end
--Every sub weapon seems useless (aside from the shield and the knives)
--No real replay value unless you just want to play a different map
--Story is okay but it never really got me invested in it
--Once you have decent gear and you are lvl 30+ the final boss is a total joke
--Strange difficulty spikes, I found myself having much more trouble against regular enemies than I did bosses

author: {'steamid': '76561198088380961', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1697839756}
review:
[h1]Resumo: Curte jogos com movimentação e jogabilidade fluida e ou rápida? Então esse jogo não é para você![/h1]

Chasm é um jogo que conheci enquanto procurava por metrovanias a uns anos atrás, na época ainda em desenvolvimento me fez querer muito joga-lo, tanto pelo pixel art, quanto pela semelhanças a Castlevania. Fiz questão de o comprar no dia que lançou. Para a minha surpresa (negativa), o jogo não era 1/3 do que esperava. 

Na parte visual o jogo tem (fora a parte inicial) uma que outra área bem trabalhada... Sem o mapa séria fácil se peder pela falta de individualidade dos locais, sendo a musica completamente esquecivel (durante meu gameplay só lembrava que ela existia nos saves e na cidade de TÃO parecida que ela nos outros lugares).

Na parte de gameplay, o jogo segue a formula de Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia, mas de um jeito ruim, os NPCs que você resgata são na maioria interessantes, entretanto a falta de história para a maioria deles te dá a sensação que foram esquecidos durante o desenvolvimento do jogo... Quanto a exploração da dungeon, é aquela coisa, vai e volta 1 milhão de vezes na medida que você pega os artefatos que te permitem chegar a lugares antes impossivel, porem durante a exploração/combate é normal ficar frustado com o quão travado o protagonista é, flexibilidade e fluideza não existem aqui! Exemplos: 
[list]
[*] Sem ter como cancelar ataques é normal você ficar olhando enquanto o protagonista apanha de graça, porque não pode fazer nada em 2 ~ 3 segundos se animação. Isso é contornavel pulando e atacando (porque você pode se mexer pelo menos) mas ainda assim não é anormal você acabar atacando na direção errada...
[*] O dash é somente para trás (backdash), se você está acostumado as mecanicas de esquiva da maioria dos jogos, esqueça, mesmo o backdash não té da invencibilidade nenhuma, além de não ser muito instantaneo (é impossivel combar bem um ataque com o backdash, melhor decorar o padrão de ataque do inimigo e recuar quando ele for atacar). Mesmo a 'rasteira' não te deixa invencivel, então nada de deslizar pelos inimigos, se te botarem contra uma parede pode ser fim de jogo facilmente.
[/list]
Mas o que pode te deixar mais indignado [i]700% putaço[/i] é a mecanica de pulo e de escalar paredes. Não queira ser rápido quando for fazer um desses dois, você vai errar (ou o jogo vai te fazer errar) e você não vai gostar de voltar pro inicio de uma sala, ou de morrer para o dano de ambiente (a lá 'lava' ou seja o que for aquilo no jogo, gas venenoso? Ironicamente, sendo a unica coisa de dano fixo, que ainda vai doer no end game).

Na parte de dificuldade, o jogo é artificialmente dificil, os inimigos tem 1, raramente 2 padrões de ataque (a maioria tem um ataque para cima, a fim de evitar você pular por eles, então não faça isso). Que não se misturam, a maioria tem uma fase de preparo (animção que mostra que vai fazer algo) e uma fase de ataque (aonde ele realmente tenta te acertar), uma ou duas vezes vendo um inimigo e você não vai mais morrer para ele, salvo se fizer algo idiota (por isso da dificuldade artiificial). Fora a área inicial do jogo, dificilmente você vai ter que lutar contra dois inimigos ao mesmo tempo, o que é estranho pois ah uma árena no jogo, que mistura duplas de inimigo tornando o jogo REALMENTE difiicil sem ser artificial (por mais que o combo seja um inimigo melee e um inimigo ranged que batem muuuuuuito forte). 
Uma das poucas coisas que me deixava apreensivo no jogo (e que a certo modo eram a minha parte divertidade dele) é a distancia entre saves e escasses de itens de cura, é normal se você não for cuidadoso acabar com pouca vida atravessamdo a dungeon sem saber quando vai vir o proximo save.

[h1]Vale a pena jogar?[/h1]
Só na ausência de algo melhor para jogar (arrisco dizer Castlevania SotN e OfE continuam sendo mais interessantes), e estando em promoção pois é um jogo compravel por 20 barões, mas por 40 é um roubo pelas 10 horas (se estendendo) e pouco conteudo de jogo. Talvez no futuro os devs corrijam adicionem mais coisas, até lá é um jogo que pode (e vai) te fazer passar raiva e te deixar entediado muitas vezes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136620481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1571751994}
review:
好玩!! 動作流暢手感很好，整體來說滿分10分得7.5分
總結來說是個像是要向惡魔城致敬的游戲，但長度、深度都差了那麼一點
部份關卡具有解謎成份，雖然沒有支援繁、簡中文，但游戲內的英文並不會很難
若能在特價時入手是相當的不錯！

另外如果出DLC的話我一定買!

優點：
手感好、流暢
滑壘、二段跳、滑翔傘(?)
美術設計很得我心
通關拿到2種使魔
副武器
劇情不錯

缺點：
稍嫌不足的是劇情偏短
武器種類看不出明顯的特色，感覺只差在硬直的時間，從頭到尾用長劍就可以通關了
武器沒有特殊效果，例如火、冰、雷、毒之類的效果。
雖然有解毒藥劑，但玩到通關好像也只有遇到1個怪物會有讓角色中毒的效果，後面完全沒有會使毒的怪物
游戲內有多種藥劑，但好像也沒有多大的用處，最有效的就是補血藥
有些時候進入存檔房間時會卡幀，但還好不影響游戲體驗
音樂稍嫌單調，一個關卡內都是同一個音樂不會變
使魔(鳥、劍)在升級後似乎在外觀沒有改變

author: {'steamid': '76561197993491971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1534687782}
review:
I'm a backer of this on kickstarter and I think I'm pretty happy with the result. 

The graphics are beautiful the sound is good and the progression is pretty well balanced. The plot is serviceable.

 The drawbacks are that it has enormous amounts of backtracking because you unlock skills and are never quite sure if you can now get some of the areas you couldn't reach before. The backtracking is important too as a lot of progression critical items or townspeople are in old areas.

The ability to make notes on the map or a free return to town ability would have been appreicated.

The idea of proc gen dungeons seems odd. It makes looking up guides almost useless. I don't think a lot of people are going to play this game multiple times. Perhaps a more tailored dungeon would have made the backtracking less of a chore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094827328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1890, 'last_played': 1701394919}
review:
I look forward to what's in store for the game as it progresses. I really hope it has some consistency in patch output but I understand the development has been a long road. A female Sprite and possibly a playable Monster sprite would enhance the experience. I truly think that the input delay should really be changed and a lot tighter. It's a very common complaint that Super Mario 2, 3, World, etc etc etc. Maybe even 1 have better response. I can see some of these were fixed recently.
Weapons dont need an overhaul but their differences should be more relevant. I LOVE THAT YOU PUT IN ATTACK ANIMATION RESETS. It is VERY satisfying to be rewarded with practice and skill at doing so. It's also a large issue for me that its viewed as a bad thing in other similar games & to my (limited) knowledge non-existent.

I think if there was also a survival mode outside of mortal, where you started with all the upgrades and made health & mana more scarce with simple checkpoints & higher weapon drop rates it should not only be attainable with the current assets of the game. I dont think it's worth 20 bucks to everyone but I know i got this game on subjective taste rather than any slightly more objective elements such as others have stated themselves. Nor did i have wide expectations for it. I found out about it randomly a few weeks back when it came out.

I dont really care for Procedurally Genned however A LOT of people expected that. Maybe this gametype i suggested could really simplify the use of the assets. However I'm not a dev so I dont know the complexity of it.

Overall really great game & product. I deeply respect labors of Love and Ill support them more readily than i will big name "blockbuster" games.

I suggest this game for those who like something of moderate difficulty, where enemies are obstacles rather than AI (which i dont mind my enemies being like puzzles) & who wants a fairly relaxing experience. The game is a sensation. I do however think it's needs to be no more than 15 dollars and no less than 10. If it was 5 the game would go like friggin hot cakes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014896810', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4087, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2593, 'last_played': 1580645050}
review:
Chasm est le Metroidvania que j'attendais. Clairement !
Après avoir suivi sa campagne Kickstarter et joué à la démo, je n'étais pas particulièrement chaud, le prenant pour un rogue-like à la mode comme le tiers des jeux qui sortent actuellement.

Contre toute attente, ce n'était pas du tout le cas. En l'occurrence, il s'agit réellement d'un Metroidvania piquant dans les meilleures références du passé telles que Metroid, Castlevania à partir de SOTN, Ys III, Wonder Boy, etc. Croyez-moi, l'ambiance, le gameplay, l'esprit est là !

On peut lire de (très) nombreuses critiques négatives décrivant finalement un genre de jeu dans son ensemble par des joueurs qui n'ont vraisemblablement jamais eu connaissance des références indiquées. Je vous le dis : Si vous avez réellement connu et apprécié l'époque des jeux évoqués ci-dessus, Chasm est fait pour vous !

POSITIF :
- Tout l'esprit d'un Metroidvania est là. Tel un Metroid, Castlevania SOTN+, mais aussi Wonder Boy et Ys III
- Un design 2d impeccable.
- Une maniabilité à l'image de ses références, et plus précise encore !
- Des combats basés sur l'apprentissage de l'ennemi, et non l'aléatoire.
- Aucun mécanisme de temps limite, si ce n'est une médaille de félicitations après la fin du jeu. Vous jouez à votre rythme !
- Une vraie map utile intégrale, et des marqueurs personnalisés.
- Un univers riche ainsi qu'un scénario intéressant et bienvenu.
- Des musiques qui collent au rythme du jeu.
- Vous êtes récompensés parce que vous êtes bons, grâce aux récompenses. Mais vous pouvez gérer quand même si vous êtes mauvais, grâce au loot.

NEGATIF :
- Impossibilité de se retourner après une attaque sautée.
- La génération procédurale a été un effort de développement conséquent inutile.

PS : Je vous recommande d'activer le mode CRT afin de profiter au mieux du rendu visuel du jeu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198140771500', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1984, 'last_played': 1534527825}
review:
Very fun game. I'd definitely recommend at least trying it if you're a fan of games like Castlevania SotN, PoR, OoE, etc. 

I don't ordinarily do reviews so apologies if I ramble on overmuch.

At first I felt the combat was a little stiff with the sword and hid behind the range of the whip a lot, but then as I got further along I learned how to make better use of the sword. It seems to be the most common weapon type and because of that, it'll often be the best one you've got. But what turned me off to the sword at first was my inability to backdash quickly after attacking. I don't remember how it was in some older Metroidvanias with backdash, but in many of the newer ones you can cancel an attack into a backdash for more nimble offense/defense. With the sword in this one you're fixed in place until the attack animation finishes. I learned to get around this by tapping backdash a split second BEFORE attacking, and that helped a lot. I also learned to do the midair-attack-land-attack combination pretty well and that quick double slash saved me a lot of grief. These were the ways I got around that stiff feeling after I couldn't hide behind the range of whips anymore. This would have certainly been my biggest complaint had I not found ways around it.

I've seen people complain about backtracking a lot as you get more maneuverability options and keys but eh, that's part of the charm of these types of games to me and I've played a whole bunch of them, so it's par for the course. There was only one time near the end that I felt really lost, before finally remembering this one door near the beginning of the garden. But I never resented wandering around (and powering up the assassin sword in the meantime) 

My final comment on this will be about the music. On the one hand, it's not bad, and I even understand the sort of earthy, sort of tribal vibe it evokes. Goes along with the story. That said, I think the BGM was just too chill at times. I feel a game like this is better served by a more upbeat soundtrack. I did like the song for the Keep though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056179747', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2192, 'last_played': 1609192548}
review:
This game was absolutely amazingly fun! I finished the main quest and did every bit of side content I could find! I searched every nook and cranny, in hopes of prolonging my enjoyment as I explored the depths of Chasm's world. I thoroughly enjoyed the journey, from start to finish, and I had fun, all the way through. 

SO yeah. Ultimately, I had fun. And that's the point of a game, right? To have fun while completing challenges? I had a lot of that, while I traversed the beautifully crafted game. 

For many of the reviewers here, fun doesn't seem to be enough, unfortunately... It's baffling to me how many people straight up said they HAD FUN, but wouldn't recommend the game... wait, what? You don't recommend a fun game? Seems to me people are more in touch with their personal [i]armchair game developement theories[/i] than they are with the reality that they HAD FUN. It breaks my heart that such a lovely game, one made by only 5 people, would receive such harsh critiques. 

But enough of that! Here's some more important info on my experience. 

[b]What I found to be fun: [/b]
[list]
[*] [b]The art:[/b] It's so amazing to look at all the detail put into the game, from the animated characters, to the paralax backgrounds. Very inspiring, especially as an artist myself. 
[*] [b]Combat:[/b] I felt the combat challenges scaled very well! I am not a master gamer by any means, but having played on normal difficulty, I found that the balance of easy and challenging monsters was well balanced. Some of the more challenging monsters were at first quite frustrating... until I realized that I just needed to be smart about how I fight them. After a bit of experimentation, I discovered that each monster has some sort of timing or weakness that can be exploited by just paying attention to their pattern of attack, and counting how many hits I could land before they restart thier attack. There's enough variation with the sorts of monsters you run into, that once you start getting used to one, a new monster type comes along. And amidst the various challenging creatures, you get a break between them often enough with little "cut-through-as-you-run-by" type monsters. A good overall balance that makes combat part of the progression, as you explore the map and find treasure. 
[*] [b]Exploration:[/b] One of my favorite things in games like these is when you are going through an earlier level, and you see a ledge or narrow gap you can't get through, with treasure on the other side. Later on, you find a power up that gives you access to areas you previously couldn't reach, and you end up going "hey, wasn't there a long pit I couldn't reach in the earlier caves? Ooh, maybe I can get there now!" And I'll run all the way back to check for secrets along the way, excited for what I will discover. Sure, I could just use the conveniently placed shortcuts to get there, but I actually do enjoy running around and looking for secrets. It's also a little bit of side fun to insta-kill monsters in earlier levels that I used to have trouble with. 
[*] [b]Finding secret monster drops:[/b] Once I discovered the bestiary, and that each monster had two ??? entries for item drops, I was hooked to farming monsters to try and see what they dropped. I avoided forums that would spoil what monsters gave the best drops, because I wanted to be surprised, and I was going to kill them all, anyways. The neat thing about features like this is that you don't have to get these drops, if you don't want to. It won't hurt your progress if you decide to just move on to the next room. It's just a neat little side thing for people who are patient and willing to put in the time and effort to "see what you get". Not every item is going to be better than your current gear, but some are, which makes it a bit of a fun gamble, and you learn how to kill the monsters pretty efficiently, when you kill them over and over. XD
[*] [b]Secret item abilities:[/b] I loved it in Symphony of the Night, and I love it here. For example, I found a spear type weapon and started messing around with it, only to discover that if you press a certain button combo, it has a special attack animation that does considerably more damage! Once I found that, I started fiddling around with other items, and found a few others that had screts, too. It's not necessary to discover these, but they are there, just waiting to be discovered. I love it!
[*] [b]Story:[/b] Some have said that the story isn't original. No, it's not. But is that a requirement for it to be enjoyable? Is a cookie only good if you've never had it before? I enjoyed this story. It was familiar, yet unique enough to have it's own "home made" taste. No, I wasn't once surprised by how it went down. But I wasn't looking to be surprised. I didn't really expect much story in a game like this, so the one I did get was enjoyable, and wraps up nicely, I think. 
[/list]

[b]What I found NOT to be fun: [/b]
[list]
[*] [b]Monster drops a bit TOO rare, for most items:[/b] While I did enjoy farming the monster drops, I feel that lesser items should be easier to get. On the other hand, I respect and appreciate that some amazing items are very rare. There was one item dropped by a particular geletenous cube that took me about 350 kills to get, which seemed like a lot... but also... hey! That item was VERY useful! But it wasn't terribly fun having to kill 100 or so trolls to get a knife or club that isn't really better than my current weapon... It felt a bit tedious after a while, since I had commited to getting all the items, I needed to farm every new creature, which caused progression to slow from room to room, until I had killed enough of the new critter to get both the item drops from it. If some of the lesser drops were more frequent, then it wouldn't slow things down so much, I think. 
[*] [b]Locked weapon attack direction:[/b] This is minor, but what I am talking about is that if you swing your sword, your character is locked in the same direction, even while jumping, so you can't quickly turn and allow the attack animation to follow your movements. Being able to change direction mid-attack was a thing I really liked about Symphony of the Night, and it felt a bit confining not to be able to do that in this game. Still, I got used to it pretty quick (it is a different game, after all), and actually, I felt that it made it more important to be deliberate with your attacks, and required more intentional skill to play, rather than button mashing. The only other control feature that annoyed me was that the back-dash seemed useless when I started playing, but the devs released a patch that fixed it, and so now I use it all the time. :)
[/list]

[b]Closing thoughts: [/b]
Chasm was fun. Absolutely fresh, yet nostalgic, lovingly crafted, fun. It breaks my heart that it has "mixed reviews" at this time. Even if you read through the negative reviews, most of them actually had fun, and still won't recommend the game. Frankly, that's appaling to me. It only hurts the devs, who worked hard for years so you could have fun and then turn your nose up at it. 

Did Chasm change my life? No. Not sure many have. Was it the next Symphony of the Night? No. Even better, it was it's own thing. I loved Symphony of the Night, but I never finished it, even though I keep saying I will. I definitely finished Chasm, and I will again, and again. Like many gamers, I've had dreams of making a game. I am a professional artist, and so who knows, maybe I'll have a shot, someday. If I ever do, Chasm will be my inspiration. Thanks BitKids, for such a lovely and inspiring experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561197994473539', 'num_games_owned': 447, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 1387, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1381, 'last_played': 1539115745}
review:
Chasm ist ein 2D Plattformer im Retrostil, der am 31. Juli des Jahres 2018 erschienen ist. Nach jahrelanger Entwicklungszeit unter dem Kickstarter-Banner hat Bit Kid, Inc. Es geschafft das Spiel auf Steam und anderen Plattformen zu veröffentlichen.

In Chasm schlüpft man in die Rolle eines jungen Rekruten eines Ritterordens, der nach Langem endlich seine erste Mission erhält, bei der er sich beweisen und eventuell seinen Ritterschlag erhalten kann. Er erhält den Auftrag sich die Situation eines Mienendorfes anzusehen, das vor einiger Zeit Hilfe anforderte, da seltsame Kreaturen in der Mine aufgetaucht und einige Bewohner verschwunden sind. So macht sich also der junge Recke auf in sein erstes großes Abenteuer.

Spiel spielt sich wie typischer explorativer 2D-Plattformer – auch Metroidvania genannt –, besitzt jedoch ein paar kleine zusätzliche Kniffe. Wie gewohnt rennt, springt, klettert und kämpft man sich durch die 2D-Umgebung von einem Endboss einer Gegend zur Nächsten. Man findet dabei auf dem Weg Relikte, die einem neue Wege zugänglich machen. Der einzige große Unterschied dabei: Die Gegenden sind zufallsgeneriert. Dabei verwendet Chasm ein Seed system, mit dem man seine Lieblingsgegend in Form eines Seeds speichern kann um sie später auf höheren Schwierigkeitsstufen zu spielen. Durch besiegte Gegner sammelt man, wie in jedem Metroidvania, Erfahrungspunkte, die sich bis zu einem vordefinierten Stufenaufstieg aufsummieren. So wird man über Zeit immer stärker und hat leichteres Spiel mit allen Gegnern. Ein klein wenig notwendig ist dies ebenfalls, da sowohl die extra Finanzspritze von eventuell fallengelassenen Gegenständen, als auch der Stufenaufstieg vieles ein wenig erleichtern, da die Kämpfe nicht gerade ein Kinderspiel sind. Die Schwierigkeit bleibt dabei jedoch immer im Bereich „Hart aber fair“. Die unterschiedlichen Schwierigkeitsstufen, die zu Beginn des Spiels frei wählbar sind, tragen dabei zur passenden Herausforderung für jeden bei. Wer es ganz brachial mag, kann sogar einen optionalen Modus hinzuschalten, indem der Tod endgültig ist und nicht nur damit bestraft wird, das Spiel vom letzten Speicherpunkt neu starten zu müssen.

Die Steuerung ist dabei sehr intuitiv und eingängig. Sowohl Gamepad, als auch Tastatur lassen sich einfach nutzen um den Helden durch die Umgebung zu manövrieren und sich durch die Feindesmengen zu kämpfen. Außerdem lassen sich alle Tastenbelegungen jederzeit nach Belieben anpassen. Da das Spiel den Controller vollständig unterstützt, ist sogar hotplugging eines Controllers im laufenden Spiel möglich.

Optisch macht Chasm dabei einiges her. Die Grafik ist zwar nicht fotorealistisch, jedoch sind die Gegenden, die Monster, Gegenstände und Charaktere liebevoll gestaltet und detailreich animiert. Der Stil ist konsistent und macht einiges her, auch wenn sich auf Grund des zufallsgenerierten Lebeldesigns manche Gegenden als etwas eintönig gestalten, da gewisse Designelemente, wie zum Beispiel Mobiliar und ähnliches, seltener vorkommen, als sie könnten. Außerdem lässt dadurch auch die logische Gestaltung der Räumlichkeiten oft zu wünschen übrig.

Im Audiobereich lässt sich Chasm auch nicht lumpen. Die Effekte sind passend gestaltet und hervorragend abgemischt. Kein Ton wirkt deplatziert oder aus dem Stil gerissen.
Ähnliches kann man auch vom Soundtrack behaupten. Die Lieder sind an Sich stimmig, dem Stil angepasst und liegen gut im Hintergrund. Leider hat der Soundtrack eine kleine Schwäche. Viele Stücke wirken vom Stil her gleich, wodurch sich sowohl im Tempo, als auch in der Atmosphäre nie wirklich viel ändert. Dies kann den Soundtrack eintönig wirken lassen. Ein paar Eingriffe in andere Stilrichtungen oder zumindest Wahl der Instrumente und Rhythmen hätten zur Abwechslung gutgetan.

Alles in allem ist Chasm ein sehr interessanter und gut gelungener Metroidvania-Titel im Retrostil, der von Fans des Genres definitiv angesehen werden sollte. Die Story ist zwar kurz und nicht allzu kompliziert, aber dennoch fein. Außerdem besitzt Chasm durch die zufallsgenerierte Welt und den unterschiedlichen Schwierigkeitsstufen eine gewisse Menge Wiederspielwert.
Wer also das Genre mag und generell auf fordernde Plattformer steht, sollte Chasm definitiv eine Chance geben.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043542881', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1535087033}
review:
*Backer*

Since I was a part of the Kickstarter for this game, I was aware of what I was getting into. A semi-roguelike RPG that will force you to do some minor resource management in between save points. You need to learn how to handle different enemies in different scenarios and put in some work to not die. That being said, it's well balanced for what it is. The game is simple and harkens back to times before $60 ultra4kHD video games. 

If you like the way games play these days and couldn't play something from before 2010, this might not be for you. If you want something simple with beautiful art, varying rogue-like platforming and puzzling, then this game is worth a shot. 

I will say there are some things that I think would improve the game such as a minor tutorial, even just a brief screen showing the control layout - I thought my game froze on start up because I wasn't sure which key would move through dialogue. I understand the feeling that the developers were going for, and I enjoy it. These days tutorials and explanations can ruin an immersion and feel of a game, even driving people away from playing. However I played nearly 4 hours of the game before realizing that the V key has a purpose. 

Otherwise, I think the game is absolutely lovely and I'm glad the team pulled through and commited. I'm not sure if it's worth the $20 yet, but supporting indie developers is like supporting your local small businesses - without them we'd live in a boring corporate world with nothing unique. Chasm stands out as a unique title that combines elements of older roguelikes and modern gaming. If you've got the $20 to spend exploring a mine (and further, deeper delves) whilst fighting monsters and hoping for a save point (and then enjoying wonderful euphoria when you find one) then Chasm is for you,.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003605125', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 661, 'last_played': 1576260501}
review:
The Good:

- Gorgeous pixel art. The environment work is especially beautiful, with painterly-like backgrounds and tiles that do well in conveying the atmosphere of each environment. Lots  of fun, interesting, and well-animated creatures and characters, too!
- Fun Castlevania-like combat. Taking out enemies never stopped feeling good, and getting into a rhythm with the jump cancelling as you run through a hallway, taking out monster after monsters never got old to me.
- Good sound design. I do think a few of the tracks become a bit grating after some time, but overall, I think the music does a great job at establishing the mood in each environment - and the SFX were spot on!

The Not-So-Good:

- I applaud the Bit Kid team for taking a risk of fusing the rogue-lite elements of a randomly generated dungeon with those of a metroidvania. But I think it still needs a few tweaks for it to be as fun as it was intended to be. The idea of experiencing a new map layout each playthrough is great - I just think it's extremely difficult to do so in a way where every layout is memborable and filled with that sense of exploration. The map layouts force you to spend a lot of time backtracking to find new items or areas you couldn't previously reach. Maybe some faster movement options or more shortcuts that connected various sections of each biome would have helped in this regard.
- Weapon variety. I would've loved for the later weapons to have more interesting properties. I basically stopped using anything else other than the Assassin's sword once I found that. It discouraged the use of any of the other weapons I found afterward, which is a bit of a bummer.

---

I had a great time with Chasm, and if you're someone who enjoys the SotN styled Castlevania games for their combat and lite RPG mechanics, I'd suggest giving this game a shot!

author: {'steamid': '76561197970703152', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1410, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1066, 'last_played': 1592189617}
review:
15 hours in and loving it!  I'm definitely enjoying the game, and probably moreso than other metroidvania games I've played (like Dust Elysian Tail, Cave Story, Hollow Knight, etc).  It does a lot of things right, feeling very NES/SNES Castlevania, and very Super Metroid.  A lot of metroidvanias fail in the nostalgia department, as they generally put more focus on modernization.  In my opinion, Chasm hit the perfect balance of nostalgia and modernization.

The graphics are absolutely beautiful!  The soundtrack is great, especially after the first mines area.  The combat, weapon system, and platforming mechanics are deeper than games like Hollow Knight, yet still very NES/SNES Castlevania, in a good way.  The exploration and map system feels very Super Metroid, again in a good way.  The fast travel system is very well done, with a hub in each area allowing you access to teleport to well different corners of each area.  The procedural generation uses mostly hand crafted rooms arranged on a procedural map, yet the item/ability locations required for progression still feels very hand-placed.  On your second playthrough, you will know the -order- of areas/items/abilities you'll need to progress, but you won't necessarily know the direction you need to go to find those things.  Even the puzzles in the game have a randomized element to them, so you won't be able to memorize a number puzzle for your second playthrough.  Honestly, it's a very polished experience!  If I have any complaint, it's that I'm finding a lot of weapons and armor that are underpowered compared to what I've currently equipped (though this may be because I'm grinding like a completionist, so I may be over-levelled for where I'm at in the game).  There's still difficulty in learning enemy and boss patterns though, and I'd expect a speedrun on a harder difficulty would be a great challenge!

TL;DR: Maybe I'll update my review after another 15 hours, but it's already a very polished game and definitely worth playing if you enjoy a good metroidvania!  I'm really not sure why there's so many negative reviews?  Maybe people developed unhealthy expectations over the past 6 years of waiting since it's kickstarter?  Really not sure.  It's sad that Chasm has a 'Mixed' review score when games like Hollow Knight have a 'Very Positive' score.  Don't get me wrong, Hollow Knight is an absolutely gorgeous game, but mechanically I find it less interesting/engaging than Chasm.  If you like a classic feeling metroidvania, do yourself a favour and pick up Chasm!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987200278', 'num_games_owned': 445, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 743, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 743, 'last_played': 1534190513}
review:
I've backed Chasm on kickstarter years ago. I've played early demo, and it was really awesome!
But the final game... Well.
Overall, it's a good game, yes. But while I was playing it, I kept asking myself: "What were they doing for five years of development?"

First of all, let's state the obvious. The graphics in this game is really nice, with great attention to details.
Yet at the same time, all locations feel... generic?

Music is hit and miss. And also feels lacking originality. Up to the point where "item pick up jingle" feels... forced. If you put a gun to my head and ask me to remember that jingle or you'll shoot me, I'd be a dead man! Which is bizarre, considering that in most games like this, "item pick up jingle" is the easierst thing to remember, since you hear it a lot.

Chasm boasts to have randomly generated levels. And the thing is - it does not add anything to the game at all! If it was roguelike, or at least had some sort of endless mode, then sure. But for a singleplayer metroidvania? No.
More so, I begin to see exact same rooms over and over within the first two hours of the game!

But what really kills the deal for me is all the little things and game mechanics, that kept me asking "why? why did you do it like that?" There are lots of minor annoying things, but combined together they make it a constant struggle against the game.
Let me provide some examples.
Chasm has bestiary, with something like 200 entries, if I remember correctly. But instead of having a list, or a grid, where you select something and see all the information, it forces you to scroll every entry... ONE BY ONE! Why?
Main character can't attack on the move, and all animations lock him in place. Which makes combat very unpleasant, and movement feel sluggish.
Some skills interfere with each other. When I got wall jump, my life became much harder! Many-many times I jumped off the wall with wall jump, instead of grabbing a ledge and making bigger jump, because my character kept sticking to walls and I was pressing the jump button 0,01 seconds earlier than he grabs the ledge. Many times I tried to get out of "lava", only to jump back into "lava" again because I stuck to the wall, instead of grabbing the ledge.
Parachute works like in Aladding game on SNES... except unlike the SNES game, you can only glide either left, or right. You can't just glide straight down. WHY?! It makes parachute feel awful.

As I said, all those little things, and many more, make the gameplay experience unpleasant.
Chasm has vibes of a SNES game, back from the era when game developers did not have many examples of good game design, and they were experimenting. But it's 2018! You have all the tools, all the games that were made before you! If you're making a generic metroidvania, just look up how things were done before you! Take good ideas, and mechanics, and implement them in to your game!

So in conclusiuon... What were they doing for five years?

author: {'steamid': '76561197966562259', 'num_games_owned': 842, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 660, 'last_played': 1658636078}
review:
Definitely one of the better executed Metroidvanias that seem to be all the rage these days.

It's rather difficult, even on Normal difficulty, which I like. My only major gripes with the game would be that the procedural generation gives the game a somewhat unstructured feeling, and frankly I'm not sure why they bothered with procedural generation. I doubt subsequent playthroughs of this game will feel radically different, just with a slight remix to the room layouts.

But beyond some repetition and other foibles, overall I really have been enjoying Chasm. The graphics are stunning, the sound is excellent, and the controls are pretty good. Overall I find it to be a worthy successor to the Castlevania spectrum of the Metroidvania genre that has gone so empty for many years.

Chasm is a solid start to what I hope is a series with further growth potential. I'd love to see Chasm 2 ditch the procedural generation and focus on better pacing and more expansive environments. Or if they keep the PG then at least they'll have more time to make more rooms and thus bring more diversity to the world? I dunno.

Anyway, it's pretty good. Not amazing. Not 11/10. But better than most Metroidvanias...

author: {'steamid': '76561197993473791', 'num_games_owned': 1541, 'num_reviews': 242, 'playtime_forever': 551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 551, 'last_played': 1533393217}
review:
XBOX Oneコントローラーを使用。クリア済み。

[u]六つに分けられた自動生成のエリアを探索するメトロイドヴァニア系横スクロールアクションRPG。鉱夫の集落との連絡が突然途絶えた。調査の為、主人公である見習い騎士が派遣され、目的地へ到着した彼は集落付近が異常な「力」によって外界から遮断されていることに気付く。主人公はその「力」の発生源の特定と攫われてしまった集落の住人達を助け、問題を解決する事となる。[/u]

[h1][b]【良い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ ＢＧＭは全体的に良い曲が多く、背景等のドット絵は綺麗な出来になっている。キャラクターのドット絵はワザとなのか少し粗い出来になっているが各種モーションが良く、攻撃のモーション等は「月下の夜想曲」や「暁月の円舞曲」の主人公の攻撃モーションにインスパイアされている。[strike] というかまんま。[/strike]

◆ ダンジョンはゲーム開始時にある程度ランダムで自動生成される。これによりリプレイ性が上がっている。また、「SEED」というコードが各セーブデータに存在し、ゲーム開始時に入力する事で特定の（例えば友人と同じ）ダンジョン内容にすることもできる。タイムアタック等を競う時にも重宝しそうだ。

[h1][b]【悪い点】[/b][/h1]

◆ 無駄に長い通路が多い。特にアイテム等が隠されているわけでもなく、敵が配置されているだけの通路が多すぎて後半はダレてくる。ある程度マップは自動生成なので「自分が偶然こうなったのか？」とも思ったが他の方も似たようなレビューが多いようなので全体的にこの仕様なようだ。

◆ 「ムチ」系と「長剣」系の武器以外は各種通常攻撃が使いづらく、またサブウェポンが強すぎて攻撃のバランスが悪い。ある程度ＭＰの最大値が上昇してからはＭＰを温存する目的以外では通常攻撃をしなくなるほどだった。後半は「探索→ＭＰ切れ→町へ戻る→探索」という風に進めた方が楽になるほど。ボス戦はサブウェポンを連打していればいつの間にか倒せてしまうので目も当てられない。逆に通常攻撃のみでプレイしようものなら恐ろしく難易度が跳ね上がる。通常武器に関しては、例えば「大剣」系の武器は通常「フリが遅く、攻撃力が高い」のがゲームの常だが、今作ではそのフリの遅さに見合った攻撃力が無く、それであれば「長剣」で二度攻撃した方がお得だったりする。勿論、攻撃範囲が違うが、それであればやはりサブウェポンでカバーできてしまうので使う理由がない。

[h1][b]【総評】[/b][/h1]

個人的には面白かったが、他の方にもオススメかと聞かれれば別のメトロイドヴァニアをすすめてしまう。ボス戦はサブウェポンを過度に使用しなければバランスも良くて面白く、ドット絵やBGM等が良かっただけに上記した不満点が足を引っ張ている。各種バランスを整えれば良作になれた残念な作品。

プレイ動画をアップしているので、気になった方は[u][url=https://youtu.be/up4gncwIpJE]こちら[/url][/u]を参考までにどうぞ。

author: {'steamid': '76561198042393975', 'num_games_owned': 515, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1335, 'last_played': 1590428881}
review:
After 11 hours or so I completed my first playthrough on Normal difficulty, and started my second run on Hard difficulty, and here are my thoughts about Chasm.

Chasm is a great little game. Lovely crafted pixel art for both bg art and sprites. Top-notch animations for all enemies. Good, atmospheric music tracks. Tight controls and simple but useful menus. The main quest is not too long, 6 areas for you to explore in typical backtracking metroidvania fashion. Boss fights are neat. I only ran into one bug and it wasn't gamebreaking, just a sprite loading glitch, only one time.

I only have three gripes. Two of them very minor: No way to sort items in your inventory. This is a useful feature for item collectors such as yours truly. The other minor one is that you don't need to collide with the edge of a screen to traverse to the adjacent room. A few times I changed rooms unintentionally. It's a bit annoying but nothing serious. Hopefully the devs can improve these later via patch.

The other one is not so minor: The proc-gen elements seem quite limited. Originally I was very excited about the procedural generation in this game, but it turns out it's pretty minor. The map layout seems to stay roughly the same, it seems some item rooms are randomized. This still doesn't damage my enjoyment of the game but I had other expectations, however, the devs pulled out an amazing game, and they were clear in their Kickstarter campaign that the game would randomize some stuff, so this one is entirely on me. No biggie, since SotN doesn't have any proc-gen elements and I've played that game countless times. Also, the future might hold additional game modes and improvements to the game, so there's that too.

If you enjoy metroidvanias, especially SotN and the GBA/DS ones, chances are you'll [i]love[/i] Chasm. Castlevania SotN being my favorite game of all time, this game scratches a similar itch and it might grow on me over time as a regular game. If you like 2D action RPGs with great pixel art and tight controls, do yourself a solid and check Chasm out. See you in the depths of Karthas!

author: {'steamid': '76561197972013546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1788, 'last_played': 1533600499}
review:
[h1]Chasm: Mind the Gap[/h1]

[b]TLDR:[/b] 
It’s a good game that could have been better. The pixel art is beautiful, the soundtrack is good, and the story is enjoyable. Sadly, it has a lot of frustrations that put it in the “Would Not Recommend category. There are a few things that could have been done to make Chasm REALLY good.

[b]Player tips and advice:[/b]
[olist]
[*] You only need two magic items to be effective. The rest are, in my opinion, a waste of gold: the magic dagger and the magic shield. Get the witch to level both to maximum. Ignore the rest. Daggers are by far the most utilitarian and easiest to use. You can use it to defeat everything from a distance with rare exception. The shield is Extremely valuable with certain bosses. 
[*] For an easier run through, watch the screen ahead of you as you run and lash in with the daggers before you get in range of the monsters.
[*] Explore everything, leave no stone unturned. Use the marker feature to mark rooms you think you should come back to later on when you have new items or artifacts. This will happen a LOT.
[*] You can buy a warp to town scroll from the witch. Don’t worry about it until you get to the temple. I won’t say why so I don’t spoil anything.
[/olist]
[b]Full Review:[/b] 
I love what a boss of mine used to say - "Don’t let perfect get in the way of good". If you put off producing something until it’s perfect, you’ll end up producing nothing. It would be better to do something and have it be good than get stuck trying to make it perfect and never see it come to life.

That’s where it feels like Bit Kid was with Chasm. I want to be very careful with how I write this review, because it’s very easy to sit in the crowd and “armchair develop”. The indie game industry has taken off and I think we all need to support indie game devs that are doing new, cool stuff. So if anyone from Bit Kid is reading this, please know that I am not intending to insult or tear apart your work.

Chasm took 6 years to make and what they delivered was good. And while it’s OK that it’s not perfect, I can’t help but feel like it falls short of what they could have accomplished in 6 years. In all fairness, I don’t know all the factors that led to the length of the development time. For example, if the “In Memory of” section of the credits would have an impact if those people passed away during the making of the game, for example. That would certainly cause an understandable delay.

Here’s the stuff I LOVE: this is a beautiful pixel art game. A lot of love was obviously put into the designs of each character, the environments, the backgrounds, and the music. Absolutely awesome. The controls are easy to understand, very straightforward, and work great with a gamepad. And because I’m over 40, the nostalgia factor is important to me and there are lots of neat little nods in Chasm.

I’m sad to say my list of frustrations is longer than what I love. But I wouldn’t be writing this if I didn’t enjoy the game! Improving these things would just help Chasm to be that much better. Most of these seem like they’d be relatively easy to implement AND be huge quality-of-life benefits for us players.

[b]Poor In-game Explanations:[/b] This is the biggest problem with the game and the longest section of my critique because there are so many things that can make our lives better in playing the game with just better explanations. Below are just a couple examples that punctuate this issue.

There is no explanation of what your stats are or do. If you’re an RPG player, you can make some educated guesses like CON (constitution) granting you more health. And LCK must surely stand for “Luck”, which one would assume increases your chances of getting better drops. But there is nothing to confirm these guesses.

Second example: the descriptive text for items leaves a lot to be desired. Don’t just give me flavor text. Give me flavor text along with whether it’s a two-handed item or a one-handed item, slow or fast attack, long or short range. One could assume that brass knuckles have next to zero range vs. a poniard, but how would I know for sure? Sword A has lower attack damage than Sword B, but I found Sword A later in the game so it must do something cool or special that B doesn’t, right? Maybe! Who knows?? 

[b]Getting Saved:[/b] No autosave or checkpoints? Really? Guys, we’ve come too far for you to require us to find save points. Don’t make me hunt and pray for a save point!

[b]Planting Seeds:[/b] The game uses a mechanic called “seeds”. The idea with a new seed is that the game becomes a whole new layout. Interesting idea which theoretically, lets you start a new game with a different seed and have a different experience each time. But does this game really need it? I’ll tell you one thing: it makes it awfully hard to find help/guides when no one’s maps are the same unless they played the exact same seed as you.

[b]Poor Diet:[/b] There’s too much reliance on potions, food, and save points. It’s distracting and detracts from the experience when I have to hunt down a save point so I can refresh my HP, find a way to get back to town so I can buy potions, or pray that the next enemy will drop some food. And I must to go into my inventory to consume anything, which interrupts my progress.

[b]On a Quest:[/b] there is no quest log so you know how many more of X you need to gather for Y person. Quests can take a long time to complete because the clues on how to obtain the items aren’t clear. So I’m told that kobolds drop venison. Awesome. But which kobolds count? And who needed it again?

[b]Oi! Drop It!:[/b] Oh my gosh drop quests are so annoying. Not only could I not always figure out what to kill in order to get the item, but when I DID, I had no idea how many times I’d have to go offscreen and come back just to kill the thing over and over and over until it hopefully drops something.

[b]Get a Clue:[/b] Sometimes you encounter rooms that the map says have treasure, but you’re given no clue whatsoever on how to obtain it. In one case, I had to get a potion in order to see the treasure…but I wasn’t told that in any way. So imagine me finding the recipe for the potion, buying the potion once it’s made and then wondering what the hell I’m supposed to do with it!

[b]Suggestions:[/b]
In addition to the changes needed to resolve the above issues, here are some other QOL suggestions:
[list]
[*] The game would dramatically improve if there were an on-screen map I could refer to and enlarge/overlay as you play so I don’t have to leave the game to check out the map. Interrupting gameplay continually to check the map is a detraction.
Change the player appearance with new gear! That’s one of the great parts of any RPG – looking the part.
[*] Make it so the parachute unfurls whenever you press the button while falling – not just once you’ve done a flip. Currently you get one use of the parachute per fall. 
[*] Make the Warp Scroll more expensive and make it a magic spells so you can warp to town when needed. At the very least, keep it as a scroll but PLEASE make it leave a portal open so you can go back to where you were when you used it! So much time is wasted trying to get back to the town to either save or refresh your health and mana pools.
[/list]

So as I stated above, I really do like the game. Unfortunately it feels a little too unpolished for me to be able to recommend it. Would you have a good time playing it? Probably. But I don’t feel like it has a lot of replayability given the frustrations. Even with the seed feature, you’d run into the same issues. 

That said, I do want to say “Thank you!” to Bit Kid for sticking with and finishing Chasm. There was obviously a lot of passion put into it. I hope you’ll consider making some updates to it in order to push it into the EXCELLENT and “Would recommend” categories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063517625', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 529, 'last_played': 1698428801}
review:
Chasm is a Metroidvania game I've been waiting for since I discovered the Kickstarter.
So, going in I already had a positive bias.

This game has some of the most beautiful pixel art I've seen in a while, and although the different enviroments tend to be a bit stale towards the end, I enjoyed the art immensely.

The music on the other hand was mostly bland in my opinion, with the exception of maybe two tracks I already forgot them all.

The "chasm" is sectioned in six levels, and you will have to backtrack several times once you gain new abilities from items. So, whenever you see a spot where you can't progress, don't forget to set a marker on the map to find the way back later.
The gameplay is very much like Metroid, so except for some short dialogues do not expect to be told where to go.

The story is kinda meh. There are no big surprises or plot twists, but for what it is it is fine.

The fighting system und abilities are very familiar to anyone who has played either Metroid or Castlevania, and while I love it, I do have to admit there is no innovation here.

Still, I'm glad for the experience and will recommend this game any day. Just don't except to find something groundbreaking here, it's more of a refinement of most things one could love of Metroidvania games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198136990895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1611255491}
review:
Seems like the developers focused more on the visuals than the actual gameplay. The longer your weapon is the easier the game, which makes weapons like daggers almost unplayable for any casual gamer. Jumping feels unintuitive, which is quite bad considering that half the game is jump and runs. Being locked in place during attack animation when not jumping allows most enemies to jsut casually walk out of your weapons way, or into you, damaging you if your weapons aren't long enough, no matter the skill. Bosses seem too random, focus on the time the first boss needs to fade in and out, the time is random and not constant, which takes skill from the boss fight, and makes it a game of luck, especially when trying to not get hit at all.

In general you can make a game that feels retro without using clunky, bad retro style controlls, clunky random gameplay takes alll skil out of the game. Casually playing every now and then is fun, and the game looks decent, but I wouldn't recommend it.
