review: Metroidvania style game with great pixel art, animation, and music. Back-dash is hardly used and a little slow for my taste. The items used for progression aren't all that unique for this type of game. They're almost all mobility based upgrades, which do help improve the somewhat, lackluster combat. Overall, not the best of the genre, but definitely not the worst. I still enjoyed playing through it from start to finish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991200082', 'num_games_owned': 1592, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 172, 'last_played': 1659125095}
review:
Castlevania: Symphony of the Night (SotN) is my all-time favorite video game. Given how much SotN clearly inspired elements of Chasm, I can't help but feel disappointed at some of the flaws in Chasm that come as a result of the developer having missed the point of what makes SotN's formula work as well as it does. It's a shame, too, because there're some very good aspects of Chasm that end up suffering due to the game's flaws.

Chasm's protagonist controls quite well at the start of the game, and anyone familiar with SotN will notice an immediate similarity between SotN's controls and Chasm's controls, right down to the default assignments of the face buttons. Alas, while Chasm does allow you to equip two different weapons at a time, one of these weapons takes the form of a spell. These "spells" are little more than Castlevania-style sub-weapons, however. While this seems like a logical approach to take to ensure some variety in combat abilities, I found myself not using spells very often and wishing that I could simply equip a different normal weapon that had better reach than one of my faster weapons.

Now, while the controls are generally fine at first, you start to run into some problems as you accumulate new abilities in the form of artifacts. You eventually get a glove that allows you to hang from ledges, thus allowing you to scale walls that have ledges scattered up and down them. You later get climbing gear that allows you to wall jump, also granting you a Mega Man X-style ability to slowly slide down walls, which in turn makes using the aforementioned glove far more touchy and tedious. Furthermore, you'd expect having these two items to open up a lot more areas to you, but the developer only allowed them to "work" together in the strictest possible sense, resulting in blown expectations when you take the time to return to a previously impassable area and find that it's...still impassable because the developer had no imagination in realizing how well these two items *should* work together.

Getting back to the wall jump...and Mega Man X, for that matter, the wall jump in Chasm feels TERRIBLE. In addition to it feeling downright unintuitive to use in general, you'll find that very few areas that require the wall jump are laid out in a way that makes it comfortable or satisfying to use. Too often, you'll find that platforms are spaced in such a way that you still need to grab ledges, which - as I mentioned before - gets really tedious once you have the wall jump (due to the aforementioned slide).

That's okay, though, because you'll eventually get a double jump. Problem is, the double jump just makes it all the more apparent how bad the wall jump is. Functionally, you end up with something akin to the Mega Man X wall jump once you have the wall jump and double jump in Chasm, only it's far more awkward to use because the protagonist is trying to get away from the wall with each wall jump, only to double jump back toward the wall while gaining less height than you'd actually want due to your character jumping back and forth like an idiot.

So, I mentioned before how the game continually blows your expectations. You know, this wouldn't be so bad if Chasm wasn't laden with backtracking. Look, I'm a huge fan of games like this, but the distribution of save rooms and teleporter/cave rooms in Chasm is HORRENDOUS. Yeah, I understand that Chasm's dungeons are procedurally-arranged, but it seems as though the algorithm doing this just intentionally lays rooms out in the least-convenient means possible. This wouldn't be so bad if you had an indication as to WHY you couldn't proceed past certain points in the dungeons, but Chasm lacks any means of marking multiple map squares with symbols to remind yourself what you might need to get further in those areas.

Speaking of progression, Chasm even fails to generate much in the way of excitement when it comes to building up the protagonist. Gaining levels doesn't have the impact that it should on its own, and you'll likely find one or two weapons for sale in town that're "good enough" and settle for those for 3/4 of the game, because anything dropped in the dungeon just feels inferior to anything you can more easily get your hands on. Furthermore, there seems to be too much of a focus on swords, with there being very little reason to use other types of weapons unless you just want to be different and underpowered. Even worse, the drop rates from enemies are ridiculously low, and Chasm seems to take inspiration from some of the worst Metroidvania-style games in existence by making many of the drops consist of crafting items that have very limited use. (And the stuff that you can craft is pretty much trash. Yay!)

Now, it probably sounds as though I'm really down on Chasm. When it isn't seriously disappointing me, though, I do find myself enjoying the combat on some level, and I have the enemy designs to thank for that. The enemy designs in Chasm are quite good, and you'll find yourself gradually having to change your tactics as you become more powerful, making your newfound strength (usually from equipment, not levels, sadly) feel all the more substantial. At first, you'll find yourself having to let enemies attack so you can exploit their recovery time, often having to do this several times in an effort to avoid damage. If you rush things, then you'll take a lot of damage at first. Once you get better equipment, though, you'll find that being more aggressive will make combat pass more quickly, but you'll still need to be careful and precise with your attacks.

Overall, I'd still recommend Chasm, as long as you go in with the right expectations. It's got some serious issues, but it's also very satisfying if you have the patience to tackle combat properly. Just be prepared to be disappointed. A lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984223904', 'num_games_owned': 2024, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 639, 'last_played': 1534014830}
review:
Honestly, I backed this game when it was on kickstarter and I had a lot of fun watching the development progress through the years.

Unfortunately, this is not quite what I expected. For a metroidvania game, it does ok, the formula works, but its downright shallow and boring at times.

Really, really hard to recommend this game given we have so many other incredible titles for the same price tag. As much as I can respect the effort put in making this game, I cannot in good faith recommend it to other fans of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026950092', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1533252733}
review: I really don't understand the mixed reviews of this game. I really enjoy it.  The gameplay was fun although the dash was kinda slow and useless most the time. The music was really hit and miss. The one thing I don't like about the game is the fact that when they said procedurally generated I thought that meant that not only the rooms but some of the items and weapons would change during each playthrough. I was hoping to have a new adventure with a new character build during each playthough but this is not the case. In all honesty the randomly generated rooms are really not necessary. If you like Castlevania SotN then you should enjoy Chasm (though it is not as meaty) at least until we get Bloodstained Ritual of the Night.

{'steamid': '76561198112295375', 'num_games_owned': 829, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 602, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 602, 'last_played': 1533557378}
review:
一边玩一边把想到的内容写下来，最后进行整合写出了这一篇评测，所以内容可能显得有些过于片段化，而且以缺点居多

开发者自称是月下厨，因为想每一次玩月下流程都不一样所以做成了roguevania，那么我们来看看哪里有七作城的影子
读档界面，剑类武器特效，剑类的斜下攻击，这很月下
传送门需要按顺序一个一个传，这很月轮
敌人没有防御力，HP等于硬度，这很白夜
副武器当魔法一样随身携带，这很晓月
最终BOSS是红色的，这很苍月
可以堆INT玩魔法流，这很废墟
BOSS无伤有奖励，这很刻印
急退不能取消攻击硬直，这很……

[h1]NEU[/h1]
·升级回满血，这是除存档之外唯一的环境友好型回血手段，这就导致在有些时候控制经验会降低不少难度，我还记得在《新约圣剑传说》里我也这么做过，不过那里可以一直积累经验，自己选择升级（回血）的时机，要方便很多
·敌人ai很有进攻性，善于车轮战消耗主角，连挂在墙上的蜘蛛的ai都是第一时间爬到主角上方垂下来糊脸而不是保持距离吐蛛丝
·掉坑（水）惩罚高（百分比扣血，流沙消耗跳跃高度和次数，不容易跳出来）
·随机地图组合导致地图设计上限被拉低，也因此导致传送点（洞口）的位置有可能很糟糕
·中期地图有向白夜跑路城学习的嫌疑

[h1]PRO[/h1]
+鞭子手感好，我tm抽爆
+等了好几年，跟最初的demo相比虽然很多机制都不一样了，但是去掉了大菠萝的随机装备我还是很高兴的
+开发者是月下厨
+评测者是七作厨

[h1]CON[/h1]
-同类型的不同武器之间没有除了数值和外型之外的任何区别，加个下前攻的特技也好啊
-传送点的设置为了“真实性”而变得非常麻烦，而且这一点也不真实，我的建议是：取消除了增加换版次数外没有任何意义的“洞口”，全部改为传送门，在村落存档点旁边设置一个传送门，可以一次换版前往任何一个地区的任何一个“洞口”，或者将每一个传送点都附带存档功能，这样就不用为了存档还要传回村落了
-地图随机机制虽然开发者说有过优化，但还是存在存档点（/传送洞口）过远的问题，我玩的seed整个花园上半部分地图一个存档点（/传送洞口）都没有
-很多平台跳跃很极限，不是说刻意考验平台跳跃的房间，而是平时赶路的房间都被设计成极限跳跃，说真的在没有二段跳/降落伞的时候每次跳跃都要卡边真的很烦人，可能是开发者画地图的时候有像素尺，就觉得玩家玩的时候也自带像素尺
-魔导器不能手动关闭，蹭墙跟搭边上跳冲突，而且还影响对隐藏墙的探索
-蹬墙跳操作反人类，建议跟洛克人zero学习一下，实在不行月轮也可
-地图色调很暗，在上面找没去过的地方时非常瞎眼
-竞技场给的潜水装备似乎并没有多少用武之地，能潜入的水太少了
-直到终盘也没有快速赶路的能力，我的裤子都要磨烂了

[h1]总结[/h1]
chasm是一个还算可玩的roguevania，但存在很多新手开发者会犯的错误的
画面水平 80%
音乐水平 75%
剧情设计 60%
地图设计 55%
操作手感 65%
[b]7.8/10 Too Little Water[/b]

SEE YOU NEXT GAME

author: {'steamid': '76561198082730311', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1603625234}
review:
I personally like this game so much. I like the soul in it and I do find the gameplay pretty good. It seems crystal clear that the developers have XP and Currency glitches in this game. Some of them works, Some of them does not. Still, to me it is a solid good game ...

- I love everything. Art - Gameplay - Audio - Minimized story line - Retro feel - Metroidvania feel (which needs to be more practiced in my opinion) 

- The reason they got mixed reviews is that the calculation/Design  of the XP system and the currency in my opinion. 
I want to share my experience  : 

I personally found myself dealing with a puzzle in the game which was so fun but I got so much XP while solving it.  When I solved and moved to the other part of the map, my character was too strong for the mobs which made game a bit easy. Plus collected so many drops and coins during puzzle so that I could buy nearly everything from vendor too early. 
I was about to finish the game and sorted out that there had been an extra items option for the blacksmith section. Plus figured out what Tokens are for in the end. 

All in all, I enjoyed every part of it. Especially Boss mechanics are awesome.  
The overall Skill and currency design needs improvement .
Still I love Chasm and I do not think that this game deserves bad  reputation ...

author: {'steamid': '76561198286870835', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1641, 'last_played': 1594724755}
review:
开的hard档，normal没玩想来差距也不会太大

操作手感有严重缺陷——
1：站A不能强制疾退！站A不能强制疾退！站A不能强制疾退！能告诉我疾退有什么用吗？
2：跳A打点低的话,直接变成站A,打怪经常被硬直坑到；
3：抓墙操作是真的恶心到我了，谁玩谁知道

地图关卡有小缺陷——
1：跑任务路程极其漫长，本不算作问题，奈何打怪的手感问题导致体验极差
2：存档点设置的莫名其妙，完全没有设计感，就瞎瘠薄放，打竞技场还要回城存，还不如直接在所有的传送房加一个
3：回城卷卖500，我真是呵呵了，不说500能买属性卷，回城这个便利功能用一次我需要刷10分钟怪赚钱，合适吗？
4：平台设计太烂，[spoiler] 我上街买包烟都能碰到9个近乎极限跳的小平台#滑稽 [/spoiler]主线流程部分高墙二段跳上墙只有10多帧的滞留时间给你按出蹬墙，自己体会
5：以上行程问题均由操作手感提供喂翔服务

流程设计——
抓墙—第2幕
滑铲—第3幕
蹬墙—第4幕→滑翔+潜水
双跳—第5幕
嗯，没有↓↑B，没有↑L

装备技能：
武器形态基本算全，但也没什么特殊玩具，剑类作为后期主力武器存在对低身位怪无力的短板[spoiler]跳A打点低=挨揍[/spoiler]
技能形态基本算全，只不过数值略强，一套INT流完爆STR流，考虑到光剑、真空刃之流，也不算什么
装备首饰还没怎么刷，但爆出过一件缓慢回血衣服，箱子开出使魔帽子（可升级），还算有趣
[spoiler] 请无视装备打造，成品强度低材料两幕[/spoiler]

亮点：
1：BOSS设计+小怪AI很好，不能无脑跳A，中期同时出现2只怪都能教做人
2：属性梯度合理，主流程较少出现属性差距过大的情况，基本处在5刀跪的状态
3：BOSS无伤有奖励，真心赞啊！



大部分不好的体验都在被操作手感拖后腿，这游戏真是太可惜了，不然打怪打爽了谁还在乎那些？
[spoiler]如出现操作优化的更新此评论将会跳反[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198148002569', 'num_games_owned': 647, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1671145807}
review: So far I have played this game for a few hours and let me tell ya, it is really awsome! This graphics are gorgeous, the gameplay is addictive, and the animation is superb. I don't understand why some people are giving this masterpiece hate. I was looking for a solid metroidvania and thats exactly what I got. This music is wonderful and the story is pretty good so far. I love the incorperated rpg elements aswell. There are many complaints over the procedural generation of the dungeons but I find it fresh. Granted the game procedurally generates a map for your current game and assigns it a seed number, so unless you start another game it won't generate another map. If you want to keep your map during another play through, just type in your seed number. I think its implemented well. One complaint I have is that when I run the game using my Nvidia GPU on my laptop the screen goes black, I have to use my iGPU. GeForce Experience doesn't detect the game anyway, but I would like to record and stream this so if anyone has a solution let me know! With that issue in mind I give this game a 4 out of 5.

author: {'steamid': '76561198849645971', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 912, 'last_played': 1533537701}
review:
如果喜歡惡魔城月下夜想曲，我還挺推薦的，因為系統幾乎照搬的。
我雖然還算喜歡這個遊戲(畢竟都破關且地圖100%了)，不過還是要講些事：
1.掉寶率算低的，不知除了運氣以外，難度有無影響?(我玩普通難度，另外鞭子類武器好用，結果序盤打到的骨鞭竟然用到了最後)
2.圖鑑解鎖是刷次數，不是說這個設計不好，只是當我想來補完圖鑑時，如果沒記住一隻怪的詳細出沒地點，真的要翻遍地圖了(累)有心完成圖鑑的，建議一遇到，在安全的情況下就來反覆刷到解鎖吧...
3.價格，我是在打折情況下購入的，NT300不到，以這個遊戲的內容來說還可以接受，畢竟還是有感受到作者的用心。(最近在其他平台上買遊戲有雷到的經驗...)

author: {'steamid': '76561198003429416', 'num_games_owned': 1783, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1999, 'last_played': 1682998206}
review:
So, Chasm is if you took all of the good parts of most Metroid games, Steamworld Dig, and some of the other Metroidvanias and made an amalgamation of all of those games and then put some polish on it.  I'll try to list the pros/cons but I'm sure I'll be missing some.

Pros:
----
- Seeds can be shared so you can race your friends or see what they liked about their seed, or try to beat your own time on the same seed.
- RPG style leveling up brings a nice touch as sometimes that extra level will help.  But it won't make the huge difference because...
- Gear is important and not having the right gear can turn an easy area into a difficult one.  This makes the gear progression feel better when you see your DEF jump from 10 to 20, or attack jump up by 10 points.  It can help.
- It doesn't feel procedurally generated.  Aside from a couple of repeat rooms, many of the rooms are standard castlevania style, vertical corridors climbed by jumping, long stretches filled with enemies, etc.  But it's stitched together masterfully.  And the handcrafted parts of the game (small bits), and rooms that need to be inside of certain areas, can feel very interestingly thought out.
- Weapon types are varied and have stronger versions (including boss weapons that have special effects) as you go along.  That leather whip you got will be weaker than the bone whip, which in turn is weaker than the thorn whip.  If you're willing to farm for it (there's a bestiary online) you can essentially play the entire game with one type of weapon.  There may be some gaps in time where your weapon will feel weak because a new one hasn't dropped yet or isn't available til a later area, but it is possible, I think, I haven't tried every single weapon class only runs, but it certainly feels that way.
- Metroid style progression is there and progress feels slow but it's more powerful than at first glance.  For example being able to grab ledges opens up a ton of spaces, and it doesn't feel like it until you're going back over the maps.
- Devs are very responsive on discord, and take feedback and hopefully will be releasing patches to make the game even better.
- Some of the secrets are pretty tough to find, fortunately you can get help with that later.  I put this as a pro because sometimes it's way too obvious in games.  Sometimes the secrets in this game can lead to entirely new areas, or shortcuts between zones.
- New area means new tiers of enemies, weapons, and drops to collect.  Believe me when I say that you can easily go to later areas and farm weapons and such and they will be drastically more powerful than what you can buy.
- Crafting is simple so you can get back into the game if you've been lucky with drops.  Some of the armors will keep you pretty set for an area.
- Two Familiars (One if you weren't a backer I believe) means you can have a floating companion.  It takes up the headgear slot, which is a bit of a ding against it, but the help they can provide is nice.
- Build your gear your way - If you want high STR, DEF and CON, you can do that.  If you want to stack LUK, you can do that.  If you want to be a jack of all trades, you can do that too.  There's plenty of gear to make this possible.


Cons:
----
- No new game plus.  Want to try out your friend's seed?  Level 1, No gear, final destination.  That being said the devs have mentioned making a new game mode, so we'll see as the game gets patched.
- Unable to edit map markers to say what they're for.  You also have to be in the same room as the marker to add/remove it.  This is being taken into consideration as well I've heard, so it may be patched.
- Unless you know about quest items for NPCs (well, where to find them) you can miss out on some pretty powerful gear.  There's no hand holding in this game.  Your best bet is to explore everywhere.  Or use a pre-defined seed that has a walkthrough.
- Drop rates are pretty low.  Even with the tweak recently.  That makes progression with weapons feel slow at times as sometimes the only way to obtain the next tier in a weapon class is through drops.
- Backtracking followed by limited save points feels like too big a risk for too little reward.
- No "Fast Travel" except back to town, so you can't save a location and warp to it or warp to checkpoints or anything that you've made.  It would be nice considering how sprawling some of these areas can be.

Personally, I love this game.  Minus the few cons I've listed I think once a few patches on a freshly released game like this come out, it'll skyrocket in popularity.  The devs are already talking further content and taking feedback into account.  I'd say it's solid 8/10 material right now and could be looking at more later.  I'm recommending this game.  Hopefully others will get it and come up with more feedback to talk to the devs about on discord so ideas can be considered and added if the team agrees with the direction.  

If you've been looking for a metroidvania recently, this is a good one.  The things it reminds me of while playing make me smile out of nostalgia and to see that some things don't change in this genre.  I hope this helps make the decision for someone, as we'd love more players, as it's a relatively unknown game (Googling anything for Chasm is a nightmare thanks to it's name being shared across multiple other games in quests or it's name or names of places, etc.)  and having more players talking on the discussion boards and discord.  Hope you enjoy it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044270025', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1193, 'last_played': 1533525230}
review:
I've been looking forward to this game for years. Nothing can live up to that amount of anticipation and Chasm is no exception. However, there are areas where Chasm shines like the Watchers' light. (Spoilers below)

Bit Kid's biggest mistake is not doing nearly enough to differentiate itself from its main inspiration: Symphony of the Night. SotN is a masterpiece and the gold standard of -vanias for a reason. Chasm's gameplay is unfortunately a lesser clone and in many ways just serves to remind the player that SotN's mechanics are more refined (for the most part). Games that are clearly an homage are best when they still innovate and introduce new mechanics instead of simply cut-and-paste. Tom Happ's Axiom Verge exemplifies this even though the game's style more closely resembles its inspiration than Chasm does. AV feels like someone took Super Metroid and added a dozen of unique mechanics that help it stand out. It reminds the player of Super Metroid while not making them wish they were playing it instead.

Chasm's art is gorgeous. Dan Fessler has made some of the most fluid sprites I've ever seen. Every enemy shares a consistent style that evokes different reacions in context. The early enemies seemed innocuous but endgame enemies were horrifying. The environments were jawdropping and the parallax is incredible. As someone who has experience in pixel-art, this game is among the best I've ever seen (and that includes the 16-bit era).

The pacing of the game suffers from a small roster of abilities. Navigation was not fun until I unlocked the double jump ability in the second-to-last area. I understand why this is the case (thematically double-jump is the most exciting of the given abilities) but it really should have been introduced earlier. The player doesn't feel any more powerful until near the endgame which is breaking a fundamental rule of good metroidvanias. Enemy design picks up in the midgame and becomes much more fun. One of the biggest flaws gameplay-wise is the balancing of different weapons. The only weapon that beats any whip is the final sword. The whips have so much utility in terms of range that every other weapon is simply inferior. They either need to be nerfed to do like 5 damage, or the other weapons all need a serious buff.

I came across several bugs that have no business being in a shipped game. A repeated one featured the walljump ability where I would slide down a wall into the ground and be teleported up like 20 pixels every 5 frames until I was back above ground. And another occurred in the Boneworm bossfight where I was actually teleported to the top of the room where I could just see my legs. I walked off-screen to the right, was placed in the next room, went back to the bossroom and the fight started from the beginning again. Also not having the files in order at launch is a rookie mistake that needs to be pointed out.

The proc-gen was impressive and lead to an organic feeling Metroidvania layout. Horizontal rooms repeating is not an issue but a couple distinctive vertical rooms repeated in obvious ways. Unfortunately the proc-gen was marketed as the defining aspect of this game and it was so well done that I hardly noticed it.

Overall, Chasm has major flaws that prevent me from recommending this game to everyone. For Metroidvania heads, however, it is a rewarding experience by the end because of familiar mechanics and immaculate spritework. 6.9 / 10 lmao

author: {'steamid': '76561198100388140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 845, 'playtime_forever': 824, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 824, 'last_played': 1533534854}
review:
Чудесная игра, которая готовилась к выходу более трёх лет. На первый взгляд может показаться, что игра ничем не выделяется среди остальных подобных, но в игре есть много приятных вещей, которые делают Chasm одной из лучших метроидваний последнего времени!

Плюсы:
+ Отличный дизайн уровней, которые поделены на секторы, а не сделаны целиком большой картой. А это значит, что легче запоминаются локации и места, куда следует вернуться после получения улучшений.
+ Музыка, графика и анимации – шикарны. Картинка на экране всегда приятна глазу и до конца игры планка качества не опускается. Если бы мне показали скриншот этой игры, когда я про неё ничего не знал, то я бы с уверенностью сказал, что это игра от WayForward, а это один из лучших комплиментов, который пиксельная игра может получить.
+ Система прокачки, возможность крафтить вещи, побочные квесты, улучшаемые заклинания.
+ Свыше 80 видов уникальных монстров, никаких перекрашиваний спрайтов! Все монстры попадают в бестиарий – игровую энциклопедию, где можно увидеть дроп и характеристики чудищ. Очень полезная штука, родом из Каслвэний на портативках.
+ Не сложная. Игра не будет требовать от вас супер-реакции или обязывать находить мощные артефакты, без которых боссов не победить. Но есть и уровни сложности, если вам недостаточно больно :) .

Минусы:
- Управление иногда отказывается делать действие за действием. Например, иногда не делается рывок после атаки или не прожимается второй прыжок от стены, когда условия выполнены.
- Свитки телепортов не бесконечны и их можно купить ограниченное количество. Из-за этого иногда приходится совершать массу ненужных путешествий.
- Большую часть времени вы будете понимать, куда нужно идти и что делать, но иногда можно просто потеряться в догадках, что же делать дальше (да, я смотрю на вас, парашют и колокола!).

Рекомендую всем любителям метроидваний, 100% не пожалеете.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025434777', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 401, 'last_played': 1533079959}
review:
I recommend this game with only one real caveat: its length.  I enjoyed all of the game.  Did I think certain parts could be bettered?  Yes, some of which have been mentioned in negative reviews, such as enemy placement and variety.  However, with each potentially negative aspect of the game, including the example I just described, it's really not bad because those moments are fleeting.  Continuing with the enemy example, as soon as I started to think, "This enemy keeps showing up and I don't consider it interesting or difficult anymore," either new enemies showed up, the scenery changed, or a new challenge presented itself.  I realize I did not back this game, but as a common consumer, many of the complaints I have seen mentioned in the negative reviews strike me as nitpicking and/or expecting too much.

There are things such as how I feel like the randomization of room order doesn't really give me incentive to play again without other goals, but I chalk that up to my opinion and am not going to rate this game poorly for something like that.  Besides, the randomization is good because it forces you to play the game for yourself instead of looking up help.  To reiterate, I think their design choices are solid and don't detract from the game.  That being said, I come back to what I said about the game's length.  I beat the game in approximately eight hours, and that felt very short.  Games can always be improved, and if new content or a Chasm 2 comes out, I look forward to positive advancements, but generally speaking, my only complaint is that I wish it was longer.

Long story short, I definitely recommend this game, just be prepared to be done with it faster than you'd like.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960270054', 'num_games_owned': 2270, 'num_reviews': 159, 'playtime_forever': 1521, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1521, 'last_played': 1533505935}
review: Despite it's flaws, it's still a fun game. Sure maybe Chasm could've been a lot more, but it is a fun metroidvania. The procedural map generation is a bit silly as there's not much reason to replay the game. The save points and quick travel are too few and far between. And the backtracking is hard to figure out as there are pretty much no hints on where to go. I feel like all of these issues could have been resolved with some proper playtesting. Still, if you can get beyond all that, it's pretty fun to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006597505', 'num_games_owned': 739, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 793, 'last_played': 1533485361}
review:
Chasm is a mostly-solid Metroidvania that’s often made frustrating by its procedurally generated map. It demonstrates the inelegance of procgen in a genre that benefits greatly from precise and skillful map design. The map introduces a level of inconsistency that throws the game off balance; difficulty seems to spike and drop randomly, and some of the most interesting systems take far too long to become rewarding.

Pros:
+ Art and music are generally enjoyable, and it stays interesting longer than you would expect for tiled maps
+ Different areas are reasonably spread out, and none really takes too long to complete
+ At its best, backtracking for missed secrets is just as gratifying as in handcrafted Metroidvanias
+ RPG elements can be fun to experiment with

Cons:
- Procgen makes the map inscrutable, and denies the player any sort of intuition to help them find save points
- Difficulty often manifests in just long stretches of enemies to claw through with ever-dwindling health and supplies
- Lots of the weapons you'll find don't feel any different from each other, and magic attacks don't really feel meaningful until after they're upgradeable
- Occasionally, parts of the foreground really blend into the background, making it hard to see the path forward

???:
-  Combat feels a lot like Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, which is decent but not as modern as I'd have liked.

Overall, it really could be a pretty decent game… if the map was layed out in a way that worked and I didn't need complete luck to find my way between save points. The mechanical guts of Chasm aren’t incredible, but they’re good. They’re sturdy and classic and consistent, and they’re bundled with RPG mechanics that create a couple of worthwhile vectors for customization.
I wish it hadn’t felt the need to be constructed on top of a procgen algorithm, because a well-made, handcrafted version of Chasm might have been a solid 8 out of 10.

Ultimately, however, it lands more in the 6 out of 10 range. And that’s not bad! If you're really itching for a Castlevania-like, maybe pick it up despite my advice. But I don't think I can really recommend it when other games out there can scratch this itch much better.

review:
100%ed it. Loved it! This game scratched my itch for old school Castlevania-style platforming. The 16-bit style pixel-art is gorgeous and the music is catchy. The mechanics don't get too complex but most of the upgrades you get fundamentally change how you move around the levels, which keeps the platforming fresh throughout. I found myself gravitating towards whip weapons (for the range) and not using the backdash at all, but still found the combat to be enjoyable and not too challenging. The story kept me intrigued right up until the end where, there final boss was a bit of a let down (though the rest of the bosses were great). 

I Kickstarted this and couldn't be happier with how it turned out. I will definitely buy and play Chasm again if it makes it to Switch.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989513924', 'num_games_owned': 297, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 248, 'last_played': 1533464682}
review:
Chasm executes the classic Metroidvania formula to a very solid tee. It has everything you could possibly want from such a game, but not much besides. 

This isn't necessarily a criticism, but for those hoping for an evolution or spin to the Metroidvania formula - this isn't it. What the game does do, however, is deliver enjoyable platforming, combat and exploration mechanics with RPG elements.

As is echoed by a lot of reviews here, the procedural generation of the game is slightly redundant, and only affects the game minimally. This isn't really a rogue-like, as an average playthrough will last about six or more hours, meaning unless you are speed-running the game at a high level, you are unlikely to replay often enough to really appreciate the procedural aspect.

Regardless, if you are looking for a solid and playable Metroidvania, this is definitely it. However, if your patience for by-the-numbers Metroidvania games is saturated at this point, then you may want to think twice before putting your money on the table. Otherwise, there is plenty of fun to be had and it's a thumbs up from me.

If you want to see the gameplay in action check out Chasm's Indie Tale - https://youtu.be/DUEx-soNW74

author: {'steamid': '76561198007055259', 'num_games_owned': 705, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1357, 'last_played': 1533485250}
review:
Chasm is a decent game, but it doesn't live up to five years of expectations.

If you are considering buying this game, know that there are many better metroidvanias out there. Ori, Hollow Knight, Guacamelee, Axiom Verge, the Shantae games or even the classic Super Metroid to name a few. Then again, if you're already familiar with those, Chasm has little new to offer.

The pixel art is the only standout part of the game. Everything else feels a little too average. Functional, but lackluster.
Controls are responsive, but there are a few things, such as arbitrary recovery frames on backdash (you can just jump to cancel the recovery frames so they serve no function), and walljumping which feels sluggish in general.
The combat lacks depth. Most of the enemies follow the same general attack pattern with a few exceptions here and there. I like the boss designs, although by the end of the game you can mostly ignore boss mechanics and brute force your way through with upgraded magic and consumables (on normal difficulty).
The loot is boring, but it does what it needs to. For the most part you just get slightly higher stats than previously with no other effects. Weapons are not balanced at all; everything that is not a sword either hits too slowly or has too little reach.
Sound effects are great for the most part. The music is kind of ambient and fits the areas well.
Backtracking is pretty obnoxious, a lot could be fixed about it by making the Warp Scroll much cheaper or by offering an alternative way to teleport back to town when you're not in combat.

The randomization of the map serves little purpose as it stands. Playing through the first two areas for the second time I couldn't even point out the differences. Because there only seems to be one variation of the key progression rooms, there are only a few ways to place the room so that you can enter and exit it in the intended way. This coupled with the fact that items don't significantly affect gameplay make the actual differences between playthroughs very minor.

Overall, a positive experience despite the complaints. The game plays well enough and it seems very polished, even if some features don't feel fully realized. I hope there will be patches to address some of the lack of replayability and iron out some of the movement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975059341', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 623, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 623, 'last_played': 1533869713}
review:
Mediocre bordering on bad.  The concept is good - procedural generation Metroidvania - but the implementation just doesn't cut it.  There are too many instances of bad controls (walljump, backdash, attack time) getting in the way of an enjoyable experience to recommend, especially at full price.  Wait this game out, see if the devs push updates, and it might be passable; otherwise there are plenty of better titles in the genre out on Steam.

Sidenote: this is maybe the first game I've seen with "excluded from Family Sharing" that wasn't a MMO/pure online title.  Not a big deal personally, but definitely another little kick while it's down.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069950030', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1327, 'last_played': 1533915039}
review:
I enjoyed playing through this game. The gameplay mechanics and art style are very well done. But there is a bit of a lack of overall depth, however, and a few nitpicks drag the game down a little. 

PROS: 
• Pixel Art looks great
• Combat controls are tight
• Platforming/Movement is also tight
• Enemy/Boss Design, Variety and Animations are mostly good
• Level Design is fairly decent, and easy to navigate. The procedural generation worked fine(no badly connected areas)
• World Design is varied and everything looks great as well
• I didn't have a problem with the # of save points as there are also several shortcuts that can quickly take you back to town where ypu can save as well.

CONS:
• There are dozens of weapons, but only like 6 types that boil down to only about 3 attack styles
• Loot feels a little light(I saved up money and bought a weapon in town that I ended up using for the majority of the first 3 worlds)
• The magic weapons/spells are a little lackluster, they are servicable but they're all available to purchase from the beginning of the game and you don't find/earn anymore through exploration or defeating enemies
• The procedural generation is probably not necessary.
• Backtracking can be a bit tedious
• (This is mostly my fault) There's an NPC that gives you a quest to dig up some stashes in the world, but I never found them until I finally figured out that the "dig spots" were what I initially thought were slabs of rock that required some kind of explosive ability, so I never opened them until very late in the game despite being able to for quite a while. I think if they just made the "dirt pile" an interactable thing instead of requiring you to equip the shovel as a weapon and use it on the "slabs" the issue would not have occurred, but I think it's mostly my fault as I just forgot about the shovel and assumed they were opened with something else I'd get later.

CONCLUSION:
I think it's a very solid and well made game that has some minor problems and could use a little more depth. 7/10
I beat the game in about 12 hours as I played at a very slow pace and did a fair bit of grinding and did everything.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026912947', 'num_games_owned': 551, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1154, 'last_played': 1574982322}
review:
Excellent game. There's something unique about this game: venturing into a huge maze not knowing which way is the exit at each playthrough. Unlike what the big reviews say, this game may take inspiration from Caslevania but then it spins in its own direction with the abilities which are unlocked during the game. Add great pixel art, especially in the backgrounds, and some unique touches like fighting off a Wendigo and a huge Wasp, and classical action platformer elements like wall jumping, locked and hidden areas, and interlocking corridors and you've got Charm. The musical score is enjoyable and very thematic.

I must say that initially the random enemies get on a slow start but as the game progresses they become a little more standard in terms of AI. I have a few gripes about how character movement plays as at some points I wished I could be able to sprint through the corridors since getting from one area of the map to the other trying to find where I was supposed to go next seemed too much. Also I wished there was more than one attack animation and wanted to be able to spam the attack button at some points, but I guess this is the nature of the beast. If you're into games like Valdis Story Abyssal City, you might want to give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977080970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 884, 'last_played': 1533481165}
review:
I've been eagerly awaiting Chasm for since its Kickstarter and...it's just a huge let down. The world is bland, and the story even blander. Everything just seems half baked. The Hub is slowly populated by characters you can rescue and each have their own sidequests you can complete. But...why would you? Many of the rewards offered by completing these quests are pointless, and I found myself not caring what happened in the hub and rather just getting through the game to complete it. Compared to other Metroidvanias, Chasm has very little personality. It controls rather well, but with its story being so incredibly basic and uninspired, there's not much else to hang onto.

Even the boss battles are just bland. Compared to SOTN, there is little sense of danger and the dungeon itself doesn't mesh into a cohesive environment. The procedural generation adds very little to Chasm, other than a sense of randomness where  it should feel like a well designed, living place.

After waiting for five years, it's depressing to see the finished product be so light on personality and soul.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000662987', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1533481010}
review:
I've been waiting for this game for years, and I'm sad to say it's a bit of a let down. It's not bad, but it gets boring pretty fast. The procedurally generated world doesn't really make sense. It doesn't reset when you die, and your characters gains abilities that unlock new rooms in old areas. This means you're left wandering aimlessly around looking for the correct room, and it's just not fun. I'd be able to see past all of this if the soundtrack was good, but unfortunately it's the only truly bad thing about the game.

+ Great art
+ Good writing/character design/story
+ Good controls
- Mediocre gameplay
- Really bad music

author: {'steamid': '76561198114185943', 'num_games_owned': 220, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1533435870}
review:
데모버전을 재미있게 즐겼기에 기대했지만 그만큼 실망이 더 큰 게임.
데모버전 보고 찜한 2015년에 찜한 뒤로 기다린 세월만 자그마치 3년이다.
그 동안 대체 무엇을 개발하고 개선했는가?

그 동안 개발이 되는 것은 당연한 것이지만, 개선이 되지는 않았다고 생각한다.
기본 이미지의 눈 내리는 마을. 저 마을 데모버전이랑 틀린 것이 하나도 없다.
차라리 얼리억세스로라도 풀고 피드백을 받아가면서 개선했다면 이런 평점은 나오지 않았을 것이다.

그리고 우리는 이런 식으로 대처하며 곧 서비스 시작한다고 설레발만 계속 치는 게임을 알고 있다. 로스트아크라고.
처음에 보여줬을 때의 컬처쇼크, 그리고 피드백 받는지조차 의문일 정도로 기나긴 잠수.
개발은 하고 있어요 하고 줄기차게 말하지만 뭐를 개발하는지조차 알 수 없이 마냥 기다리라고만 한다.

카즘은 정확하게 로스트아크와 똑같은 행보를 보여줬고, 평가의 복합적이 그 결과를 말해준다.

앞으로도 계속 이 게임을 파긴 하겠지만, 다른 사람에게 추천하진 않을 것이며,

누가 한 마디로 요약해보라고 하면 주저없이 로스트아크의 미래라고 얘기할 것이다.
평가 몇 번 써보지도 않았지만 불따봉 리뷰는 정말 처음이다. 그만큼 이 게임에 기대했고, 실망했다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984682842', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 373, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1533405011}
review:
This game is really close to being good, but I just can't recommend it. The randomized map ends up making the world pretty bland and a chore to backtrack through, very little is added as far as new mechanics with combat/platforming so the sense of progression is fairly lackluster.

There are plenty of other games similar to this that do a better job of emulating its predecessors while also setting itself apart in some way. This is just Castlevania with less going on. For $10 I wouldn't have been as let down, but this just seems a bit empty for the pricetag.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996079355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1047, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1533461561}
review:
Like everyone I've been waiting for Chasm for a veeery long time, and so I bought it straight away even though I saw it had mixed reviews. I decided I would read the reviews after I'd finished the game, to not affect my opinion of it.

After I was done, I was honestly stumped. The game is great, perhaps even on the level of a classic. 

The art is perfect throughout, with beautiful backdrops and fluid animations. There are a large variety of weapons, spells and unlockable items that help you traverse the levels. There are also plenty of side quests from the various villagers that you rescue from the caves, and it feels great to slowly have the village come to life on the surface. Chasm gets the progression system right; it feels like there is always some new thing to find or some new item that will allow you to get past a previous obstacle, and all the while your character is getting stronger. There is also a DISGUSTINGLY large list of enemies in the game, all beautifully animated, all of which have different ways of attacking the player and a few that require that you mix up your strategy to defeat. In short, Chasm is chock full of great stuff to uncover.

So I came back here to finally look at the reviews. A lot of gripes I disagree with, while other complaints are valid. I'll offer my opinion on some common complaints here.

[b]The game is boring[/b] - I strongly disagree. Chasm kept me hooked for basically 10 hours straight, disrupted only by needing to sleep. Some have said that the levels are samey and full of the same enemies, and while I agree the levels could be more interesting (will address later) I felt like the enemies were introduced at a pretty good pace. I found that by the time I had got used to fighting a particular enemy, a stronger version or a completely new enemy would be introduced. With all of the quests I constantly found that I had something exciting to head towards. The only concession I'll make in this area is that some of the enemies were way too easy, sometimes being attackable from out of range with no reaction. Due to the level layout this isn't possible in most cases, but there were some minibosses which were entirely killable with this method. If an update changed anything, it would be to at least have enemies aggro if you attack them from far away.

[b]I don't know where to go[/b] - Again, I feel like this isn't a reasonable gripe. There were a few times that I got a bit lost, but when I took stock of all the quests I had and also looked at the map, I would always find some place I hadn't looked or something new that I hadn't done. I felt like the game lead me but didn't hold my hand, and I never had to look up where to go next.

[b]The procgen/roguelike elements barely come into play[/b] - I agree with this. Because of the longform nature of the game (the whole playthrough will take around 8-10 hours) permadeath isn't a thing until you finish the game once (and then it's basically masochist mode). The random generation of the levels is also minimal, just using preset rooms, and perhaps sacrificed design for not a lot of return. This may have also been disappointing for a lot of players who were searching for a roguelike experience and got a Metroidvania instead. I feel like this isn't a big deal if you manage expectations, but I can understand how this may have affected reviews negatively.

[b]Spells/weapons are bland[/b] - This I sort of agree with. The spells are interesting in their own right, basically offering different kinds of ranged attacks, but the first spell you get is leaps and bounds more useful than any of the others. Once you upgrade it (which you can do rather cheaply and early into the game) it becomes more powerful than even any of the melee weapons. It's also cheaper on mana than anything else. This kinda ruins the fun of choosing between different spells for different circumstances. The balance is less broken on the weapon side. Different weapon types basically offer different attack styles (axes do a chopping motion over the head, swords slash further but only right in front of you, etc) but they didn't come into play that much. Most of the time you just want the strongest weapon and good timing attacking while jumping.

So while the game is not without its flaws, I feel like the pros heavily outweigh the cons. I strongly recommend Chasm for fans of Metroidvania style games and action platformers. It's not a roguelike! If you can manage expectations around this point, and also take your time to progress and uncover your next goal, you'll have fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034086266', 'num_games_owned': 223, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 716, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 633, 'last_played': 1575126437}
review:
Assez déçu. Sur le papier ça semblait bien pourtant. J'aime bien les Metroidvania, y'a un peu de procédural - dont j'aime aussi le principe - et même graphiquement ça annonçait un truc sympa... mais en faite le jeu est très loin d'être parfait. Il est pas extrêment mauvais mais plus moyen qu'autre chose.

Le début est un peu ennuyant (premier niveau) mais ensuite ça s'enchaine assez bien et le jeu est agréable à jouer... jusqu'au niveau 5 où ça devient nimp. Globalement le début du jeu fonctionne assez bien, mais arrivé au niveau 4 la difficulté augmente et le game design en prend un coup. C'est pas tant la partie graphique qui pèche, mais bien le gameplay. Déjà dans les premiers niveaux les phases de plateforme sont parfois limite ridicules, genre un saut qui passe pas parce qu'il faut sauter au 2 pixels près du bout de la plateforme... ou encore des murs presque trop haut pour que le perso puisse monter dessus (avec l'un des powerups). Alors dans des niveaux plutôt gentil avec des checkpoints réguliers, ça va... mais alors en fin de jeu... c'est bien simple le niveau 5 cumule les problèmes de plateforme et offre 0 checkpoints, en plus d'avoir des ennemis plutôt forts. Et je rappelle qu'une mort = recharger ta partie depuis la dernière sauvegarde / checkpoint. Et en plus de ça (oui, encore), les combats finissent pas se limiter au spam du lancer de couteau. Car oui le jeu offre des magies, toutes presque inutiles, sauf le couteau qui part bien droit et ne coûte presque rien à utiliser. Et si tu l'augmente de niveau tu lances 3 couteaux par lancer, ce qui devient complètement craqué. Et à la fin du jeu, les ennemis faisant relativement mal et la magie étant quasi illimité si tu joues avec le couteau, tu est toujours gagnant à n'utiliser presque que ça puisque ça défonce tout (un coup d'épée en fin de jeu : ~40-45 points de dégâts, à courte portée ; un lancer de couteau : ~25-30 dégâts par hit, donc très souvent 25-30 x2 minimum et presque systématiquement x3 sur les grands ennemis, à moyenne portée.

Un point aussi sur la génération procédurale : même si je pense que ça peut être intéressant si on fait plusieurs partie, sur une seule partie je trouve pas ça toujours parfait. Dans chaque niveau il y a toujours des salles en double à plusieurs reprises. Ca peut paraître un peu con, mais pourtant ça se voit et ça fait moyen. Si on prend un jeu comme Enter the Gungeon (pour son côté procédural j'entend) y'a pas une seule salle qui se ressemble dans une même génération de niveau, jamais de doublons (ou alors c'est très rare?).

Sinon, globalement je donne un + pour le bestiaire qui est assez varié. On a quelques "move set" différents sur les armes, avec chacun des points forts et points faibles. Niveau musiques, j'aime beaucoup celle du niveau 3, sans quoi le reste est pas formidable, elles deviennent même vite répétitive parfois. L'histoire est plutôt osef, à la fois assez bateau et à mon avis mal ammené, y'a quelque chose qui ne marche pas. Le héro est un "no name" mais d'autres jeux ammène ça infiniment mieux (Hollow Knight, les Souls...). A mon sens c'est pas grave d'avoir une histoire en retrait (on joue pas à un Mario ou un Zelda pour leur histoire), par contre faut que le reste ça suive.

Bref. C'est surtout le dernier tiers qui me déçois car les deux premiers tiers était plutôt bon et bien équilibrés (malgré quelques défauts et le niveau 1 un peu mou). En l'état je ne recommande pas spécialement, éventuellement en solde et si vous ne savez pas quoi faire de mieux, ou par curiosité.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996896861', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1093, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1047, 'last_played': 1534173331}
review:
Chasm is a direct throw-back to Castlevania: Symphony of the Night and it plays like a Lite version of that game. If you enjoyed C:SotN as thoroughly as I did then this game will be fun for you. Many of the moves are very similar to identical, spells, the way you swing weapons, etc. (cutting this list short so I don't spoil anything for anyone). If C:SotN was a masterpiece, and I would argue that it is, Chasm is a well done game.

As it stands on it's own it's a fun new metroidvania game that will keep you jumping and slashing for hours. It would be an excellent game to use to introduce young players to the genre due to the leveling system allowing you to back off of harder areas for a while to gain the edge you may need. Plus they're generous with save-point placement up until the final few zones.

At the time of writing this review I have just beaten the game on normal mode, and I plan to jump into hard mode. I'm having a bunch of fun playing this game and I would definitely say it's worth your $20.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027898694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 726, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1691547579}
review: Com tantos outros Metroidvanias na steam, como: Hollow Knight, Dead Cells, Iconoclasts, etc. Chasm parece uma cópia sem sal, com música repetitiva, cenários vázios (com exceção de algumas áreas iniciais e sua cidade base, o restante da mina em diante é muito sem graça.) luta repetitiva e um sistema de "procedurally-generated map" que não faz sentido. Os devs deveriam ter gasto o tempo que demorou pra lançar esse jogo pra criar mapas interessantes, com encontros mais interativos, do que criar o sistema que gera "mapas de forma aleatoria" para gerar um rejogabilidade. O que acontece em fato são mapas com corredores extremamente longos, tendo que enfrentar inimigos repetidas vezes, forçando MUITO o backtracking. É um jogo bacana, mas não vale seu preço full. Espere uma promoção para comprar com um bom desconto, não está perdendo muito coisa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050163735', 'num_games_owned': 172, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1044, 'last_played': 1663610238}
review:
I only found this game early 2017 so I haven't been waiting for years, I've never played any Metroid or Castlevania game, and I played on easy difficulty, so this review is written from that perspective:

Music and Sound: 
Audially and visually, I found the game appealing. I sort of played as long as I did because the visuals were so satisfying, and the music wasn't bad enough to make me not want to play. I even found myself humming along to many themes by the end. 

Boring Rooms: 
Some rooms feel a bit empty, but I don't think this is a negative point. It happens in almost any game, unless the team goes to extra effort to cram every inch with action. Sometimes blank or slow areas have an enemy you need for your bestiary, a secret hidden in the wall, a magically hidden chest sitting in the open, or are designed to build a sense of progressive tension. 

Procedural Generation: 
I think some reviews are particularly critical because the reviewers know the maps are procedurally generated (in terms of room arrangement, not the rooms themselves). I don't see it as constructive to be so critical. Sure, the devs could tighten the design over time, but I presume they would be well aware of whether that needs doing or not. It didn't break the game, or subtract from my overall experience. 

Warp/Save Rooms: 
I don't know if it gives you extra warp/save points on easy, but I found the spacing just fine. Sure, it was a bit of a trek to get from place to place, but I think that's the point; you learn the procedurally arranged maps as you traverse them. If you don't want to go through maps a few times over (which isn't too tedious on easy) then maybe this isn't the game for you.

Guidance: 
There are definitely many parts where the game doesn't tell you where to go. It's up to you to mark any positions of interest on your map. I even drew some maps by hand for my own reference. The fact that doing so improved my experience is a good thing, in my opinion. The game doesn't hold your hand in this sense. You need to think. Got an item and not sure what it's for? Have you seen a slot in the same shape as it? Is it referenced in any of the journal entries? Sometimes you need to do the thinking and searching yourself. I liked that. 

Weapons: 
I found reviews saying certain weapons are superior to other weapons. I don't think it's this imbalanced. There seems to be spear, sword, two-handed, whip, and dagger-type weapons. I couldn't find any powerful whip or spear weapons, but I have an end-game option for the other three, which I actually switched between depending on the situation, and found each to be useful in its own ways. 

Spells: 
Honestly, I got the magic knife thing, levelled it up, and bought not a single other spell. I opted for high attack and defence instead. Can't say much here. The magic knives served me just fine. 

Combat: 
Again, I played on easy, but I found combat to be satisfying by the end. I ignored the dash button after the first hour or so of play, but I don't see that as a point against the game; it's common to not use a particular button, skill, or feature in almost any video game. Combat itself was easy enough for me to be able to plough through rooms if I needed to, and challenging enough that I had to think for a moment before approaching particular foes so I knew the most efficient way to dispatch them. Just my cup of tea. 

Controls and Movement: 
Just needs getting used to. I'm really not used to platformers, but I think I became quite good at traversing in every direction by the end of the game. If you're having trouble finding the attack animations too slow, find other ways to attack, such as hopping/jumping and attacking to get through the animation quicker, or pressing attack right after pressing dash to do both at once. 

Characters and Story: 
Don't expect to be immersed and invested. The story and characters are shallow, but it doesn't pretend they're going to be anything but shallow. Just go along for the ride, and take what it gives you. The game seems to be self-aware. Don't take it too seriously. 

Motion Blur: 
Weird, but unnoticable once you start playing. 

AI: 
Some enemies at the start make no effort to attack you. That's no secret. They wander back and forth, or sit still, or climb around platforms. You'll find enemies that try to pursue you before your first hour is up. 

Platforming: 
A bit frustrating at times, but not enough to make me anywhere close to stop playing. I just kept trying and made sure I jumped right from the edge and held the button as long as I could. Obviously becomes much easier once you get all the artifacts. 

Overall: 
Get it on special and set your expectations to medium. The game rewarded my effort, thought, familiarity, and exploration. I got almost 18 hours out of it (filled bestiary, found every mapped and hidden room, and got every chest, but not every item) and I'm happy.

review:
Waited 5 years for this game to come out, bought the bronze early adopter pack and everything. The thought of a modern metroid-vania with character development and a unique art style was VERY appealing to me. I waited... and waited... and waited... and after 3 years of nothing, Hollow Knight came out anbd filled that void. I had forgotten about this game after spending years checking the official site and forums waiting for a release, delay after delay. Finally, it comes out and is very lackluster -- compared to hollow knight. 

Seriously, just buy Hollow Knight. This is the last 'early access' alpha, beta, whatever, title I will ever buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996550335', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1584, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1685216331}
review:
I just beat this game on normal, and I gotta say, it exceeded my expectations, and I don't think it deserves some of the negative reviews I'm seeing here.

For background, I'm an Igavania fan, and I've even just recently re-played through Castlevania SotN, Aria and Dawn of Sorrow, and Portrait of Ruin.  This game is essentially a new take on the same formula that made those games great, plus a pretty good procedural level generation system.

Key Points:

Gameplay:
While the entire game is procedurally generated, you're given the option to specify a seed when you start a new game so that you can play through the same exact world multiple times.  The actual level generation is certainly not as breathtaking as a hand-crafted world can be, but it's good enough that the game is still very compelling, and adds an extra bit of exploration every time you start a new playthrough.

I only beat the game on normal, and I will say that I found the difficulty to be a tad on the easy side.  Regular monsters and navigating through the levels can be a challenge, but I think there was only a single boss fight where I wasn't able to beat the boss on the first try.  I'm going to play this game again on hard and see how much more of a challenge that becomes.

Combat:
A lot of the negative reviews are saying that they can't stand the combat.  While I will agree that it felt a bit off at first, I believe this was due to the fact that it's extremely similar to the combat in the Iga games, but with enough slightly timing differences that it threw me off (especially the dash).  I found myself adapting to these changes fairly quick, and eventually it no longer was a complaint.  Overall, the combat is basically what you would expect if you've played an Igavania (similar weapon thrust / swing animations), so if you didn't like the combat in those games, you won't like it in this one either.

Graphics:
Top notch pixel art.  I'm a huge pixel art fan, and even dabble in it myself, so I know good pixel art when I see it, and this game has some of the best I've seen, hands-down.

Music/Sound:
I personally thought the songs were decent, but ultimately forgettable, and certainly not as catchy as the songs in the Igavania games.  The sound effects are well done, but nothing particularly special.

In summary, if you're an Igavania fan (SotN, Aria/Dawn of Sorrow, etc), then you'll probably love this game too.

EDIT:  After thinking over it more, this game does lack a bit of the depth and hand-crafted feel of other Metroidvanias.  However, I would definitely still definitely recommend this game to any fan of old school style platformer/Metroidvania fans, as it's still a reasonable ~20 hour playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976577562', 'num_games_owned': 1298, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 592, 'last_played': 1533253827}
review:
I pitched in for this game on Kickstarter ages ago, and watched it with passing interest over the following five years. I almost thought it would never actually get completed at times, but here we are. Is it the best Metroidvania I've ever played? No. Does it really reflect five years worth of dev time? Maybe not. Having said that, I enjoyed the game from start to finish, and don't regret plunking down advance money on it all those years ago.

I completed my first playthrough, and will probably give it another run sometime in the next few months to try and clean up those last few achievements. The gameplay isn't really anything new or unseen, but the art is particularly gorgeous. It's a good way to spend 6-10 hours, if you're the sort that enjoys Metroidvanias, and the randomized level design should help keep it fresh for at least a little while.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980333161', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1007, 'last_played': 1534320721}
review:
Here my review for Chasm:

8 bit grafic is nice, Music is okay.

You have a town hub and rescue people from the dungeon as you explore deeper and deeper.

You find new ways to travel around inside the dungeon. Like a gauntlet to grip corners or a gauntlet to slide narrow corridors or a double jump.

All rooms you find are handcrafted, the layout of the dungeon is randomly generated with each game. 

Enemies are relatively easy at the beginning get more difficult further into the game. For each enemy you need to learn how to beat them. Sounds harder then it is. You could spam everything with ranged attacks.

Different weapons have different ranges. Knives have shorter ranges then the long sword or the whip.

You can build your character by equipping items. Those come in two flavors. Melee and armor and magic plus magic ranged attacks.

The bosses are relative easy. I am not the very best metrovania player, but i still managed to beat all bosses except the last in Hollowknight, i have no problems to beat the first three bosses in this game on normal. -> balanced difficulty.

Dungeons involve some backtracking to explore the parts you could not access the first time.

Monster give xp and you level your character. You can outlevel content and make things easier that way by grinding. But the next area will still give you new challenges. 

It is good game, if you like Metrovania games it is good and fun to play.

Thanks for reading, have a nice day.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006970124', 'num_games_owned': 3932, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 1531, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1487, 'last_played': 1533414789}
review:
Хорошая-ли игра Chasm? Определенно. Могла бы она быть лучше? Безусловно!

Я купил эту игру пять лет назад на Кикстартере. Уже на стадии сбора средств была доступна альфа и она была чудо как хороша — отличная графика в стиле Super Nintendo, неплохая музыка, отличное отзывчиво управление и затягивающий геймплей. По всем задаткам — суперхитовая метроидвания. Надо только подождать.
Через год в стиме появилась бета. Кое-что убрали кое-что добавили. Еще до выхода я наиграл в Chasm десять часов. И ждал релиза. Очень. Я еще не знал что до релиза еще около четырех лет…
За время пока делался Chasm вышло множество метроидваний задавших очень высокую планку качества - Ori, Axiom Verge, Owlboy, Hollow Knight. И это проблема для Chasm. Выйди он хотя бы года на три раньше критерии оценки были бы совсем другими.

Итак, Chasm вышел.
И я не понимаю что разработчики делали столько времени. Графика чудесная. Музыка хорошая. Но это та же графика и та же музыка что были в альфе пять лет назад! Разве что прикрутили к спрайту героя неотключаемый эффект медленной LCD матрицы.
Выкинута на мороз прокачка оружия гемами. Жаль. Туда же отправилась свободная прокачка характеристик. Хочешь вырастить мага? Фиг тебе. Даже скроллы, которые могут увеличить характеристики, увеличивают их рандомно. Тоже жаль, даже очень. Раньше Chasm ощущался своего рода Diablo в 2D (да и сюжет похож). А сейчас это метроидвания с элементами RPG. И срастить нормально не получилось — не знаю чем там отдел тестирования занимался но по итогу игра чудовищно легкая. Купив самую дорогую броню можно пролететь пол игры за пол часа. А если закупиться поушенами, то хоть какой-то челлендж исчезает вовсе.
Помните разучивание паттернов боссов в Hollow Knight? Можете забыть. Все боссы уничтожаются "в лоб". Один-два перерыва на обед посреди боя и победа у вас в кармане.
Обидно что в бете челлендж был. И паттерны Wendigo приходилось хорошо знать чтобы пройти дальше.
О сюжете стоит сказать что он есть. Как и в упомянутой Diablo – древнее зло пробудилсоь. Спускаемся в подземелье, спасаем мирных жителей, выполняем их квесты. Как и положено в  метроидвании — с бэктрэкингом и продвижением по сюжету через получение новых способностей (в данном случае оборудования — от когтей для лазанья до акваланга). Часть способностей не обязательна для прохождения но позволяет собрать больше всякого лута и получить быстрый и мощный клинок. Который практически не пригодится, так как самая комфортная "пушка" — моргнештерн с механикой хлыста. Дальнобойная имба с огромным хитбоксом, в том числе и сзади героя. Саймон Бельмонт всячески одобряет!
Карта представляет из себя набор заранее нарисованных комнат, соединенных рандомными коридорами-паттернами. Паттернов очень мало (где-то на порядок меньше чем в Rogue Legacy, где уровни построены по тому-же принципу). И, увы, на реиграбельность такого рода генерация почти никак не влияет. Вы прошли игру один раз? Вы видели всё.
Сама по себе "карта мира" маленькая. Точками отмечаются места где есть запертые сундуки. Можно поставить свою собственную точку. Эргономика прям ваще!
Еще в игре есть однорукий бандит, рулетка, две пары. Можно зарабатывать деньги, но под конец игры с продажи лута денег будет очень много. Да и как-то глупо в игре с сохранением вводить азартные игры.
Еще есть крафт. Ни одну вещь созданную кузнецом поносить не придется — даже у кольчуги из метеоритной стали параметры хуже чем у найденного в сундуке магического плаща. Руда для крафта появляется тогда когда у вас уже все есть.
Нельзя также не отметить проблемы с управлением возникающие после получения способностей. Прыгнули на платформу рядом со стеной? Сейчас вы отпрыгните от стены прямо в лаву. Но у вас есть шанс спланировать на парашюте обратно. Изо всех щелей лезет немотивированность. В паре мест необходим идеальный тайминг прыжка чтобы пройти дальше. Прыжок в комнате с двумя лучниками (о, вы узнаете что это такое, если будете играть в версию 1.02!) я сделал с десятой попытки, а кто-то после сотого трая забил на игру.

Подводя итог — сильно запоздавший продукт. Со сломанной механикой и отсутствующей сложностью. Без надежды что-то исправить патчами. Очень красиво. И стоит купить и пройти. Но не за полную цену. Разработчикам респект за таланты и позорище за спущенные рукава и сорванные сроки.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983190864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 1990, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1552624731}
review:
I almost feel dirty writing a negative review, but sorry, I have to. The devs seem like nice people and are respectful at all times, even when people complain angrily on the forums. I want them to succeed. Problem is, I put down $50 on the kickstarter half a decade ago, got a short demo, waited forever, and then to my dismay I can't recommend this game. If I see a major patch come out and things have changed, maybe I'll come back and adjust.

-The music is mostly awful. The town theme is great, and there are a few others, but the mines theme is atrocious, for example.
-Movement between 5 different maps is a pointlessly obnoxious PITA.
-The procedural generation makes everything feel disjointed and spread out, not fresh.
-The maps are big, but feel empty. There are a bunch of custom jumping puzzles and stuff and each individual room was hand-designed, but overall you're going to see the same 3 enemies in the next 20 same-color rooms, and most of the loot you find will be disappointing.
-Save points are too spread out, IMO, especially considering they designed every single enemy you face to require several hits to kill and the weapons all have short range (except the Elven Blade).
-There is basically no guidance on where to go next or what to do. Once you get to, say, the Gardens, you've got several maps to keep track of and you hit a point where you wander aimlessly for hours exploring every nook and cranny to find the ONE ROOM on some other map that will progress the game. Literally hours in my case, on two occasions.
-The weapons are bland as hell. It doesn't matter that there are 8 swords or whatever in the game because they all have exactly the same behavior. There are a couple that have a special property, but only the Elven Blade changes how you confront enemies.
-The loot, at least until you get close to completing the 2nd map, is largely a huge let-down. I used my starter weapon on the second boss fight because the single other weapon I found was worse. Once you get to around that point, however, it does improve as you find more stuff and can start to customize your kit.
-The spells are a let-down. They're not spells. They're just the special weapons from Symphony of the Night, basically. If you were thinking spells as in Aria of Sorrow, nope.

One good thing about the game is the pixel art. It's consistently fantastic. Sadly, you stop paying attention after 20 rooms of the same thing, so it diminishes the impact. 

Shutting the backers out of the design process entirely was a bad idea. Lots of the frustration people are having with the game right now could have been avoided had the developers let people give feedback as they went.  Now it's kinda too late.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059488692', 'num_games_owned': 2040, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 898, 'last_played': 1533362061}
review:
I'm a bit of a metroidvania nut, so take that into account. If you like the genre in particular, you're likely to derive more fun from this one. I enjoyed this game. It's a bit on the shorter side, but procedurally generated levels should add some degree of replayability. I'm hopeful the devs invest a bit more time for some features people have asked for like a New Game + or some additional content, because there is a lot to expand on here.

Pros
+ The art style is beautiful if you like pixel art. A lot of really likable character and enemy designs.
+ I found the game length to be a plus. It's a little bit too short at ~8-10 hours of play, but I'm a busy person and a game I can beat in a little less than a week hits the spot for me.
+ Procedurally generated levels work surprisingly well. Maybe this is just the seed that I got, but I was surprised at how logically laid out the levels were, how balanced the enemy progression seemed, and how well placed items were.
+ I didn't have nearly as much of a problem with the controls as some people have. There are slight hitches and delays in control, but I found it to be part of the experience and just how timing worked in this game.

Cons
- There is a certain amount of sameness to the levels, and there will be a couple of parts of each area that leave you thinking, "Wasn't I just here?" The vertical rooms with crawlers are the most repetitive.
- Weapon balance issues. The sword seems to be the best weapon for timing and balance. I tried using some of the other weapons, but I found them to be much too slow to react to most of the enemies. The game design puts timing and health preservation at a priority, so you feel every missed swing. Magic also becomes much more overpowered as the game progresses, and I found myself much less likely to use weapons at all when I had a ranged magic attack that did 150% the damage of a weapon hit at virtually no mana cost.
- Enemy progression. As you move on, boss fights actually become much easier since you are more able to simply wade in and do massive DPS and say "screw it" while just soaking up enemy attacks.
-Some bugs. A surprisingly large number of sub-bosses are happy to sit at the edge of the screen and let you blast them with magic until they die without putting up so much as a peep. If at least a few enemies attacked once they took damage, that would fix this issue.
- Still just feels a bit short. Again, I listed this in the pros, but if you're expecting an epic 80 hour game this is going to disappoint. If you take it for what it is, it's quite nice, but at $20 I can understand why people would want more content. This game doesn't live up to Hollow Knight - but again, if we're all being honest, HK is criminally undervalued at $20.

That's a longer list of cons than pros, but I find the positive points to be more important. Overall, I have zero buyers' remorse for this game and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it with the above caveats. If the devs have the commitment that those who worked on Stardew Valley and Hollow Knight have had, this could continue to become a better game over time. The procedural generation adds to replayability, and it would be easy to further extend that.

7/10 Solid but with some warts, big potential.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071634639', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 304, 'last_played': 1533470675}
review:
Chasm clearly takes its inspiration from Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, but builds upon it with procedural level generation. Unfortunately, whereas Castlevania: Symphony of the Night was a masterpiece of 2D platforming, action, roleplay, and exploration; Chasm is not. The procedural content generation doesn't fit the metroidvania elements and instead of adding replayability, it makes the first playthrough (and any thereafter) very boring. Some game systems have been implemented half-assedly, such as magic, story, zones, movement in general, and even upgrades that make you able to reach new areas. Acquiring new parts to any of these does not feel rewarding as it doesn't really tie well into the game. Furthermore, movement abilities such as the wall jumping feels terrible compared to how other games have implemented similar systems.

Perhaps had this game come out 4 years ago, as was originally planned, it would be hailed as one of the better metroidvania games.However, while Chasm was in perpetual development other games have done what Chasm set out to do much better and more importantly: much sooner. Chasm is therefore an unfortunate but big pass for anyone except the most devoted metroidvania lover who may derive some enjoyment from the game solely because it is metroidvania game.

Pros:
